div2.p: In compliance with the wishes of many of my former pupils, I have determined to publish my Greek Syntax in parts. The framework was planned many years ago, and corresponds in its structure to the scheme of my Latin Grammar, the first edition of which was published in 1867. In fact, the Latin Syntax was based on the MS of the Greek. Doubtless the syntactician of to-day will find ample opportunity to criticise the arrangement, but to refashion the book would require more time than the speeding years will allow me to presume on. Nor will I undertake in this place a vindication of the principles that have guided me in my syntactical studies. A word, however, as to the order of the examples may be deemed appropriate. A catena of syntactical usage would be a memorable achievement, and I do not deny that at one time I thought it possible to organize such a work, for which a large staff of helpers would have been needed; but I have learned to renounce this ambitious scheme. and even the present far more modest undertaking would have been impossible unless I had associated with myself a scholar who is acquainted with every detail of my syntactical work, published and unpublished, and who has brought to the task not only a hearty sympathy with my views and methods, but a clearness of judgment and an accuracy in details that have been of great service to me in my own researches. In completing the list of examples, and in filling up the gaps in the presentation, I have availed myself freely of his help, and we have worked side by side in the collection and the scrutiny of the passages cited; and to this pupil, colleague, friend, Professor C. W. E. MILLER, the completion of the work has been committed, in case the privilege should be denied me of putting the last hand to the labor of many years.

Like myself, Professor MILLER is thoroughly imbued with the conviction that the study of syntax is of the utmost importance for the appreciation of literary form, and we both believe that the presentation of the phenomena under the rubrics of the different departments of literature will be found useful for instruction and even more so for suggestion. Taking the Attic Orators as the standard of conventional Greek, we have worked backward through philosophy and history to tragic, lyric, and epic poetry, comedy being the bridge which spans the syntax of the agora and the syntax of Parnassus. Individual syntax we have not been able to set forth with any fulness, but the different departments have been represented to the best of our ability and judgment. The plan has saved us from giving the usual medley of examples, it has forced us to rely largely on our own collections and to examine the texts for ourselves, and it will enable those who come after us to fill up these outlines with greater ease.
div2.signed: BASIL L. GILDERSLEEVE, THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, BALTIMORE.

div2.p: Syntax treats of the formation and combination of sentences.
A sentence is the expression of thought in words. It is a lo/gos.
The necessary parts of the sentence are the subject and the predicate.
The predicate is that which is said of the subject.
The subject is that of which the predicate is said.
a)/nqrwpos manqa/nei, PLATO, Soph. 262C ; Man learns. a)/nqrwpos is the subject; manqa/nei is the predicate. See also 2, 27, and 68-82.
Sentences are divided into simple and compound.
A simple sentence is one in which the necessary parts of the sentence occur but once, as above, a)/nqrwpos manqa/nei.
For the compound sentence, see Index.
The most simple form of the sentence is the finite verb: ei)-mi/, I am; di/dw-s, thou givest; fh-si/, he says.
Here the form contains in itself all the necessary elements, the subject being indicated by the ending.

div2.head: Nominative Case
div2.p: The subject of the finite verb is always in the nominative case, or so considered.
*ko/nwn . . . e)ni/khse, DIN. 1.75 ; Konon gained the victory.
The subject of the infinitive is in the accusative case, or so considered. See Infinitive.
a)du/naton . . . a)/nqrwpon pa/nta kalw=s poiei=n, XEN. Cyr. 8.2.5 ; For a man to do all things well is impossible.
For the nominative with the infinitive, see Index.
The nominative is used as in English, not only as the subject of the verb, but in titles, inscriptions, and the like, which imply action or character.
*kallistw\ *nikofi/lou *)aggelh=qen, CIA. II, 1682. *proklei/dhs *filokle/ous *)aggelh=qen, CIA. II, 1686. CIA. II, 1689. 1690. 1691. 1692. etc.

p.hi: Nominative in citations, enumerations, and indefinite predications.

div2.p: Under the former head more properly belongs also the use of the so-called nominative absolute in the citation of names, in enumerations, and in indefinite predications.
a)nh\r de\ geno/menos prosei/lhfe th\n tw=n ponhrw=n koinh\n e)pwnumi/an sukofa/nths, AESCHIN. 2.99 ; When he became a man, he received the common surname of scoundrels, i. e. sycophant (informer).
AESCHIN. 2.99 (see above).

PLATO, Legg. 956C: diaithtai\ dikastw=n tou)/noma ma=llon pre/pon e)/xontes . PLAT. Soph. 218E: oi(=on a)spalieuth/s . Theag. 124 D: ti/na ga\r a)/llhn (sc. e)pwnumi/an), . . ., plh/n ge xrhsmw|doi/; Ibid. 124 E.
XEN. Cyr. 3.3.58: parhggu/a o( *ku=ros su/nqhma *zeu\s su/mmaxos. kai\ h(gemw/n . Oec. 6.14: tou\s e)/xontas to\ semno\n o)/noma tou=to to\ kalo/s te ka)gaqo/s .
AR. Vesp. 1185: mu=s kai\ galh= me/lleis le/gein (so R).
EUR. Tr. 1233 (but Kirchhoff puts a comma after i)atro/s).
DEM. 23.207: ta\ de\ th=s po/lews oi)kodomh/mata . . . toiau=ta (sc. o(ra=|), . . ., propu/laia tau=ta, new/soikoi, stoai/, *peiraieu/s .
PLATO, Soph. 266D: ti/qhmi du/o dixh=| poihtikh=s ei)/dh: qei/a me\n kai\ a)nqrwpi/nh kte( .
AESCHYL. Pers. 33 sqq.: a)/llous d' o( . . . *nei=los e)/pemyen: *sousiska/nhs, *phgastagw\n *ai)guptogenh/s, o(/ te th=s i(era=s *me/mfidos a)/rxwn kte(. , And others Nile sent, Susiskanes, etc.
This use of the nominative abounds in inscriptions:

CIA. 1.37 (= Hicks, No. 47). Ibid. 170-3 (= Hicks, No. 50): ta/de pare/dosan . . . ste/fanos . . ., fia/lai . . ., ko/rh . . ., koi/th . . . kte(., kte(. Ibid. 259 (= Hicks, No. 48), etc., etc. See Msth., Gr. d. Att. Inschr.2 § 82.3 d).

HOM. Od. 1.51: nh=sos dendrh/essa, qea\ d' e)n dw/mata nai/ei , A wooded island, and in it a goddess hath her abode.
Il. 6.395-6: megalh/toros *)heti/wnos, *)heti/wn o(\s e)/naien . Ibid. 10.437. 547.
For the free and frequent use of this nom. in inscriptions, see Msth.2 § 82.3 a-c.

CIA. 11.809 c, 154-55 (325/324 B.C.): a)po\ th=s tetrh/rous *)anu/sews, *)antidw/rou e)/rgon, From the quadrireme Anysis, the work of Antidorus. So often in the same inscription. Ibid. 1.179.7 sqq. (433 B.C.): pare/dosan . . . trei=s kai\ de/ka h(me/rai e)selhluqui/as.
The nominative is sometimes left in suspense (nominativus pendens, anacoluthon, want of sequence), an equivalent construction being substituted.
dialego/menos au)tw=| e)/doce/ moi, PLATO, Apol. 21C ; Talking with him it seemed to me.
ISOC. 4.107-8: e)/xontes . . . kekthme/noi . . . kratou=ntes . . . ei)do/tes . . . o(/mws ou)de\n tou/twn h(ma=s e)ph=re . 12.118.
ANDOC. 1.16. Ibid. 29-30: kai\ ga\r oi( lo/goi tw=n kathgo/rwn . . . tou/twn ou)=n e)moi\ tw=n lo/gwn . . . ti/ prosh/kei; ; Ibid. 95.
PLATO, Apol. 21C (see above). Crat. 403 A (twice). Ibid. 404 C: *ferre/fatta de/, polloi\ me\n kai\ tou=to fobou=ntai to\ o)/noma . Ibid. 412 B-C. 419 B.
XEN. An. 2.5.41: *pro/cenos de\ kai\ *me/nwn . . . pe/myate au)tou\s deu=ro . Cf. 3.3.16, 7.6.37. Hiero, 4.6. Cf. 6.15.
EUR. H. F. 185. Phoen. 283-5.
In exclamations, the nominative characterises, the vocative addresses, the accusative implies an object of emotion, and the genitive the source or sphere of emotion.
PLATO, Phaedr. 227C: w)\ gennai=os, ei)/qe gra/yeien w(s kte( .
AR. Ran. 652: a)/nqrwpos i(ero/s . Pl. 23: lh=ros , Stuff and nonsense!
EUR. Med. 61: w)= mw=ros , O foolish woman that she is!
SOPH. El. 1354. Ph. 254: w)\ po/ll' e)gw\ moxqhro/s, w)\ pikro\s qeoi=s . Tr. 1046 sq.
HOM. Od. 20.194: du/smoros .

Il.1.231: dhmobo/ros basileu/s, e)pei\ ou)tidanoi=sin a)na/sseis , Folk-devouring king that thou art, etc. 2.38: nh/pios
5.403: sxe/tlios , Ibid. 406: nh/pios , Ibid. 787: ai)dw/s , 9.630: sxe/tlios , Ibid. 632: nhlh/s , 13.95: ai)dw/s , 16.422: also. 17.236: nh/pioi . 22.86: sxe/tlios .
For the Vocative, see 24.
For the Accusative in Exclamations, see Index.
For the Genitive in Exclamations, see Index.

In the absence of a vocative form, the nominative is used as a vocative. When the vocative exists, the use of the nominative as a vocative has often a perceptible difference of tone. It is graver and more respectful, because it appeals to character, though sometimes metrical considerations come into play. In Homer, the nominative of proper nouns is frequently substituted for the vocative because of certain irregularities of metre.

cit.quote: e)gw\ . . ., w)= gh= kai\ h(/lie kai\ . . . su/nesis . . . beboh/qhka,

div2.p: PLATO, Hipp. Mai. 281 A: *(ippi/as o( kalo/s te kai\ sofo/s, w(s dia\ xro/nou h(mi=n kath=ras ei)s ta\s *)aqh/nas .

AR. Nub. 264-5:
w)= de/spot' a)/nac
lampro/s t' ai)qh/r
This is a curious coincidence with the Vedic rule (Delbrück, Forsch. V. Synt.§ 66) which prohibits copulation of two vocatives by ca (te), but requires the word connected by ca to be put in the nominative instead of in the vocative. . 1168.
EUR. Hel. 1399: w)= kleino\s h(mi=n po/sis . Suppl. 277: w)= fi/los, w)= dokimw/tatos *(ella/di .
SOPH. Ai. 525: *ai)/as , and so regularly in Sophocles. (See Ellendt, Soph. ).

AESCHYL. P. V. 88-90:
w)= di=os ai)qh\r kai\ taxu/pteroi pnoai/,
potamw=n te phgai\ ponti/wn te kuma/twn,
a)nh/riqmon ge/lasma, pammh=to/r te gh=
. Ibid. 545: w)= fi/los, ei)pe/ . Fr. 207 N2: tra/gos, ge/neion a)=ra penqh/seis su/ ge.
HOM. Od. 1.301: kai\ su/, fi/los, ma/la ga/r se, kte . 17.415: do/s, fi/los . 19.406: gambro\s e)mo\s qu/gate/r te, ti/qesq' o)/nom' o(/tti ken ei)/pw .

Il. 3.276 sq.:
*zeu= pa/ter *)/idhqen mede/wn ku/diste me/giste
*)he/lio/s q' o(\s pa/nt' e)fora=|s
.
For the occasional use of the Nominative of an Adjective with a Vocative Substantive, or of a Vocative Adjective with a Nominative Substantive, see Index.

p.hi: Nominative in apposition with the vocative.

div2.p: The nominative with the article is sometimes in apposition with an expressed or unexpressed vocative which is identical with the subject of the verb. Similarly the pronoun ou(=tos is often used in calling to a person.

o( pai=s, a)kolou/qei deu=ro, AR. Ran.521 ; You boy, follow this way!
ou(=tos, ti/ poiei=s; Ibid. Nub. 723 : You there, what are you doing?

PLATO, Conv. 172A: *)=w *falhreu/s, e)/fh, ou(=tos *)apollo/dwros, ou) perimenei=s; ka)gw\ e)pista\s perie/meina: kai\ o(/s, *)apollo/dwre, e)/fh kte( . (note difference between nom. and voc.). Ibid. 218 B: oi( de\ oi)ke/tai kai\ ei)/ tis a)/llos e)sti\ be/bhlos ..., pu/las ... toi=s w)si\n e)pi/qesqe . Protag. 337 C: w)= a)/ndres, e)/fh, oi( paro/ntes .

XEN. An.1.5.16: *pro/cene kai\ oi( a)/lloi oi( paro/ntes *(/ellhnes, ou)k i)/ste o(/ ti poiei=te , Proxenus and the rest of you Greeks that are present, you do not know what you are doing.
Cyr. 4.5.17: i)/qi me\n ou)=n su), e)/fh, o( presbu/tatos, kai\ i)w\n tau=ta le/ge . Ibid. 4.5.22: su\ d', e)/fh, o( tw=n *(grkani/wn a)/rxwn, u(po/meinon . Ibid. 5.3.43: e)pime/lesqe . . . oi(/ te a)/rxontes kai\ pa/ntes de\ oi( swfronou=ntes . Ibid. 6.3.33: su\ de\ o( a)/rxwn . . . e)kta/ttou . Ibid. 8.7.28: kai\ pa/ntes de\ oi( paro/ntes kai\ oi( a)po/ntes fi)loi xai/rete . Mem. 3.14.4: parathrei=t', e)/fh, tou=ton, oi( plhsi/on .
SOPH. Ai. 71-72: ou(=tos, se\ … kalw= . Ibid. 89: w)= ou(=tos, *ai)/as, deu/tero/n se proskalw= .
AESCHYL. Pers. 155-6: w)= baquzw/nwn a)/nassa … mh=ter h( *ce/rcou geraia/, xai=re .
HOM. Od. 3.427: oi( a)/lloi . Cf. 9.172: a)/lloi me\n nu=n mi/mnet' e)moi\ e)ri/hres e(tai=roi .
Il. 3.94: oi( a)/lloi , 19.83: similarly. Cf. ibid. 190: a)/lloi .

div2.head: Vocative Case
div2.p: The Vocative (the case of direct address) is not affected by the structure of the sentence, and does not enter as an element into syntax, except in the matter of concord.
w)= is commonly prefixed to the vocative.

w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi, DEM.1.1 ; Gentlemen of Athens.
a)ei\ o(/moios ei)=, w)= *)apollo/dwre, PLATO, Conv. 173D ; You are always alike, Apollodorus.
DEM. 1.1: w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi , and so hundreds of times in the same author. 19.4: w)= a)/ndres dikastai/ , and the same phrase hundreds of times in the same author.

PLATO, Conv. 173D (see above). In the Conv.there are about 70 examples of the use of w)= with the vocative of proper names, and only 8 instances of the vocative of proper names without w)=. (See Hug on Plat. Conv.init.). Protag.: All of about a hundred vocatives of proper names seem to have the w)=. (See Hug l.c.).
XEN. Anab.: w)= with the vocative occurs about 40 times;Cf. Rockel, De Allocutionis Usu, Königsberg, 1884, p. 8. l.c. p. 5 sq. e.g. 1.7.3.
THUC.: About 40 times; e.g. 1.32.1.
SOPH. Ant. 49, 572.
AESCHYL. Sept.203, 255.
HOM. Od.1.45 and frequently.
Il. 1.74 and frequently.
w)= regularly precedes the vocative or the vocative and its attribute. In poetry it is sometimes interjected between the vocative and its attribute.
PLATO, Phaedr. 227A: w)= fi/le *fai=dre . Ibid. D: w)= be/ltiste *sw/krates . PLAT. Soph. 230C: w)= pai= fi/le .
SOPH. El.86, Ph. 1128.
Cf. El.167, Hel.1451, Or. 1246: *mukhni/des w)= fi/liai .
PIND. P. 2.1: megalopo/lies w)= *sura/kosai .
HOM. Od. 8.408: xai=re, pa/ter w)= cei=ne .
Il. 4.189: fi/los w)= *mene/lae . 17.716.
w)= is occasionally used with both substantive and attribute.
SOPH. Ph.799: w)= te/knon w)= gennai=on .
HOM. Il.6.55: w)= pe/pon w)= *mene/lae .
The omission of w)= in prose is passionate or late.
lhrei=t', *)aqhnai=oi, DEM.8.31 ; You are talking nonsense, Athenians.

a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi, as for example in 8.35, is rare by the side of w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi. a)/ndres dikastai/, as for example in 18.196, is rare by the side of w)= a)/ndres dikastai/. 18.243: e)mbro/ntht', ei)=ta nu=n le/geis ; Ibid. 290: a)kou/eis, *ai)sxi/nh;
PLATO, Conv. 172A. 173 E. 175 A. (twice). Gorg. 518 C: a)/nqrwpe, e)pai+/eis ou)de\n peri\ gumnastikh=s . Lach. 197 E. Phileb. 11 A. Soph. 220 D. Theaet. 143 C.
SOPH. Ai. 36 and frequently, Ant.11. 223.
AESCHYL. Pr. V. 3. 144. 635.
SIMON. C. 145 Bgk.4
In quiet passages the vocative does not begin the sentence. When it heads the sentence, the omission of w)= heightens the excitement still further.
DEM. more than a thousand times, as in 18.5. 21.1. 23.1. 30.1.
AESCHIN.1.122: au(/th me/n e)stin, w)= *ti/marxe, a)ndro\s a)gaqou= . . . a)pologi/a , and so in the other orators.
PLATO, Conv. 173D. 212 B. Gorg. 518 E. Phileb. 11 A (s In this section and the following, w)= is used in all those passages which are not followed by an s = sine, without.).
THUC. Postposition is the rule for Thuc. as in 1.75.1. 1.76.1.
SOPH. Ant. 11 (s). 49.
HOM. Od. 1.1 (s).
DIN.1.72 (once in 67 times).Rockel, l. c., pp. 49-50.
AESCHIN.1.121 (s) (only once, and that a quotation).
ISAE. 3.1 (s).
PLATO, Conv. 173E. Crito, 46 B. Euthyphr. 3 C.
EUR. Hel. 858 (s).
SOPH. Ant. 223 (s), 572.
AESCHYL. P. V. 3 (s), Sept. 203, 255.
The vocative may be used in exclamations.
*(hra/kleis DEM.9.31 ; Herakles!
DEM. 19.308: *(hra/kleis . 21.66: the same. 22.78: w)= gh= kai\ qeoi/ ; also at 24.186, 39.21, 40.5.
PLATO, Prot. 310D: w)= *zeu= kai\ qeoi/ .
XEN. Mem.1.3.12: w)= *(hra/kleis .
AR. Nub. 153: w)= *zeu= basileu= . Ibid. 184: w)= *(hra/kleis . Vesp. 143: a)/nac *po/seidon . Ibid. 161: *)/apollon a)potro/paie . Ibid. 420: *(hra/kleis . Pl. 374: w)= *(hra/kleis .
EUR. Med. 764: w)= *zeu= *di/kh te *zhno\s *(hli/ou te fw=s .
AESCHYL. Ag. 1257: o)totoi=, *lu/kei) *)/apollon, oi)\ e)gw\ e)gw/ .
ALCMAN, fr. 29, Bgk.4: *zeu= pa/ter, ai) ga\r e)mo\s po/sis ei)/h.
HOM. Od. 4.341: *zeu= te pa/ter kai\ *)aqhnai/h kai\ *)/apollon (not real prayers).
Il. 2.371: similarly
The vocative, not being a case proper, cannot take a predicate, but the predicate (nominative) adjective is occasionally attracted into the vocative. Clear cases are late:
a)nti\ ga\r e)klh/qhs *)/imbrase *parqeni/ou, CALLIM. fr. 213, Thou wast called (Imbrasus), O Imbrasus, instead of Parthenius.
o)/lbie kou=re, ge/noio, THEOCR. 17.66 ; Happy laddie, mayst thou prove (so).
In the classical period the examples are only apparent, or, at most, the predicate may be picked out from the attribute which precedes the verb.
AR. Av. 627. w)= fi/ltat' e)moi\ polu\ presbutw=n e)c e)xqi/stou metapi/ptwn .

EUR. Tr. 1221-3
su/ t' w)= pot' ou)=sa kalli/nike muri/wn
mh=ter tropai/wn, *(/ektoros fi/lon sa/kos
stefanou=
.

SOPH. Ai. 695-6
w)= *pa\n *pa\n a(li/plagkte, *kullani/as xionoktu/pou
petrai/as a)po\ deira/dos fa/nhq', w)= qew=n xoropoi/' a)/nac
. Ph. 759-60:
i)w\ i)w\ du/sthne su/
du/sthne dh=ta dia\ po/nwn pa/ntwn fanei/s
.
AESCHYL. Pers. 674. w)= polu/klaute qanw\n duna/sta .

div2.head: Adjectives
div2.p: The expressed subject of the finite verb may be in the form of a substantive, a pronoun, or some word or phrase used as a substantive.

*ko/nwn . . . e)ni/khse, DIN. 1.75 , Conon gained the victory.
pollw=n xrhma/twn to\ xrhsto\n ei)=nai lusitele/stero/n e)sti, DEM. 36.52.
ou(=tos e)/ghme, DEM. [46], 21 , This man got married.
DEM.36.52(see above). [46], 21 (id.)

LYS. 1.11 to\ paidi/on e)bo/a , The baby was bawling.
13.85: ei) me\n to\ e)p' au)tofw/rw| mh\ prosege/grapto .
PLATO, Alc. I, 116 C. ta\ a)gaqa\ sumfe/rei h)\ ou)/ , Rpb. 372 E: o)/ya a(/per kai\ oi( nu=n e)/xousi .
Cf. Hell.4.2.21 ou)k a)pe/qanon au)tw=n plh\n ei)/ tis kte( . (Partitive genitive as subject)
THUC. 1.126. 9: oi( . . . meta\ tou= *ku/lwnos . 3.108.2: oi( kata) to\ decio\n ke/ras e)ni/kwn to\ kaq' e(autou/s . 4.33.1: oi( de\ peri\ to\n *)epita/dan .

HDT. 1.62. oi( a)mfi\ *peisi/straton
3.76, 9.69.
Even prepositional phrases like ei)s o)ktwkai/deka, etc., without the article, may be treated as the subject.

ei) kataskafei/h tw=n teixw=n tw=n makrw=n e)pi\ de/ka sta/dia e(kate/rou, LYS. 13.8 . (Strictly speaking, tw=n teixw=n is the partitive genitive dependent on kataskafei/h and e)pi\ de/ka sta/dia is an adverbial modifier.)
XEN. An. 3.4.5 zwoi\ e)lh/fqhsan ei)s o)ktwkai/deka , About 18 were taken alive. Ibid. 6.4.23: ei)s disxili/ous a)nqrw/pous . Hell. 6.5.10: e)/fugon . . . peri) o)ktakosi/ous .
THUC.3.20.2: e)s de\ a)/ndras diakosi/ous kai\ ei)/kosi ma/lista e)ne/meinan th=| e)co/dw| e)qelontai/ .

HDT. 5.64: kai/ sfewn e)/peson u(pe\r tessera/konta a)/ndras , And of them there fell above 40 men.
6.117: a)pe/qanon . . kata\ e(cakisxili/ous .
Masculine and feminine adjectives and participles are used as personal substantives freely with the article in both numbers, less freely without the article in standard prose.
DEM.1.1: tw=n boulome/nwn . 3.17: tou\s ai)ti/ous . Ibid. 21: to\n o(mw/numon . 4.44: tw=n lego/ntwn . 20.74: tou\s kwlu/sontas . 29.44: oi( dika/zontes .
ISOC.5.24: toi=s e)pithdei/ois toi=s e)moi=s .

PLAT. Alc. I, 113 A: o( e)rwtw=n . . . o( a)pokrino/menos . 125 B: tou\s a)gaqou/s . 134 B: oi( kakoi/ . Conv. 178 E: to\n e)rw/menon . 181 B: oi( fau=loi . 204 D: o( e)rw=n . Lach. 180 D: oi( h(li/koi e)gw/ . Legg. 868 A: tw=| kekthme/nw| . Rpb. 409 C: o( e)/xwn . Theaet. 147 D: tw=| sw=| o(mwnu/mw| .
XEN. Apol. 20: toi=s geiname/nois . 27: toi=s e)moi=s eu)/nois . Hell. 5.2.33: toi=s u(mete/rois dusmene/si . Mem. 1.1.1: oi( graya/menoi .

THUC. 3.4.4: tw=n . . . diaballo/ntwn
5.32.1: tou\s h(bw=ntas .
HDT. 1.120: tou\s geiname/nous , 3.65: tw=n . . . oi)khiota/twn .
AR. Eccl. 1126: th=s e)mh=s kekthme/nhs . Pl. 495: tou\s a)gaqou/s .
EUR. Alc. 167: au)tw=n h( tekou=sa . El. 335: o(/ t' e)kei/nou tekw/n . Hipp. 413: ta\s sw/fronas . Or. 510: o( kei/nou geno/menos .
SOPH. Ai. 456: xw) kako\s to\n krei/ssona . Ant. 520: ou)x o( xrhsto\s tw=| kakw=| laxei=n i)/sos . fr. 321 N2: to\n qnhto/n.

1231: a)/rsenos . Suppl. 393, 644: a)rse/nwn .

Of course a)nh/r, gunh/, and a)/nqrwpos are often expressed. a)nh/r is at once more poetic and more homely than the article.
DEM.15.23: ba/rbaron a)/nqrwpon (fem.). 19.196: *)olunqi/an gunai=ka .
ANT. 1, 14: a)nh\r kalo/s te kai\ a)gaqo/s . 2 d 5: qermo\n kai\ a)ndrei=on a)/nqrwpon . 5.72. ou) ga\r e)/stin o(/ ti a)\n o)rgizo/menos a)/nqrwpos eu)= gnoi/h .

PLATO, Alc. I, 125 B: tou\s a)gaqou\s a)/ndras . Gorg. 470 C: fi/lon a)/ndra . Legg. 846 D. a)ndro\s e)pixwri/ou . Menex. 247D: qnhtw=| a)ndri/ . 335 E: tou= dikai/ou a)ndro/s . Prot.316 C: ce/non a)/ndra . 316 D: tw=n palaiw=n a)ndrw=n . Rpb. 331 C: fi/lou a)ndro/s .

THEOG. 31-2:
kakoi=si de\ mh\ prosomi/lei
a)ndra/sin a)ll' ai)ei\ tw=n a)gaqw=n e)/xeo
. 43 and frequently.
HOM. Il. 3.108: o(plote/rwn a)ndrw=n . 9.320: o(/ t' a)ergo\s a)nh/r . 13.278: o( . . . deilo\s a)nh/r . 23.704: a)ndri\ de\ nikhqe/nti .
When persons are not meant a substantive is understood. Ellipses of masculine substantives are rare but clear.
o( *kuzikhno/s (sc. stath/r), The Cyzicene (a coin).
LYS. 12.11: tetrakosi/ous kuzikhnou/s (sc. stath=ras), but 32.6: tria/konta stath=ras *kuzikhnou/s .
THUC.1.47.2, and elsewhere: o( pezo/s (sc. strato/s) (but o( pezo\s strato/s, 4.8.2 ). 3.107.1: to\n *)amprakiko/n (sc. ko/lpon). 6.30.1: to\n *)io/nion (sc. ko/lpon). 34.4: (similarly).

HDT. 3.25: to
 pezo/n . 4.128: o( pezo/s and to

 strato/n ).
AR. Ach. 1229: a)/kraton (sc. oi)=non). Eq. 105: a)/kraton . . . polu/n . Ibid. 1187: e)/xe kai\ piei=n kekrame/non tri/a kai\ du/o .

COM. FR. Mein. 3.462.13-4. e)n pothri/w| gluku/n (sc. oi)=non). 4.563:
pro\ tou= piei=n
to\n a)/kraton h(mw=n . 4.352.420: o( polu\s a)/kratos o)li/g' a)nagka/zei fronei=n, Much makes your senses crooked, if you take it straight.

HOM. Il. 9.203: zwro/teron (sc. oi)=non?) de\ ke/raie , Don't draw it too mild.
Much more common are ellipses of feminine substantives, such as a)/gkura, gh=, gnw/mh, draxmh/, h(me/ra, labai/, meri/s, moi=ra, o(do/s, oi)ki/a, plhgh/, te/xnh, xei/r, xordh/, xw/ra, yh=fos.

DEM.18.281: ou)k e)pi\ th=s au)th=s (sc. a)gku/ras) o(rmei= toi=s polloi=s , He does not ride at, depend on, the same anchor as the people.
21.84: h( kuri/a (sc. h(me/ra) … ei)s th\n u(sterai/an (sc. h(me/ran). 24.7: w)=fle xili/as (sc. draxma/s). 27.34: tri/a ta/lanta kai\ xili/as (sc. draxma/s) ei)lhfo/ta , Three talents and a thousand drachmae.
ISOC. [1], 43: h( peprwme/nh (sc. moi=ra).

 e)mh/n (sc. gnw/mhn). PLAT. Soph. 231C: o)rqh\ ga h( paroimi/a, to\ ta\s a(pa/sas (sc. laba/s) mh\ r(a/|dion ei)=nai diafeu/gein .

There is often no conscious, or at all events no definite, ellipsis (cf. Lobeck, Paralipp. pp. 329-388). So in the examples of the preceding sections the exact ellipsis is often doubtful.
DEM.14.6: a)p' i)/shs .
XEN. Hiero, 6.8: ou) ga\r e)c e)nanti/as mo/non a)lla\ kai\ pa/ntoqen .

So the feminine adjective is often used adverbially for locality, distance, direction. Regularly in the case of dhmosi/a|, i)di/a|, koinh=|, pezh=|, for examples of which see the dictionaries.

cit.quote: ti/ ou)=n sune/bh meta\ tau=t' eu)qu/s, ou)k ei)s makra/n;

div2.p:
Legg. 683 C: makra
 (sc. o(do/n?) a)
 e)/lqoimi e)/gwge . Theaet. 200 A: makra
 perielqo/ntes .
XEN. An. 3.4.17: i(e/ntes makra/n . Ibid. 7.8.20: o(/pws o(/ti makrota/thn e)/lqoi . Hell. 4.5.8: h(/kein th\n taxi/sthn . Mem. 3.6.10: th\n prw/thn .
THUC.6.98.3: a)poski/dnasqai makrote/ran .
AR. R. 434: mhde\n makra\n a)pe/lqh|s .
EUR. Phoen.906: ou) makra\n a)/pesti .

Neuter Adjectives and Participles are freely employed as substantives in almost any relations, but Homer's range is limited, and the boldness of Thucydides is to be noticed, nor is poetry ever very free.

to\ parelhluqo/s . . . to\ me/llon . . . to\ paro/n, DEM. 18.192 ; The past . . . the future . . . the present.
a)\n e(\n h)\ du/' a)stei=' ei)/pwsin, Ibid. 23.206 ; If they say one or two clever things.

DEM. 18.192 (see above). 19.151: duoi=n xrhsi/moin . 20.26: ei)s de/on . 23.51: du/o dhloi= di/kaia (sc. o( no/mos). The law sets forth two lines of legal procedure.
23.120: pa/nt' h)=n *)ale/candros . 23.206 (see above). [61], 6: duoi=n toi=n kalli/stoin .
AESCHIN.3.165: to\ d' e)so/menon . 3.218: a)rkei= ga/r moi mikra\ kai\ meizo/nwn ai)sxrw=s ou)k e)piqumw= .

[1] 29: to\ me/llon . 31: to\ . . . a)/kairon . 34: to\ . . . a)fane\s e)ktou= fanerou= . 40: me/giston e)n e)laxi/stw| . 3.19: e)n tw=| de/onti . 4.42: e)n me/sw| th=s *(ella/dos . 4.54: polu\ . . . pro\ tw=n *trwikw=n . . . kai\ mikro\n pro\ tou/twn . 4.189: mega/la . . . mikra/ . 11.43: duoi=n toi=n ai)sxi/stoin .

Ibid. 488 E: to\ i)/son e)/xein . Legg. 642 A: peri\ smikrou= polla/ . Ibid. 731 E: tuflou=tai peri\ to\ filou/menon o( filw=n . Ibid. 791 E: pa=n . . . to\ gennw/menon . Ibid. 796 E: ei)s koino/n . Ibid.: peri\ . . . tou= o(/lou . Meno, 89 A: to\ w)fe/limon . Parm. 145B: to/ ge me/son i)/son tw=n e)sxa/twn a)pe/xei . Ibid. 166 B: polla/ . Phaedo, 90 C: pa/nta ta\ o)/nta . Ibid. 92 D: dia\ tw=n ei)ko/twn . Ibid. 100 D: tw=| kalw=| pa/nta ta\ kalw\ gi/gnetai kala/ . Ibid. 112 B: to\ u(gro
