Vesp. 982: e)s ko/rakas. w(s ou)k a)gaqo/n e)sti to\ r(ofei=n (cf. Ach.864: pau=' e)s ko/rakas . Nub. 133: ba/ll' e)s ko/rakas . Plut.604: e)/rr' e)s ko/rakas ). Thesm. 241: u(/dwr u(/dwr (sc. fe/rete?), w)= gei/tones . Ran. 1279: ei)s to\ balanei=on (sc. i)e/nai?) bou/lomai . Plut. 526: e)s kefalh\n soi/ (cf. Ach. 833: polupragmosu/nh nun e)s kefalh\n tra/poit' e)moi/ . DEM.18.290: a(\ soi\ kai\ toi=s soi=s oi( qeoi\ tre/yeian ei)s kefalh/n ).

div2.head: The three concords.
div2.p: There are three great concords in Greek:
1. The agreement of the predicate with the subject (88-136).
2. The agreement of the attributive or the appositive with the substantive (see Index).
3. The agreement of the relative with the antecedent (see Index).

div2.head: Agreement of the Predicate with the Subject
div2.p: The verbal predicate agrees with its subject in number and person.

tou=to ga\r au)to\n e)gw\ prou)balo/mhn kai\ peri\ tou/tou th\n yh=fon oi)/sete nu=n u(mei=s, DEM.21.28; This is why I presented him (this is the gist of my charge against him), and this is the point about which YOU are now to cast your votes. ti/ poiou=sin oi( no/moi; DEM.21.30; What do the laws do? tw\ me\n ou)=n a)delfw\ au)tw=|, w(/ per e)gene/sqhn, a)/mfw a)/paide e)teleuthsa/thn, ISAE. 6.6; He had both his brothers to die childless.
i)/t', w)= megi/sths *palla/dos kalou/menai
pasw=n *)aqh=nai timiwta/th po/lis,
SOPH. O. C. 107-8.
For the use of a verb of the First Person Plural with a subject of the First Person Dual, see 105.
The adjective predicate agrees with its subject in number, gender, and case.

do/ch| me\n xrh/mata kthta/, do/ca de\ xrhma/twn ou)k w)nhth/, ISOC.2.32.
pasw=n h)=n belti/sth (sc. h( e)mh\ gunh/), LYS.1.7.
e)gw\ de\ . . . mesto\s h)=n u(poyi/as, Ibid. 17. ai( deu/terai/ pws fronti/des sofw/terai, EUR. Hipp. 436 (84). ai)sxro\s fanou=mai, SOPH. Ph. 906 (Neoptolemos speaks).

p.hi: Concord when the subject is an infinitive or a sentence, or the verb is impersonal.

div2.p: When the subject is an infinitive or a sentence (77), or the verb is impersonal (76), the predicate adjective (including verbals in -te/os) is regularly in the neuter singular.

a)kou=sai/ g' a)/cion, AR. Eq. 624 ; 'Tis worth the while to lend an ear.
fanero
 h)=n o(/ti ou)de
 deino
 e)gego/nei peri\ th
 po/lin, LYCURG. 21 ; It was evident that no calamity had befallen the city.
deino
 . . . ei) maxou/meqa, AR. Vesp. 426 ; It's dreadful if we've got to fight.
e)ro/menos ei)/ pou ei)dei=e/n ti xwri/on . . . e)/nqa ou) prosbato
 qana/tw|, XEN. Apol. 23 (86). badiste/on ta)/r' e)sti
 ei)s a)gora
 e)moi/, AR. Eccl. 711.
LYCURG.3.Ibid. 21 (see above).

LYS.12.36: deino
 ei) tou\s . . . strathgou\s . . . e)zhmiw/sate . 18.15. 34.11: deino
 ga a)
 ei)/h, w)= *)a., ei) . . . ou)k ou)=n ai)sxro
 ei) … ;
AND.1.8: a(/ma de\ peri\ pa/ntwn ei)pei=n a)du/naton.
PLATO , Crito 53 C: a)=ra a)/cio/n soi zh=n e)/stai; Theaet. 187 E: krei=tton ga/r pou smikro\n eu)= h)\ polu\ mh\ i(kanw=s pera=nai.
XEN. Apol. 23 (see above). Mem. 1.7.2 (76).
AR. Lys. 292. 293. Ran. 652. 656. 658. Eccl. 711 (see above). 875-6: badiste/on o(mo/s' e)sti\ deipnh/sonta kou) mellhte/on .
EUR. Alc. 1078: r(a=|on parainei=n h)\ paqo/nta karterei=n. Tr. 472. 637: tou= zh=n de\ luprw=s krei=sso/n e)sti katqanei=n. 1225.
PIND. P. 4.272: r(a/|dion me\n ga\r po/lin sei=sai.
SOLON, 7: e)/rgmasin e)n mega/lois pa=sin a(dei=n xalepo/n.
MIMNERM. 2.10: au)ti/ka teqna/menai be/ltion h)\ bi/otos.
HOM. Od. 5.359: o(/qi moi fa/to fu/cimon ei)=nai (37).
Il. 2.298. 5.253: ou) ga/r moi gennai=on a)luska/zonti ma/xesqai.
For the use of the neuter plural instead of the singular, see 37.

p.hi: Agreement of the predicate with the subject of the leading verb.

div2.p: When the subject of the infinitive is the same as the subject of the leading verb, the subject of the infinitive is commonly suppressed. In that case the substantive or adjective predicate of a copulative verb, or the predicate attributes of any verb, agree with the subject of the leading verb.

polu\ a)\n au)th=s ma=llon e)gw\ poli/ths decai/mhn ei)=nai h)\ e(te/rwn po/lewn, ANDOC.1.5; Far rather would I be a citizen of her (my country) than of other states. i)dw\n de\ tau=t' e)/fh e)pi\ *lau/rion i)e/nai, Ibid. 39; He said that when he had seen (all) this he went on to Laurion.
a)ciou=men e)leu/qeroi ei)=nai, XEN. Cyr. 8.1.4 ; We claim to be free.
For further exx., see Infinitive.
On the use of the Predicate Vocative for the Nominative, see 25.
The substantive predicate agrees with its subject in case.

tw=n ga\r o)/mbrwn kai\ tw=n au)xmw=n . . . o( *zeu\s tami/as e)sti/n, ISOC.11.13; Zeus is the dispenser of showers and droughts. e)pei\ ou(=toi/ ge fanera/ e)sti . . . diafqora\ tw=n suggignome/nwn, PLATO , Meno, 91 C; Since these fellows are a manifest ruin of those who go with them.
ISOC.11.13(see above).
PLATO , Hipp. Mai. 284 C: no/mon de\ le/geis, w)= *(ippi/a, bla/bhn po/lews ei)=nai h)\ w)fe/leian; Meno, 91 C (see above).
HDT.2.38: a)sh/manton de\ qu/santi qa/natos h( zhmi/h e)pike/etai.
PIND. P. 1.88: pollw=n tami/as e)ssi/.
On the use of the Predicate Nominative, etc., where the Latin uses the Dative of the Object For Which, see under the Dative.
For the Substantive Predicate agreeing with the Subject of the Leading Verb, see 91.
Substantiva mobilia are treated as adjectives and follow the number and gender of the subject.

th=s *)afrodi/ths . . . qera/pwn ge/gonen o( *)/erws, PLATO, Conv. 203C ; Eros is the man-servant (valet) of Aphrodite. ou) ga/r e)stin e)n ge/nei soi h( a)/nqrwpos, ou)de\ qera/paina, DEM. [47]DEM., 70; The wench is of no kin to you, not even a maid (-servant).
DEM. [47]DEM., 70(see above).
PLATO, Conv. 203C (see above). Politic. 301 B: basile/a (sc. au)to/n) kalou=men. Tim. 22 D: h(mi=n de\ o( *nei=los . . . swth/r.
XEN. Cyr. 1.4.9: su\ ga\r nu=n ge h(mw=n e)/oikas basileu\s ei)=nai .
HDT.1.7: *)/agrwn . . . basileu\s e)ge/neto *sardi/wn, Agron became King of Sardis. 1.205: h)=n de/ . . . gunh\ tw=n *massagete/wn basi/leia.
AR. Ran. 1127: swth\rIt must be noted, however, that the inflection is capricious and swth/r is found for sw/teira. genou= moi (To Hermes).

div2.head: General Exceptions
div2.p: The neuter plural is treated as a collective, and takes a singular verb.

diarpasqh/setai ta\ xrh/mata, DEM.8.54 ; Our money (treasury) will be pillaged.
h(/sqh ta\ meira/kia, PLATO, Riv. 134B ; The lads were delighted.
ta\ kuni/dia . . . kubista=n kai\ a)/lla polla\ manqa/nei, XEN. Oec. 13.8 ; Poodles learn to turn a somersault, etc.
DEM.8.54(see above). [59]DEM., 58: tau=t' e)/stw u(mi=n tekmh/ria.
ANT. 5.20: sune/plei de\ ta/ te a)ndra/poda.
PLATO, Crat. 402A: pa/nta xwrei= kai\ ou)de\n me/nei. Riv.134B (see above).
THUC.6.32.1: e)peidh\ . . . e)se/keito pa/nta.
HDT.7.9, g): ou)k e)s tou=to qra/seos a)nh/kei ta\ *(ellh/nwn prh/gmata. Ibid.: a)po\ pei/rhs pa/nta a)nqrw/poisi file/ei gi/nesqai.

AR. N. 39-40: ta\ de\ xre/a ... ei)s th
 kefalh
 a(/panta th
 sh
 tre/yetai . Vesp. 818: ta\ d' a)/ll' a)re/skei moi.
EUR. Heracl. 838: h)=n de\ du/o keleu/smata. Ibid. 1004: toiau=ta drw=nti ta)/m' e)gi/gnet' a)sfalh=.
SOPH. Ph. 113: ai(rei= ta\ to/ca tau=ta th\n *troi/an mo/na.
AESCHYL. Pers. 418-9: u(ptiou=to de\ | ska/fh new=n.
PIND. O. 1.77-8: fi/lia dw=ra *kupri/as a)/g' ei)/ ti, *posei/daon, e)s xa/rin | te/lletai.
THEOGN. 171-2: ou)/ toi a)/ter qew=n | gi/netai a)nqrw/pois ou)/t' a)ga/q) ou)/te kaka/.

HOMER. — In Homer, neuter plurals are found sometimes with the singular, sometimes with the plural. There is a long list of neuter pluralsSee Vogrinz, Gram.des hom. Dialektes, pp. 288-9, and compare Monro, Homeric Grammar2, § 172. that are construed only with a singular verb; other words, such as pa/nta, tau=ta, a(/rmata, dou/rata, etc., occur with both singular and plural verbs, and a few are used exclusively with the plural.
Examples of the neuter plural with a singular verb are: Od. 4.703: th=s d' au)tou= lu/to gou/nata. 5.297: kai\ to/t' *)odussh=os lu/to gou/nata.
Il. 10.252: a)/stra de\ dh\ probe/bhke. 24.420: su\n d' e(/lkea pa/nta me/muken.
This construction is ascribed to the form, for some of the neuter plurals seem to have been originally collective singulars.

p.hi: Adjective predicate of neuter plural subject.

div2.p: The adjective predicate of the neuter plural subject is, of course, plural.
tau=t' e)sti\n a)lhqh=, DEM.2.19; That is true.
The neuter dual is found with the dual, the plural, and the singular.
o)/sse w. dual: HOM. Od. 4, [662]. Il. 1.104: o)/sse de/ oi( puri\ lampeta/onti e)i/kthn. 17.679-80.
o)/sse w. plural: HOM. Il. 1.200: deinw\ de/ oi( o)/sse fa/anqen. 19.16-7.
o)/sse w. sing.: HOM. Od. 6.131-2: e)\n de/ oi( o)/sse | dai/etai. Il. 12.466. 23.477.

p.hi: Accusative absolute in plural accompanied by a participial predicate in the singular.

div2.p: In the accusative absolute, the participial predicate sometimes follows the analogy of the verbal predicate. See Participial Accusative.

p.hi: Neuter plural with a plural verb.

div2.p: When the neuter is merely a formal neuter, the plural verb may be used. So also when variety is emphasized (distributive plural). In older poetry, this occurs frequently when the plural form of the verb would be more convenient than the singular, yet not without a tinge of personification or a suspicion of dualism. In the mechanical syntax of later Greek the neuter plural with the verb plural becomes common.

ou) mh
 ta\ meira/kia . . . th
 au)th
 e)moi\ gnw/mhn e)/sxen, a)ll' e)me\ me
 e)ph/|nesan . . . e)kei/nou de\ katefro/nhsan, ISOC.12.229; True, the lads did not take the same view with me, but (for all that) they applauded me and despised him.

ISOC.12.229: ou) mh
 ta\ meira/kia ta\ pa=si paragegenhme/na tou/tois th
 au)th
 e)moi\ gnw/mhn e)/sxen, a)ll' e)me\ me
 e)ph/|nesan w(s dieilegme/non te nearwte/rws h)\ prosedo/khsan, . . . e)kei/nou de\ katefro/nhsan, ou)k o)rqw=s gignw/skontes a)lla\ dihmarthko/tes a)mfote/rwn h(mw=n.
ANT. 5.34: ou)de/tera w)fe/lhsan, Neither did any good (sc. ta)lhqh= . . . ta\ yeudh=); but Blass follows Reiske and the Zurich editors in reading w)fe/lhsen.

PLATO, Lach. 180E: ta\ ga\r meira/kia ta/de pro\s a)llh/lous oi)/koi dialego/menoi qama\ e)pime/mnhntai *swkra/tous kai\ sfo/dra e)painou=sin, These lads, while conversing with each other at home, often make mention of Socrates, and praise him highly. Legg. 856 D-E: tw=n de\ laxo/ntwn ta\ o)no/mata ei)s *delfou\s pemfqe/ntwn, Let the names of those who drew the lot be sent to Delphi.

XEN. Cyr. 2.3.9: w(/sper ge kai\ ta)/lla zw=|a e)pi/stantai/ tina ma/xhn e(/kasta . . . kai\ fula/ttesqai/ g), e)/fh, a(/panta tau=ta e(pi/stantai . 5.1.14: ta\ moxqhra\ a)nqrw/pia pasw=n oi)=mai tw=n e)piqumiw=n a)krath= e(sti, ka)/peita e)/rwta ai)tiw=ntai , The wretched mass of humanity is powerless over all its desires, and then they (the individuals) blame love.
Hell. 1.1.23: para\ de\ *(ippokra/tous . . . ei)s *lakedai/mona gra/mmata pemfqe/nta e(a/lwsan ei)s *)aqh/nas .

THUC.3.82.8: ta\ de\ me/sa tw=n politw=n . . . diefqei/ronto, The neutral party of the citizens (in the state) were exposed to ruin.
5.75.2: *ka/rneia . . . e)tu/gxanon o)/nta , The Karneia happened to be holding, but HDT.7.206: *ka/rneia ga/r sfi h)=n e)mpodw/n. 6.13.1: e)piqumi/a| me\n e)la/xista katorqou=ntai, pronoi/a| de\ plei=sta.
HDT. 4.149: toi=si de\ e)n th=| fulh_| tau/th| a)ndra/si ou) ga\r u(pe/meinan ta\ te/kna, i(dru/santo . . . i(ro/n: kai\ meta\ tou=to u(pe/meinan .

quote.l: podapa\ ta\ xoiri/'; w(s *tragasai=a fai/netai (note sing.).
a)ll' ou)/ti pa/sas kate/tragon ta\s i)sxa/das.

div2.p: PIND. O. 2.92. 8.12. 10 (11), 85. P. 1.13. 4.121: e)k d' a)/r) au)tou_ pomfo/lucan da/krua ghrale/wn glefa/rwn. 9.88: ta/ (sc. u(/data) nin qre/yanto kai\ *)ifikle/a, Which waters reared him and Iphikles.
See remark on HOMER, 97. Od. 4.132: xrusw=| d' e)/pi xei/lea kekra/anto. Ibid. 417-8: o(/ss' e)pi\ gai=an | e(rpeta\ gi/gnontai. 437: pa/nta d' e)/san (sc. ta\ de/rmata) neo/darta.

Il. 7.102: ni/khs pei/rat' e)/xontai e)n a)qana/toisi qeoi=sin, The cords (lit. = rope-ends) of victory are in the holding of the immortal gods. (Elsewhere in Homer pei/rata takes a singular verb.) Ibid. 16.403-4: e)k d' a)/ra xeirw=n | h(ni/a h)i/xqhsan, The reins leaped (like a pair of living things).

p.hi: Neuter plural subject with a dual verb.

div2.p: The neuter plural subject may take a dual verb when the subject comprises but two.

PLATO, Tim. 56E: du/o puro\s sw/mata ei)s e(\n cuni/stasqon ei)=dos a)e/ros, Two corpuscles of fire combine into one figure of air. Compare ibid. 56 D-E (124), where genoi/sqhn is due to the neuter plural predicate du/o sw/mata.
The singular, however, is the rule:
AESCHIN.1.116: du/o de/ moi th=s kathgori/as ei)/dh le/leiptai, Two heads of the accusation are left me—I have two heads of the accusation left.
On the use of the Neuter Plural Adjective Predicate for the Singular, see 37.

When the subject is of the dual number, but of the first person, the verb is regularly of the plural number, for in the first person the dual and the plural forms of the verb coincide, the dual in -meqon occurring but thrice in classic Greek, and being even then questioned by some scholars.

e)pedikasa/meqa a)/mfw, AND.1.120; We laid our claims (to the heiresses), both of us. nw\ kataba/nte ei)s to\ *numfw=n na_ma . . . h)kou/samen lo/gwn, oi(\ kte(., PLATO, Phaedr. 278B; We both went down to the fount of the Nymphs and heard utterances, which etc.
ANDOC.1.120(see above).
PLATO, Phaedr. 278B (see above).
When the dual subject is of the second or of the third person, the verb is occasionally in the plural.
dissw\ ga\r a)ste/r' i(ppikoi=s e)pi\ zugoi=s | staqe/nt' e)/kruyan a(/rma lugai/w| ne/fei, EUR. Heracl. 854-5; Twain stars atop the horses' yokes did perch | and hid the chariot with a murky cloud.
PLATO, Phaedr. 256C: fi/lw me\n ou)=n kai\ tou/tw . . . a)llh/loin dia/ te tou= e)/rwtos kai\ e)/cw genome/nw dia/gousi.

cit.quote: e)mou= de/ ge sfw\ . . . a)/mfw . . . prosla/besq', w)= fi/lai.

div2.p: EUR. Heracl. 854-5 (see above). Or. 1415: e)/balon e)/balon . . . a)/mfw . Cf. Phoen. 1423-4: gai=an d' o)da\c e(lo/ntes a)llh/lwn pe/las | pi/ptousin a)/mfw kou) diw/risan kra/tos. Ibid. 1454: a)/mfw d' a(/m' e)ce/pneusan a)/qlion bi/on, Both at once breathed forth a wretched life.

SOPH. Ant. 55-7:
tri/ton d' a)delfw\ du/o mi/an kaq' h(me/ran
au)toktonou=nte tw\ talaipw/rw mo/ron
koino\n kateirga/sant' e)pallh/loin xeroi=n
, And third (both) our twain brethren in one day self-murdering—the ill-fated pair—wrought out a common doom with mutual hands.
HES. Sc.233-4: e)pi\ de) zw/nh|si dra/konte | doiw\ a)ph|wreu=nt(o).
HOM. Od. 4.20-2: tw\ d' au)=t' e)n proqu/roisi do/mwn . . . sth=san.
Il. 1.321: tw/ oi( e)/san kh/ruke kai\ o)trhrw\ qera/ponte. 16.218: du/) a)ne/re qwrh/ssonto, The two men 'gan to don their corselets.

p.hi: The dual subject with a plural participial attribute (semi-predication).

div2.p: PLATO, Euthyd. 273D: e)gelasa/thn ou)=n a)/mfw ble/yantes ei)s a)llh/lous, Then they laughed, both of them, looking at one another. Compare Phaedr. 259 A: ei) ou)=n i)/doien kai\ nw\ kaqa/per tou\s pollou\s e)n meshmbri/a| mh\ dialegome/nous, a)lla\ nusta/zontas.

p.hi: Dual genitive absolute with plural participle.

div2.p: DEM. 24. 9: dikasthri/oin duoi=n . . . e)yhfisme/nwn . DEM. [50] 20: e)pitetrihrarxhme/nwn h)/dh moi duoi=n mhnoi=n .

p.hi: Dual subject and plural predicate adjective.

div2.p: ISOC.12.156: ei) ga/r tis fai/h tw\ po/lei tou/tw plei/stwn a)gaqw=n ai)ti/as gegenh=sqai, If any one should say that both these cities have been the authors of many blessings. (The dual in -a does not occur in the orators, and is rare elsewhereSee Keck, Über den Dual bei den Griechischen Rednern, Würzburg, 1882, p. 14.).

The dual verb is used with the plural subject only when the dual notion is expressed or in some way suggested. Of the Attic orators only ANTIPHON, ANDOCIDES, LYSIAS, ISOCRATES, and ISAEUS use dual forms of the finite verb.For entire subject, see Hasse. Der Dualis im Attischen, Leinzig, 1803.
e)c h(=s au)tw=| e)gigne/sqhn ui(ei=s du/o, ISAE. 8.7; Of whom there were born to him—by whom he had issue—two sons.
ISAE. 8.7 (see above).
LYS.13.37: du/o de\ tra/pezai e)n tw=| pro/sqen tw=n tria/konta e)kei/sqhn , Two tables had been placed (= stood) in front of the Thirty.
PLATO, Rpb. 478A-B: ei)/per . . . duna/meis . . . a)mfo/terai/ e)ston.
HOM. Il. 4.27: kame/thn de/ moi i(/ppoi. 9.198: oi(/ (Aias and Odysseus) moi skuzome/nw| per *)axaiw=n fi/ltatoi/ e)ston. 23.392-3. 417-8 = 446-7.
III. Even here the plural is the rule.

kai\ ta\s ei)sfora\s ei)senhno/xasin a)mfo/teroi pa/sas, ISAE. 6.60. du/o tro/poi tugxa/nousin o)/ntes, ISOC.7.46; (It so happens that) there are two methods. loipoi\ du/o mh=nes h)=san, ANT. 6.42; Two months were left.
DEM.23.75: pa=si/n ei)si pra/gmasi . . . du/o prosqh=kai. 142: e)n dh\ *lamya/kw| tine\s a)/nqrwpoi gi/gnontai du/o. 180: h)di/khnto . . . oi( du/o tw=n basile/wn.
ISAE. 2.19: du/o ga/r ei)sin au)th=|. 6.60 (see above).
ISOC.7.46(see above).
ANT. 6.42(see above).
The Plural Verb is found with a Participle in the Dual.
kai\ diapracame/nw to\ loipo\n h)/dh xrw=ntai me\n au)th=|, spani/a| de/, PLATO, Phaedr. 256C ; And having effected their desire, they continue to enjoy it, but only rarely.
PLATO, Phaedr. 256C (see above). Riv. 132 B: kai\ e)gkli/seis tina\s e)mimou=nto toi=n xeroi=n e)pikli/nonte kai\ ma/l' e/spoudako/te.
EUR. Med. 969 ff.: a)ll' w)= te/kn', ei)selqo/nte . . . i(keteu/et' e)caitei=sqe . Phoen. 1404 ff.: a(rpa/sante . . . h(=kon, sumbalo/nte d' . . . a)mfiba/nt' ei)xon .

HOM. Il. 5.487-8: mh/ pws, w(s a)yi=si li/nou a(lo/nte pana/grou, | a)ndra/si dusmene/essin e(/lwr kai\ ku/rma ge/nhsqe. 16.370-1: polloi\ d' e)n ta/frw| e)rusa/rmates w)ke/es i(/ppoi | a)/cant' e)n prw/tw| r(umw=| li/pon a(/rmat' a)na/ktwn.
The Dual verb occurs with a complementary plural predicate participle.
Of course the use of a Dual Predicate with a verb in the First Person Plural is not a violation of the rules of concord. See above 105.
e)sme\n de\ mo/nw e)n e)rhmi/a|, PLATO, Phaedr. 236C; We are alone (just you and I)—all alone.
Transition from a dual verb to a plural verb, or vice versa, takes place even within the limits of the same sentence.

e)/ghman . . . du/o o)/nte *medontia/da . . . kai\ cunw|kei/thn, LYS. fr. 4 (Scheibe). kai\ o(/te paidi/a h)/sthn kai\ eu)qu\s geno/menoi h)pi/stasqe; PLATO, Euthyd. 294E. i(/ppous d' *)atrei+/dao kixa/nete, mhde\ li/phsqon, HOM. Il. 23.407.

The dual number carries with it the notion of a pair, natural or artificial, and emphasizes the notion “both” rather than the notion “two.” It goes back to the beginnings of Greek speech, but is not found to any great extent except in the language of the epos and in It is a stranger to Asiatic Aeolic, is absent from Herodotus, and even in Attic dies out towards the end of the fourth century, by which time it had become more or less literary and studied, as is shown by Plato 's usage. The dual declines from Aristotle to Diodorus, and rises again after Christ, but it is limited to a few familiar nouns, and of dual verbs there is but a trace. See A. J. P. xiv (1893), 521.

As the singular is the generic, and the plural the specific, a plural subject following a singular verb may be regarded as an afterthought. In Greek the oblique cases of e)/stin oi(/ are common, but e)/stin oi(/ itself is very rare, ei)si\n oi(/ being regularly used instead.
a)/kwn d' e)/stin ou(\s e)gw\ e)painw= kai\ filw=, PLATO, Prot. 346E; There be those whom—there are some whom—I praise and love against my will.
PLATO, Prot. 346E: e)/stin ou(/s (see above).

THUC.3.92.5: plh\n *)iw/nwn kai\ *)axaiw=n kai\ e)/stin w(=n a)/llwn e)qnw=n, Except Ionians and Achaeans and other tribes that be.
5.25.2: e)/stin e)n oi(=s .

Outside of these phrases, the construction is commonly called the sxh=ma *pindariko/n, or Pindaric Figure, though the name is hardly justified by Pindar's usage. When the verb precedes, the genuine examples are to be explained on the principle given above, but many of the examples cited are to be accounted for on other grounds, and in many the reading is doubtful.Compare L. G., Pindar lxxxviii, and R. S. Haydon, A. J. P. xi (1890), 182-192.
h)=n de\ tou= danei/smatos tettara/konta me\n kai\ pe/nte [mnai=] e)mai/, ta/lanton d' *eu)e/rgou, DEM.37.4; In the loan there was forty-five minae of mine and a talent of Euergus's.
DEM.37.4(see above).
AND.1.145: gege/nhtai (?) (vid. Blass2 ad loc.).

PLATO, Conv. 188B: pa/xnai kai\ xa/lazai kai\ e)rusi=bai . . . gi/gnetai (all MSS.). Gorg. 500 D: ei) e)/sti tou/tw dittw\ tw\ bi/w, If the existence of these two different lives is accepted; but see B. L. G. on PIND. O. 11 (10), 6. Legg. 732 E, e)/sti agrees with pred. (124). Rpb. 463 A: ti/ ou)=n; e)/sti me/n pou kai\ e)n tai=s a)/llais po/lesin a)/rxonte/s te kai\ dh=mos, e)/sti de\ kai\ e)n au)th=|; There is such a thing as, etc.? Theaet. 173 D, anacoluthon.

THUC.2.3.3, a(/macai is not the subject of i(/n a)nti\ tei/xous h)=|
4.26.5: ai)/tion de\ h)=n oi( *lakedaimo/nioi proeipo/ntes . Here the sing, is due to attraction of predicate (see 124 and 126). 8.9.3 (see 124 and 126).
HDT.1.26: e)/sti de\ . . . e(pta\ sta/dioi. 7.34: e)/sti de\ e(pta\ sta/dioi e)c *)abu/dou e)s th\n a)panti/on, It is seven stadia from Abydos to the opposite shore.

quote.l: h(mi=n ga\r ou)k e)/st' ou)/te ka/ru' e)k formi/dos

p.gloss: For we have no such thing as a brace of servants, etc.

div2.p: EUR. Bacch.1350: ai)ai=, de/doktai, pre/sbu, tlh)mones fugai/, It is decreed —decreed is bitter exile. Hel. 1358-61: me/ga toi du/natai nebrw=n | pampoi/kiloi stoli/des | kissou= te stefqei=sa xlo/a | na/rqhkas ei)s i(erou/s, There is great virtue in, etc.
PIND. See Gildersleeve, Pindar lxxxviii, and note on O. 11 (10), 6.

HOM. Il. 17.385 sqq.:
kama/tw| de\ kai\ i(dro/i nwleme\s ai)ei\
gou/nata/ te knh=mai/ te po/des q' u(pe/nerqen e(ka/stou
xei=re/s t' o)fqalmoi/ te pala/sseto marname/noisin
. (The emphatic position of gou/nata keeps it before the mind, and te is treated as cum would be in Latin.)

div2.head: Special Exceptions
div2.p: The natural relation may be preferred to the artificial, the nearer to the more remote. Hence:
Nouns of multitude often take the verb in the plural.
me/ros . . . ti . . . a)nqrw/pwn . . . ou)x h(gou=ntai qeou/s, PLATO, Legg. 948C; A portion of mankind do not believe in gods.
PLATO, Legg. 948C (see above).
XEN. Cyr. 2.4.20: to\ me\n plh=qos tw=n pezw=n kai\ tw=n i(ppe/wn w)/gmeuon au)tw=| . Hell. 3.3.4: toiau=ta de\ a)kou/sasa h( po/lis . . . *)aghsi/laon ei(/lonto basile/a .
THUC.1.89.3. 125.1. 4.112.3: o( de\ a)/llos o(/milos kata\ pa/nta o(moi/ws e)skeda/nnunto, The rest of the multitude scattered in every direction alike.
AESCHYL. Ag. 189: eu)=t(e) . . . baru/nont' *)axaii+ko\s lew/s. Ibid. 577-9: *troi/an e(lo/ntes . . . *)argei/wn sto/los . . . la/fura . . . e)passa/leusan.
PIND. P. 2.46-7: e)k d' e)ge/nonto strato\s | qaumasto/s.

HOM. Il. 2.278: w(\s fa/san h( plhqu/s. 15.304-5: au)ta\r o)pi/ssw | h( plhqu\s e)pi\ nh=as *)axaiw=n a)pone/onto. Cf. 17.755-7: w(/s te yarw=n ne/fos e)/rxetai h)e\ koloiw=n, | ou)=lon keklh/gontes, o(/te proi+/dwsin i)o/nta | ki/rkon. 23.156-7: *)atrei+/dh, soi\ ga/r te ma/lista/ ge lao\s *)axaiw=n | pei/sontai mu/qoisi.
Organized number is singular. So dh=mos of the (official) people. The conception often shifts.

o( dh=mos despo/ths h)=n kai\ ku/rios pa/ntwn, DEM. 3.30 ; The people was lord and master of all.
h( de\ boulh\ . . . o)ligarxi/as e)pequ/mei, LYS.13.20 ; The senate craved an oligarchy.
DEM.3.30(see above).
LYS.13.20 (see above). 35: o( de\ dh=mos . . . e)yhfi/sato , and frequently.

XEN. Hell. 1.4.12: h(me/ra| h(=| *plunth/ria h)=gen h( po/lis , The day on which the city was celebrating the Plynteries. Ibid. 1.7.3: h( boulh\ e)/dhse . Ibid. 1.7.12: to\ de\ plh=qos e)bo/a deino
 ei)=nai ei) mh/ tis e)a/sei to
 dh=mon pra/ttein o(\ a)
 bou/lhtai , The multitude cried out that it was an outrage if the commons were not to be permitted to do what they would. (Here the plh=qos claims to be the dh=mos.)

THUC.3.22.5: to\ de\ strato/pedon e)pi\ to\ tei=xos w(/rmhsen, The army rushed to the wall.
3.72.3: o( me
 dh=mos e)s th
 a)kro/polin katafeu/gei . . . kai\ to
 *(ullai+ko
 lime/na ei)=xon , The people flee to the citadel and they held the Hyllaean harbor.
5.82.2: o( dh=mos a)naqarsh/sas e)pe/qento (= oi( polloi/) toi=s o)li/gois, The commonalty took heart again and they attacked the oligarchy.
6.30.2: cugkate/bh de\ kai\ o( a)/llos o(/milos a(/pas w(s ei)pei=n o( e)n th=| po/lei kai\ a)stw=n kai\ ce/nwn . 6.31.1: oi( de\ ce/noi kai\ o( a)/llos o)/xlos kata\ qe/an h(=ken w(s e)pi\ a)cio/xrewn kai\ a)/piston dia/noian .
SOPH. Ant. 733. O. C. 741-2: pa=s se *kadmei/wn lew\s kalei= dikai/ws . Tr. 194-5.
AESCHYL. Pers. 127-8: lew\s smh=nos w(\s e)kle/loipen.
PIND. N. 7.23-4: tuflo\n d' e)/xei | h)=tor o(/milos a)ndrw=n o( plei=stos. 9.21: fainome/nan d' a)/r) e)s a)/tan speu=den o(/milos i(ke/sqai.

HOM. Il. 2.99: spoudh=| d' e(/zeto lao)s. 17.723-4: e)pi\ d' i)/axe lao\s o)/pisqe | *trwiko/s, w(s ei)/donto kte(. 17.755 (120). 18.603-4: pollo\s d' i(mero/enta xoro\n perii/staq) o(/milos | terpo/menoi. 23.133: meta\ de\ ne/fos ei)/peto pezw=n.

p.hi: Agreement in sense of participle or adjective with subject.

div2.p: The adjective predicate may follow the natural number or gender (or both) of the subject. So especially often the participle.
o( . . . o)/xlos h)qroi/sqh pro\s ta\s nau_s . . . i)dei=n boulo/menoi to\n *)alkibia/dhn, XEN. Hell. 1.4.13 ; The rabble gathered to meet the ships, they wishing to see Alcibiades.
DEM.21.117: kai\ tau=t' e)/leg) h( miara\ kai\ a)naidh\s au(/th kefalh/, e)celhluqw\s kte(.
AESCHIN.3.133: *qh=bai, po/lis a)stugei/twn, . . . peri\ tw=n o(/lwn ou)k o)rqw=s bouleusa/menoi, a)lla\ . . . kthsa/menoi.

PLATO, Lach. 180E: ta\ ga\r meira/kia ta/de pro\s a)llh/lous oi)/koi dialego/menoi qama\ e)pime/mnhntai *swkra/tous (see 102). Cf. Phaedr. 239 A: ou)/te dh\ krei/ttw ou)/te i)sou/menon e(kw\n e)rasth\s paidika\ a)ne/cetai, h(/ttw de\ kai\ u(podee/steron a)ei\ a)perga/zetai. Ibid. 240 A: a)/gamon, a)/paida, a)/oikon o(/ ti plei=ston xro/non paidika\ e)rasth\s eu)/cait' a)\n gene/sqai.
XEN. Hell. 1.4.13 (see above).

THUC.3.2.1: *le/sbos plh
 *mhqu/mnhs a)pe/sth a)p' *)aqhnai/wn, boulhqe/ntes me
 . . . a)nagkasqe/ntes de\ kte(. 7.75.4: w(/ste da/krusi pa=n to\ stra/teuma plhsqe
 kai\ a)pori/a| toiau/th| mh\ r(a|di/ws a)forma=sqai, kai/per e)k polemi/as te kai\ mei/zw h)\ kata\ da/krua ta\ me
 peponqo/tas h)/dh, ta\ de\ peri\ tw=n e)n a)fanei= dedio)tas mh\ pa/qwsi .

quote.l: ka)n tw=| dh/mw| gnw/mhn ou)dei\s pw/pot' e)ni/khsen, e)a\n mh\
ei)/ph| ta\ dikasth/ri' a)fei=nai prw/tista mi/an dika/santas.

div2.p: In the case of a periphrastic subject like to/ or ta/ with the genitive plural, i)\s *thlema/xoio and the like, the verbal predicate regularly agrees in number, and the participial or adjective predicate in number and gender with the real subject which is contained in the genitive.

PLATO, Legg. 657D: to\ de\ tw=n presbute/rwn (= oi( de\ presbu/teroi) h(mw=n, e)kei/nous (sc. tou\s ne/ous) au)= qewrou=ntes dia/gein h(gou/meqa prepo/ntws, xai/rontes kte(. Cf. Phileb. 45 È: to\ de\ tw=n a)fro/nwn te kai\ u(bristw=n (opposed to tou\s me\n sw/fronas) me/xri mani/as h( sfodra\ h(donh\ kate/xousa periboh/tous a)perga/zetai. Rpb. 563 C: to\ me\n ga\r tw=n qhri/wn . . . o(/sw| e)leuqerw/tera/ e)stin e)ntau=qa h)\ e)n a)/llh|, ou)k a)/n tis pei/qoito a)/peiros.

SOPH. Ph. 497-9: a)ll' h)\ te/qnhken, h)\ ta\ tw=n diako/nwn, | w(s ei)ko/s, oi)=mai, tou)mo\n e)n smikrw=| me/ros | poiou/menoi to\n oi)/kad' h)/peigon sto/lon, “But either he is dead, or else, methinks, my messengers—as was likely—made small account of my concerns, and hastened on their homeward voyage.”—Jebb.
HOM. Od. 11.90-1: h)=lqe d' e)/pi yuxh\ *qhbai/ou *teiresi/ao, | xru/seon skh=ptron e)/xwn. 16.476-7: mei/dhsen d' i(erh\ i)\s *thlema/xoio | e)s pate/r' o)fqalmoi=sin i)dw/n.
Il. 11.690: e)lqw\n ga/r r() e)ka/kwse bi/h *(hraklhei/h. Cf. 17.755-6 (120).
The copula (copulative verb) often agrees with the predicate. Cf. “The wages of sin is death.” This is true also when the copula is in the form of a participle.

*mukh=nai mikro\n h)=n, THUC.1.10.1; Mycenae was a small affair. h(/ te proi\c o)gdoh/konta mnai= genh/sontai, DEM.31.7: The dowry will amount to eighty minae. u(pece/qento ta\s qugate/ras (sc. *)apollofa/nous) paidi/) o)/n t' ei)s *)/olunqon, DEM.19.194; (For safety's sake) they removed his daughters, who were little children, to Olynthus.
DEM.19.194(see above). 31.7 (see above).

PLATO, Legg. 732E: e)/sti dh\ fu/sei a)nqrw/peion ma/lista h(donai\ kai\ lu=pai kai\ e)piqumi/ai. Ibid. 735 E: tou\s ga\r me/gista e)chmarthko/tas, a)nia/tous de\ o)/ntas, megi/sthn de\ ou)=san bla/bhn po/lews. Meno, 91 C (93).  a)ei\ o(ra=te/ moi parou=san . Hell. 1.7.5: meta\ tau=ta de\ oi( strathgoi\ braxe/ws e(/kastos a)pelogh/sato .

p.hi: Neuter adjective as the substantive predicate.

div2.p: The neuter singular adjective is often used as the substantive predicate of a masculine or feminine subject, whether singular or plural.

 h( a)reth\ e(ka/stou; Legg. 663 E: kalo

XEN. Mem. 2.3.1: xrhsimw/teron nomi/zousi xrh/mata h)\ a)delfou/s . Oec. 12.15: kerdale/on e)sti\n h( e)pime/leia .

 ou)=n gunai=kes. H. F. 1292: ai( metabolai\ luphro/n. Or. 232: dusa/reston oi( nosou=ntes a)pori/as u(/po . Ibid. 772: deino

So a Neuter Relative or other pronoun may have for its antecedent a Masculine or Feminine substantive. See Relative Sentences.

p.hi: Attraction of the demonstrative by the predicate.

div2.p: The demonstrative pronoun is commonly attracted into the gender of the predicate.
e)kei=nos d' e)sti\n e)/legxos me/gistos, LYS.16.6 ; That is the most cogent proof.
LYS.16. 6 (see above). 25.23: nomi/zontes kai\ th=s po/lews tau/thn i(kanwta/thn ei)=nai swthri/an kai\ tw=n e)xqrw=n megi/sthn timwri/an .
PLATO, Men. 71E: au(/th e)sti\n a)ndro\s a)reth/, i(kano\n ei)=nai ta\ th=s po/lews pra/ttein kte(., This is a man's virtue, to be able to manage affairs of state.
XEN. Cyr. 8.7.24: ei) de\ mh/, kai\ para\ tw=n progegenhme/nwn manqa/nete: au(/th ga\r a)ri/sth didaskali/a .
THUC.1.1.2: ki/nhsis ga\r au(/th megi/sth . . . e)ge/neto.
HDT.1.1: *(hrodo/tou *(alikarnhsse/os i(stori/hs a)po/decis h(/de, This is the setting forth of the research of Herodotus.
SOPH. Ph. 1-2: a)kth\ me\n h(/de . . . | *dh/mnou.
HOM. Il. 17.336-7: ai)dw\s me\n nu=n h(/de . . . | *)/ilion ei)\s a)nabh=nai kte(.
LYS.1.16: tau/thn ga\r te/xnhn e)/xei (sc. to\ gunai=kas diafqei/rein), This is his trade.

PLATO. Cf. Euthyphr. 2 A: ou)/toi dh\ *)aqhnai=oi/ ge, w)= *eu)qu/fron, di/khn au)th\n kalou=sin, a)lla\ grafh/n, The Athenians do not call it diké but graphé. Phaedr. 245 E: w(s tau/ths ou)/shs fu/sews yuxh=s, “Nam haec est propria natura animi atque vis,” CIC. Tusc.1.23.54.
The attraction is sometimes pretermitted, especially in definitions in which the pronoun is the predicate.
tou=to/ e)stin h( pro/noia, LYS.3.28 ; This is what is meant by malice prepense (Answer to the question ti/ h( pro/noia;). u(perbolh\ ga\r a)diki/as tou=to/ ge, DEM.18.16.
ANT. 1.5: qauma/zw d' . . . ei) nomi/zei tou=to eu)se/beian ei)=nai, to\ . . . mh\ prodou=nai.

PLATO, Gorg. 478C: ou) ga\r tou=t' h)=n eu)daimoni/a, w(s e)/oike, kakou= a)pallagh/. Cf. Phaedr. 245 C: a)lla\ kai\ toi=s a)/llois o(/sa kinei=tai tou=to (sc. to\ au(to\ kinou=n) phgh\ kai\ a)rxh\ kinh/sews. But Cicero, Tusc.1.23.53, translates: Quin etiam ceteris, quae moventur, hic fons, hoc principium est movendi.

p.hi: Difference between ti/ and ti/s in the predicate.

div2.p: In questions distinguish between ti/, the essence of a thing, and ti/s, the classification of a thing.
ti/ d' e)sti\n o( xro/nos kai\ ti/s au)tou= h( fu/sis . . . a)/dhlo/n e)sti, ARISTOT. Phys. 4.218 a 31-2; What time is and what its nature does not appear.
ti/:

PLATO, Crat. 398C: o( de\ dh\ h(/rws ti/ a)
 ei)/h; What might “hero” be? Men.71D: ti/ fh\|s a)reth
 ei)=nai; Prot. 312 C: o(/ti de/ pote o( sofisth/s e)sti, qauma/zoim' a)
 ei) oi)=sqa.
XEN. Mem. 1.2.43: tau=ta ti/ e)sti; . . . kai\ tau=ta no/mos e)sti/; . . . kai\ tau=ta no/mos kalei=tai .

PLATO, Gorg. 448E: a)ll' ou)dei\s h)rw/ta poi/a tis ei)/h h( *gorgi/ou te/xnh, a)lla\ ti/s kai\ o(/ntina de/oi kalei=n to
 *gorgi/an. Ibid. 449 A: ei)pe\ ti/s h( te/xnh kai\ ti/na *gorgi/an kalei=n xrh\ h(ma=s. Phaedr. 278 E: *)isokra/th to
 kalo/n, w(=| ti) a)paggelei=s, w)= *sw/krates; ti/n' au)to
 fh/somen ei)=nai;
When the subject is a neuter plural that may be considered as a unit, ti/ is regularly used instead of ti/na, unless the idea of selection is to be emphasized.
ti/:
ti/ ou)=n e)sti tau=ta, a(\ u(mei=s i)/ste kai\ ou) par' h(mw=n u(ma=s a)kou=sai dei=; DEM.19.217; What then are these things, things that you yourselves know and need not hear from us?
DEM.19.217(see above).

PLATO , Phaedo 57 A: ti/ ou)=n dh) e)stin a(/tta ei)=pen o( a)nh\r pro\ tou= qana/tou; Ibid. 58 C: ti/ h)=n ta\ lexqe/nta kai\ praxqe/nta kai\ ti/nes oi( parageno/menoi tw=n e)pithdei/wn tw=| a)ndri/; (Best MSS. ti/. Schanz and Wohlrab both read ti/, Herm. ti/na.)
XEN. An. 2.1.22: h(mi=n tau)ta\ dokei= a(/per kai\ basilei=. *ti/ ou)=n tau=ta/ e)stin; e)/fh o( *fali=nos .

DEM.18.246: a)lla\ mh\n w(=n g' a)\n o( r(h/twr u(peu/qunos ei)/h, pa=san e)ce/tasin lamba/nete: ou) paraitou=mai. ti/n) ou)=n e)sti tau=ta; But 19.217 (132): ti/.
PLATO , Phaedo 102 A: a)lla\ ti/na dh\ h)=n ta\ meta\ tau=ta lexqe/nta; But ibid. 57 A and 58 C cited in 132: ti/.
For the Attraction of the Relative with the Predicate, see Relative.
The superlative predicate may agree in gender with the subject rather than with the genitive.
o( de\ h(/lios to\n pa/nta xro/non pa/ntwn lampro/tatos w)\n diame/nei, XEN. Mem. 4.7.7 ; The sun abideth forever the most brilliant of all things (thing in the world).

PLATO, Gorg. 487E: pa/ntwn de\ kalli/sth e)sti\n h( ske/yis . . . peri\ tou/twn w(=n kte(. Tim. 29 A: o( me\n ga\r (sc. o( ko/smos) ka/llistos tw=n gegono/twn, o( d' (sc. o( dhmiourgo/s) a)/ristos tw=n ai)ti/wn.

HDT.4.85: pelage/wn ga\r a(pa/ntwn pe/fuke qwumasiw/tatos (sc. o( *po/ntos). Cf. 6.37: pi/tus mou/nh pa/ntwn dendre/wn e)kkopei=sa blasto\n ou)de/na meti/ei, Of all trees the pine is the only one that after being cut lets out no aftershoot.
COM. 4.231: no/swn xalepw/tatos | fqo/nos, Of (all) diseases hardest to bear is envy.
HOM. Cf. Od. 13.86-7: ou)de/ ken i)/rhc | ki/rkos o(marth/seien, e)lafro/tatos petehnw=n.

p.hi: Superlative Predicate agreeing with the Genitive:

div2.p: o( de\ pai=s pa/ntwn qhri/wn e)sti\ dusmetaxeiristo/taton, PLATO, Legg. 808D; The boy (animal) is the hardest to manage of all (animals).
PLATO, Legg. 808D (see above).
HDT.5.24: kthma/twn pa/ntwn e)sti\ timiw/taton a)nh\r fi/los, Of all possessions most valuable is a friend.
On the Attraction of the Predicate Adjective into the Vocative, see 25.
The dramatic h(mei=s for e)gw/ of a woman is masculine. See 55.

p.hi: Indefinite subject, referring to a woman, treated as masculine.

div2.p: The masculine, as the more generic, is sometimes used of an indefinite subject, even when the indefinite subject is known to be a woman.
EUR. Andr. 711-2: h(\ stei=ros ou)=sa mo/sxos ou)k a)ne/cetai | ti/ktontas a)/llous, ou)k e)/xous' au)th\ te/kna.

SOPH. El. 770-1: deino\n to\ ti/ktein e)sti/n: ou)de\ ga\r kakw=s | pa/sxonti mi=sos w(=n te/kh| prosgi/gnetai, Strange is this thing of being a mother. Not even when one suffers wrong can one be brought to hate the child that one has borne. Tr. 151-2: to/t' (sc. [o(/tan] tis a)nti\ parqe/nou gunh\ | klhqh=| kte(., vv. 148-9) a)/n tis ei)si/doito, th\n au(tou= skopw=n | pra=cin, kakoi=sin oi(=s e)gw\ baru/nomai.Eur. Med. 1018, Soph. El. 145 and 1026, are sometimes unjustly cited as instances of this usage. In each of these examples a woman makes but a personal application of a rule that applies to men as well as women.

div2.head: Voices of the Verb
div2.p: There are three voices in Greek: Active, Middle, and Passive.

The distinction of passive from middle is a distinction of function, not of form. The terminations of the passive are either middle or active, and only one comparatively late form is uniformly differentiated, the future in -qh/somai, which is constructed on the basis of -qhn, itself only prevalently passive.

div2.head: Active Voice
div2.p: The Active Voice denotes that the action proceeds from the subject.
ou)=tos e)/ghme, DEM. [46]DEM., 21; This man got married (26). to\ paidi/on e)bo/a, LYS.1.11 ; The baby was bawling (26).

Verbs that regularly take an object are called transitive verbs, verbs that do not regularly take an object are called intransitive verbs. So ktei/nw, I kill, is a transitive verb; siwpw=, I am silent, is an intransitive verb. But any verb may be transitive or intransitive, according to its use, and the traditional distinction given is a mere matter of convenience, and does not rest on a difference of nature.

As all verbs involve an inner object and may take an inner object, it is better to confine the term transitive to verbs that take an outer object, and when such verbs are used without an outer object, they serve to characterize the subject. So foneu/w, I commit murder, and nikw=, I gain a victory, become I am a murderer (foneu/s), and I am a victor (nikhth/s). a)/gei (PIND. P. 2.17), she is a leader, she is in the van.

The analysis given above is sometimes expressed. So a)natre/pw, I overturn, may be analyzed into a)natropeu\s gi/gnomai, I show myself a subverter, or a)natroph\n poiou=mai, I produce subversion. The former dwells on the character of the agent, the latter on the character of the action. Hence the solemnity of both the periphrases, involving as they do moral responsibility. Compare 61 and A. J. P. xx, III.

ISOC.2.17: ma/lista me\n eu(reth\s gi/gnou tw=n belti/stwn, ei) de\ mh/, mimou= ta\ para\ toi=s a)/llois o)rqw=s e)/xonta. 10.42: tw=n de\ dwrew=n a)nagkasqei\s gene/sqai krith/s. Ibid. 43: e)pequ/mhse *dio\s gene/sqai khdesth/s.

ANT. 1.2(see 61). 1.4 (60). 2 b 2: e)moi\ de\ zw=n te a(/nqrwpos a)natropeu\s tou= oi)/kou e)ge/neto kte(. 5.47: kai\ tw=n me\n . . . lo/gwn . . . toutousi\ krita\s h)ciw/sate gene/sqai, tw=n de\ e)/rgwn au)toi\ dikastai\ e)ge/nesqe, et sim. alib.

PLATO, Conv. 218C: su\ e)moi\ dokei=s, h)=n d' e)gw/, e)mou= e)rasth\s a)/cios gegone/nai mo/nos. Legg. 872 C: e)a\n de/ tis dou=lon ktei/nh| mhde\n a)dikou=nta, fo/bw| de/, mh\ mhnuth\s ai)sxrw=n e)/rgwn kai\ kakw=n au)tou= gi/gnhtai kte(.

THUC.1.4: kai\ tw=n *kukla/dwn nh/swn h)=rce/ te kai\ oi)kisth\s prw=tos tw=n plei/stwn e)ge/neto. 1.132.5: mhnuth\s gi/gnetai . 1.136.3: i(ke/ths geno/menos . 3.2.3 (60). 5.11.1: swth=ra . . . gegenh=sqai . Cf. 8.48.6: porista\s o)/ntas kai\ e)shghta\s tw=n kakw=n tw=| dh/mw| . 8.86.4: kwluth\s gene/sqai , and similarly elsewhere.
AR. Ran. 1152: swth\r genou= moi . 1191: i(/na mh\ )ktrafei\s ge/noito tou= patro\s foneu/s .
EUR. Cf. [Rhes.] 167: su\ d' a)lla\ gh/mas *priamidw=n gambro\s genou=.
SOPH. Ai. 1092 (61). O. C. 582: o(/tan . . . su/ mou tafeu\s ge/nh| .
AESCHYL. Ag. 224-5: e)/tla d' ou)=n | quth\r gene/sqai qugatro/s. Cho. 2 (61). Ibid. 246: qewro\s . . . genou=. Sept. 130 (61).
PIND. P. 4.274: ei) mh\ qeo\s a(gemo/nessi kubernath\r ge/nhtai.
HOM. Od. 17.223: ei)/ moi doi/hs staqmw=n r(uth=ra gene/sqai.
Il. 18.100: e)meu= de\ de/hsen a)rh=s a)lkth=ra gene/sqai.

Among the active transitive verbs that are freely used intransitively and are sometimes called immediatives may be mentioned e)lau/nw, I drive, and its compounds; the compounds of i(/hmi, I send forth; ba/llw, I hit, cast, and compounds of ba/llw.

The following is a more complete list of the verbs belonging to this class: a)/gein and cpd.cpd. stands for one or more compounds. , ai)/rein and cpd., cpd. of a)lla/ttein, cpd. of a)nu/ein, ba/llein and cpd., cpd. of dido/nai, dinei=n, e)lau/nein and cpd., e)pei/gein, e)/xein and cpd., i(e/nai and cpd., a)nakalu/ptein, keu/qein, cpd. of kli/nein, cpd. of lamba/nein, cpd. of lei/pein, cpd. of mignu/nai, minu/qein, nika=n, nwma=n and cpd., oi)kei=n, o(rma=n and cpd., pau/ein, pra/ttein, ste/llein, stre/fein and cpd., tei/nein and cpd., teleuta=n, fai/nein and cpd., fe/rein and cpd., fu/ein, xala=n.

e)gw\ de/, e)/fh, e)pi\ tou/sde, h)\n e)pi\ de\ kinw=ntai, e)lw=, XEN. Cyr. 1.4.20 ; I will ride against (charge) these people, if they undertake to move against you.
e)ci/hsi de\ . . . *)axerousi/a li/mnh e)s qa/lassan: dia\ de\ th=s *qesprwti/dos *)axe/rwn potamo\s r(e/wn e)sba/llei e)s au)th/n, THUC.1.46.4 ; The Acherusian lake has an outlet into the sea, while the river Acheron, flowing through Thesprotia, empties (itself) into the lake itself.

PLATO, Phaedr. 228E: pau=e. Ibid. 229 A: pro/age dh/. Ibid. 229 B: proa/gois a)/n.
XEN. Cyr. 1.4.20 (see above). Ibid.: o( *kuaca/rhs labw\n tw=n e)rrwme/nwn i(/ppwn te kai\ a)ndrw=n proselau/nei .

SOPH. El. 1435: h(=| noei=s e)/peige nu=n . O. R. 967-8: o( de\ qanw\n keu/qei ka/tw dh\ gh=s .

HOM. Od. 7.130: h( d' (sc. krh/nh) e(te/rwqen u(p' au)lh=s ou)do\n i(/hsin. 11.239: o(\s polu\ ka/llistos potamw=n e)pi\ gai=an i(/hsin.
Il. 12.268: nei/keon, o(/n tina pa/gxu ma/xhs meqie/nta i)/doien. 23.758-9: w)=ka d' e)/peita | e)/kfer' *)oilia/dhs.

p.hi: Infinitive active apparently as a passive.

div2.p: The infinitive being a verbal noun is not so strictly bound by the voices as the finite form. The infinitive as a complement to adjectives and the so-called epexegetic infinitive often coincide with the English idiom in which “good to eat” is “good for food,” “fair to see” is “fair to the sight,” and in Greek the active form is more common and, if anything, more natural than the passive. kalo\s i)dei=n, fair to see; xalepa\ eu(rei=n, PLATO, Rpb. 412B, hard to find; but xalepoi\ . . . gnwsqh=nai, ANTIPHON, 2 a 1, hard to recognize. See Infinitive.
As in other languages, the subject is said to do what it causes to be done, qui facit per alium, facit per se.
h( boulh\ e)/dhse (sc. au)tou/s), XEN. Hell. 1.7.3; The senate put them in jail.
LYS.12.23: to\n a)delfo\n ga/r mou, w(/sper kai\ pro/teron ei)=pon, *)eratosqe/nhs a)pe/kteinen (Polemarchos drank the cup at the command of the Thirty, l.c. § 17).
PLATO , Meno 94 C: *qoukudi/dhs au)= du/o ui(ei=s e)/qreye . . . kai\ tou/tous e)pai/deuse ta/ te a)/lla eu)= kai\ e)pa/laisan ka/llista *)aqhnai/wn, et sim. alib.
XEN. An. 1.4.10: *ku=ros d' au)to\n (sc. to\n para/deison) e)ce/koye kai\ ta\ basi/leia kate/kausen. Hell. 1.7.3 (see above).

HDT.8.118: w(s de\ e)kbh=nai ta/xista e)s gh=n to
 *ce/rchn . . . a)potamei=n th
 kefalh
 au)tou= (sc. tou= kubernh/tou).
For Intransitive Verbs of Passive Signification, see 171.

div2.head: Middle Voice
div2.p: The Middle Voice denotes that the subject is in some especial manner involved or interested in the action of the verb. In some of its uses the middle corresponds to the English reflexive, but the signification is much wider and shades off from what is practically a direct reflexive until it ceases to present any translatable difference from the active.

The interest may be that of the direct object. This is limited chiefly to natural or habitual actions. The only middle for self-murder is a)pa/gcasqai, to hang oneself, which seems to have been the most natural form of suicide.
e)peidh\ de\ e)lou/sato, PLATO , Phaedo, 116 B; After he had bathed himself (taken his bath).
DEM. [50]DEM., 35: lou=sqai e)n balanei/w|.
PLATO , Phaedo, 116 B (see above).
XEN. Cyr. 3.1.25: oi( me\n r(iptou=ntes e(autou/s, oi( d' a)pagxo/menoi, oi( d' a)posfatto/menoi.
THUC.3.81.3: e)k tw=n de/ndrwn tine\s a)ph/gxonto.
HDT.2.40: tu/ptontai pa/ntes, All beat their breasts (natural expression of grief). 2.131: h( pai=s a)ph/gcato, The maid hanged herself.

AR. Ach. 17: e)c o(/tou )gw\ r(u/ptomai, I scour myself.
Av. 1163: a)poni/yomai , I'll wash myself, i. e. my hands. Thesm. 230: poi= stre/fei; fr. 2.1100.9: a)ll' a)rti/ws kate/lipon au)th\n smwme/nhn | e)n th=| pue/lw|.
PIND. O. 7.15: a)/ndra par' *)alfeiw=| stefanwsa/menon. Ibid. 80-1: tw=n a)/nqesi *diago/ras | e)stefanw/sato di/s. 12.17: stefanwsa/menos.
SAPPHO, fr. 62: kattu/ptesqe ko/rai.
AM.16: kh)leifo/mhn mu/roisi kai\ quw/masin.
HOM. Od. 5.491: w(\s *)oduseu\s fu/lloisi kalu/yato.
Il. 10.576: loe/santo, They bathed themselves.

Much more frequent is the indirect middle, in which the subject is more or less remotely involved, sometimes with sharp distinction from the active, sometimes without any perceptible, or at any rate translatable, difference. See the examples of this and the following section.
me/qhn de\ kai\ u(/pnon o(moi/ws e)ne/dra| fula/ttomai, XEN. Hiero, 6.3; Drunkenness and sleep I guard against like an ambush. (fula/ttw = keep guard, mount guard over.)
LYCURG.85: ou)d(e\) . . . th\n qreyame/nhn . . . toi=s polemi/ois pare/dosan, Nor did they surrender to the enemy the country that reared them for herself.
DEM.20.17: h(=s a)/n tinos politei/as to\ komi/zesqai tou\s eu)/nous toi=s kaqestw=sin xa/rin e)ce/lh|s, ou) mikra\n fulakh\n au)tw=n tau/thn a)fh|rhkw\s e)/sei.
XEN. Hiero, 6.3 (see above). [R. A.] 1.1: eu)= diasw/|zontai th\n polirei/an, Excellently well do they preserve their form of government.
HDT.2.121: mnhmo/suna e)li/peto ta\ propu/laia. 3.79: spasa/menoi de\ ta\ e)gxeiri/dia. 7.119: a)pelau/neskon, lei/pontes ou)de\n a)lla\ fero/menoi.

AR. Ach. 51-2: e)moi\ d' e)pe/treyan oi( qeoi\ | sponda\s poiei=sqai pro\s *lakedaimoni/ous mo/nw|, The gods permitted me and me alone to make a treaty for myself with the Lacedaemonians. But vv. 57-8: to\n a)/ndr' a)pa/gontes, o(/stis h(mi=n h)/qele | sponda\s poih=sai (the generous creature), Taking away the man who wished to make a treaty for us. Ibid. 130-1: e)moi\ . . . | sponda\s poi/hsai pro\s *lakedaimoni/ous mo/nw|.
COM. 4.355.539: xqw\n pa/nta komi/zei kai\ pa/lin komi/zetai, Earth bringeth everything and takes it back again; Nam terra donat ac resorbet omnia.

AESCHYL. Sept. 718: a)ll' au)ta/delfon ai(=ma dre/yasqai qe/leis; What! wilt thou make thee a harvest of thy brother's blood? fr. 44: h( de\ (sc. gai=a) ti/ktetai brotoi=s | mh/lwn te boska\s kai\ bi/on *dhmh/trion.
PIND. O. 7.42: semna\n qusi/an qe/menoi. 8.68-9: a)peqh/kato . . . no/ston e)/xqiston. N. 2.6-10 (148). I. 5.60-1: a)/ranto ga\r ni/kas a)po\ pagkrati/ou | trei=s.

HOM. Il. 4.529-30: e)k d' o)/brimon e)/gxos | e)spa/sato ste/rnoio, From out the breast he plucked the ponderous spear, and similarly 5.621: e)spa/sat(o), 7.255: e)kspassame/nw, and 13.510: e)spa/sat(o); but the active is used 5.859; 6.65; 12.395; and 13.178 (see 148). 11.802-3: r(ei=a de/ k' a)kmh=tes kekmho/tas a)/ndras a)uth=| | w)/saisqe proti\ a)/stu new=n a)/po kai\ klisia/wn, and similarly 5.691; 8.295; 15.418; 16.592; 655; but 16.44-5: r(ei=a de/ k' a)kmh=tes kekmho/tas a)/ndras a)uth=| | w)/saimen proti\ a)/stu new=n a)/po kai\ klisia/wn, and so the active 8.336; 13.193; 16.569; 17.274 (see also 148).

Homer has a certain fondness for the middle. So, for example, i)de/sqai occurs 38 times over against the 19 instances of i)de/ein or i)dei=n. The middle forms of o(ra/w are not uncommon, whereas in prose we have only proora=sqai. The verse has something to do with all this. So i)dw/n is the only possible form for the aorist participle.

The middle is not compulsory. The use of the active where the middle might have been expected may sometimes be ascribed to the aristocratic disdain of effect (see Pindaric examples below), just as in late Greek the middle is sometimes used in order to produce a grander sound.
ta\ xrh/mata . . . e)ceko/mise, LYCURG.38; He got his money out safe.
LYCURG.38(see above).

PLATO, Protag. 324D: oi( a)/ndres oi( a)gaqoi\ . . . tou\s au(tw=n ui(ei=s dida/skousi a(\ didaska/lwn e)/xetai, with which compare ibid. 325 D: oi( a)gaqoi\ a)/ndres . . . ta\ me\n a)/lla dida/skontai tou\s ui(ei=s . . . ta\ me\n a)/lla a)/ra tou\s ui(ei=s dida/skontai.

HDT.2.51: tou= de\ *(erme/w ta\ a)ga/lmata o)rqa\ e)/xein ta\ ai)doi=a poieu=ntes ou)k a)p' *ai)gupti/wn memaqh/kasi, a)ll) a)po\ *pelasgw=n, with which compare just below: o)rqa\ w)=n e)/xein ta\ ai)doi=a ta)ga/lmata tou= *(erme/w *)aqhnai=oi prw=toi *(ellh/nwn maqo/ntes para\ *pelasgw=n e)poih/santo. 2.143: a)rxiereu\s ga\r e(/kastos au)to/qi i(sta=| (v. l. i(/statai) e)pi\ th=s e(wutou= zo/hs ei)ko/na e(wutou=.

PIND. P. 1.49: oi(/an (sc. tima/n) ou)/tis *(ella/nwn dre/pei, and similarly P. 4.130 and 6.48; with which compare N. 2.6-10: o)fei/lei d' e)/ti . . . qama\ me\n *)isqmia/dwn dre/pesqai ka/lliston a)/wton . . . *timono/ou pai=d(a).

HOM. Il. 5.859: e)k de\ do/ru spa/sen au)=tis, And out again he plucked the shaft; and similarly 6.65; 12.395; 13.178. (For the use of the middle in similar examples, see 147). Ibid. 8.336: oi(\ d' i)qu\s ta/froio baqei/hs w)=san *)axaiou/s, But they thrust the Achaeans straight toward the deep trench; and similarly 13.193; 16.45; 569; 17.274. (For the use of the middle in similar examples, see 147.)

As the reflexive may be used for the reciprocal, so the middle, which represents the reflexive relation, may be used to intimate the reciprocal relation. Such verbs are ma/xesqai, se battre, sich schlagen, a)gwni/zesqai, diale/gesqai, and many other deponent verbs.
e)n xersi\ geno/menoi e)ma/xonto, THUC.7.5.2; Coming to close quarters they fought, but a)llh/lois . . . e)ma/xonto, 3.77.2; They fought one another.
THUC.7.5.2(see above).
HDT.2.63: kefala/s te sunara/ssontai, They butt one another's heads.
AR. Pl. 329-30: triwbo/lou me\n ei(/neka | w)stizo/mesq' e(ka/stot' e)n th)=kklhsi/a|, We hustle one another; but Ach. 24-5: w)stiou=ntai . . . a)llh/loisi.
SOPH. O. C. 424: h(=s (sc. ma/xhs) nu=n e)/xontai ka)panai/rontai do/ru .
PIND. O. 1.98: taxuta\s podw=n e)ri/zetai = taxei=s po/des e)ri/zontai.
HES. O. et D. 37: klh=ron e)dassa/meq(a).
HOM. Il. 23.735: mhke/t' e)rei/desqon, No longer press each the other.

As the active is often used of what one does by an agent, so the middle is used of that which the subject has done for itself. This is an occasional use of the middle, but it is not a characteristic use, and must not be pressed as differentiating it from the active.

*qemistoklh=s *kleo/fanton to
 ui(o
 i(ppe/a me
 e)dida/cato a)gaqo/n, PLATO, Men. 93D ; Themistocles had his son K. taught to be a good horseman, but ibid. 94 B: tou/tous . . . i(ppe/as me
 e)di/dacen ou)deno\s xei/rous *)aqhnai/wn .

PLATO , Meno, 93 D (see above). Protag. 325 B: oi( a)gaqoi\ a)/ndres . . . ta\ me
 a)/lla dida/skontai tou\s ui(ei=s . . . ta\ me
 a)/lla a)/ra tou\s ui(ei=s dida/skontai, but 324 D: oi( a)/ndres oi( a)gaqoi\ ta\ me
 a)/lla tou\s au(tw=n ui(ei=s dida/skousin, a(\ didaska/lwn e)/xetai.

THUC.1.132.2: e)pi\ to\n tri/poda . . . h)ci/wsen (sc. *pausani/as) e)pigra/yasqai au)to\s i)di/a| to\ e)legei=on to/de, but § 3: to\ me\n ou)=n e)legei=on oi( *lakedaimo/nioi e)ceko/layan eu)qu\s to/te . . . kai\ e)pe/grayan o)nomasti\ ta\s po/leis kte(.
HDT.1.50: e)poie/eto [sc. *kroi=sos] de\ kai\ le/ontos ei)ko/na xrusou= a)pe/fqou, Croesus had an image of a lion made for himself out of refined gold.
AR. Eq. 5: plhga\s a)ei\ prostri/betai toi=s oi)ke/tais (see v. 64).
Direct reflexive actions are commonly expressed by the active and the reflexive; so, regularly, unnatural actions, and actions which circumstances have made unnatural or difficult.

e)mauto
 filw=, DEM. [47]DEM., 73; I love myself. r(i/ptei au(to
 ei)s th
 qa/lattan, DEM.32.6; He throws himself into the sea.
DEM.32.6(see above). [47]DEM., 73(see above).
AESCHIN.1.53: ou)k e)nouqe/thsen e(auto/n.
ISOC. [1]ISOC., 15: e)/qize seauto/n. 2.29: e)/qize sauto/n. 5.118: e)qi/zein sauto\n xrh/.
PLATO, Legg. 861A: e)rwtw=men h(ma=s au)tou/s, Let us ask ourselves. Phaedo 96 A: polla/kis e)mauto\n a)/nw ka/tw mete/ballon. Theaet. 148 E.
XEN. An. 1.2.7: o(po/te gumna/sai bou/loito e(auto/n te kai\ tou\s i(/ppous. Hell. 1.6.10: ou)k e)duna/mhn e)mauto\n pei=sai, I could not persuade myself.
THUC.2.4.4: e)/rriyan . . . sfa=s au)tou/s. 4.38.3: ta\ o(/pla pare/dosan kai\ sfa=s au)tou/s .
HDT.2.116: ou)damh=| a)/llh| a)nepo/dise e(wuto/n (sc. *(/omhros). 3.36: i)/sxe kai\ katala/mbane sewuto/n.
AR. Vesp. 286-7: mhd' ou(/tws seauto\n | e)/sqie, Stop gnawing at yourself so. Ibid. 996: e)/paire sauto/n. Ibid. 1213: xu/tlason seauto/n, Dump yourself. Thesm. 230: e)/x' a)tre/ma sauto/n.
EUR. Alc. 188: ka)/rriyen au(th/n. Ibid. 250: e)/paire sauth/n. Ibid. 788: eu)/fraine sauto/n.
SOPH. El. 988: pau=son de\ sauth/n.
AESCHYL. P.V. 748: e)/rriy' e)mauth/n.
Extreme unnaturalness is expressed by au)to\s e(auto/n and the like.
au)to\s au(to\n die/fqeiren, XEN. Hell. 7.4.19; He made away with himself.
AESCHIN.3.233: katale/luken au)to\s th\n au(tou= dunastei/an.
PLATO, Menex. 243D: h(mei=s de\ au)toi\ h(ma=s au)tou\s kai\ e)nikh/samen kai\ h(tth/qhmen.
XEN. Hell. 7.4.19 (see above).
HDT.1.93: e)kdidou=si de\ au)tai\ e(wuta/s.
The reflexive relation may be brought out more clearly by adding the reflexive forms to the middle.
u(po\ nu/kta th\n swthri/an au(toi=s e)/mellon pori/zesqai, LYCURG.70; Under cover of the night they were about to provide safety for themselves.
LYCURG, 70 (see above).
AESCHIN.1.132: kataskopou/menos e(auto/n.
ANTIPHON, 5.13: au)to\s sautw=| no/mon qe/menos, Having laid down a law for yourself.
XEN. [R. A.] 2.10: o( de\ dh=mos au)to\s au(tw=| oi)kodomei=tai i)di/a| palai/stras polla/s.
PIND. O. 13.53: *mh/deian qeme/nan ga/mon au)ta=| (= au(ta=|).
Of course when the middle has acquired a special significance this is necessary.
e(auto\n . . . lu/sasqai, ANTIPHON, 5.63; To ransom himself.
ANTIPHON, 5.63 (see above).
PLATO, Protag. 346B: au)tou\s e(autou\s paramuqei=sqai.
COM. *(eauto\n timwrou/menos, Self-Tormentor (Title of a play by MENANDER).
HOM. Il. 10.378: e)me\ lu/somai, I will ransom myself.

p.hi: Middle and accusative of the part affected.

div2.p: Of course an accusative of the part affected may be used with the middle.
ta\ me/twpa ko/ptontai maxai/rh|si, HDT.2.61: They gash their foreheads with knives.

HDT.2.61(see above). 3.14: e)plh/cato th\n kefalh/n, He smote his head. 4.71: tri/xas perikei/rontai, braxi/onas perita/mnontai, me/twpon kai\ r(i=na katamu/ssontai. 4.75: ou) ga\r dh\ lou/ontai u(/dati to\ para/pan to\ sw=ma.
AR. Eccl. 63: a)leiyame/nh to\ sw=m' o(/lon.
SOPH. Ai. 245: ka/ra kalu/mmasi kruya/menon .
PIND. N. 10.44: e)piessa/menoi nw=ton malakai=si kro/kais.
HES. Sc. 243: kata\ d' e)dru/ptonto pareia/s.
HOM. Od. 6.224-5: e)k potamou= xro/a ni/zeto . . . a(/lmhn.
Il. 18.30-1: xersi\ de\ pa=sai | sth/qea peplh/gonto.

p.hi: Details of difference between the active and the middle.

div2.p: The details of difference between the active and the middle belong to the dictionary. Many of them are conventionally of great importance. a)podi/dwmi is I render, restore, a)podi/domai, I sell; danei/zw is I lend (on interest), danei/zomai, I borrow (on interest); ki/xrhmi is I lend to use, ki/xramai, I borrow to use, the aorist in use being h)|thsa/mhn; e)/xw means I have, e)/xomai, I cling to; e)/ghma signifies I married, duxi (of the man), e)ghma/mhn, I got married, nupsi (of the woman); misqw= is I let, misqou=mai, I hire. There is a long string of differences between poiei=n and poiei=sqai with verbal nouns in which the active gives the literal side “to fashion,” “to bring about,” whereas the middle serves to form a periphrasis with the dependent substantive for the corresponding verb. So lo/gon poiei=n is to compose a speech, lo/gon poiei=sqai, to make a speech (le/gein); o(do\n poiei=n is to construct a road, o(do\n poiei=sqai, to make one's way (o(deu/ein); ei)rh/nhn poih=sai, to bring about a peace (between two contending parties), ei)rh/nhn poiei=sqai, to make peace (with an enemy); no/mous tiqe/nai, to be a nomoqe/ths, to be a lawgiver (for those who desire legislators), no/mous ti/qesqai, to make laws for one's own state. Regularly e)kklhsi/an poiei=n, to convoke an assembly.
A few examples by way of illustration are given here.
ISOC.6.1: tosau/thn pepoi/hmai th\n metabolh/n.
AND.3.1: o(/ti me\n ei)rh/nhn poiei=sqai dikai/an a)/meino/n e)stin h)\ polemei=n. 3.2: o( dh=mos o( *aqhnai/wn ei)rh/nhn e)poih/sato pro\s *lakedaimoni/ous.
PLATO, Lach. 180C: e)ntau=qa a)ei\ ta\s diatriba\s poiou/menon.
XEN. An. 7.6.41: tau=ta a)podo/menos ou)/te *seu/qh| a)pe/dwken ou)/te h(mi=n ta\ gigno/mena . . . h)\n ou)=n swfronw=men, e(co/meqa au)tou=.
THUC.1.40.2: o(/stis mh\ toi=s decame/nois . . . po/lemon a)nt' ei)rh/nhs poih/sei, but 5.17.2: cunexwrei=to w(/ste a(\ e(ka/teroi pole/mw| e)/sxon a)podo/ntas th\n ei)rh/nhn poiei=sqai .

HDT.7.42: e)poie/eto de\ th\n o(do/n. 8.40: boulh\n . . . poih/sasqai (= bouleu/sasqai). 8.74: th=|si nhusi\ ou)k e)lpi/zontes e)lla/myesqai (act. = to shine upon Not expecting to make a brilliant record with their ships.

AR. Ach. 830: ta\ xoiri/di) a)pe/dou, You sold the pigs, but Vesp. 1128: a)pe/dwk(a) . . . tw=| knafei= triw/bolon, I paid the fuller three obols.
Lys. 1056-7: o(/stis a(\n . . . danei/shtai . . . mh\ a)podw=| , but Pax, 374: da/neison trei=s draxma/s.
AESCHYL. fr. 13: soi\ me\n gamei=sqai mo/rsimon, gamei=n d' e)moi/.
ANACR. fr. 86: kai\ qa/lamos, e)n tw=| kei=nos ou)k e)/ghmen a)ll' e)gh/mato.
THEOGN. 32: a)ll' ai)ei\ tw=n a)gaqw=n e)/xeo.
HOM. Od. 14.393: a)ll' a)/ge nu=n r(h/trhn poihso/meq(a). Ibid. 21.70-1: ou)de/ tin' a)/llhn | mu/qou poih/sasqai e)pisxesi/hn e)du/nasqe.
Il. 7.2: *zeu)s de\ qew=n a)gorh\n poih/sato terpike/raunos.

div2.head: Passive Voice
div2.p: The Passive Voice denotes that the subject receives the action of the verb.

*polu/stratos . . . sunelh/fqh, ANDOC.1.13; Polystratos was arrested. o( th=s po/lews . . . ko/smos . . . suntara/ttetai, DEM.25.19: The constitution of the state is disturbed. e)te/quto ta\ i(era/, ANTIPHON, 1.17. a)pefe/reto e)k tou= desmwthri/ou teqnew/s, LYS.12.18.
le/getai, DEM.24.212; It is said. dida/sketai a)/nqrwpos, PLATO , Meno, 87 C, which is actively expressed by a)/nqrwpos manqa/nei, PLATO, Soph. 262C.
With the passive, the instrument, means, or cause is expressed by the dative or by a prepositional phrase, for which see Prepositions.
li/qw| peplhgme/nos, AR. Ach. 1218; Struck with a stone. xrh/masi peisqh=nai, THUC.2.21.1. limw=| diafqarh=nai, THUC.3.57.3; To perish of (by, with) hunger.
DEM.23.156: lhfqh/setai . . . tw=| . . . limw=|. 55.30: mega/lois li/qois a)poikodomhqe/ntos.
PLATO, Rpb. 469E: oi(=s a)\n (sc. li/qois) blhqw=si. Tim. 38 E: desmoi=s te e)myu/xois . . . deqe/nta.
XEN. An. 2.3.1: basileu\s e)cepla/gh th=| e)fo/dw|.
THUC.1.126.8: truxo/menoi th=| prosedrei/a|. 2.21.1 (see above). 3.57.3 (see above). 7.47.2: no/sw| . . . e)pie/zonto , They were pinched with sickness.
HDT.1.34: ai)xmh=| sidhre/h| blhqe/nta. 1.41: sumforh=| peplhgme/non.
AR. Ach. 1218 (see above). Nub. 24: ei)/q' e)ceko/phn pro/teron to\n o)fqalmo\n li/qw| . Vesp. 1296: e)gw\ d' a)po/lwla stizo/menos bakthri/a|.
AESCHYL. P.V. 237: phmonai=si ka/mptomai, I am bowed with thrills of anguish. Sept. 607: plhg(ei\s qeou= ma/stigi, Smitten with god's scourge.
PIND. P. 3.48: poliw= galkw= me/lh tetrwme/noi.
HOM. Od. 10.532: e)sfagme/na nhle/i xalkw=|.
Il. 8.455: plhge/nte keraunw=|.
The agent of the passive is put in the genitive with u(po/.
oi( . . . tu/rannoi . . . u(po\ *lakedaimoni/wn katelu/qhsan, THUC.1.18.1; Tyrants were abolished by the Lacedaemonians.
DEM.21.36: u(po\ *poluzh/lou plhgh=nai. 21.74: e)gw\ d' u(p) e)xqrou= . . . u(brizo/mhn. [47]DEM., 15: e)plh/ghs u(p' e)mou=. 54.33: u(f' ou(= ge prw/tou t' e)plh/ghn kai\ ma/lisq) u(bri/sqhn.
PLATO, Conv. 217E: e)/ti de\ to\ tou= dhxqe/ntos u(po\ tou= e)/xews pa/qos ka)me\ e)/xei.
XEN. An. 1.3.10: nomi/zei u(p' e)mou= h)dikh=sqai.
THUC.1.18.1(see above). 4.12.1: a)neko/ph u(po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn .
HDT.1.35: e)celhlame/nos . . . u(po\ tou= patro/s.
AR. Av. 285: u(po\ tw=n sukofantw=n ti/lletai .
SOPH. Ai. 164: u(po\ toiou/twn a)ndrw=n qorubh=| .
PIND. N. 2.20-2: a)lla\ *korinqi/wn u(po\ fwtw=n . . . o)ktw\ stefa/nois e)/mixqen h)/dh.
HOM. Od. 9.66: *kiko/nwn u(/po dh|wqe/ntes.
Il. 13.675-6: dhio/onto | laoi\ u(p' *)argei+/wn.
For the so-called Dative of the Agent with the Passive and with Verbals, see Dative.
Other prepositions than u(po/ are sometimes used with special verbs and in special authors.
e)k, out of, often in poetry and in Herodotus; in Attic prose with the notion of emanation from a source.
ANTIPHON, 2 d 1: tw=n e)c e)mou= praxqe/ntwn.
PLATO, Theaet. 171B: e)c a(pa/ntwn . . . a)mfisbhth/setai.
XEN. An. 1.1.6: po/leis . . . e)k basile/ws dedome/nai, Cities a gift of the king's.
THUC.1.20.2: e)k tw=n cuneido/twn sfi/sin *(ippi/a| memhnu=sqai, “That information had been conveyed to Hippias from the body of their fellow-conspirators.”—Shilleto.
HDT.3.62: ta\ e)ntetalme/na e)k tou= *ma/gou, The orders given of, by the Magus.
HOM. Il. 2.668-9: e)fi/lhqen | e)k *dio/s, They were loved of Zeus.
pro/s, before (comp. Engl. “from before”).
DEM.29.20: ei) . . . mh\ prowmolo/ghto pro\s tou=d' e)leu/qeros ei)=nai. Lutz Vid., Präp. b. d. att. Redn., p. 155.
XEN. An. 1.9.20: fi/lous ge mh\n . . . o(mologei=tai pro\s pa/ntwn kra/tistos dh\ gene/sqai qerapeu/ein, He is acknowledged on all hands, etc.
HDT.8.111: *)/andrioi . . . ai)thqe/ntes pro\s *qemistokle/os xrh/mata ou)k e)/dosan.
AR. Nub. 1122: pro\s h(mw=n oi(=a pei/setai kaka/ .
EUR. Med. 255-6: u(bri/zomai pro\s a)ndro/s , and similarly elsewhere.
SOPH. El. 790: pro\s th=sd' u(bri/zh| mhtro/s, and similarly elsewhere.
PIND. O. 2.25-6: pe/nqos de\ pitnei= baru\ | kresso/nwn pro\s a)gaqw=n.

HOM. Il. 6.56-7:
h)= soi\ a)/rista pepoi/htai kata\ oi)=kon
pro\s *trw/wn
. 11.831: ta/ se proti/ fasin *)axillh=os dedida/xqai .
para/, “on the part of,” chiefly with verbs of giving, taking, sending.
DEM.21.170: tou/tois ga\r dh\ me/gistai de/dontai dwreai\ par' u(mw=n.
XEN. An. 1.9.1: para\ pa/ntwn o(mologei=tai, It is acknowledged on all sides.
HOM. Il. 15.121-2: e)/nqa k' e)/ti mei/zwn te kai\ a)rgalew/teros a)/llos | pa\r *dio\s a)qana/toisi xo/los kai\ mh=nis e)tu/xqh.

dia/, through (of the mediator), a post-Homeric construction. Never to be confounded with dia/ w. acc. di) e)me\ e)sw/qhs, CTESIAS ap. DEM. [PHAL. ] 213; Thanks to me, it is owing to me that, you were saved. di) e)mou= e)sw/qhs, Through me you were saved. A. J. P. xi (1890), 372.
ISOC. Ep.4.2: e)boulo/mhn a)\n au)to\n sustaqh=nai/ soi di) h(mw=n, I should have preferred that he had been commended to you through us (me).
AR. Eq. 76: dia\ sou= tau=ta pa/nta pe/rnatai, Through you all these things are sold.
a)po/, Latin ab, found chiefly in Thucydides.
THUC.1.17: e)pra/xqh te a)p' au)tw=n ou)de\n e)/rgon a)cio/logon, No considerable deed was performed by them. (Some uniformitarians would write u(po/).
u(po/ with the dative revives the plastic “under”-sense, and is poetical.
HOM. Il. 13.668: u(po\ *trw/essi damh=nai, To be quelled beneath the might of the Trojans.

When the instrument is considered as an agent or the agent as an instrument the construction is reversed. The former construction, which rests on personification, is very common; the latter in prose is confined chiefly to military phrases, for which see Dative.

a(li/sketai u(po\ trih/rous, DEM. [53]DEM., 6; He is captured by a trireme.
h)na/gkasmai u(po\ tw=n gegenhme/nwn tou/tou kathgorei=n, LYS. 12.3 ; I have been compelled by what has happened to undertake to prosecute this man.

DEM.6.8, 8.71: ou)de\ proh/xqhn ou)/q' u(po\ ke/rdous ou)/q) u(po\ filotimi/as. 20.166: u(po\ th=s . . . kraugh=s kai\ bi/as kai\ a)naisxunti/as. 23.143: e)cedi/dont' a)\n u(po\ tou= u(mete/rou yhfi/smatos. [43]DEM., 72: ti/ pot' oi)/esq) h(ma=s pa/sxein e)n tw=| parelhluqo/ti xro/nw| u(po\ tou/twn kai\ u(po\ th=s u(/brews th=s tou/twn. [53]DEM., 6(see above). 55.30: diefqarme/non (masc.) u(po\ no/sou.
AESCHIN.1.42 AESCHIN., 1.90 AESCHIN., 3.218: ou)k a)nagkazo/menos u(po\ th=s e)n th=| fu/sei dapa/nhs.
LYS.1.49: u(po\ tw=n no/mwn . . . e)nedreu/esqai .
PLATO, Rpb. 609E: u(po\ th=s tw=n siti/wn ponhri/as . . . ou)k oi)o/meqa dei=n sw=ma a)po/llusqai.
XEN. Conv. 2.26: ou) biazo/menoi u(po\ tou= oi)/nou mequ/ein. Oec. 16.14: ou)damw=s a)\n ma=llon h( me\n u(/lh . . . au)ai/noito u(po\ tou= kau/matos, h( de\ gh= o)ptw=|to u(po\ tou= h(li/ou.
THUC.1.76.2: u(po\ tw=n megi/stwn nikhqe/ntes, timh=s kai\ de/ous kai\ w)feli/as. 1.126.10: u(po\ tou= limou= , but 3.57.3: limw=| . 7.69.2: o( de\ *niki/as u(po\ tw=n paro/ntwn e)kpeplhgme/nos .
HDT.8.129: diefqa/rhsan u(po\ th=s qala/sshs.
AR. Ach. 18: e)dh/xqhn u(po\ koni/as ta\s o)fru=s, My eyebrows were bitten by lye.
SOPH. Tr. 1104: tuflh=s u(p' a)/ths e)kpepo/rqhmai.
PIND. O. 2.21: e)slw=n ga\r u(po\ xarma/twn ph=ma qna/|skei (171).
HOM. Od. 5.393: mega/lou u(po\ ku/matos a)rqei/s.See also A. J. P. vi (1885), 487-8.
The passive is sometimes used in a permissive sense.
ti/ poiou=sin; . . . ou) katalipo/ntes th\n xw/ran . . . w)/|xonto, . . . a)ll' e)poliorkou=nto, LYCURG.85; What did they do? . . . They suffered themselves to be besieged.
LYCURG.40: gunai=kas . . . a)naci/ws au(tw=n kai\ th=s po/lews o(rwme/nas. Ibid. 85 (see above).
R. L. 1.5: e)/qhke ga/r, ai)dei=sqai me\n ei)sio/nta o)fqh=nai, ai)dei=sqai d' e)cio/nta.

AR, Ach. 408-9: a)ll' e)kkuklh/qht'. *e*u*r. a)ll) a)du/naton. *d*i*k. a)ll) o(/mws. | *e*u*r. a)ll' e)kkuklh/somai: katabai/nein d' ou) sxolh/. Nub. 494: fe/r' i)/dw, ti/ dra=|s, h)/n ti/s se tu/pth|; tu/ptomai .

p.hi: Future middle in a passive sense.

div2.p: The future middle and the future passive are coincident as to form in the earlier language,In fact, there is only one distinctly future passive form in Homer, migh/sesqai, Il. 10.365. and even in prose the future middle is often used as a future passive.

As the subsequent future passive forms were developed on the basis of the passive aorists in -hn and -qhn, they naturally incline to the aoristic sense, and this aoristic sense becomes more distinct when the future middle is used as a passive. Hence the contrasted groups.
DURATIVE. AORISTIC.
bla/ptw, I hurt.
bla/yomai
blabh/somai
tima/w, I honor.
timh/somai
timhqh/somai
w)fele/w, I help.
w)felh/somai
w)felhqh/somai
dhlo/w, I manifest.
dhlw/setai
dhlwqh/setai

It is to be noted, however, that consistency in this distinction requires considerable alteration of texts, and that even in the most careful authors such distinctions may lie dormant, just as synonyms lie dormant. Of course, in poetry metre must be allowed to have a certain sway.Cf. SOPH. O. C. 581-2:
poiw| (sc. xro/nw|) ga\r h( sh\ prosfora\ dhlw/setai
o)/tan qa/nw )gw/
, where dhlw/setai is clearly aoristic, with THUC.1.144.2: e)kei=na . . . kai\ e)n a)/llw| lo/gw| a(/ma toi=s e)/rgois dhlwqh/setai, where dhlw/setai might be justified by the plural e)/rgois.
o( di/kaios mastigw/setai, streblw/setai, dedh/setai, e)kkauqh/setai tw)fqalmw/, teleutw=n pa/nta kaka\ paqw\n a)nasxinduleuqh/setai, PLATO, Rpb. 361E362 A.

DEM.18.144: mega/l' w)felh/sesqe pro\s i(stori/an tw=n koinw=n. 21. 30: toi=s a)dikhsome/nois (masc.). 23.110: polemh/setai. 115: a)dikh/setai. [52]DEM., 11: zhmiw/somai. 57.37: kai\ tau=ta marturh/setai.
ANDOC.1.72: toiau/thn a)pologi/an peri\ au)tou= poih/somai, o(/pou mh\ pei/qwn me\n u(ma=s au)to\s zhmiw/somai, pei/sas de\ kte(.
PLATO, Gorg. 521E: krinou=mai ga\r w(s e)n paidi/ois i)atro\s a)\n kri/noito kathgorou=ntos o)yopoiou=. Rpb. 361 E-362 A (see above). Tim. 57 E: to\ . . . kinhso/menon . . . tou= kinhsome/nou.
XEN. Conv. 7.5: eu)franei=sqe. Cyr. 1.5.9: w(s . . . eu)franou/menoi. Ibid. 8.7.15: ti/s d' a)/llos timh/setai di) a)/ndra me/ga duna/menon ou(/tws w(s a)delfo/s; Hiero, 9.9: timh/setai.
THUC.1.68.3: polemh/sontai. 1.81.4: blayo/meqa . 2.87.9: timh/sontai . 3.40.3: zhmiw/setai . 8: zhmiwso/menon (masc.). 7.48.5: fqerei=sqai . 7.67.3: w)felh/sontai .
HDT.3.132: tou\s *ai)gupti/ous i)htrou\s . . . me/llontas a)naskolopiei=sqai . . . e)rru/sato.
AR. Ach. 409: a)ll' e)kkuklh/somai (see 167).
EUR. Andr. 708: ei) mh\ fqerh=| th=sd' w(s ta/xist' a)po\ ste/ghs.

SOPH. Ai. 1154-5:
w)/nqrwpe, mh\ dra= tou\s teqnhko/tas kakw=s:
ei) ga\r poih/seis, i)/sqi phmanou/menos
. O. R. 272: fqerei=sqai .
PIND. P. 4.10-1: fami\ ga\r . . . *)epa/foio ko/ran | a)ste/wn r(i/zan futeu/sesqai.
HOM. Od. 1.123: par' a)/mmi filh/seai.
Il. 12.66: o(/qi trw/sesqai o)i+/w. 14.481: w(=de kataktene/esqe kai\ u)/mmes. 24.728-9: pri\n ga\r po/lis h(/de kat' a)/krhs | pe/rsetai.See further Blass, Rh. Mus. 47 (1892), 269-90.

And on the other hand the passive aorist is often used to the exclusion of the aorist middle; h)ra/sqhn, I fell in love (was enamored), e)dunh/qhn, I could (was enabled), e)boulh/qhn, I would (was decided), e)poreu/qhn, I proceeded (was forwarded).The form, though not distinctively passive at first, became distinctively passive, and hence a passive conception is often possible.
The following is a list of the most important of these verbs:

ai)dei=sqai, a(milla=sqai, a)rnei=sqai, a)/xqesqai, bou/lesqai, dei=sqai, diale/gesqai, dianoei=sqai, du/nasqai, e)nantiou=sqai, e)nqumei=sqai, e)nnoei=sqai, e)pimelei=sqai, e)ra=n, eu)labei=sqai, h(/desqai, oi)/esqai, poreu/esqai, proqumei=sqai, filotimei=sqai.
DEM.28.14: ou(=tos de\ kai\ metapemfqh=nai fa/skwn u(po\ tou= patro/s (cf. ibid.: ei)selqei=n me\n ou)/ fhsin w(s to\n metapemya/menon).
LYS.13.23: e)peidh\ . . . tou=to to\ yh/fisma e)yhfi/sqh, kate/rxontai . . . oi( a i(reqe/ntes tw=n bouleutw=n . Ibid. 29: e)yhfi/sqh .
PLATO, Legg. 755E: pri\n . . . boulh\n h(|rh=sqai. 770 A: h(/|rhntai de\ h(mi=n nomofu/lakes.
XEN. Conv. 2.26: ou) biazo/menoi (166). Mem. 3.2.3: basileu\s ai(rei=tai ou)x i(/na e(autou= kalw=s e)pime/lhtai, a)ll' i(/na kte(. (cf. ibid.: strathgou\s ai(rou=ntai).
THUC.7.77.3: a)poxrw/ntws h)/dh tetimwrh/meqa.
HDT.1.70: ta/xa de\ a)\n kai\ oi( a)podo/menoi le/goien . . . w(s a)paireqei/hsan u(po\ *sami/wn [cf. ibid.: le/gousi w(s . . . *sa/mioi a)peloi/ato au)to/n (sc. to\n krhth=ra)].
AR. Nub. 758: ei)/ soi gra/foito . . . di/kh (cf. 1481-2: ei)/t' au)tou\s grafh\n diwka/qw graya/menos ).
SOPH. Ant. 1073: e)k sou= bia/zontai ta/de .

Intransitive verbs of passive signification are construed as passives. So a)poqnh/|skw is regularly used as the passive of a)poktei/nw, eu)= pa/sxw of eu)= poiw=, a)kou/w of le/gw, pi/ptw of ba/llw, feu/gw of diw/kw.

u(po\ de\ tou= i)atrou= fa/skwn au)to\n a)poqanei=n, ANTIPHON, 4 g 5; Alleging him to have been killed by his physician. e)kpi/ptousin oi( *lakwnistai/, XEN. Hell. 1.1.32; The Laconizers are cast out. oi( *)aqhnai=oi . . . pra/gmata ei)=xon u(po\ . . . tw=n lh|stw=n, XEN. Hell. 5.1.5; The Athenians were harassed by the pirates. eu)= pa/sxousa (sc. gh=) eu)= poiei=, XEN. Oec. 20.14; Land, when well treated, treats you well.
DEM. [49], 1: feu/gei nu=n u(p' e)mou= tau/thn th\n di)khn .
ANTIPHON, 4 g 5: a)poqanei=n (see above). 5.48: ou)d' ou(=toi a)poqnh/|skousin u(p) au)tw=n tw=n proshko/ntwn.
PLATO, Apol. 35D: a)sebei/as feu/gonta u(po\ *melh/tou toutoui+/. Hipp. Mai. 304 E: sumbe/bhke dh/ moi . . . kakw=s me\n u(f' u(mw=n a)kou/ein kai\ o)neidi/zesqai, kakw=s de\ u(p) e)kei/nou.
XEN. Hell. 1.1.32: e)kpi/ptousin (see above). Ibid. 5.1.5: pra/gmata ei)=xon (see above). Oec. 20.14: eu)= pa/sxousa (see above).

THUC.1.20.2: *(/ipparxon oi)/ontai u(f' *(armodi/ou kai\ *)aristogei/tonos tu/rannon o)/nta a)poqanei=n (cf. ibid.: *(ippa/rxw| perituxo/ntes . . . a)pe/kteinan). 3.58.4: a)poqano/ntas u(po\ *mh/dwn .
HDT.4.125: o(re/ontes kai\ tou\s o(mou/rous feu/gontas u(po\ *skuqe/wn kai\ tetaragme/nous. 8.16: o( ga\r *ce/rcew strato\s . . . au)to\s u(p' e(wutou= e)/pipte.
AR. Ach. 167-8: tauti\ periei/deq' . . . pa/sxonta/ me | . . . kai\ tau=q' u(p) a)ndrw=n barba/rwn;
PIND. O. 2.21: e)slw=n ga\r u(po\ xarma/twn ph=ma qna/|skei.

HOM. Il. 1.242-3: eu)=t' a)\n polloi\ u(f) *(/ektoros . . . | qnh/|skontes pi/ptwsi. 3.61: o(/s t' ei)=sin dia\ douro\s u(p) a)ne/ros. 3.128: e)/pasxon. 6.74: a)ne/bhsan . 13.796: ei)=si. 16.519: baru/qei. 17.428: peso/ntos. 616: w)/lese qumo/n. 21.22-3: w(s d' u(po\ delfi=nos . . . i)xqu/es a)/lloi | feu/gontes pimpla=si muxou\s kte(.

Note that the element of the disagreeable enters into most of these verbs, so that the intransitive construction is an evasion of responsibility. eu)= pa/sxw and eu)= a)kou/w merely serve to match kakw=s pa/sxw and kakw=s a)kou/w. Cf. A. J. P. vii (1886), 42, Note 2.
Passives of intransitive verbs are rare. o)/nos u(/etai, PROVERB; A donkey in the rain.
ISOC.11.22: diakekinduneume/nois farma/kois (risky medicines) xrwme/nhn.
ANT. 5.75: o(/mws d' ou)=n kekinduneu/setai, periclitatum erit.
THUC.3.23.5: h( nu\c . . . u(ponifome/nh polu\ to\ u(/dwr e)n au)th=| e)pepoih/kei, The snowiness of the night had caused a rise in the water.

HDT.2.22: ei) e)xio/nize, u(/eto a)\n tau=ta ta\ xwri/a, If there were any snowfall, these parts would have rain on them. 3.10: u(/sqhsan ga\r *qh=bai ai( *ai)gu/ptiai . . . ou) ga\r dh\ u(/etai ta\ a)/nw th=s *ai)gu/ptou to\ para/pan.
PIND. O. 10.76: a)ei/deto de\ pa=n te/menos, The whole grove was full of song.
HOM. Od. 6.131: o(/s t' (sc. le/wn) ei)=s' u(o/menos.

p.hi: Passive of verbs that take a genitive or dative.

div2.p: An active verb may be turned into the passive, even if it takes a genitive or a dative. But there are limits.

ou)ke/ti de\ a)peilou=mai, a)ll' h)/dh a)peilw= a)/llois, XEN. Conv. 4.31; I am no longer threatened, but am now threatening others. e)rw=n th=s gunaiko\s a)ntera=tai, Ibid. 8.3; Loving his wife, he is loved back again.
ANTIPHON, 4 b 7: ou) dikai/ws kathgorou=mai (but 2 b 10: a(\ kathgo/rhtai/ mou).

PLATO, Euthyd. 273C: ei)pw\n ou)=n tau=ta katefronh/qhn u(p' au)toi=n. Lach. 181 B: e)painei= u(p' a)ndrw=n a)ci/wn pisteu/esqai. Rpb. 556 C-D: o(/tan . . . mhdamh=| tau/th| katafronw=ntai oi( pe/nhtes u(po\ tw=n plousi/wn.
XEN. Conv. 4.31 (see above). Ibid. 8.3 (see above). Hiero, 11.11: ou) mo/non filoi=o a)/n, a)lla\ kai\ e)rw=|o u(p' a)nqrw/pwn. Ibid. 11.15: eu)daimonw=n ga\r ou) fqonhqh/sei.
EUR. I. A. 1093-4: a( d' a)reta\ kato/pisqen qnatoi=s a)melei=tai.
SOPH. O. R. 111: e)kfeu/gei de\ ta)melou/menon.

The verb must take the dative without an intervening outer object. So in dido/nai plou=ton toi=s *(/ellhsin, AR. Pax, 1321, toi=s *(/ellhsin cannot be turned into the subject of the passive. Rare is such a construction as a)nasth/santes de\ au)tou\s oi( . . . e)pitetramme/noi th\n fulakh/n, THUC.1.126.11, where we should expect oi(=s e)pete/trapto h( fulakh/. th\n fulakh/n is a manner of inner object.

p.hi: Impersonal passive of verbs governing an oblique case.

div2.p: The impersonal construction which is the rule in Latin is rare in Greek.
ANTIPHON, 1.31: e)moi\ me\n ou)=n dedih/ghtai kai\ beboh/qhtai tw=| <te> teqnew=ti kai\ tw=| no/mw|. Ibid. 2 b 13: e)f' oi(=s kathgorei=tai/ mou (v. l. kathgorei=te).
XEN. Vect. 1.1: nomi/zwn, ei) tou=to ge/noito, . . . th=| . . . peni/a| au)tw=n e)pikekourh=sqai a)/n.
THUC.5.49.2: a)nte/legon mh\ dikai/ws sfw=n katadedika/sqai, They maintained that they had not been justly condemned, but kataded. is probably middle: they had not justly condemned them. See Classen.
The deponent is a middle form which has no active. gi/gnomai, I become, get, qea/omai, I behold.
On the passive aorists of these verbs, see 169.

p.hi: Passive of deponents expressed by periphrasis.

div2.p: The passive of deponents is often expressed by periphrasis. So especially outside of the passive form (1 aor. pass.). Familiar is ai)ti/an e)/xein as passive of ai)tia=sqai.
nau=s ai)ti/an e)/xontes prodou=nai, HYP. pro HYP. Eux.1; Being accused of having betrayed ships.
HYP. pro Eux. 1 (see above). Ibid. 31: tw=n ga\r kathgorhqe/ntwn to\ mh\ labo\n a)pologi/an u(po\ th=| o)rgh=| tw=n dikastw=n katalei/petai.
DEM.18.200: prodedwke/nai pa/ntas a)\n e)/sxen (sc. h( po/lis) ai)ti/an.
LYS.11.10: ei) . . . ai)ti/an e)/xoi .
PLATO, Rpb. 565B: ai)ti/an dh\ e)/sxon u(po\ tw=n e(te/rwn . . . w(s e)pibouleu/ousi tw=| dh/mw|.
THUC.2.41.3: mo/nh ga\r tw=n nu=n a)koh=s krei/sswn e)s pei=ran e)/rxetai. 7.81.5: feidw/ . . . tis e)gigneto .
THEOGN. 1265-6: e)gw\ de\ . . . ai)dou=s ou)demih=s e)/tuxon.
HOM. Od. 2.136-7: ne/mesis de/ moi e)c a)nqrw/pwn | e)/ssetai.
Il. 7.409-10: feidw\ . . . gi/gnet(ai). 22.243-4: mhde/ ti dou/rwn e)/stw feidwlh/.

div2.head: Reciprocal expressions.
div2.p: Reciprocal relations are expressed by forms of a)llh/lwn, for which the reflexive is not infrequently substituted.

pro\s me\n ga\r e)kei/nous met' a)llh/lwn e)maxe/santo, peri\ de\ tau/ths pro\s sfa=s au)tou\s e)pole/mhsan, ISOC.10.53; They fought against them in alliance with one another, but made war for her against (themselves) one another.
a)llh/lwn:
ISOC.10.53(see above).
LYS.3.40: ei) a)/ra peri\ pai/dwn e)filonikh/samen h(mei=s pro\s a)llh)lous .
PLATO, Phaedr. 237C: ou)/te ga\r e(autoi=s ou)/te a)llhlois o(mologou=sin. Protag. 322 B: h)di/koun a)llh/lous.

The Greek language has four moods proper. A mood is a tone given to the predication by the speaker or writer. These moods are the indicative, the imperative, the subjunctive, and the optative. The verb has also a nominal form, the infinitive, which is often called a mood, and an adjective form, which is called a participle.

Of these moods the indicative alone expresses with uniform directness the relations of time, or tense, and as some of the modal uses cannot be understood without the use of the tenses, it is necessary to consider first the tenses.

div2.head: Tense in general
div2.p: The tenses express the relations of time, embracing:
1. The stage of the action, duration in time, kind of time.
2. The period of the action, position in time, sphere of time.
The first tells, for example, whether the action is going on or finished.
The second tells whether the action is past, present, or future.

Peculiar to the Greek language, as compared with Latin and English, is the specific form for the relation of attainment called the aorist, the tense of concentrated action, the absolute tense. The kind of time and the sphere of time are both expressed by the tenses of the indicative mood or declarative form of the verb. But present and future have no special aoristic form in the active and middle, though in the passive it is possible to make a distinction.

The absence of special forms for designating the kind of time in the future helps to account for many modal combinations. The subjunctive and optative often serve to express exact temporal relations in the future.

The tenses are further divided into principal and historical, or primary and secondary, according as they refer to the present and the future on the one hand (time not past) and to the past on the other.

div2.head: Present Tense
div2.p: The present is used, as in English, of that which is going on now (specific present), and of statements that apply to all time (universal present).
to\n a)/ndra o(rw=, XEN. An. 1.8.26 ; I see my man.

EPICHARM. fr. 117 Ahr.: no/os o(rh=| kai\ no/os a)kou/ei, (It is) mind (that) sees and mind (that) hears.

The Greek has no special form for the progressive present of English, nor for the progressive tenses generally. In the periphrasis with the present participle, the participle is generally equivalent to a characteristic adjective or substantive, with which it is often coupled. Notice must also be taken of the position of the copula, which readily resumes its emphasis.See W. Alexander J. in A. J. P. iv (1883), 291-308, and B. L. G. in J. H. U. Circ. 1882-3, p. 67.
