As continuance involves the notion of incompleteness, the present is used of attempted and intended action (present of endeavor, conative present). But on account of the double use of the present as a tense of continuance and as a tense of attainment, this signification is less prominent and less important than in the imperfect. Notice that this conative sense runs through the moods.

p.hi: Present anticipating the future. — praesens propheticum.

div2.p: The present tense is used more rarely than in English in anticipation of the future, chiefly in verbs in which the will is equivalent to the deed: ei)=mi, I go, ou)k e)w=, I suffer not, gi/gnomai, I am becoming. The present as a vision of the future is called praesens propheticum.

In standard prose ei)=mi in the indicative is future everywhere. In the optative, infinitive, and participle it is now future, now present. The subjunctive is future by virtue of its meaning.

In passionate questions, the present is used as a form of exhortation.

The present tense is used far more frequently than in English as a lively representation of the past (historical present). Especially strange to us is the free use of the historical present in relative and dependent clauses generally, as these demand more reflection.On the conception of the ancients, see Ps.- Long.peri\ u(/yous, Gr. I, p. 275 ( Sp.). Some statistics are given A. J. P. xiv, 106, and xvi, 259.

quote.l: o(/pws ta/xista to\n patrw=|on e)s qro/non

div2.p: This use of the present belongs to the original stock of our family of languages. It antedates the differentiation into imperf. and aorist. Being a familiar form, it is set down as a mark of simplicity (a)fe/leia) of style. By reason, therefore, both of its liveliness and its familiar tone it is foreign to the leisurely and dignified unfolding of the epos, and is not found in Homer, whereas it is very common in the rhetorical Vergil, as it is very common in the Attic orators. Nor is it used to any extent, if at all, in the statuesque Pindaric ode, whereas it is frequent in the Attic drama, which seems to have introduced it to higher literature.

Akin to the Historical Present, and not always to be distinguished from it, is the Annalistic Present, Note - book Present, or Present of Registration, which transfers a record or register to the historical page. So especially in dates of births, deaths, and accessions.

*darei/ou kai\ *parusa/tidos gi/gnontai pai=des du/o, XEN. An. 1.1.1; To (of) Darius and Parysatis are born two sons. *kuaca/rhs me\n . . . teleuta=|, e)kde/ketai de\ *)astua/ghs . . . th\n basilhi/hn, HDT.1.106; Cyaxares dies and Astyages succeeds to the throne. tou/tou de\ *keleo\s gi/gnetai, AR. Ach. 48.
The present is used in Greek of actions that are continued from the past into the present, especially with designations of time. The English translation is often the progressive perfect.

 plei=n katale/luka, me/tria d' e)/xwn tou/tois peirw=mai nautikoi=s e)rga/zesqai. [47]DEM., 53(see above).
LYS.17.9: ou)/te newsti\ tau=ta ta\ xrh/mata a)ciou=men h(me/tera ei)=nai .
PLATO, Conv. 172C: a)f' ou(= d' e)gw\ *swkra/tei sundiatri/bw . . . ou)de/pw tri/a e)/th e)sti/n. Phaedo 84 D: pa/lai . . . prowqei= kai\ keleu/ei.

HDT.3.49: nu=n de\ ai)ei\ e)pei/te e)/ktisan th\n nh=son, ei)si\ a)llh/loisi dia/foroi. 7.102: th=| *(ella/di peni/h . . . ai)ei/ kote su/ntrofo/s e)sti. 8.62: komieu/meqa e)s *si=rin th\n e)n *)itali/h|, h(/ per h(mete/rh te/ e)sti e)k palaiou= e)/ti kai\ kte(.
AR. Ach. 17: e)c o(/tou )gw\ r(u/ptomai (146). Vesp. 317: th/komai me\n pa/lai. Ibid. 320: bou/lomai/ ge pa/lai.
EUR. H. F. 702-3: xro/nos ga\r h)/dh daro\s e)c o(/tou pe/plois | kosmei=sqe sw=ma.
HOM. Od. 13.377: oi(\ dh/ toi tri/etes me/garon ka/ta koirane/ousin.
Il. 1.553: kai\ li/hn se pa/ros g' ou)/t' ei)/romai ou)/te metallw=.

p.emph: So in the other moods of continuance:

div2.p: LYS.17.8: i)/sasin h(ma=s h)/dh tri/a e)/th a)mfisbhtou=ntas .
HDT.8.41: au(/th d' h( melito/essa e)n tw=| pro/sqe ai)ei\ xro/nw| a)naisimoume/nh to/te h)=n a)/yaustos.
AR. Vesp. 1074: r(a|di/ws e)gw\ dida/cw, ka)\n a)/mousos h)=| to\ pri/n, Readily will I teach him e en if he have been untrained before.
This does not exclude the use of the perfect.
ta\ . . . *sfhttoi= h)/dh tri/a e)/th memi/sqwka, LYS. 17.5 ; I have let the Sphettian property now three years.
LYS.9.4: a)fiko/menos prope/rusin ei)s th\n po/lin, ou)/pw du/o mh=nas e)pidedhmhkw\s katele/ghn stratiw/ths .

nu=n d' e(te/rou pole/mou kairo\s h(/kei tis, DEM.3.6, nikw=men . . . basile/a, XEN. An. 2.1.4; We are victorious over (have conquered) the king. e)kei=no a)kh/koas; . . . kai\ tou=to/ g), e)/fh, a)kou/w, Mem. 3.5.26. stero/meqa e)pisth/mhs, PLATO, Theaet. 196E; We are deprived of, have to go without, science.

DEM.3.6(see above). 4.24: pro/tero/n pot' a)kou/w ceniko
 tre/fein e)n *kori/nqw| th
 po/lin, but 19.221: kai\ ga tau=t' a)kh/ko) au)to
 le/gein.
ANTIPHON. Cf. 3 d 9: ei) de\ au)qe/nths e)k tw=n legome/nwn e)pidei/knutai, ou)x h(mei=s au)tw=| oi( le/gontes ai)/tioi/ e)smen, a)ll' h( pra=cis tw=n e)/rgwn.

PLATO, Gorg. 503C: *qemistokle/a ou)k a)kou/eis a)/ndra a)gaqo
 gegono/ta; Theaet. 142 B: xalepw=s me
 ga e)/xei kai\ u(po\ trauma/twn tinw=n, ma=llon mh
 au)to
 ai(rei= to\ gegono\s no/shma e)n tw_| strateu/mati. Ibid. 196 E (see above).
XEN. An. 2.1.4 (see above). Mem. 3.5.26 (see above).

THUC.1.70.7: a(\ me\n a)\n e)pinoh/santes mh\ e)ce/lqwsin, oi)kei=a ste/resqai h(gou=ntai, “In failing to attain an object, they consider that they have lost” (are suffering the loss of) “what was really their own.”—Morris.
HDT.7.53: w(s ga\r e)gw\ punqa/nomai, e)p' a)/ndras strateuo/meqa a)gaqou/s.
EUR. Hel. 134: oi)/xetai qanou=sa dh/.
SOPH. El. 1326: w)= plei=sta mw=roi kai\ frenw=n thtw/menoi. Ph. 414: a)ll' h)= xou)=tos oi)/xetai qanw/n;
PIND. P. 6.22-3: o)rfanizome/nw| | *phlei+/da|.

HOM. Od. 1.298: h)\ ou)k a)i/eis, oi(=on kle/os e)/llabe di=os *)ore/sths; 2.118: oi(=) ou)/ pw/ tin' a)kou/omen. 3.86-8: a)/llous me\n ga\r pa/ntas, o(/soi *trwsi\n pole/mizon, | peuqo/meq), h(=xi e(/kastos a)pw/leto lugrw=| o)le/qrw|: | kei/nou d' au)= kai\ o)/leqron a)peuqe/a qh=ke *kroni/wn.

div2.head: Imperfect TenseSee B. L. G., A. J. P. iv (1883), 158-65; C. W. E. Miller, A. J. P. xvi (1895), 139-185.
div2.p: The imperfect tense denotes continuance in the past. It is the tense of evolution, of vision.
to\ paidi/on e)bo/a, LYS.1.11 ; The baby was squalling, began to squall, squalled.

The continuance is in the mind of the narrator; it has nothing to do with the absolute duration of the action. The aorist is the rule with the expression of definite numbers (see 208), and it is not at all inconsistent with the nature of the imperfect tense that it should be accompanied by an adverb expressing the notion of rapidity.
eu)qu\s e)xw/rei e)pi\ th\n *)arkadi/an, XEN. Hell. 6.5.12; Forthwith he proceeded on his way to Arcadia.

LYS.1.17: eu)qe/ws e)taratto/mhn . 8.15: eu)qu\s . . . e)ba/dize . 9.4: u(petopou/mhn eu)qe/ws . 13.35: eu)qe/ws kri/sin toi=s a)ndra/si tou/tois e)poi/oun e)n th=| boulh=| . 21.3: eu)qu\s e)gumnasia/rxoun .
XEN. An. 3.4.27: oi( de\ pole/mioi taxu\ a)peph/dwn. Hell. 6.5.12 (see above).

THUC.3.49.2: trih/rh eu)qu\s a)/llhn a)pe/stellon, They despatched (were for despatching) another trireme at once.
3.106.1: e)boh/qoun kata\ ta/xos . 3.109.3: dia\ ta/xous e)/qapton . 3.111.1: qa=sson a)pexw/roun . 5.21.1: eu)qu\s . . . a)fi/esan . 5.21.3: kata\ ta/xos e)poreu/eto . 6.69.1: e)ph=ge to\ strato/pedon eu)qu/s . . . a)nalabo/ntes ta\ o(/pla eu)qu\s a)nteph=|san . 7.29.1: eu)qu\s a)pe/pempon . 7.69.1: a)nteplh/roun ta\s nau=s eu)qu/s . 7.84.3: eu)qu\s diefqei/ronto . 8.12.3: dia\ ta/xous to\n plou=n e)poiou=nto .
HDT.1.79: e)poi/ee kata\ ta/xos.
AR. Nub. 1357: o( d' eu)qe/ws . . . e)/faske . Vesp. 355: i(/eis sauto\n kata\ tou= tei/xous taxe/ws.
PIND. P. 9.38-9: mh=tin e(a\n | eu)qu\s a)mei/beto.
HOM. Od. 9.179: oi( d' ai)=y) ei)/sbainon kai\ e)pi\ klhi=si kaqi=zon.
Il. 2.52: toi\ d' h)gei/ronto ma/l) w)=ka.
The imperfect is employed to represent manners, customs, situations, to describe and to particularize.

h(=s (sc. th=s boulh=s) e)pistatou/shs ou) dikw=n ou)d' e)gklhma/twn ou)d' ei)sforw=n ou)de\ peni/as ou)de\ pole/mwn h( po/lis e)/gemen, a)lla\ kai\ pro\s a)llh/lous h(suxi/an ei)=xon kai\ pro\s tou\s a)/llous a(/pantas ei)rh/nhn h)=gon. parei=xon . . . dih=gon . . . e)poi/oun . . . e)doki/mazon, ISOC.7.51-3, a description of the good old times. h( de\ gunh\ tou= basile/os au)th\ ta\ siti/a sfi e)/pesse, HDT.8.137; The queen herself would cook them their food. tw=n de\ polemi/wn, e)pei\ fw=s e)ge/neto, oi( me\n e)qau/mazon ta\ drw/mena, oi( d' e)gi/gnwskon h)/dh, oi( d' h)/ggellon, oi( d' e)bo/wn, oi( d' e)/luon i(/ppous, and so on to the number of 16 imperfects, XEN. Cyr. 4.2.28. prohgo/rei de\ au)tw=n *qhrame/nhs, Hell. 2.2.22; Theramenes was their spokesman.
ISOC.7.51-3 (see above).
LYS. 12.8-9: e)gw\ de\ *pei/swna me\n h)rw/twn ei) bou/loito/ me sw=sai xrh/mata labw/n: o( d' e)/fasken, ei) polla\ ei)/h .
PLATO, Theaet. 143A: kai\ o(sa/kis *)aqh/naze a)fikoi/mhn, e)panhrw/twn to\n *swkra/th o(\ mh\ e)memnh/mhn, kai\ deu=ro e)lqw\n e)phnwrqou/mhn.

XEN. Cyr. 4.2.28 (see above). Hell. 2.2.22 (see above). Ibid. 2.4.33: h)ko/ntizon, e)/ballon, e)to/ceuon, e)sfendo/nwn. Ibid. 4.3.19: e)wqou=nto, e)ma/xonto, a)pe/kteino/n, a)pe/qnh|skon. Ibid. 6.4.36: ei)/xeto tou= r(o/ptrou, e(/ws a)pe/qanen o( a)nh/r. Ibid. 7.2.6-8. (In the spirited account of the fight the imperfect outnumbers the aorist 5 to 1.)
THUC.3.81.3: w(s e(w/rwn ta\ gigno/mena, die/fqeiron au)tou= e)n tw=| i(erw=| a)llh/lous kai\ e)k tw=n de/ndrwn tine\s a)ph/gxonto, oi( d' w(s e(/kastoi: e)du/nanto a)nhlou=nto.
HDT.7.173: e)strath/gee de\ *lakedaimoni/wn . . . *eu)ai/netos. 8.137 (see above).

AR. Ach. 185: e)gw\ d' e)/feugon: oi( d' e)di/wkon ka)bo/wn. Eq. 46-8: ou(=tos katagnou)s tou= ge/rontos tou\s tro/pous, | . . . | h)/|kall), e)qw/peu), e)kola/keu), e)chpa/ta. Av. 1282: e)ko/mwn, e)pei/nwn, e)rru/pwn, e)swkra/twn .
EUR. Hipp. 1194-8: e)ph=ge . . . ei(po/mesqa . . . ei)seba/llomen.
SOPH. Ai. 298-300: hu)xe/nize . . . e)/sfaze ka\rra/xize . . . h)|ki/zeq' .
AESCHYL. Pers. 416-26: e)/qrauon . . . e)/qeinon . . . u(ptiou=to . . . e)plh/quon . . . h)re/sseto . . . e)/paion, e)rra/xizon.
PIND. P. 4.240-1: w)/regon xei=ras . . . e)/repton . . . a)gapa/zont(o).
HOM. Od. 1.110-2: oi( me\n a)/r' oi)=non e)/misgon . . . oi( d(e\) . . . trape/zas ni/zon kai\ pro/tiqen, toi\ de\ kre/a polla\ dateu=nto.
Il. 1.249: tou= kai\ a)po\ glw/sshs me/litos gluki/wn r(e/en au)dh/.
With definite numbers, the aorist is employed (see 243), but when there is a notion of interruption or of continuance into another stage (overlapping), the imperfect is used.

tau=ta d' e)poi/ei te/ttaras h(me/ras, XEN. Hell. 2.1.24; He kept this up four days (but on the fifth, e)pei\ h)=n h(me/ra pe/mpth, § 27). kataba\s de\ ka/tw e)s to\ kata/gaion oi)/khma diaita=to e)p' e)/tea tri/a: . . . teta/rtw| de\ e)/tei+ e)fa/nh toi=si *qrh/ici, HDT.4.95; He went down into the underground room and lived there for three years, but in the fourth he appeared to the Thracians.
DEM.19.78: te/ttaras mh=nas o(/lous e)sw/|zonq' oi( *fwkei=s tou\s u(/steron, h( de\ tou/tou yeudologi/a meta\ tau=q) u(/steron au)tou\s a)pw/lesen.
XEN. Hell. 2.1.24 (see above). Ibid. 2.2.16-7: die/tribe para\ *lusa/ndrw| trei=s mh=nas kai\ ple/on . . . e)pei\ de\ h(=ke teta/rtw| mhni/, a)ph/ggeilen kte(.

THUC.4.69.3: kai\ tau/thn me\n th\n h(me/ran o(lhn ei)rga/zonto: th=| d' u(sterai/a| peri\ dei/lhn to\ tei=xos o(/son ou)k a)petete/lesto, kai\ oi( e)n th=| *nisai/a| dei/santes . . . cune/bhsan toi=s *)aqhnai/ois.

HDT.1.18-9: e)pole/mee e)/tea e(/ndeka . . . tw=| de\ duwdeka/tw| e)/tei+ . . . sunhnei/xqh ti toio/nde gene/sqai prh=gma. 4.95 (see above). 4.158: tou=ton oi)/keon to\n xw=ron e(\c e)/tea: e(bdo/mw| de/ sfeas e)/tei+ . . . oi( *libu/es . . . a)ne/gnwsan e)klipei=n. 7.191: h(me/ras ga\r dh\ e)xei/maze trei=s' te/los de\ e)/ntoma/ te poieu=ntes kai\ kataei/dontes go/hsi oi( *ma/goi tw=| a)ne/mw| . . . e)/pausan teta/rth| h(me/rh|.
AR. Thesm. 502-3: e(te/ran d' e)gw)=|d' h(\ )fasken w)di/nein gunh\ | de/x' h(me/ras, e(/ws e)pri/ato paidi/on.
The above succession of imperfect and aorist is the type, but there are variations.
h(me/ras me\n pe/nte h(su/xazon, th=| d' e(/kth| e)ta/ssonto a)mfo/teroi w(s e)s ma/xhn, THUC.3.107.3; Five days they kept quiet, but on the sixth both parties began to draw up as for battle.
THUC.3.107.3(see above).
HDT.7. 20: e)pi\ me\n te/ssera e)/tea plh/rea pararte/eto stratih/n te kai\ . . ., pe/mptw| de\ e)/tei+ a)nome/nw| e)strathla/tee xeiri\ mega/lh| plh/qeos.

HOM. Od. 10.28 sqq.: e)nnh=mar me\n o(mw=s ple/omen nu/ktas te kai\ h)=mar, | th=| deka/th| d' h)/dh a)nefai/neto patri\s a)/roura, | kai\ dh\ purpole/ontas e)leu/ssomen e)ggu\s e)o/ntas: | e)/nq' e)me\ me\n gluku\s u(/pnos e)ph/luqe kekmhw=ta. (Only an apparent exception. The action is interrupted by the e)ph/luqe.)

Il. 6.174-6:
e)nnh=mar cei/nisse kai\ e)nne/a bou=s i(e/reusen
a)ll' o(/te dh\ deka/th e)fa/nh r(ododa/ktulos h)w/s,
kai\ to/te min e)re/eine kai\ h)/tee sh=ma i)de/sqai
. (Aorist followed by imperfect.)
When the imperfect alone is used, the definite statement is an afterthought, or, at all events, the matter is not fully disposed of by the narrator.
kai\ w)/|kei e)n *mega/rois plei/w h)\ pe/nte e)/th, LYC.21; He lived at Megara more than five years.
LYC.21(see above).
ISAE. 5.7: e)ke/kthto (plpf.=ipf.) e(/kastos dw/deka e)/th a(\ e)/laxe.
LYS. 21.2: to\n de\ metacu\ xro/non e)trihra/rxoun e(pta\ e)/th .

The two tenses are often so combined that the general statement is given by the aorist and the details of the action by the imperfect, or the situation is described by the imperfect and isolated points presented by the aorist.See also B. L. G., A. J. P. xiv (1893), 104-6.

[*swkra/ths] to\ fa/rmakon e)/pien . . . pw=s e)teleu/ta; PLATO , Phaedo, 57 A; Socrates drank the poison. How did he die? (Describe the closing scenes.) ou)k e)ch/rkese d' au)toi=s tau=t' e)camartei=n, a)lla\ peri\ tou\s au)tou\s xro/nous e)po/rqoun me
 th
 h)/peiron, u(/brizon de\ ta\s nh/sous, a)nh/|roun de\ . . . kai\ . . . kaqi/stasan, e)lumai/nonto de\ th
 *pelopo/nnhson kai\ mesth
 sta/sewn kai\ pole/mwn e)poi/hsan. e)pi\ poi/an ga tw=n po/lewn ou)k e)stra/teusan; h)\ peri\ ti/nas au)tw=n ou)k e)ch/marton; ou)k *)hlei/wn me
 me/ros ti th=s xw/ras a)fei/lonto, th
 de\ gh=n th
 *korinqi/wn e)/temon, . . . diw/|kisan, . . . e)cepolio/rkhsan, . . . ei)se/balon, ou)de
 d' e)pau/santo tou\s me
 a)/llous kakw=s poiou=ntes, au(toi=s de\ th
 h(=ttan th
 e)n *leu/ktrois paraskeua/zontes; ISOC.8.99-100.

ISOC.5.53-4: ou) ga\r e)/fqasan tw=n e)xqrw=n krath/santes kai\ pa/ntwn a)melh/santes h)nw/xloun me\n . . . e)to/lmwn . . . h)pei/loun . . . a)peste/roun . . . e)po/rqoun . . . e)ce/pempon . . . teleutw=ntes de\ pro\s *fwke/as po/lemon e)ch/negkan. 5.87: e)/sxe ga\r ditta\s e)piqumi/as . . . proh|rei=to ga\r basilei= te polemei=n kai\ tou\s e(tai/rous . . . katagagei=n. 8.99-100 (see above).
PLATO , Phaedo, 57 A (see above).

XEN. Hell. 2.3.55-6: w(s de\ tau=ta ei)=pen, ei(=lke me\n a)po\ tou= bwmou= o( *sa/turos, ei(=lkon de\ oi( u(phre/tai. o( de\ *qhrame/nhs . . . e)pekalei=to . . . . h( de\ boulh\ h(suxi/an ei)=xen . . . . oi( d' a)ph/gagon to\n a)/ndra kte(.

THUC.3.22(a number of examples of shifting tenses). 4.119.1-3: tau=ta cune/qento kai\ w)/mosan *lakedaimo/nioi kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi *)aqhnai/ois kai\ toi=s cumma/xois . . . cuneti/qento de\ kai\ e)spe/ndonto *lakedaimoni/wn me\n oi(/de . . . h( me\n dh\ e)kexeiri/a au(/th e)ge/ neto, kai\ cunh=|san e)n au)th=| peri\ tw=n meizo/nwn spondw=n dia\ panto\s e)s lo/gous .
HDT.2.162: tw=n tis *ai)gupti/wn o)/pisqe sta\s perie/qhke/ oi( kune/hn, kai\ peritiqei\s e)/fh e)pi\ basilhi/h| peritiqe/nai. 3.123: tau=ta a)kou/sas *polukra/ths h(/sqh te kai\ e)bou/leto.
HOM. Od. 10.352-67: A string of imperfects followed by a string of aorists.

An actual interchange of tenses is not to be admitted except in the case of a few old preterites, such as h)=n and e)/fhn. In the earliest period the typical difference is held fast. The apparent exceptions, then, may be accounted for by undifferentiated forms, by mistaken meanings, by the distributive or intensive use of the imperfect. So e)/fhn=e)/fhsa, but in e)/pempon the thoughts follow the motion,See B. L. G. on PIND. P. 4.114. and e)ke/leuon is “I gave orders,” “urged.”
o( *kroi=sos e)/pempe e)s *spa/rthn a)gge/lous . . . oi( de\ e)lqo/ntes e)/legon “e)/pemye h(me/as *kroi=sos kte(.”, HDT.1.69.

ANTIPH.6.27: ei) me\n e)gw\ tou/twn prokaloume/nwn mh\ h)qe/lhsa tou\s paragenome/nous a)pofh=nai, h)\ qera/pontas e)caitou=si mh\ h)/qelon e)kdido/nai . . . au)ta\ a)\n tau=ta me/gista tekmh/ria kat' e)mou= e)poiou=nto o(/ti a)lhqh\s h)=n h( ai)ti/a.

THUC.2.71.2-3: *pausani/as ga . . . a)pedi/dou *plataieu=si gh=n kai\ po/lin th
 sfete/ran e)/xontas au)tono/mous oi)kei=n kte(. ta/de me
 h(mi=n pate/res oi( u(me/teroi e)/dosan kte(. 3.58.5: *pausani/as me
 ga e)/qapten au)tou\s nomi/zwn e)n gh=| te fili/a| tiqe/nai kai\ par' a)ndra/si toiou/tois kte( . 7.20.1-2: peri/ te *pelopo/nnhson nau=s tria/konta e)/steilan kai\ *xarikle/a to
 *)apollodw/rou a)/rxonta, . . . kai\ to
 *dhmosqe/nh e)s th
 *sikeli/an, w(/sper e)/mellon, a)pe/stellon .

HDT.1.69(see above). 3.41: dizh/menos de\ eu(/riske to/de. 8.136: *mardo/nios de\ . . . meta\ tau=ta e)/pemye a)/ggelon e)s *)aqh/nas *)ale/candron to\n *)amu/ntew …, a(/ma me\n o(/ti . . . a(/ma te o( *mardo/nios puqo/menos o(/ti pro/ceino/s te ei)/h kai\ eu)erge/ths o( *)ale/candros e)/pempe. . . . toi=si dh\ peiqo/menos e)/pempe.
EUR. Or. 552: path\r me\n e/fu/teuse/n me, sh\ d' e)/tikte pai=s .
PIND. See B. L. G. on P. 4.114 and 247, and on P. 5.76: moi=ra/ tis a)/gen as compared with ibid. 87: tou\s *)aristote/lhs a)/gage. O. 6.41, on e)/tikte.

HOM. Od. 4.5: th
 me
 *)axillh=os r(hch/noros ui(e/i pe/mpen. Ibid. 8: th
 a)/r' o(/ g) e)/nq) i(/ppoisi kai\ a(/rmasi pe/mpe ne/esqai.

Il. 2.42 sqq.: e(/zeto d' o)rqwqei/s, malako\n d' e)/ndune xitw=na, | kalo/n nhga/teon, peri\ de\ me/ga ba/lleto fa=ros: | possi\ d' u(/po liparoi=sin e)dh/sato kala\ pe/dila: | a)mfi\ d' a)/r) w)/moisin ba/leto ci/fos a)rguro/hlon, kte(. 6.192-3:
au)tou= min kate/ruke, di/dou d' o(/ge qugate/ra h(/n,
dw=ke de/ oi( timh=s basilhi/dos h(/misu pa/shs
. 7.303-5: w(\s a)/ra fwnh/sas dw=ke ci/fos a)rguro/hlon . . . *ai)/as de\ zwsth=ra di/dou foi/niki faeino/n.

The imperfect is used of attempted and interrupted, of intended and expected actions.Pliny, H. N., Praef. 26, explains the “artistic” e)poi/ei as a manner of conative imperfect (Apelles faciebat aut Polyclitus, tamquam inchoata semper arte et imperfecta), but Urlichs showed long ago (1857) that the aorist outnumbered the imperfect in the olden time, and Löwy (Inschriften gr. Bildhauer xiii) has counted 260 aorists against 87 imperfects. The imperfect does not appear in the ISS of the IV. century, and becomes more common only in the imperial time (47 imperfects to 18 aorists). e)poi/hse “he made,” e)poi/ei “he was the maker.”

a(\ (sc. ta\ patrw=|a) pa/nt' e)ma\ e)gi/gneto, DEM.39.6; All of which (i. e. my father's estate) was going to be mine. to\ xwri/on e)pw/lei, ISAE. 2.28; He was for selling the piece of ground. ou) pai/dwn e(/neka e)ga/mei, ISAE. 6.24; It was not for the sake of children that he wanted to marry. a)pwllu/mhn (= h)/|dh a)polou/menos), ANTIPHON, 2 b 3; I knew (expected) that I was going to be ruined.

DEM.19.46: kai\ u(mei=s e)gela=te, And you started to laugh. 39.6 (see above). [49], 2: sfale/ntos me\n tou/tou a)pw/lluto kai\ tw=| patri\ tw=| e)mw=| to\ sumbo/laion. 54.33: tou/tw| de\ mh\ parasxome/nw| tou/tous ma/rturas h)=n (=e)/mellen e)/sesqai) dh/pou lo/gos ou)dei/s, a)ll' h(lwke/nai paraxrh=m' u(ph=rxe siwph=|.
ISAE. 2.28 (see above). 5.44: e)gi/gneto. 6.24 (see above).

ISOC.5.48: mh\ katorqw/santes me
 eu)qu\s a)pw/llunto. 10.36: o( me
 to
 dh=mon kaqi/sth ku/rion th=s politei/as, oi( de\ mo/non au)to
 a)/rxein h)ci/oun.
LYS.7.32: tau=ta de\ pra/cas . . . e)ke/rdainon me\n ou)de/n, e)mauto\n d' ei)s ki/ndunon kaqi/sthn .
ANTIPHON, 2 b 3 (see above). 2 b 9: a(lou\s me\n ga\r . . . th=s me\n ou)si/as h)/|dh e)ksthso/menos, tou= de\ sw/matos kai\ th=s po/lews ou)k a)pesterou/mhn.

PLATO, Phaedr. 230A: a)ta/r, w)= e(tai=re, . . . a)=r' ou) to/de h)=n to\ de/ndron, e)f) o(/per h)=ges h(ma=s; But, my friend, isn't this the tree to which you were going to, wanted to, started out to, take us?

XEN. Cyr. 5.5.22: ou)kou=n tou/tou tuxw
 para\ sou= ou)de
 h)/nuton, ei) mh\ tou/tous pei/saimi. Hell. 1.7.7: toiau=ta le/gontes e)/peiqon to
 dh=mon . . . e)/doce de\ a)nabale/sqai ei)s e(te/ran e)kklhsi/an.
THUC.4.68.5: a)sfa/leia de\ au)toi=s ma=llon e)gi/gneto th=s a)noi/cews.

HDT.1.68: e) misqou=to par' ou)k e)kdido/ntos th
 au)lh/n. 3.139: e)pequ/mhse th=s xlani/dos kai\ au)th
 proselqw
 w)ne/eto. o( de\ *sulosw=n . . . le/gei “e)gw\ tau/thn pwle/w me
 ou)deno\s xrh/matos, di/dwmi de\ a)/llws.” 8.60: pareo/ntwn ga tw=n summa/xwn ou)k e)/fere/ oi( ko/smon ou)de/na kathgore/ein. 8.63: a)polipo/ntwn ga *)aqhnai/wn ou)ke/ti e)gi/nonto a)cio/maxoi oi( loipoi/.
AR. Vesp. 116-7: a)ne/peiqen au)to\n mh\ forei=n tribw/nion | mhd' e)cie/nai qu/raz): o( d' ou)k e)pei/qeto.
EUR. H. F. 465: a)mfe/balle (= e)/mellen a)mfibalei=n). I. T. 26-9: e)lqou=sa d' *au)li/d' h( ta/lain) u(pe\r pura=s | metarsi/a lhfqei=s' e)kaino/mhn ci/fei: | a)ll' e)ce/kleyen . . . | *)/artemis.

HOM. Il. 3.79-80: tw=| d' e)petoca/zonto ka/rh koma/ontes *)axaioi\ | i)oi=si/n te titusko/menoi la/essi/ t' e)/ballon. 5.318: h( me
 e(o
 fi/lon ui(o
 u(pece/feren pole/moio. 5.377: u(pece/feron. 9.465: katerh/tuon.
See also the imperfects of 214.

p.hi: Imperfect of endeavor combined with aorist of attainment.

div2.p: Here the aorist often presents a sharp contrast.

e)/peiqon au)tou\s kai\ ou(\s e)/peisa tou/tous e)/xwn e)poreuo/mhn, XEN. Cyr. 5.5.22; I tried to persuade them, and those whom I succeeded in persuading I marched on with. suneta/canto kai\ toi=s o(pli/tais . . . e)ph=|san . . . toi=s me\n ou)=n o(pli/tais ou)k e)dunh/qhsan prosmei=cai, THUC.4.33.1-2; They formed and tried to charge the hoplites . . . Howbeit they could not get at them.
DEM.32.17: e)ch=gen au)to\n o( *prw=tos . . . ou(tosi\ d' ou)k e)ch/geto, ou)d' a)\n e)/fh diarrh/dhn u(p) ou)deno\s e)caxqh=nai.

PLATO, Theaet. 143A: e)graya/mhn me
 to/t' eu)qu\s oi)/kad' e)lqw
 u(pomnh/mata, u(/steron de\ kata\ sxolh
 a)namimnh|sko/menos e)/grafon.
XEN. Cyr. 5.5.22 (see above).
THUC.2.4.1-2: ta\s prosbola\s h(=| prospi/ptoien a)pewqou=nto. kai\ di\s me\n h)\ tri\s a)pekrou/santo. 4.33.1-2 (see above).
HDT.1.69: pe/myantes ga\r oi( *lakedaimo/nioi e)s *sa/rdis xruso\n w)ne/onto . . . *kroi=sos de/ sfi w)neome/noisi e)/dwke dwti/nhn.

HOM. Il. 6.51-4:
tw=| d' a)/ra qumo\n e)ni\ sth/qessin e)/peiqen,
kai\ dh/ min ta/x' e)/melle qoa\s e)pi\ nh=as *)axaiw=n
dw/sein w(=| qera/ponti katace/men: a)ll' *)agame/mnwn
a)nti/os h)=lqe qe/wn kai\ o(moklh/sas e)/pos hu)/da:
Then v. 61: w(\s ei)pw\n e)/treyen a)delfeo/o fre/nas h(/rws .
Expected actions are more commonly expressed by e)/mellon and the infinitive.
e)k ti/nos tro/pou e)/melle/ tis au)tw=n swqh/sesqai; LYS. 13.37 ; How was any of them to escape?

LYS. 3.32: tw=| u(mw=n pisto
 w(s . . . h)=gon au)to
 e)pi\ th
 oi)ki/an th
 *si/mwnos, ou(= plei=sta e)/mellon pra/gmata e(/cein;
Ibid. 34: ou(= au)to\s e)/mellon . . . o)fqh/sesqai .
PLATO, Crat. 418B: o(\ e)/mello/n soi e)rei=n. Phaedr. 228 C: teleutw=n de\ e)/melle . . . bi/a| e)rei=n.
XEN. An. 1.8.1: plhsi/on h)=n o( staqmo\s e)/nqa e)/melle katalu/ein. Cyr. 3.1.1: o)fqh/sesqai e)/melle.
THUC.1.130.1: a)ll' e)/rgois . . . proudh/lou a(\ . . . e)/melle pra/cein. 3.115.5: *sofokle/a de\ . . . a)pope/myein e)/mellon .
HDT.2.43: tou/twn . . . e)/mellon mnh/mhn e(/cein.
AR. Eq. 267: le/gein gnw/mhn e)/mellon. Eccl. 597: tou=to ga\r h)/mellon e)gw\ le/cein.
SOPH. Ai. 925-6. O. R. 967: ktenei=n e)/mellon pate/ra to\n e)mo/n .
PIND. O. 7.61: mnasqe/nti de\ *zeu\s a)/mpalon me/llen qe/men.
Theogon. HES.468-9: o(/te dh\ *di/) e)/melle . . . | te/cesqai. 552: ta\ kai\ tele/esqai e)/melle.
HOM. Od. 7.270: e)/mellon e)/ti cune/sesqai o)izui=. 9.475-6: ou)k a)/r' e)/melles . . . e)/dmenai.
Il. 6.52-3: e)/melle . . . dw/sein (parallel with imperfect. See 214).
The negative imperfect commonly denotes resistance to pressure or disappointment. Simple negation is aoristic.

DEM.18.151(see above). 18.250: ou) metedi/dote (as was expected by my enemies). 21.163: ou)k a)ne/bain' e)pi\ th\n nau=n, He would not go on board the ship (as was expected). 25.57 (see above). 32.17: ou)k e)ch/geto (see 214). 39.18: ou)k e)poiei=q). [44], 17: o( me\n *)arxia/dhs ou)k e)ga/mei, o( de\ *meiduli/dhs . . . e)/ghmen.
PLATO, Theaet. 142C: h)pei/geto oi)/kade: e)pei\ e)/gwg' e)deo/mhn kai\ sunebou/leuon (sc. au)tou= katalu/ein), a)ll' ou)k h)/qelen.

XEN. Cyr. 1.4.21: ou)k a)ni/esan, a)ll' h(/|roun tina\s au)tw=n. 4.2.28: e)ma/xeto ou)dei/s, a)ll' a)maxhti\ a)pw/llunto. Hell. 2.2.11: ou) diele/gonto peri\ diallagh=s. Ibid. 7.5.21: th\n me\n suntomwta/thn pro\s tou\s polemi/ous ou)k h)=ge.

THUC.2.23.1: ou)k e)pech=|san au)toi=s oi( *)aqhnai=oi e)s ma/xhn. 3.3.1: ou)k a)pede/xonto . . . ta\s kathgori/as . 3. 64.3: ou)k e)de/xesqe . 4.33.2: ou)k a)nteph=|san, a)ll' h(su/xazon , They would not go out to meet them but kept quiet.
4.110.1: w(s d' ou)k e)sh/kouon . 7.3.3: ou)k e)ph=ge . . . a)ll' h(su/xaze .

HDT.1.76: *)/iwnes . . . ou)k e)pei/qonto. 3.50. dialegome/nw| te ou)/ ti prosdiele/getoHDT., i(store/onti/ te lo/gon ou)de/na e)di/dou. 5.41: h( de\ *kleome/uea tekou=sa . . . gunh\ . . . ou)ke/ti e)/tikte to\ deu/teron.
AR. Vesp. 116-7: a)ne/peiqen au)to\n mh\ forei=n tribw/nion | mhd' e)cie/nai qu/raz): o( d: ou)k e)pei/qeto (213).
COM. Pherecr. 2.289: ou)dei\s ga\r e)de/xet' ou)d' a)ne/w|ge/ moi qu/ran.
EUR. Phoen. 405: to\ ge/nos ou)k e)/ boske/ me.

AESCHYL. Ag. 1212: e)/peiqon ou)de/n' ou)de/n, w(s ta/d' h)/mplakon.Cited by E. Abbott on p. 210 of his translation of Curtius' Erläut., in opposition to the distinction made by Curtius between e)/peiqon and e)/peisa.
PIND. P. 4.86: to\n me\n ou) gi/nwskon.
HOM. Od. 4.12-3: *(ele/nh| de\ qeoi\ go/non ou)ke/t' e)/fainon, | e)pei\ dh\ to\ prw=ton e)gei/nato pai=d' e)rateinh/n.
Il. 2.779: ou)d' e)ma/xonto. 6.161-2: to\n ou)/ ti pei=q' a)gaqa\ frone/onta . (“o( paratatiko\s th\n polla/kis tou=to le/gousan e)dh/lwse.”—Schol. BL.) 16.102: ou)ke/t' e)/mimne.

The imperfect as the tense of past impressions is used:
In descriptions of scenery
Of points previously assumed
Of views previously held
Of sudden appreciation of real state of affairs
Imperfect in description of scenery.—In descriptions of scenery as well as of events.
to\ d' *(ellhniko\n ei)s *leu/kofrun (sc. a)ph=lqen), e)/nqa h)=n *)arte/midos . . . i(ero\n ma/la a(/gion, XEN. Hell. 3.2.19.
Of points previously assumed in argument.

PLATO , De Iusto, 373 C-D: me/tron (staqmo/s, a)riqmo/s, lo/gos) ga\r h)=n w(=| tau=t' e)kri/neto. Legg. 867 D: a(/teros e)/feuge ta\ du/o (sc. e)/th), The other was to be in exile (as we have seen) the two years. Rpb. 522 A: a)ll' h)=n e)kei/nh (sc. mousikh/) . . . a)nti/strofos th=s gumnastikh=s, ei) me/mnhsai. 587 C (see above).
Of views that were once fondly entertained.
tou=to . . . ou) didakto\n w)/|mhn ei)=nai, XEN. Oec. 12.10; I thought that this was not to be taught.
ISAE. 7.1-2: w)/|mhn me/n, w)= a)/ndres, prosh/kein ou) ta\s toiau/tas a)mfisbhtei=sqai poih/seis kte(. e)/oike d' ou)de\n prou)/rgou tou=to ei)=nai.
XEN. Oec. 12.10 (see above).

p.hi: Imperfect of sudden appreciation of real state of affairs.—imperfect for present.

div2.p: Of sudden appreciation of a real state of things, regularly with a)=ra (a)/ra).
ou) ga\r tou=t' h)=n eu)daimoni/a, w(s e)/oike, kakou= a)pallagh/, PLATO, Gorg. 478C. *d*i*k. touti\ ti/ h)=n to\ pra=gma; *m*e*g. xoi=ros nai\ *di/a, AR. Ach. 767; What's all this? A pig, by Jove.

PLATO, Conv. 213B: w)= *(hra/kleis, touti\ ti/ h)=n; *swkra/ths ou(=tos; Gorg. 478 C (see above). Phaedr. 227 B: a)ta\r *lusi/as h)=n, w(s e)/oiken, e)n a)/stei. Ibid. 230 A: a)=r' ou) to/de h)=n to\ de/ndron, e)f) o(/per h)=ges h(ma=s; Isn't this the tree, etc.? (213).

XEN. Cyr. 1.3.10: tou=t' a)/r) h)=n h( i)shgori)a. Ibid. 1.4.27: tau=t' a)/ra . . . kai\ e)new/ras moi. Oec. 1.20: lu=pai a)/ra h)=san h(donai=s peripepemme/nai, So they turn out to be (are after all) pains sugar-coated with pleasure.
HDT.3.65: e)n th=| ga\r a)nqrwphi/h| fu/si ou)k e)nh=n a)/ra to\ me/llon gi/nesqai a)potra/pein. 4.64: de/rma de\ a)nqrw/pou kai\ paxu\ kai\ lampro\n h)=n a)/ra.

AR. Ach. 767 (see above). Eq. 1170: w(s me/gan a)/r' ei)=xes, w)= po/tnia, to\n da/ktulon. Vesp. 183-4: touti\ ti/ h)=n; | ti/s ei)= pot', w)=nqrwp), e)teo/n; Ibid. 451: su\ d' a)xa/ristos h)=sq) a)/ra.

EUR. H. F. 339-41: w)= *zeu=, ma/thn a)/r' o(mo/gamo/n s) e)kthsa/mhn, | ma/thn de\ paido\s gone/) e)mou= s' e)klh/|zomen: | su\ d' h)=sq) a)/r) h(=sson h)\ )do/keis ei)=nai fi/los. I. A. 404: ai)ai=, fi/lous a)/r' ou)xi\ kekth/mhn ta/las.
THEOGN. 700: tw=n d' a)/llwn ou)de\n a)/r) h)=n o)/felos. 788: ou(/tws ou)de\n a)/r' h)=n fi/lteron a)/llo pa/trhs.

HOM. Od. 4.333-4: w)\ po/poi, h)= ma/la dh\ kratero/fronos a)ndro\s e)n eu)nh=| | h)/qelon eu)nhqh=nai a)na/lkides au)toi\ e)o/ntes. 9.230: ou)d' a)/r) e)/mell) e(ta/roisi fanei\s e)rateino\s e)/sesqai. 475-6 (215). 11.553: ou)k a)/r' e)/melles. 13.209-10: w)\ po/poi, ou)k a)/ra pa/nta noh/mones ou)de\ di/kaioi | h)=san *faih/kwn h(gh/tores.
Il. 4.155: qa/nato/n nu/ toi o(/rki) e)/tamnon. 5.205: ta\ de/ m' ou)k a)/r) e)/mellon o)nh/sein. 16.33: ou)k a)/ra soi/ ge path\r h)=n i(ppo/ta *phleu/s.

p.hi: Origin of modal e)/dei, e)xrh=n, etc.

div2.p: From this use of the imperfect comes, perhaps, the use of e)/dei, e)xrh=n, and the like, with the infinitive, in opposition to the infinitive. e)/dei se poiei=n tou=to (a)ll' ou) poiei=s), You ought to do this (but are not doing it). The unfulfilled duty is a surprise. See 364.
As the present is used of actions that are continued from the past into the present (see 202), so the imperfect is used of actions that are continued into the past from a remoter past.
e)qau/mazon pa/lai, AR. AV. 1670; I had long been astonished at it (i.e. before you asked me the question).
PLATO, Conv. 209C: a(\ pa/lai e)ku/ei ti/ktei.
HDT.4.1: ai( ga\r tw=n *skuqe/wn gunai=kes, w(/s sfi oi( a)/ndres a)ph=san xro/non pollo/n, e)foi/teon para\ tou\s dou/lous.
AR. Nub. 1311-2: oi)=mai ga\r au)to\n au)ti/x' eu(rh/sein o(/per pa/lai pot' e)ph/|tei . Av. 1670 (see above). Lys. 1033: nh\ *di/' w)/nhsa/s ge/ m', w(s pa/lai ge/ m' e)frewru/xei .
PIND. P. 4.25-7: dw/deka de\ pro/teron a(me/ras . . . fe/romen . . . ei)na/lion do/ru.
HOM. Od. 23.29: *thle/maxos d' a)/ra min pa/lai h)/|deen (=Impf.) e)/ndon e)o/nta (dudum noverat).
Il. 23.871: a)ta\r dh\ o)isto\n e)/xen pa/lai, iam sagittam tenebat dudum.
This overlapping use of the imperfect (comp. 208) is especially important in correlated temporal sentences. See Temporal Sentences.

e)peidh\ de\ kalw=s au)tw=| ei)=xen, e)kei=nos me\n a)piw\n w)/|xeto, e)gw\ de\ e)ka/qeudon, LYS.1.23 ; After he had (thought he had, had had) enough, he took himself off and I slept (proceeded to go to sleep).

p.hi: Imperfect apparently used as a pluperfect.

div2.p: Of course in those verbs in which the present is used as a perfect (204), the imperfect is used as a pluperfect.
e)/feugen o( *cenofw=n, XEN. An. 5.3.7 ; Xenophon was in exile, had been banished.
PLATO, Menex. 242E: meq' w)=n to/te tou\s barba/rous e)ni/kwn, tou/tous nikw=ntes i)di/a|.

p.hi: Imperfect of h(/kein and oi)/xesqai used aoristically.

div2.p: h(=kon and w)|xo/mhn are often used aoristically.
e)pei\ de\ h(=ke teta/rtw| mhni/, a)ph/ggeilen kte(., XEN. Hell. 2.2.17 (208). w)/|xeto de\ pro\s qeo/n, PIND. N. 7.40.

div2.head: Perfect Tense
div2.p: The perfect tense expresses completion in the present, and hence is sometimes called the present perfect.

a)khko/ate, e(wra/kate, pepo/nqate, LYS. 12.100 ; You have heard, you have seen. you have felt. e)mpeplh/kasin u(mw=n ta\ w)=ta, PLATO, Apol. 23E; They have filled your ears. te/qaptai . . . *ki/mwn pro\ tou= a)/steos, HDT.6.103; Kimon (has been, is) lies buried before the city.
DEM.3.22: prope/potai . . . ta\ th=s po/lews pra/gmata. 4.48: pre/sbeis pe/pomfen w(s basile/a. 6.37: i(kanw=s ei)/rhtai.
AESCHIN.2.147: e)/th ga\r h)/dh bebi/wken e)nenh/konta kai\ te/ttara. 3.186: e)ntau=qa h( e)n *maraqw=ni ma/xh ge)graptai.

PLATO, Apol. 23E (see above). Gorg. 448 A: ou)dei/s me/ pw h)rw/thke kaino\n ou)de\n pollw=n e)tw=n. Meno 93 A: e)/moige . . . kai\ ei)=nai dokou=sin e)nqa/de a)gaqoi\ ta\ politika/, kai\ gegone/nai e)/ti ou)x h(=tton h)\ ei)=nai. Prot. 314 D: ou)k a)khko/ate, o(/ti ou) sxolh\ au)tw=|;
XEN. Hell. 6.5.37: de/ndra e)kkeko/fasi kai\ oi)ki)as katakekau/kasi kai\ xrh/mata kai\ pro/bata dihrpa/kasi.
HDT.6.103(see above). 7.162: e)k tou= e)niautou= to\ e)/ar . . . e)carai/rhtai.
SOPH. Ai. 480: pa/nt' a)kh/koas lo/gon .
PIND. O. 10.1-3: to\n *)olumpioni/kan a)na/gnwte/ moi | . . . po/qi freno\s | e)ma=s ge/graptai (stands written).
HOM. Od. 2.63-4: ou) ga\r e)/t' a)nsxeta\ e)/rga teteu/xatai, ou)d' e)/ti kalw=s | oi)=kos e)mo\s dio/lwle.
Il. 1.125: a)lla\ ta\ me\n poli/wn e)\c e)pra/qomen, ta\ de/dastai.

The perfect looks at both ends of an action. The time between these ends is considered as a present. When one end is considered, the present is used; when the other, the aorist. Hence present and perfect are often used side by side, and the translation into English is often present (228); the aorist is the shorthand of the perfect (248-51); and the perfect is sometimes used even of a past action that is dated (233).
kalo\n . . . te/xnhma a)/ra ke/kthsai, ei)/per ke/kthsai, PLATO, Prot. 319A; A fine contrivance is that you have got, to be sure, IF you have got it.
AESCHIN.3.144: sunei/qisqe h)/dh ta)dikh/mata ta\ tou/tou a)kou/ein.
ANTIPHON, 5.54: te/qnhken o( a)nh/r.
PLATO, Prot. 319A (see above). Tim. 23 B: e(/na gh=s kataklusmo\n me/mnhsqe pollw=n e)/mprosqen gegono/twn.
XEN. Oec. 9.4: pro\s meshmbri/an a)nape/ptatai (sc. h( oi)ki/a).
THUC.3.82.7: r(a=|on d' oi( polloi\ kakou=rgoi o)/ntes decioi\ ke/klhntai h)\ a)maqei=s a)gaqoi/.
HDT.2.47: u(=n de\ *ai)gu/ptioi miaro\n h(/ghntai qhri/on ei)=nai. 4.28: te/ras neno/mistai. 6.103 (226).
AR. Ach. 993: h)\ pa/nu gero/ntion i)/sws neno/mika/s me su/;
SOPH. El. 1101: *ai)/gisqon e)/nq' w)/|khken i(storw= pa/lai.
PIND. P. 4.248: polloi=si d' a(/ghmai sofi/as e(te/rois.
SAPPHO, 2.9-10: a)lla\ kam me\n glw=ssa e)/age, le/pton d' | au)/tika xrw=| pu=r u)padedro/maken.
HES. Theog. 726: e)lh/latai. 727: ke/xutai. 728: pefu/asi. 730: kekru/fatai.
HOM. Od. 5.412: lissh\ d' a)nade/drome pe/trh. 6.44-5: a)lla\ ma/l' ai)/qrh | pe/ptatai a)nne/felos, leukh\ d' e)pide/dromen ai)/glh.
Not to be confounded with this use, which has many English analogies, is the survival of the old intensive perfects, chiefly in verbs of sound and verbs of emotion.
Verbs of Sound (Onomatopoetic Verbs):
Most of these are poetic or popular. ke/kraga, I am bawling, bawling; sesi/ghka, I am mum.
labw\n me\n sesi/ghkas, a)nalw/sas de\ ke/kragas, AESCHIN.3.218; When you get money you are mum, when you have spent it you are in full cry.
AESCHIN.3.218(see above).
HDT.4.183: tetri/gasi kata/ per ai( nukteri/des.
AR. Vesp. 944: ti/ sesiw/phkas;
SOPH. Tr. 1072: be/bruxa kla/wn.
HES. O. et D. 207: daimoni/h, ti/ le/lhkas;
HOM. Od. 5.411-2: a)mfi\ de\ ku=ma | be/bruxen r(o/qion.
Il. 4.433-5: o)/ies . . . e(sth/kasin . . . a)zhxe\s memakui=ai. 10.362: memhkw/s. 17.264: be/bruxen me/ga ku=ma.
de/dia, I am in a perfect tremble, I quiver and quake. de/di) w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi mh\ tou/tois met' e)kei/nou polemei=n a)nagkasqw=men, DEM.14.4.
DEM.4.8: misei= tis e)kei=non kai\ de/di(e) . . . kai\ fqonei= . . . kate/pthxe me/ntoi pa/nta nu=n. 14.4 (see above). 25.1: e(\n de\ teqau/maka.

PLATO , Phaedo 64 D: fai/netai/ soi filoso/fou a)ndro\s ei)=nai e)spoudake/nai peri\ ta\s h(dona\s kaloume/nas; Theaet. 161 B-C: oi)=sq' ou)=n . . . o(\ qauma/zw . . .; . . . th\n d' a)rxh\n tou= lo/gou teqau/maka.
SOPH. Ai. 139: me/gan o)/knon e)/xw kai\ pefo/bhmai .
SIMON. AM. 7.28: th\n me\n gela=| te kai\ ge/ghqen h(me/rhn.
TYRT.12.28: a)rgale/w| te po/qw| pa=sa ke/khde po/lis.
HOM. Od. 6.106: ge/ghqe de/ te fre/na *lhtw/.
Il. 10.93-4: ou)de/ moi h)=tor | e)/mpedon, a)ll' a)lalu/kthmai.
de/dorka, I look. The classification cannot always be exact. teqau/maka, I am astonished, is also teqau/maka, I am agaze.
PIND. O. 1.96-7: to\ de\ kle/os | thlo/qen de/dorke (intr.) ta=n *)olumpia/dwn.
HES. O. et D. 508: me/muke de\ gai=a kai\ u(/lh.
HOM. Od. 19.446: pu=r d' o)fqalmoi=si dedorkw/s.
So also the solitary Verb of Smell, for which see HOM. Od. 9.210.

p.hi: Verbs of Gesture, Expression, and the like:

div2.p: e)skuqrwpa/kasi, DEM.54.34; They are grim and grum. dedragme/nos, grimly gripping. ke/xhna, I am all agape.
DEM.54.34(see above).
AR. Eq. 755: ke/xhnen. 1118-9: pro\s to/n te le/gont' a)ei\ | ke/xhnas.
HES. Theog. 826: glw/ssh|sin dnoferh=|si lelixmo/tes.
HOM. Od. 11.222: yuxh\ . . . pepo/thtai.
Il. 2.90: pepoth/atai, They are all a-flutter. 13.393: ko/nios dedragme/nos ai(matoe/sshs, With his fists full of bloody dust.
For the use of the Aorist as a Perfect, see 248-51.

p.hi: Perfect of an action that is dated.

div2.p: The Greek perfect may be used of a past action even when it is dated.
e)pide/deiktai to/te, ISAE. 3.7; It has been shown (nay, was shown) then.
LYCURG.103: *(/ektwr ga\r toi=s *trwsi\ parakeleuo/menos u(pe\r th=s patri/dos ta/de ei)/rhken.
DEM.21.7: u(/brismai me\n e)gw\ kai\ propephla/kistai to\ sw=ma tou)mo\n to/te, a)gwniei=tai de\ kai\ kriqh/setai to\ pra=gma nuni/. 38.8: pa/nta [tau=t'] a)fei=tai to/te.
ISAE. 3.7 (see above).
As the present may be used rhetorically for the future, so the perfect may be used for the future perfect.

AESCHIN.1.90: ei) ga\r h( me\n pra=cis au(/th e)/stai . . ., o( de\ . . . ei)dw\s . . . e)/noxos e)/stai . . ., o( de\ krino/menos . . . a)ciw/sei . . ., a)nh/|rhtai o( no/mos kai\ h( a)lh/qeia, kai\ de/deiktai fanera\ o(do/s, di) h(=s kte(.
ANDOC.1.146: e)a/n me nuni\ diafqei/rhte, ou)k e)/stin u(mi=n e)/ti loipo\s tou= ge/nous tou= h(mete/rou ou)dei/s, a)ll' oi)/xetai pa=n pro/rrizon.
PLATO, Hipparch. 231C-D: fe/re ga/r, e)a/n tis xrusi/ou staqmo\n h(/misun a)nalw/sas dipla/sion la/bh| a)rguri/ou, ke/rdos h)\ zhmi/an ei)/lhfen (=ei)lhfw\s e)/stai);

EUR. Or. 304-5:
ei) ga\r prolei/yeis m' h)\ prosedri/a| no/son
kth/sh| tin), oi)xo/mesqa
(see above).
SOPH. O. R. 1166: o)/lwlas, ei)/ se tau=t' e)rh/somai pa/lin. Ph. 75-6: w(/st' ei)/ me to/cwn e)gkrath\s ai)sqh/setai, | o)/lwla kai\ se\ prosdiafqerw= cunw/n.
On the Periphrastic Perfect, see 286-8.
On the Gnomic Perfect, see 257.

div2.head: Pluperfect Tense
div2.p: The Pluperfect denotes completion in the past. It may be defined as the perfect of the past, and hence is naturally associated with the imperfect. It is more distinctly than in Latin and in English the tense of fixed condition.

spaniw/tera ta\ e)pith/deia h)=n: ta\ me\n ga\r a)nh/lwto, ta\ de\ dih/rpasto, ta\ de\ e)ceke/xuto, ta\ de\ kateke/kauto, XEN. Hell. 6.5.50; Provisions were rather scarce; for part had been used up, part plundered, part spilled, part burned.
LYS.13.20: h( de\ boulh\ . . . die/fqarto kai\ o)ligarxi/as e)pequ/mei . 13.52: ploi=a pareskeu/asto kai\ oi( e)gguhtai\ e(/toimoi h)=san .

XEN. Cyr. 3.2.11: e)pei\ de\ h)risth/kesan, . . . eu)qu\s e)tei/xize frou/rion. Hell. 1.1.32: e)pi\ de\ to\ nautiko/n, o(\ e)kei=nos h)qroi/kei . . ., ecepe/mfqh *krathsippi/das. Ibid. 1.3.20: e)pei\ de\ au)toi=s pareskeu/asto, nukto\s a)noi/cantes ta\s pu/las . . . ei)sh/gagon to\ stra/teuma, When they had all their preparations made, they opened the gates by night and introduced the army. Ibid. 6.5.21: e)k ga th=s pro/sqen a)qumi/as e)do/kei ti a)neilhfe/nai th
 po/lin, o(/ti kai\ e)nebeblh/kei ei)s th
 *)arkadi/an kai\ dh|ou=nti th
 xw/ran ou)dei\s h)qelh/kei ma/xesqai. Ibid. 6.5.23: oi( . . . *qhbai=oi kalw=s sfi/sin w)/|onto e)/xein, e)pei\ e)bebohqh/kesan me/n, pole/mion de\ ou)de/na e)/ti e(w/rwn e)n th=| xw/ra|. Ibid. 6.5.50 (see above). Ibid. 7.5.21: e)pei/ ge mh
 e/te/takto au)tw=| to\ stra/teuma . . ., th
 . . . suntomwta/thn pro\s tou\s polemi/ous ou)k h)=ge.
THUC.2.59.1: h)lloi/wnto ta\s gnw/mas. 4.29.2: w(/rmhnto diakinduneu=sai .
HDT.1.85: o( *kroi=sos to\ pa=n e)s au)to\n e)pepoih/kee . . . kai\ dh\ kai\ e)s *delfou\s peri\ au)tou= e)pepo/mfee. 8.72: *)olu/mpia de\ kai\ *ka/rneia paroixw/kee h)/dh.
PIND. O. 6.53-4: a)ll' e)n ke/krupto ga\r sxoi/nw| .
HES. Sc. 143: h)lh/lanto. 154: te/tukto. 208: e)te/tukto. 218: e)sth/rikto. 288: e)sta/lat(o).
HYMN. HOM. I, 91-102: *lhtw\ d' e)nnh=ma/r te kai\ e)nne/a nu/ktas a)e/lptois | w)di/nessi pe/parto . . . ai(\ d' *)=irin prou)/pemyan kte(. (cf. 208).
HOM. Od. 4.132: xrusw=| d' e)/pi xei/lea kekra/anto. 4.135: teta/nusto.

Il. 5.387-90: xalke/w| d' e)n kera/mw| de/deto trei=s kai\ de/ka mh=nas. | . . . o(\ d' e)ce/kleyen *)/arha (cf. 208). 10.155-6: eu(=d', u(po\ d' e)/strwto r(ino\n boo\s a)grau/loio, | au)ta\r u(po\ kra/tesfi ta/phs teta/nusto faeino/s. 10.540: ou)/ pw pa=n ei)/rhto e)/pos, o(/t' a)/r) h)/luqon au)toi/.
For the Greek use of the Aorist, where English and Latin would use the Pluperfect, see 253.
The pluperfect is sometimes used to denote rapid relative completion. The later Greek writers often abuse it.Rutherford, Babrius lxiii, but compare A. J. P. xvii (1896), 518 and 519.

tou/twn gnwsqe/ntwn ou)demi/an diatribh\n e)poihsa/mhn, a)ll' eu)qu\s pareke/klhnto me\n ou(\s ei)=pon, proeirhkw\s d' h)=n au)toi=s, e)f) a(\ sunelhluqo/tes h)=san, a)ne/gnwsto d' o( lo/gos, e)ph|nhme/nos d' h)=n kai\ teqorubhme/nos kai\ tetuxhkw\s w(=nper oi( katorqou=ntes e)n tai=s e)pidei/cesin, ISOC.12.233.
ISOC.12.233(see above).

XEN. Cyr. 1.4.5: taxu\ me\n . . . a)fi/keto . . ., taxu\ de\ parh/|ei . . ., taxu\ de\ ta\ e)n tw=| paradei/sw| qhri/a a)nhlw/kei . . . w(/ste o( *)astua/ghs ou)ke/t' ei)=xen au)tw=| sulle/gein qhri/a.
THUC.4.47.1: w(s de\ . . . e)kple/ontes elh/fqhsan, e)le/lunto/ te ai( spondai\ kai\ toi=s *kerkurai/ois parede/donto oi( pa/ntes.

HDT.1.79: w(s de/ oi( tau=ta e)/doce, kai\ e)poi/ee kata\ ta/xos: e)la/sas ga to
 strato
 e)s th
 *ludi/hn au)to\s a)/ggelos *kroi/sw| e)lhlu/qee.
HOM. Od. 1.360: h(\ me\n qambh/sasa pa/lin oi)=ko/nde bebh/kei.

Il. 4.134-6: e)n d' e)/pese zwsth=ri a)rhro/ti pikro\s o)isto/s: | dia\ me\n a)\r zwsth=ros e\lh/lato daidale/oio | kai\ dia\ qw/rhkos poludaida/lou h)rh/reisto. 13.593-5: xei=ra . . . *mene/laos | th\n ba/len, h(=| r() e)/xe to/con e)u/coon: e)n d' a)/ra to/cw| | a)ntikru\ dia\ xeiro\s e)lh/lato xa/lkeon e)/gxos.
When the perfect is used as a present (228), the pluperfect is used as an imperfect.

kakw=n *)ilia\s perieisth/kei *qhbai/ous, DEM.19.148; An Iliad of woes was encompassing Thebes (the Thebans). e)kekra/gesan . . . tou\s pruta/neis a)fie/nai, AR. Eq. 674; They kept on bawling “The prytanes must dismiss.”
DEM.19.148(see above).
PLATO, Phaedr. 233D: ou)/t' a)\n pistou\s fi/lous e)kekth/meqa. Theaet. 198 D: a(\ pa/lai e)ke/kthto.
THUC.3.70.3: h)=n ga\r . . . e)qelopro/ceno/s te tw=n *)aqhnai/wn kai\ tou= dh/mou proeisth/kei.
AR. Ach. 10: o(/te dh\ )kexh/nh (sat with mouth open) prosdokw=n to\n *ai)sxu/lon. Eq. 674 (see above).
HES. Sc. 148: deinh\ e)/ris pepo/thto (was afly, “flying all abroad”) koru/ssousa klo/non a)ndrw=n. 155: dedh/ei. 191: e(/stasan. 269: ei(sth/kei. 274: o)rw/rei.
HOM. Od. 9.210: o)smh\ . . . o)dw/dei.
Il. 8.68: h)e/lios me/son ou)rano\n a)mfibebh/kei, The sun stood astride the midheaven.

div2.head: Aorist Tense
div2.p: The Aorist states a past action without reference to its duration simply as a thing attained. It is one of the two great narrative tenses of the Greek language, and is best studied in connection with the other, the imperfect. Examples are found everywhere.On the proportion of aorist and imperfect, see B. L. G. in A. J. P. iv (1883), 163; xiv (1893), 104; xvi (1895), 259; and C. W. E. M. in A. J. P. xvi (1895), 142. (Upshot Aorist.)

*ko/nwn . . . e)ni/khse th\n e)n *kni/dw| naumaxi/an . . . *)ifikra/ths a)nei=le th\n *lakedaimoni/wn mo/ran, DIN.1.75; Conon gained the (great) naval victory of (at) Cnidus, Iphicrates annihilated the Lacedaemonian mora.

The aorist often appears as the point of origin. This is due to the character of the verbs, which are chiefly denominative. Hence this aorist, which is called the ingressive aorist, is usually the first aorist. (Outset Aorist.)
e)basi/leuse . . . *gu/ghs, HDT.1.13; Gyges became king.

PLATO, Euthyd. 276D: e)ge/lasa/n te kai\ e)qoru/bhsan, They set up a laugh and broke out into applause.It should be noted that the ingressive rendering is not a proof, but only an illustration. See C. W. E. M. in A. J. P. xvi (1895), 150-1.
XEN. Hell. 2.2, [24]: *dionu/sios . . . e)tura/nnhse (=tu/rannos e)ge/neto), D. became tyrant.
THUC.1.4: h)=rce/ te kai\ oi)kisth\s . . . e)ge/neto, He acquired the rule and became founder.
HDT.1.13(see above). 1.19: e)no/shse o( *)alua/tths, Alyattes fell sick. 7.45: o( *ce/rchs . . . e)da/kruse, Xerxes burst into tears.
AR. Eccl. 431: ei)=t' e)qoru/bhsan ka)ne/kragon w(s eu)= le/goi.
AESCHYL. P.V. 235: e)gw\ d' e)to/lmhs(a).
PIND. O. 7.37: a)norou/sais' a)la/lacen u(perma/kei boa=| (gave a wild halloo).
HOM. Il. 3.259: r(i/ghsen (gave a shudder) d' o( ge/rwn. 11.546: tre/sse, He took to flight.
ANTIPHON, 2 b 1: o(/tan . . . nosh/swsin, u(giei=s geno/menoi sw/|zontai.
PLATO , Critias, 111B: nosh/santos sw/matos o)sta=. Timae. 84 A: to\ de\ dh\ sa/rkas o)stoi=s cundou=n o(po/t' a)\n nosh/sh| (becomes diseased) . . . katayh/xetai .
THUC.2.58.2: w(/ste kai\ tou\s prote/rous stratiw/tas nosh=sai.
AR. Pl. 569: plouth/santes (257). 834-6: ka)gw\ me\n w)/|mhn ou(\s te/ws | eu)hrge/thsa deome/nous e(/cein fi/lous | o)/ntws bebai/ous, ei) dehqei/hn pote/.
AESCHYL. P.V. 203: speu/dontes, w(s *zeu\s mh/pot' a)/rceien (become lord) qew=n.

Ingressive translations are, of course, possible with a number of second aorists, as e)/sthn, I took a stand, e)/bhn, I took a step; but there is not the same contrast between state and entrance upon a state as in the first aorist, not the same po/reusis ei)s to\ ei)=nai, as it is called by a late writer, [PLATO ], Deff. 411 A. Especially common is the ingressive translation of e)/sxon. e)/xw, I hold, e)/sxon, I took hold; e)/xw, I possess, I am possessor, have, e)/sxon, I took possession, I got. This is all the more natural as e)/xw connotes a state and is often used in periphrases with verbal nouns. ai)ti/an e)/sxon=h)|tia/qhn, got blamed (see 178).
XEN. Cyr. 1.5.2 (see above).

THUC.1.12.3: *dwrih=s . . . o)gdohkostw=| e)/tei cu
 *(hraklei/dais *pelopo/nnhson e)/sxon (cf. w)/|khsan ibid.). 1.103.4: kai\ e)/sxon *)aqhnai=oi *me/gara kai\ *phga/s . 4.49: au)toi\ *)akarna=nes oi)kh/tores a)po\ pa/ntwn e)/sxon to\ xwri/on . 4.95.3: th
 *boiwti/an pote\ e)/sxon . 8.23.3: tou\s a)ntista/ntas ma/xh| nikh/santes th
 po/lin e)/sxon . 8.106.1: th
 . . . ni/khn tau/thn . . . e)/sxon , They gained this victory.
AR. Ran. 1035: timh\n kai\ kle/os e)/sxen.
PIND. O. 2.10: i(ero\n e)/sxon oi)/khma potamou=. P. 1.65: e)/sxon d' *)amu/klas o)/lbioi. 3.24: e)/sxe toiau/tan mega/lan a)va/tan (cf. HOM. Il. 16.685: me/g' a)a/sqh).

p.hi: So with the moods and verbals:

div2.p: h(gou/menoi, ei) tau/thn (sc. th\n h(mete/ran po/lin) sxoi=en, r(a|di/ws kai\ ta)=lla e(/cein, THUC.6.33.2. th\n e)pwnumi/an . . . sxei=n, Ibid. 1.9.2. tw=| . . . sxo/nti gunai=ka =gh/manti, Ibid. 2.29.3; Who took to wife.

p.hi: Aorist of actions of long duration.

div2.p: The aorist is often used for rapid, individual action. But it is rather the tense of momentum than the tense of momentary action. No matter how long the action, it may be represented by the aorist, and it must be represented by the aorist when it is summed up. With definite numbers the aorist is the rule except as set forth in sections 208-10. (Complexive Aorist.)
*eu)kth/mwn . . . e)bi/w e)/th e(\c kai\ e)nenh/konta, ISAE. 6.18; Euctemon lived ninety-six years.
LYCURG.72: e)nenh/konta . . . e)/th tw=n *(ellh/nwn h(gemo/nes kate/sthsan.
DEM.38.12: tou/twn . . . e)pi/tropos . . . e)ge/neq' e(kkai/dek) e)/th, Of these he was (not became) guardian sixteen years.
ISAE. 6.18 (see above).
LYS.12.4: e)/th de\ tria/konta w)/|khse .
ANDOC.3.4: h(mi=n ei)rh/nh e)ge/neto . . . e)/th penth/konta, kai\ e)nemei/namen a)mfo/teroi tau/tais tai=s spondai=s e)/th triakai/deka.
THUC.2.2: te/ssara me\n ga\r kai\ de/ka e)/th e)ne/meinan ai( triakontou/teis spondai/. 4.6.2: h(me/ras . . . pentekai/deka e)/meinan e)n th=| *)attikh=| , They remained fifteen days in Attica.
HDT.2.157: *yammh/tixos . . . e)basi/leuse *ai)gu/ptou te/ssera kai\ penth/konta e)/tea.
AR. Pl. 846: ou)/k, a)ll' e)nerri/gws) e)/th triakai/deka.
HOM. Il. 6.174: e)nnh=mar cei/nisse (209).
LYCURG.58: e(\c e)/th sunexw_s a)podhmh/sas, Having been abroad for six years continuously.
LYS.24.9: deka/kis a)\n e(/loito xorhgh=sai ma=llon h)\ a)ntidou=nai a(/pac .
PLATO, Legg. 955A: deqh=nai . . . e)niauto/n, To be put in jail a year.
HDT.1.7: a)/rcantes . . . e)/tea pe/nte te kai\ pentako/sia. 1.16. 25.
ANACR. 8: e)/tea penth/konta/ te kai\ e(kato\n . . . basileu=sai.
HOM. Il. 6.217: e)ei/kosin h)/mat' e)ru/cas .
As the aorist is used of one, so it is used of none. Total negation is expressed by the aorist, as resistance to pressure is expressed by the imperfect (216).

ou)x ei(=lon, They did not take; ou)x h(/|roun, They could not take. ou)k e)de/canto, They did not receive; ou)k e)de/xonto, They would not receive. oi( me\n ou)k h)=lqon, oi( d' e)lqo/ntes ou)de\n e)poi/oun, DEM.18.151; Some did not come; some, when they did come, would not do anything.

LYS.3.14: ou)dei\s ou)/te katea/gh th
 kefalh
 ou)/te a)/llo kako
 ou)de
 e)/laben .
PLATO, Gorg. 471B: ou/ meteme/lhsen au)tw=|.
XEN. Conv. 1.14: ou)k e)ki/nhse ge/lwta.
AR. Ach. 34-6: ou)depw/pot' ei)=pen (sc. o( dh=mos), a)/nqrakas pri/w, | . . . | a)ll' au)to\s e)/fere pa/nta.
AESCHYL. Pers. 179: ou)/ti pw toio/nd' e)narge\s ei)do/mhn.
PIND. O. 1.47: ou)de\ matri\ polla\ maio/menoi fw=tes a)/gagon.
HOM. Il. 3.239-40: h)\ ou)x e(spe/sqhn *lakedai/monos e)c e)rateinh=s, | h)\ deu/rw me\n e(/ponto kte(.
The same principle applies to the moods. The change of tense from present to aorist is often to be accounted for by a change from positive to negative, and vice versa.
mhde\n a(martei=n e)sti qew=n kai\ pa/nta katorqou=n, Epigr.ap. DEM.18.289; To make no blunder and do all things right, (that) is (the province) of the gods (alone).
DEM. (Epigr. ap.), 18.289 (see above).
ISOC.4.11: w(/sper . . . to\n . . . a)kribw=s e)pista/menon le/gein a(plw=s ou)k a)\n duna/menon ei)pei=n.
ANTIPHON, 1.6: e)cousi/a h)=n safw=s ei)de/nai . . . ou)k h)=n puqe/sqai.

PLATO , Alc. II, 143 B: o(/per ou)=n ou)dei\s a)
 oi)hqei/h, a)lla\ tou=to/ ge pa=s a)
 oi)/oito i(kano\s ei)=nai. Ion, 531 B: ei) de\ su\ h)=sqa ma/ntis, ou)k, ei)/per peri\ tw=n o(moi/ws legome/nwn oi(=o/s t' h)=sqa e)chgh/sasqai (= ou)x oi(=o/s t' ei)= e)chgh/sasqai), kai\ peri\ tw=n diafo/rws legome/nwn h)pi/stw a)
 e)chgei=sqai;
XEN. An. 2.4.6: a)du/naton diabh=nai.
THUC.1.70.2: ta\ u(pa/rxonta/ te sw/|zein kai\ e)pignw=nai mhde/n.
AR. Lys. 129: ou)k a)\n poih)saimi (no metrical necessity).
AESCHYL. P.V. 63: plh\n tou=d' a)\n ou)dei\s e)ndi/kws me/myaito/ moi (no metrical necessity).
PIND. N. 8.44-5: to\ d' au)=tis tea\n yuxa\n komi/cai | ou)/ moi dunato/n (no metrical necessity).
When the negative is the equivalent of the positive present, the present is more frequently used in both members.
qa/rsee, *gu/gh, kai\ mh\ fobeu=, HDT.1.9; Be of good courage, Gyges, and be not afraid. a)posterei=n kai\ mh\ a)podido/nai, DEM. [35]DEM., 42.
DEM. [35]DEM., 42(see above).
AESCHIN.2.59: parei=nai kai\ mh\ a)podhmei=n.
HDT.1.9(see above).
HOM. Od. 4.825: qa/rsei, mhde/ ti pa/gxu meta\ fresi\ dei/diqi li/hn.
The aorist is very often used where we should expect the perfect.

1. Many verbs form no perfect. So many of the liquid verbs. The aorist is next of kin. In later Greek many mechanical perfects have been formed from the desire of analogy. See Curtius, Verbum II, 211.

p.quote: a)lla\ *qettali/a pw=s e)/xei; ou)xi\ ta\s politei/as kai\ ta\s po/leis au)tw=n parh/|rhtai, kai\ tetrarxi/as kate/sthsen, HAL., De admir. vi, 54 (R. vi, p. 1120), in quoting this passage, gives kaqe/staken, a characteristic variant. i(/na mh\ mo/non kata\ po/leis, a)lla\ kai\ kat' e)/qnh douleu/wsin;

div2.p: DEM.9.26(see above).

ISOC.5.19-21: ou)k e)la/ttw th\n basilei/an pepoi/hken a)ll' eu)xh=s a)/cia diape/praktai. ti/ ga\r e)lle/loipen; ou) . . . pepoi/hken . . . prosh=ktai . . . pepoi/hken … kate/straptai . . . ei)/lhfen . . . ge/gonen; a(pa/shs de\ th=s *qra/|khs ou(\s h)boulh/qh despo/tas kate/sthsen; (A solitary aorist after a long string of perfects.)
AR. Av. 301: ti/ fh/|s; ti/s glau=k' *)aqh/naz' h)/gage; (No classic perfect.)
AESCHYL. P. V. 28: toiau=t' e)phu/rou (no perfect) tou= filanqrw/pou tro/pou .
PIND. O. 10.7-8: o( me/llwn xro/nos | e)mo\n katai/sxune baqu\ xre/os (see note ad loc.).

HOM. Il. 5.127-8: a)xlu
 d' au)= toi a)p) o)fqalmw_n e(/lon, h(\ pri
 e)ph=en, | o)/fr' eu)= gignw/skh|s h)me
 qeo
 h)de\ kai\ a)/ndra (h(/|rhka is not found in Homer).
2. When the perfect is used as a present, the aorist may take a perfect translation.A. J. P. iv (1883), 429, note.
polla/kis e)qau/masa, XEN. Mem. 1.1.1; I have often wondered. e)/kthso . . . au)to\s ta/ per au)to\s e)kth/sao, HDT.7.29; Keep thyself what thyself hast made.
LYS.12.3: polla/kis ei)s pollh\n a)qumi/an kate/sthn, mh\ . . . poih/swmai .
HDT.4.97: ou) ga\r e)/deisa/ kw mh\ e(sswqe/wmen u(po\ *skuqe/wn ma/xh|. 7.29 (see above).
EUR. Alc. 541: teqna=sin oi( qano/ntes: a)ll' i)/q) ei)s do/mous, Once dead, the dead stay dead. Get thee within. fr. 507: ti/ tou\s qano/ntas ou)k e)a=|s teqnhke/nai;
AESCHYL. Cho. 504: ou(/tw ga\r ou) te/qnhkas ou)de/ per qanw/n, Thus (shalt thou show) thou art not dead though thou hast died.
HOM. Od. 1.166-8: nu=n d' o( me\n w(\s a)po/lwle . . . tou= d' w)/leto no/stimon h)=mar.
Il. 13.623-4: ou)de/ ti . . . e)ddei/sate. 772-3: nu=n w)/leto pa=sa kat' a)/krhs *)/ilios ai)peinh/.
3. The aorist is used from affinity to the negative.
tw=n oi)ketw=n ou)de/na kate/lipen, a)ll' a(/pantas pe/prake, AESCHIN.1.99; Not a servant has he left (did he leave), but he has sold them all (they are all sold).
AESCHIN.1.99(see above).
ISOC.3.35: fanh/somai ga\r ou)de/na me\n pw)pot' a)dikh/sas, plei/ous de\ . . . tw=n politw=n . . . eu)= pepoihkw\s . . . h)\ su/mpantes oi( pro\ e)mou= basileu/santes.
4. Other examples:

ISOC.8.19: o( me\n toi/nun po/lemos a(pa/ntwn h(ma=s tw=n ei)rhme/nwn a)peste/rhken: kai\ ga\r peneste/rous e)poi/hse kai\ pollou\s kindu/nous u(pome/nein h)na/gkase kai\ pro\s tou\s *(/ellhnas diabe/blhke kai\ pa/ntas tro/pous tetalaipw/rhken h(ma=s.

HOM, Il. 4.243-6: ti/fq' ou(/tws e)/sthte teqhpo/tes h)u/te nebroi/; | ai(/ t' . . . | e(sta=s), . . . | w(\s u(mei=s e)/sthte teqhpo/tes ou)de\ ma/xesqe (e)/sthte is here used instead of a perfect in a present sense).

This is especially important in the matter of sequence. See LYS. 12.3 (249), HDT.4.97(249), and HOM. Il. 5.127-8 (248), where the aorist equals the perfect and naturally takes the sequence of the principal tenses.A. J. P. iv (1883), 429, note.
We often translate the aorist by a pluperfect for the sake of clearness.
toi=s i)di/ois xrh/sesqai e)/fh, a(\ o( path\r au)tw=| e)/dwken, XEN. Hell. 1.5.3; He said that he would use his own means, which his father had given him.
XEN. Hell. 1.5.3 (see above). 7.2.19: w(s de\ th\n nu/kta h)gru/pnhsan, e)ka/qeudon me/xri po/rrw th=s h(me/ras, As they had been awake all night, they slept until far into the day.
THUC.7.1.3: ta\s ga\r nau=s a)nei/lkusan e)n *(ime/ra|, The ships they had beached in Himera.
HDT.4.146: ai( de\ e)pei/te e)sh=lqon, poie/ousi toia/de. 147: deino\n poieu/menos a)/rxesqai u(p' a)/llwn e)pei/te e)geu/sato a)rxh=s.
For other examples, see Temporal Sentences.

For the difference of the aorist and the pluperfect, compare HDT.3.25: pri\n de\ th=s o(dou= to\ pe/mpton me/ros dielhluqe/nai th\n stratih/n, au)ti/ka pa/nta au)tou\s ta\ ei)=xon siti/wn e)xo/mena e)peleloi/pee, meta\ de\ ta\ siti/a kai\ ta\ u(pozu/gia e)pe/lipe katesqio/mena, Before they HAD completed the fifth part of the journey, the provisions HAD entirely failed them, and after their provisions their beasts of burden FAILED them.

The universal present may be represented by the aorist. The principle is that of the generic article. A model individual is made to represent a class. This is called the gnomic aorist, because it is used in maxims, sentences, proverbs (gnw=mai), which delight in concrete illustrations. The gnomic aorist interchanges freely with the present, but does not thereby lose its peculiar effect.See note on PIND. P. 8.15.

r(w/mh . . . meta\ me\n fronh/sews w)fe/lhsen, a)/neu de\ tau/ths plei/w tou\s e)/xontas e)/blaye, ISOC. [1]ISOC., 6; Strength with judgment does good, without it does greater harm to those that possess it.

DEM.2.9: o(/tan me\n ga\r u(p' eu)noi/as ta\ pra/gmata susth=|, . . . sumponei=n … e)qe/lousin a(/nqrwpoi: o(/tan d' e)k pleoneci/as kai\ ponhri/as tis w(/sper ou(=tos i)sxu/sh|, h( prw/th pro/fasis kai\ mikro\n ptai=sma pa/nt' a)nexai/tisen kai\ die/lusen. Ibid. 10. 21. 5.12.
ISOC.1.6(see above). 5.38: e)ph\n de\ kakw=s a)llh/lous diaqw=sin, ou)deno\s dialu/ontos au)toi\ die/sthsan.

PLATO, Legg. 720D: o( de\ e)leu/qeros (sc. i)atro/s) . . . dida/skei to
 a)sqenou=nta au)to/n, kai\ ou) pro/teron e)pe/tace pri
 a)/n th| cumpei/sh|, The physician who is free (and not a slave) instructs the patient himself and does not give a prescription until he in some way succeeds in convincing him. Phaedo 73 D: oi( e)rastai/, o(/tan i)/dwsi lu/ran . . . h)\ a)/llo ti oi(=s ta\ paidika\ au)tw=n ei)/wqe xrh=sqai, pa/sxousi tou=to: e)/gnwsa/n te th
 lu/ran kai\ e)n th=| dianoi/a| e)/labon to\ ei)=dos tou= paido/s, ou(= h)=n h( lu/ra.

HDT.7.10, e): ou(/tw de\ kai\ strato\s pollo\s u(po\ o)li/gou diafqei/retai kata\ toio/nde. e)pea/n sfi o( qeo\s fqonh/sas fo/bon e)mba/lh| h)\ bronth/n, di) w)=n e)fqa/rhsan a)naci/ws e(wutw=n (a good example of general principle and particular illustration).
COM. Men.4.354.495: tu/xh te/xnhn w)/rqwsen, ou) te/xnh tu/xhn.

PIND. O. 4.4: cei/nwn d' eu)= prasso/ntwn, e)/sanan au)ti/k) a)ggeli/an poti\ glukei=an e)sloi). O. 7.30-1: ai( de\ frenw=n taraxai\ pare/plagcan kai\ sofo/n. fr. 225: o(po/tan qeo\s a)ndri\ xa/rma pe/myh|, pa/ros me/lainan kradi/an e)stufe/licen . . .
SIMON. C. 65: o( d' au)= qa/natos ki/xe kai\ to\n fugo/maxon.

THEOGN. 661-6: kai\ e)k kakou= e)sqlo
 e)/gento, | kai\ kako
 e)c a)gaqou=: kai/ te penixro\s a)nh | ai)=ya ma/l' e)plou/thse: kai\ o(\s ma/la polla\ pe/patai, | e)capi/nhs pa/nt' ou)=n w)/lese nukti\ mih=|. | kai\ sw/frwn h(/marte, kai\ a)/froni polla/ki do/ca | e(/speto, kai\ timh=s kai\ kako\s w)
 e)/laxen.
TYRT.12.20-2: ou(=tos a)nh\r a)gaqo\s gi/gnetai e)n pole/mw|: | ai)=ya de\ dusmene/wn a)ndrw=n e)/treye fa/laggas | trhxei/as, spoudh=| t' e)/sxeqe ku=ma ma/xhs.

HES. Theog. 436: paragi/gnetai h)d' o)ni/nhsi, but 442-3: r(h|idi/ws a)/grhn kudrh\ qeo\s w)/pase pollh/n, | r(ei=a d' a)fei/leto fainome/nhn, e)qe/lousa/ ge qumw=|. 447: e)c o)li/gwn bria/ei, ka)k pollw=n mei/ona qh=ken. (The end of the verse is more than a metrical shift; it is a swoop.)
HOM. Il. 4.442-3: h(/ t' o)li/gh me\n prw=ta koru/ssetai, au)ta\r e)/peita | ou)ranw=| e)sth/rice ka/rh kai\ e)pi\ xqoni\ bai/nei.
Ultimately akin to the gnomic aorist is the aorist of comparison which is often used in poetry, the concrete example being more vivid and striking.

dei= dh\ pa/ntas, w(/sper oi( i)atroi/, o(/tan karki/non . . . i)/dwsin, a)pe/kansan h)\ o(/lws a)pe/koyan, ou(/tw tou=to to\ qhri/on u(ma=s e)cori/sai kte(., DEM.25.95; As physicions, when they see a cancer, burn it off or cut it off bodily, so ought you all to landdamn this monster.

SOLON, 13.18-25: w(/st' a)/nemos nefe/las ai)=ya dieske/dasen | h)rino/s, o(\s . . . gh=n kata\ purofo/ron | dh|w/sas kala\ e)/rga, qew=n e(/dos ai)pu\n i(ka/nei | ou)rano/n, ai)qri/hn d' au)=tis e)/qhken i)dei=n | . . . | toiau/th *zhno\s pe/letai ti/sis.

HOM. Od. 4.335-40: w(s d' o(po/t' e)n culo/xw| e)/lafos krateroi=o le/ontos | nebrou\s koimh/sasa vehgene/as galaqhnou\s | knhmou\s e)cere/h|si kai\ a)/gkea poih/enta | boskome/nh, o( d' e)/peita e(h\n ei)sh/luqen eu)nh/n, | a)mfote/roisi de\ toi=sin a)eike/a po/tmon e)fh=ken: | w(\s *)oduseu\s kei/noisin a)eike/a po/tmon e)fh/sei.
Il. 3.23-28: w(/s te le/wn e)xa/rh mega/lw| e)pi\ sw/mati ku/rsas, | . . . w(\s e)xa/rh *mene/laos *)ale/candron qeoeidh= | o)fqalmoi=sin i)dw/n.
The so-called gnomic perfect and gnomic future correspond to English uses. The gnomic future is based on expectation, the gnomic perfect on experience.
Perfect:
polloi\ . . . h)/dh dou=loi . . . sesw/kasi despo/tas, PLATO, Legg. 776D-E; Many slaves ere now have saved masters.
ANDOC. [4]. 19: o(/stis de\ u(perora=| tau=ta, th\n megi/sthn fulakh\n a)nh/|rhke th=s po/lews, Whoso overlooks this, has taken away the greatest safeguard of the state.
PLATO, Legg. 776D-E (see above).
HDT.2.6: o(/soi me\n ga\r gewpei=nai/ ei)si a)nqrw/pwn, o)rguih=|si memetrh/kasi th\n xw/rhn, o(/soi de\ h(=sson gewpei=nai, stadi/oisi, kte(.

AR. Vesp. 493-5: h)
 me
 w)nh=tai/ tis o)rfw/s, membra/das de\ mh\ qe/lh|, | eu)qe/ws ei)/rhx' o( pwlw=n plhsi/on ta\s membra/das: | ou(=tos o)ywnei=n e)/oix' a(/nqrwpos e)pi\ turanni/di. Pl. 567-9: ske/yai . . . tou\s r(h/toras, w(s o(po/tan me
 | w)=si pe/nhtes, peri\ to
 dh=mon . . . ei)si\ di/kaioi, plouth/santes d' a)po\ tw=n koinw=n paraxrh=m' a)/dikoi gege/nhntai.
EUR. fr. 1028: o(/stis ne/os w)\n mousw=n a)melei=, | to/n te parelqo/nt' a)po/lwle xro/non | kai\ to\n me/llonta te/qnhken.
PIND. O. 1.54: a)ke/rdeia le/logxen qamina\ kakago/rous. P. 3.54: ke/rdei kai\ sofi/a de/detai.
THEOGN. 109-10: a)/plhston ga\r e)/xousi kakoi\ no/on: h)\n d' e(\n a(ma/rth|s, | tw=n pro/sqen pa/ntwn e)kke/xutai filo/ths.
SOLON, 13.27-8: ai)ei\ d' ou)/ e( le/lhqe diampere/s, o(/stis a)litro\n | qumo\n e)/xh|, pa/ntws d' e)s te/los e)cefa/nh.
TYRT.11.14: tressa/ntwn d' a)ndrw=n pa=s) a)po/lwl) a)reth/.

HOM. Il. 5.531-2: ai)dome/nwn d' a)ndrw=n ple/ones so/oi h)e\ pe/fantai: | feugo/ntwn d' ou)/t' a)\r kle/os o)/rnutai ou)/te tis a)lkh/. 15.139-40: h)/dh ga/r tis tou= ge bi/hn kai\ xei=ras a)mei/nwn | h)\ pe/fat' h)\ kai\ e)/peita pefh/setai.
Future:
ou)de\ a)/llou ou)deno\s e)myu/xou kefalh=s geu/setai *ai)gupti/wn ou)dei/s, HDT.2.39: No Egyptian (none of the E.) tastes (will taste) of the head of this or any other animal.

HDT.1.173: ei)rome/nou de\ e(te/rou to
 plhsi/on ti/s ei)/h, katale/cei e(wuto
 mhtro/qen. 2.5: katei\s katapeirhthri/hn phlo/n te a)noi/seis kai\ e)n e(/ndeka o)rguih=|si e)/seai (Traveller's Future). 2.39 (see above). 41: tw=n ei(/neka ou)/te a)nh *ai)gu/ptios ou)/te gunh\ a)/ndra *(/ellhna filh/seie a)
 tw=| sto/mati, ou)de\ maxai/rh| a)ndro\s *(/ellhnos xrh/setai . . . ou)de\ kre/ws kaqarou= boo\s diatetmhme/nou *(ellhnikh=| maxai/rh| geu/setai (fut. parallel with opt. and a)/n).
SOLON, 13.55-6: ta\ de\ mo/rsima pa/ntws | ou)/te tis oi)wno\s r(u/setai ou)/q' i(era/.
But when the aorist has a temporal adverb or a negative or a numeral with it, it is best referred to the same class with the English perfect of experience (empirical aorist).
polla/kis . . . despo/tai o)rgizo/menoi mei/zw kaka\ e)/paqon h)\ e)poi/hsan, XEN. Hell. 5.3.7 : Often have masters suffered from anger greater evils than they have inflicted.
LYCURG.79: tou\s me\n ga\r a)nqrw/pous polloi\ h)/dh e)capath/santes kai\ dialaqo/ntes ou) mo/non tw=n paro/ntwn kindu/nwn a)pelu/qhsan a)lla\ kte(.
PLATO, Phaedr. 234B: tou\s me\n e)rw=ntas oi( fi/loi nouqetou=sin . . . toi=s de\ mh\ e)rw=sin ou)dei\s pw/pote tw=n oi)kei/wn e)me/myato.

XEN. Hell. 5.3.7 (see above). Oec. 5.18: kai\ pro/bata d' e)ni/ote ka/llista teqramme/na no/sos e)lqou=sa ka/kista a)pw/lesen. Cf. [R. A.] 2.20: o(/stis de\ mh\ w)\n tou= dh/mou ei(/leto e)n dhmokratoume/nh| po/lei oi)kei=n ma=llon h)\ e)n o)ligarxoume/nh|, a)dikei=n paresk eua/sato kai\ e)/gnw o(/ti kte(.
HDT.2.68: glw=ssan de\ mou=non qhri/wn ou)k e)/fuse. 3.53: polloi\ de\ h)/dh ta\ mhtrw/ia dizh/menoi ta\ patrw/ia a)pe/balon.
COM. Men. 4.346.205: h( glw=ssa pollou\s ei)s o)/leqron h)/gagen.
EUR. fr. 360.28-9: ta\ mhte/rwn de\ da/kru) o(/tan pe/mph| te/kna, | pollou\s e)qh/lun' ei)s ma/xhn o(rmwme/nous.

PIND. O. 1.31-3: xa/ris d', a(/per a(/panta teu/xei ta\ mei/lixa qnatoi=s, | . . . kai\ a)/piston e)mh/sato pisto\n | e)/mmenai to\ polla/kis. N. 11.39-41: e)n sxerw=| d' ou)/t' w)=n me/lainai karpo\n e)/dwkan a)/rourai, | de/ndrea/ t' ou)k e)qe/lei pa/sais e)te/wn pero/dois | a)/nqos eu)w=des fe/rein.

THEOGN. 137-8: polla/ki ga\r doke/wn qh/sein kako/n, e)sqlo\n e)/qhken: | kai/ te dokw=n qh/sein e)sqlo/n, e)/qhke kako/n. 605: pollw=| toi ple/onas limou= ko/ros w)/lesen h)/dh. 639-640: polla/ki par do/can te kai\ e)lpi/da gi/netai eu)= r(ei=n | e)/rg' a)ndrw=n, boulai=s d' ou)k e)pe/gento te/los.
HES. O. et D. 240-247: polla/ki . . . a)phu/ra, . . . e)ph/gage . . . a)pofqinu/qousi . . . ti/ktousin, minu/qousi . . . a)pw/lesen . . . a)poai/nutai.
HOM. Il. 2.117-8: o(\s dh\ polla/wn poli/wn kate/luse ka/rhna | h)d' e)/ti kai\ lu/sei. (This example is very instructive as to the conception of the empirical aorist.)
From this gnomic use of the aorist arises its use in general descriptions, in which the aorist is designedly employed to express concentrated action.

ai( me\n ga\r a)qa/natoi kalou/menai (sc. yuxai/), h(ni/k' a)\n pro\s a)/krw| ge/nwntai, . . . e)/sthsan, PLATO, Phaedr. 247B-C; The souls called immortal, when they get in front of the top, stop (short).

DEM. [35]DEM., 1-2: ou(=toi ga\r deino/tatoi me/n ei)si danei/sasqai xrh/mat' e)n tw=| e)mpori/w|, e)peida\n de\ la/bwsi . . ., eu)qu\s e)pela/qonto . . . a)ll) a)nti\ tou= a)podou=nai sofi/smata eu(ri/skousi . . . kai\ ei)si\ ponhro/tatoi a)nqrw/pwn.
PLATO , Phaedr. 245-56. Often in this celebrated description, e.g. 247 B-C (see above).

HDT.2.47: h)/n tis yau/sh| au)tw=n (sc. *ai)gupti/wn) pariw
 u(o/s, au)toi=si toi=si i(mati/oisi a)p' w)=n e)/baye e(wuto
 ba\s e)pi\ to
 potamo/n. 87: e)pea
 tou\s klusth=ras plh/swntai tou= a)po\ ke/drou a)lei/fatos ginome/nou, e)n w)=n e)/plhsanNotice the tmesis which heightens the effect and helps to prove the purposefulness of the aorist. tou= nekrou= th
 koili/hn. 3.82: e)s e)/xqea mega/la a)llh/loisi a)pikne/ontai, e)c w(=n sta/sies e)lli/nontai, e)k de\ tw=n stasi/wn fo/nos: e)k de\ tou= fo/nou a)pe/bh e)s mounarxi/hn.

COM. Apollodor. 4.455: ei)s oi)ki/an o(/tan tis ei)si/h| fi/lou, | e)/stin qewrei=n, *nikofw=n, th\n tou= fi/lou | eu)/noian eu)qu\s ei)sio/nta ta\s qu/ras. | o( qurwro\s i(laro\s prw=to/n e)stin, h( ku/wn | e)/shne kai\ prosh=lq), u(panth/sas de/ tis | di/fron eu)qe/ws e)/qhke, ka)\n mhdei\s le/gh| | mhde/n.
PIND. O. 2.63-4: qano/ntwn me\n e)nqa/d' au)ti/k) a)pa/lamnoi fre/nes | poina\s e)/tisan.
SOLON, 13.53: a)/llon ma/ntin e)/qhken a)/nac e(ka/ergos *)apo/llwn.
In passionate and impatient questions the aorist is used of things to be despatched at once.
ti/ ou)k au)to/ ge/ moi tou=to a)pekri/nw; PLATO, Gorg. 509E; Why don't you answer me this very point?
PLATO, Charm. 155A: a)lla\ ti/ ou)k e)pe/deica/s moi to\n neani/an kale/sas deu=ro; Gorg. 509 E (see above). So elsewhere.
XEN. Cyr. 2.1.4: ti/ ou)=n . . . ou) kai\ th\n du/namin e)/leca/s moi; Hiero, 1.3: ti/ ou)=n . . . ou)xi\ kai\ su\ . . . u(pe/mnhsa/s me;
HDT.9.48: ti/ dh\ ou) . . . e)maxesa/meqa;
AR. Vesp. 213: ti/ ou)k a)pekoimh/qhmen o(/son o(/son sti/lhn; Why don't we snatch a little nap, a wee wee nap?

In questions, the English language may also use the past tense, not so readily in such expressions as e)ph/|nesa, Thank you (literally I praised); e)memya/mhn, I blame; h(/sqhn, I am delighted (Dramatic Aorist).
h(/sqhn a(peilai=s, e)ge/lasa yolokompi/ais, AR. Eq. 696; I like your threats, I laugh at your fire-eating brags.
AR. Eq. 696 (see above).

EUR. Cycl. 266: a)pw/mos), w)= ka/lliston w)= *kuklw/pion. H. F. 1235: e)ph/|nes): eu)= dra/sas de/ s' ou)k a)nai/nomai. Or. 1672: kai\ le/ktr' e)ph/|nes', h(ni/k' a)\n didw=| path/r . fr. 282.13: e)memya/mhn de\ kai\ to\n *(ellh/nwn no/mon.
HOM. Il. 2.323: ti/pt' a)/new| e)ge/nesqe; 14.95: nu=n de/ seu w)nosa/mhn pa/gxu fre/nas, oi(=on e)/eipes.
The aorist may be used as a vision of the future.
a)pwlo/mhn a)/r), ei)/ me dh\ lei/yeis, gu/nai, EUR. Alc. 386; I am undone, if thou shalt leave me, wife.
EUR. Alc. 386 (see above). Med. 78: a)pwlo/mesq' a)/r), ei) kako\n prosoi/somen | ne/on palaiw=|.

HOM. Il. 9.412-5: ei) me/n k' au)=qi me/nwn *trw/wn po/lin a)mfima/xwmai, | w)/leto me/n moi no/stos, a)ta\r kle/os a)/fqiton e)/stai: | ei) de/ ken oi)/kad' i(/kwmai e)mh\n e)s patri/da gai=an, | w)/leto/ moi kle/os e)sqlo/n.

p.hi: Imperfect, aorist, and pluperfect side by side.

div2.p: How keenly the differences of the imperfect, aorist, and pluperfect might be felt, is best shown in those passages in which all three are used side by side.
e)gw\ me\n a)pedh/moun . . . e)teteleuth/kei d' o( path\r pa/lai, o(/te ou(=tos e)/ghme, DEM. [46]DEM., 21; I was abroad and my father had long been dead when this man got married.

DEM. [46]DEM., 21(see above). [56]DEM., 9: e)peidh\ o( *sikeliko\s kata/plous e)ge/neto kai\ ai( timai\ tou= si/tou e)p' e)/latton e)ba/dizon kai\ h( nau=s h( tou/twn a)nh=kto ei)s *ai)/gupton, eu)qe/ws ou(=tos a)poste/llei ktl..

LYS.12.53: e)peidh\ de\ ei)s to\n *peiraia= h)/lqomen kai\ ai( taraxai\ gegenhme/nai h)=san kai\ peri\ tw=n diallagw=n oi( lo/goi e)gi/gnonto, polla\s e(ka/teroi elpi/das ei)/xomen kte( . 13.5: diefqa/rhsan . . . e)gege/nhto . . . e)gi/gnonto .

HDT.1.80: w(s w)/sfranto ta/xista tw=n kamh/lwn oi( i(/ppoi kai\ ei)=don au)ta/s, o)pi/sw a)ne/strefon, die/fqarto/ (lay shattered) te tw=| *kroi/sw| h( e)lpi/s. 4.125: paraxqe/ntwn . . . tarassome/nwn . . . tetaragme/nous. 6.108: e)dedw/kesan . . . e)/dosan . . . e)di/dosan, They had given, they gave, they were for giving, offered. 7.193: oi( de\ ba/rbaroi, w(s e)pau/sato/ te o( a)/nemos kai\ to\ ku=ma e)/strwto, . . . e)/pleon para\ th\n h)/peiron, The barbarians, as the wind ceased and the waves had become calm, went sailing along the mainland.
HOM. Il. 7.464-5: w(\s oi( me\n toiau=ta pro\s a)llh/lous a)go/reuon. | du/seto d' h)e/lios, tete/lesto de\ e)/rgon *)axaiw=n.

div2.head: Future Tense
div2.p: The future denotes either continuance or attainment in the future, and is either shall or will.
e(/cw, I will or shall have, I will or shall get. a)/rcw, I will or shall be ruler, I will or shall become ruler.
LYCURG.81(Iusiur. ap.): ou) poih/somai peri\ plei/onos to\ zh=n th=s e)leuqeri/as, I will not value life more highly than freedom.
LYS. 1.36: ou)dei\s au)tw=n a(/yetai , No one will touch them.
PLATO, Apol. 29E: ou)k eu)qu\s a)fh/sw au)to\n ou)d' a)/peimi (will).
THUC.1.22.4: a)rkou/ntws e(/cei, It will (shall) suffice.
AR. Ach. 203: e)gw\ de\ feu/comai/ (will) ge tou\s *)axarne/as.
EUR. Bacch. 63: summetasxh/sw (will) xorw=n . fr. 176: ti/s ga\r petrai=on sko/pelon ou)ta/zwn dori\ | o)du/naisi dw/sei (will succeed in, etc.);
PIND. O. 1.37: se\ d' a)nti/a prote/rwn fqe/gcomai (will).
HOM. Od. 1.88: au)ta\r e)gw\n *)iqa/khnd' e)seleu/somai.
Il. 1.29: th\n d' e)gw\ ou) lu/sw.

Owing to this indefiniteness of the future in regard to continuance and attainment, the Greek language has a tendency to use other forms of greater temporal exactness, such as the optative with a)/n and a)/n with the subjunctive. The Greek is very rich in expressions for the future.

The future was originally a mood, and this original modal force is regularly retained in dependent clauses, with the exception of the identifying relative, where it serves to describe a definite person or thing. In the principal clauses, this modal force is more or less effaced, just as the force of the English auxiliaries will and shall is more or less effaced according to the person employed. At the same time, it must be remembered that whenever we translate the Greek future by shall or will, we make an analysis for which the Greek language is not responsible. The periphrasis that comes nearest to the modal future is me/llw with the infinitive.
As the modal use of the future in dependent clauses is not treated in the following sections, a few illustrative examples are here given.

pai=des de/ moi ou)/pw ei)si
 oi(/ me qerapeu/sousi, LYS. 24.6 ; And I have as yet no children who shall nurse me (= to nurse me). ou)de\ (sc. pre/pei) toiau=ta le/gein e)c w(=n o( bi/os mhde
 e)pidw/sei, ISOC.4.189. deh/sei de\ kai\ tw=n a)/llwn boskhma/twn pampo/llwn, ei)/ tis au)ta\ e)/detai (is to eat them), PLATO, Rpb. 373C. kai\ mh
 a)ndrei=o/n ge (sc. dei= e(ka/teron ei)=nai), ei)/per eu)= maxei=tai (is to be a good fighter), Ibid. 375 A. (Here ei)/per . . . maxei=tai is parallel with e)a
 de/h| . . . diama/xesqai just preceding.)
On the Gnomic Future, see 257-8.
For examples of the Future in the Apodosis of an Ideal Condition, see Ideal Conditional Sentences.
The future indicative, like the subjunctive, may be used in questions which expect an imperative answer.
ei)/pwmen h)\ sigw=men; h)\ ti/ dra/somen; EUR. Ion, 758; Shall we speak out or hold our peace? What shall we do?
DEM.4.44: poi= dh\ prosormiou/meq(a); 8.37: ti/ e)rou=men h)\ ti/ fh/somen, w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi; e)gw\ me\n ga\r ou)x o(rw=.
PLATO, Protag. 331A: ti/ ou)=n, w)= *prwtago/ra, a)pokrinou/meqa au)tw=|; Ibid. B: ti/ au)tw=| a)pokrinou/meqa;
AR. Ach. 312: ei)=t' e)gw/ sou fei/somai;
EUR. Ion, 758 (see above).
PIND. O. 2.2: ti/na qeo/n, ti/n' h(/rwa, ti/na d' a)/ndra keladh/somen; (See B. L. G. ad loc.)
HOM. Il. 1.123: pw=s ga/r toi dw/sousi ge/ras mega/qumoi *)axaioi/;

The future is sometimes used where an imperative might be expected. It is not a milder or gentler imperative.So Aken: “Die ruhige Behauptung kann weit stärker sein.” See Hopkins, A. J. P. xiii (1892), 37. The N. T. su\ de\ o)/yei, “See thou to that,” seems to be an idiomatic colloquial expression rather than a Hebraism. The Latin use of the future as a familiar imperative, A. J. P. xviii (1897), 121, in the same class of words, lends strength to the imperative conception, which is denied by some scholars. A prediction may imply resistless power or cold indifference, compulsion or concession.

au)to\s gnw/sei, PLATO, Gorg. 505C; That is a matter for you to determine. o( . . . a)/ggelos . . . e)lqw\n e)kei=se w(=de le/cei, XEN. Cyr. 3.2.29; The messenger will go thither and hold the following discourse.

ISAE. 2.37: a)nagnw/setai. (The speaker before court uses of the clerk a)na/gnwqi, a)nagi/gnwske, a)nagnw/setai, rarely a)nagnw/tw.C. W. E. Miller, A. J. P. xiii (1892), 408.) 4.30: tou=ton . . . a)/llos, e)a/n tis bou/lhtai, timwrh/setai, Him another shall punish if he will.

PLATO, Gorg. 505C: au)to\s gnw/sei (Schol.: a)nti\ tou= ei)/ ti qe/leis, poi/ei: e)moi\ ga\r ou) me/lei). Phileb. 12 A: su\ de/, *prw/tarxe, au)to\s gnw/sei. Rpb. 432 C: kai\ e)moi\ fra/seis (so the best MS), And you will report to me. Theaet. 143 B: o( pai=s a)nagnw/setai (of a servant), but Phaedr. 262 D: a)na/gnwqi (to a friend).

XEN. An. 1.3.5: kai\ ou)/pote e)rei= ou)dei/s, And no one shall ever say. Cyr. 3.2.29 (see above). 3.3.3: u(mei=s e)me\ ou) poih/sete misqou= periio/nta eu)ergetei=|n, a)lla\ su/, w)= gu/nai, e)/xousa tau=ta ta\ xrh/mata a(\ fe/reis a)/piqi, kte(., You are not to make of me a paid travelling philanthropist, etc.
AR. Nub. 1352: pa/ntws de\ tou=to dra/seis .
EUR. Med. 1320: le/g' ei)/ ti bou/lei, xeiri\ d' ou) yau/seis pote/ .
ION, Eleg. 2.7-10 (Bgk.4): pi/nwmen, pai/zwmen: i)/tw . . . o)rxei/sqw . . . a)/rxe . . . kei=nos . . . pi/etai (Meineke pie/tw).
SOPH. Ph. 843: ta/de men qeo\s o)/yetai.
HOM. Od. 1.123-4: au)ta\r e)/peita | dei/pnou passa/menos muqh/seai, o(/tteo/ se xrh/.

This “jussive” use of the future is denied for Homer by Paech.Joh. Paech, Ueber den Gebrauch des Indicativus Futuri als Modus iussivus bei Homer, Breslau, 1865. In many of the passages once cited, the so-called future has been shown to be an aorist imperative and others have been explained away.

p.hi: mh/ and the future indicative in prohibitions.

div2.p: The use of the future as an imperative with mh/ is rare and hardly sure. In Attic prose it rests on just two passages, both suspicious, both open to emendation, LYS.29.13 and DEM.23.117, on which see A. J. P. xv (1894), 117f. In XEN. Hell. 2.1.22: proei=pen w(s mhdei\s kinh/soito, w(s = o(/pws, and the oratio recta was o(/pws mhdei\s kinh/setai. In AR. Pl. 488, malako/n t' e)ndw/sete mhde/n belongs to the relative complex w(=| nikh/sete thndi/. In SOPH. Ai. 572-3, o(/pws precedes. In HOM. Il. 10.238, o)pa/sseai is subjunctive, and in Il. 13.47, saw/sete is imperative. The jussive future has ou).
On ou) mh/ with the Future, see Negatives.

p.hi: ou) with future indicative in questions as imperative.

div2.p: In questions, the future indicative with ou) is often used as an imperative.
DIN.1.18(see above).
DEM.4.44: ou)k e)mbhso/meq(a); 21.116: “ou)k a)poktenei=te; ou)k e)pi\ th\n oi)ki/an badiei=sqe; ou)xi\ sullh/yesqe;”
On ou) mh/ with the Future Indicative in questions, see Negatives.

In very common use is the periphrastic future with me/llw, I am thinking (compare the use of penser in French), I expect, I am about, I am (destined) to. As a verb of thinking, me/llw takes the typical future, but also the present, seldom the aorist and then to make a special point. Whatever difference there may have originally been between the present and the future, has been abraded. Sometimes there seems to be a conscious interval with the future, but the distinction vanishes and authors vary.
The imperfect of the me/llw-periphrastic may be called the future of the past, and it plays an important part in a large class of sentences.
me/llete th\n yh=fon oi)/sein, ANDOC.1.2; You are about to cast your vote.
ISAE. 7.30: pa/ntes ga\r oi( teleuth/sein me/llontes pro/noian poiou=ntai sfw=n au)tw=n.
LYS.3.32(215). 34 (215). 13.37 (215). 19.38: o(\ mh\ ge/noito, ei) mh/ ti me/llei me/ga a)gaqo\n e)/sesqai th=| po/lei .
ANDOC.1.2(see above). Ibid. 21: o(/pou [a)\n] e)/mellen au)to\s swqh/sesqai e(me/ te ou)k a)polei=n.
ANTIPHON, 6.36: r(a|di/ws e)/mellon a)pofeu/cesqai kai\ di/khn ou) dw/sein.
PLATO, Apol. 21B: me/llw . . . u(ma=s dida/cein. Crat. 418 B (215). Phaedr. 228 C (215).

HDT.2.43(215). 7.8, b): me/llw zeu/cas to
 *(ellh/sponton e)la=n strato
 . . . e)pi\ th
 *(ella/da.
AR. Thesm. 181: me/llousi/ m' ai( gunai=kes a)polei=n th/meron. Eccl. 597 (215).
SOPH. El. 379-80: me/llousi ga/r s), ei) tw=nde mh\ lh/ceis go/wn, | e)ntau=qa pe/myein e)/nqa kte(. O. R. 967 (215).
HES. Theog. 468-9: e)/melle . . . te/cesqai (215).
HOM. Od. 6.135-6: *)oduseu\s kou/rh|sin . . . e)/mellen | mi/cesqai gumno/s per e)w/n. 7.270 (215).
Il. 6.52-3 (215). 515-6: e)/mellen stre/yesq' e)k xw/rhs .

ou)=tos, ti/ dra/seis; tw=| pti/lw| me/lleis e)mei=n; AR. Ach. 587; Ho! fellow! What are you going to do? Are you going to give yourself a vomit with the feather? (Here the future and the periphrasis are parallel.)

LYS.13.88: me/llein le/gein . 19.23: me/llonta plei=n , On the point of sailing.
24.15: me/llwn a)lhqh= le/gein .
ANTIPHON, 1.15: a)dikei=sqai e)/mellen. Ibid. 16: ei)s *na/con plei=n e)/mellen.
PLATO , Phaedo 59 A: au)ti/ka . . . e)/melle teleuta=n. Phaedr. 242 B: e)/mellon . . . to\n potamo\n diabai/nein.
