AR. Ach. 493: a(/pasi me/lleis ei(=s le/gein ta)nanti/a (the future is not favored by the iambic metre). Eq. 267 (215).
EUR. fr. 459: ke/rdh toiau=ta xrh/ tina kta=sqai brotw=n, | e)f' oi(=si me/llei mh/poq) u(/steron ste/nein.
SOPH. Tr. 756-7: me/llonti d' au)tw=| . . . teu/xein sfaga\s | kh=ruc . . . i(/ket(o).
PIND. O. 8.63-4: a)/ndra . . . me/llonta poqeinota/tan do/can fe/rein (in prose to\n . . . oi)/sonta).
Il. 10.454-5: o( me/n min e)/melle . . . li/ssesqai.

p.hi: me/llw with the Present and the Future Infinitive:

div2.p: DEM.21.55: e)stefanw/meqa, o(moi/ws o(/ te me/llwn nika=n kai\ o( pa/ntwn u(/statos genh/sesqai.

PLATO, Conv. 198B: pw=s . . . ou) me/llw a)porei=n . . . me/llwn le/cein; Politic. 295 C: i)atro\n me/llonta . . . a)podhmei=n (on the point of going abroad) kai\ a)pe/sesqai tw=n qerapeuome/nwn suxno\n . . . xro/non (and expecting to be absent from his patients a long time).

tou=to toi/nun . . . h(mi=n poihte/on, ei) mh\ me/llomen e)pi\ tw=| te/lei kataisxu=nai to\n lo/gon, PLATO, Politic. 268D: This is what we must do, if we are not to bring dishonor on our discussion at the (very) last.
ANTIPHON, 1.14: e)pi\ pornei=on e)/melle katasth=sai (once out of 20 times).
PLATO, Politic. 268D (see above). Ibid. 291 C: ei) me/llomen i)dei=n e)nargw=s to\ zhtou/menon.

EUR. Ion, 760: ei)rh/setai/ toi kei) qanei=n me/llw diplh=| (282). Or. 292-3:
ei) mh/t' e)kei=nos a)nalabei=n e)/melle fw=s
e)gw) q' o( tlh/mwn toia/d' e)mplh/sein kaka/
(aorist and future side by side).
AESCHYL. P.V. 625: o(/per me/llw paqei=n.
PIND. O. 7.61: me/llen qe/men (215). 8.32: me/llontes . . . teu=cai. P. 9.52-3: me/lleis . . . e)nei=kai.
HES. Theog. 478: h)/melle teke/sqai, but ibid. 468-9: e)/melle . . . te/cesqai.
HOM. Il. 23.773: e)/mellon e)pai+/casqai. (So La Roche with the better MSS. Cauer reads e)pai+/cesqai.)
me/llw, I postpone, takes regularly the present infinitive (resistance to pressure), rarely the aorist infinitive.
e)/ti me/llomen a)mu/nesqai, THUC.6.10. 5; We are still delaying to punish.
THUC.1.86.2: tou\s cumma/xous . . . ou) perioyo/meqa a)dikoume/nous ou)de\ mellh/somen timwrei=n. 1.124.1 (278). 6.10.5 (see above).
EUR. Phoen. 299 (see 278).
mh\ me/llete *poteidaia/tais te polei=sqai timwri/an . . . kai\ tw=n a)/llwn metelqei=n th\n e)leuqeri/an (present and aorist), THUC.1.124.1.
THUC.1.124.1(see above).

EUR. Phoen. 299-300: ti/ me/lleis u(pw/rofa me/laqra pera=n, | qigei=n t' w)le/nais te/knou (present and aorist); [Rhes.] 673-4: ti/ me/llete | skhptou= )pio/ntos polemi/wn sw=sai bi/on; (So the MSS, but Nauck follows Elmsley in reading sw/|zein.)

div2.head: Future Perfect Tense
div2.p: The future perfect is the perfect transferred to the future.

The future perfect active is found chiefly in the periphrastic form, where it has the full perfect force. The simple form is found only in a few verbs in which the perfect is used as a present: teqnh/cw, I shall be dead; e(sth/cw, I shall stand.

a)\n tau=t' ei)dw=men, kai\ ta\ de/ont' e)so/meq' e)gnwko/tes kai\ lo/gwn matai/wn a)phllagme/noi, DEM.4.50.
pw=s ou)=n eu)/opka a)ntomwmokw\s e)/stai fa/skwn eu)= ei)de/nai; ANTIPHON, 1.8 . a)=r' ou)=n to\n a)ei\ xro/non memaqhkui=a e)/stai h( yuxh\ au)tou=; PLATO , Meno, 86 A (future ascertainment). teqnh/ceis, AR. Vesp. 654 ; You will be a dead man.
e(sth/cw par' au)to/n, Lys. 634 ; I will stand by his side.

Of more frequent use is the future perfect middle, which is chiefly used passively. The dramatists incline to the tense on account of its impatience of anything except entire fulfilment. Neither suddenness nor certainty lies in the form.
mastigw/setai, streblw/setai, dedh/setai, PLATO, Rpb. 361E; He shall be scourged, tortured, kept in prison (deqh/setai, shall be put in prison).

DEM.14.2: pa=s o( parw\n fo/bos lelu/setai , All the present fear will be finally dispelled.
19.74: tau=ta pepra/cesqai (sc. e)/fh) duoi=n h)\ triw=n h(merw=n .
ANTIPHON, 5.75: o(/mws d' ou)=n kekinduneu/setai.
PLATO, Rpb. 361E (see above). Theaet. 180 A: ka)\n tou/tou zhth=|s lo/gon labei=n, ti/ ei)/rhken, e(te/rw| peplh/cei kainw=s metwnomasme/nw|.
THUC.3.39.8: h(mi=n de\ . . . a)pokekinduneu/setai ta/ te xrh/mata kai\ ai( yuxai/.
HDT.6.9: ou)de/ sfi ou)/te ta\ i(ra\ ou)/te ta\ i)/dia e)mpeprh/setai.
AR. Eq. 1370-1: ou)dei\s kata\ spouda\s meteggrafh/setai, | a)ll' w(/sper h)=n to\ prw=ton e)ggegra/yetai (will stay enrolled). Pax, 246: w(s e)pitetri/yesq' au)ti/ka.

EUR. Bacch. 1313: nu=n d' e)k do/mwn a)/timos e)kbeblh/somai . Hippol.894: duoi=n de\ moi/rain qate/ra| peplh/cetai. Or. 271-2:
beblh/setai/ tis qew=n brothsi/a| xeri/
ei) mh\ )camei/yei xwri\s o)mma/twn e)mw=n
.

SOPH. Ai. 577: ta\ d' a)/lla teu/xh koi/n) e)moi\ teqa/yetai . Ibid. 1140-1:
*ME. e(/n soi fra/sw: to/nd' e)sti\n ou)xi\ qapte/on
*t*e*u. a)ll' a)ntakou/sh| tou=ton w(s teqa/yetai
.Metri causa cannot be invoked in any of the above examples from tragedy. See A. J. P. xvii (1896), 518.
ANACR.77: eu)=te/ moi leukai\ melai/nais a)namemi/contai tri/xes.
HOM. Il. 1.139: o( de/ ken kexolw/setai, o(/n ken i(/kwmai, and similarly 5.421; 762; and 23.543. 21.585: h)= t' e)/ti polla\ teteu/cetai a)/lge) e)p) au)th=|.

p.hi: Future perfect in an imperative sense.

div2.p: The future perfect, like the future, may be used in a quasi-imperative sense.
ta\ d' a)/lla teu/xh koi/n' e)moi\ teqa/yetai, SOPH. Ai. 577 ; My other arms shall in a common tomb with me lie buried (281).
DIN.1.10: ei)rh/setai ga\r a(\ gignw/skw, I must say what I think.
DEM. [44]DEM., 4: ei)rh/setai ga/r, It shall be said (the truth must out).
ISOC.7.76: ei)rh/setai ga\r ta)lhqe/s, and similarly 12.225; 15.177 and ibid. 243.
ANDOC.1.72: a)lla\ ga\r ta)lhqh= ei)rh/setai.
PLATO, Rpb. 457B: ka/llista ga\r dh\ tou=to kai\ le/getai kai\ lele/cetai o(/ti to\ me\n w)fe/limon kalo/n, to\ de\ blabero\n ai)sxro/n.
EUR. I. T. 1464: ou(= kai\ teqa/yh| katqanou=sa. Ion, 760: ei)rh/setai/ toi kei\ qanei=n me/llw diplh=|.
SOPH. Ai. 577 (see above). 1140-1 (see 281).

p.hi: Future perfect used as a future.

div2.p: Of course, when the perfect is predominantly present, the future perfect is a simple future and the middle may have an active meaning.
de\ d' a)/llh tis gunh\ kekth/setai, EUR. Alc. 181; But thee some other woman will possess. e(sth/cw par' au)to/n, AR. Lys. 634; I will stand by his side (280).
EUR. Alc. 181 (see above).
AR. Lys. 634 (see above).
HOM. Il. 5.238: to/nde d' e)gw\n e)pio/nta dede/comai o)ce/i douri/. 22.390: au)ta\r e)gw\ kai\ kei=qi fi/lou memnh/som' e(tai/rou.
The periphrastic future perfect may be middle.
e)n w(=| me/llei e)kei=nos *)/olunqon katastre/fesqai, su\ katestramme/nos e)/sei *qh/bas, XEN. Hell. 5.2.27; While he is thinking about overthrowing Olynthus, you will have overthrown Thebes.
ANDOC.1.72: pei/sas de/ (sc. u(ma=s), u(pe\r tw=n e)xqrw=n a)poleloghme/nos e)/somai.
XEN. Hell. 5.2.27 (see above).

div2.head: Periphrastic Tenses
div2.p: The Greek language has ample facilities for a large number of periphrastic tenses. With its many participles and its various auxiliaries, the possible combinations are almost inexhaustible, while the existing combinations show at once the resources and the moderation of the language. Few languages capable of e)/melle ou) to\ deu/teron diafugw\n e)/sesqai ( HDT.7.194), and of e)/melle . . . e)/sesqai dedwkw/s (PS.- DEM.52.24), would have shown such self-restraint.

Most common are the periphrases with the perfect participle, which has more of an adjectival character than the others. Theoretically these periphrases ought to emphasize the maintenance of the result.W. J. Alexander, A. J. P. iv (1883), 307-8. But it must be remembered that many middle and passive verbs regularly use the periphrasis in the third person plural, and that the periphrastic form is almost the only form employed in the subjunctive and optative,M. Beyer, de perfecti apud Herodotum usu syntactico, Vratislaviae, 1868. so that a certain indifference is bred thereby. e)fqarme/noi ei)si/ is the regular form, and not e)fqa/ratai, which is old-fashioned ( THUC.3.13.3). e)kpe\feugw\s ei)/hn is the rule, not e)kpefeugoi/hn (SOPH. O. R. 840). le/loipe becomes in oratio obliqua leloipw\s ei)/h (XEN. An. 1.2.21). Still, much depends on the position of the copula, much on the context and on the character of the verbs.

DEM.19.336: th
 a)/llws e)ntau=q' e)parei= th
 fwnh
 kai\ pefwnaskhkw\s e)/stai. [48]DEM., 16: e)/fh ei)=nai par' e(autw=| o(/son mh\ h)=n a)nhlwme/non.
ISOC.12.233: eu)qu\s . . . proeirhkw\s . . . h)=n au)toi=s e)f' a(\ sunelhluqo/tes h)=san, a)ne/gnwsto d' o( lo/gos, e)ph|nhme/nos d' h)=n kte(. (236).

PLATO, Conv. 191E: ma=llon pro\s ta\s gunai=kas tetramme/nai ei)si/. Euthyd. 280 C: te/ktwn ei) pareskeuasme/nos ei)/h . . . cu/la i(kana/, tektai/noito de\ mh/, e)/sq' o(/ ti w)feloi=t' a)
 a)po\ th=s kth/sews; Legg. 814 B: ou(/tws ai)sxrw=s ta\s gunai=kas ei)=nai teqramme/nas. Rpb. 601 D: pro\s h(
 a)
 e)/kaston h)=| pepoihme/non h)\ pefuko/s. PLAT. Soph. 218A: pa=si kexarisme/nos (= adj. gratus) e)/sei. (Compare Gorg. 502 B: e)a/n ti au)toi=s h(du\ . . . h)=| kai\ kexarisme/non.)
XEN. Hell. 1.1.11: puqo/menos de\ o(/ti ai( tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn nh=es e)c *)abu/dou a)nhgme/nai ei)=en ei)s *ku/zikon . . . h)=lqen ei)s *shsto/n.

AR. Pl. 867-8: polu\ ma=llon e)ni/ous e)sti\n e)colwlekw/s. | KAP. kai\ ti/na de/drake dh=ta tou=t(o); But Av. 655: e)/sesqon e)pterwme/nw, e)pterwme/nw is almost an adjective and Ran. 433: ce/nw ga/r e)smen a)rti/ws a)figme/nw, e)smen belongs to ce/nw.
SOPH. Ai. 740: ti/ d' e)sti\ xrei/as th=sd' u(pespanisme/non (= e)llipe/s);

HOM. Od. 2.187: to\ de\ kai\ tetelesme/non e)/stai, and so 17.229; 18.82; 19.487; Il. 1.212; 2.257; 8.401; 23.672. But Od. 5.89-90: tele/sai de/ me qumo\s a)/nwgen, | ei) du/namai tele/sai ge kai\ ei) tetelesme/non e)sti/n, where tetelesme/non = telesto/n = dunato\n gene/sqai (Paraphrastic), and so Il. 14.195-6; 18.426-7. Od. 8.454: to\ de/ ken tetelesme/non h)=en.
Il. 3.309: peprwme/non e)sti/n. 5.873: ai)ei/ toi r(i/gista qeoi\ tetlho/tes ei)me/n.
The force of the copula ei)mi/, however, revives under slight pressure. So under emphatic position or correlation.
h)=san e)/k te *ai)/nou bebohqhko/tes, THUC.4.28.4; They had actually come to their help from Aenos. h)=n . . . ou)de\n peponqw/s, XEN. An. 6.1.6.

Especially worthy of note is the periphrasis of the perfect participle with the optative ei)/hn and a)/n. This periphrasis gives the opinion of the speaker as to the future ascertainment of a completed action, which action may lie either in the past or in the future of the speaker.

ou)k a)/topon . . . a)\n pepoihko/tes u(mei=s ei)/hte, ei) . . . tou=ton a)fei/ht(e); DEM.19.71; Would you not proue to have done an absurd thing, if you were to acquit this fellow (future)? te/xnai o(/saiper sidh/rou de/ontai . . . h)fanisme/nai a)\n ei)=en, PLATO, Legg. 678E; All the arts that require the use of iron must have disappeared (past).

DEM.19.71(see above). 30.10: ou)k a)
 dia\ tou=to/ g' ei)=en ou)k eu)qu\s de dwko/tes. 39.15: ei)/ tis di/khn e)cou/lhs au)tw=| laxw
 mhde
 e)moi\ fai/h pro\s au(to
 ei)=nai, kuri/an de\ poihsa/menos e)ggra/yai, ti/ ma=llon a)
 ei)/h tou=ton h)\ e)/m' e)ggegrafw/s;
ISOC.12.130: ou)k e)/xw ti/nas e)pai/nous ei)pw\n a)ci/ous a)\n ei)/hn ei)rhkw\s th=s e)kei/nwn dianoi/as.
LYS.1.2: kai\ tau=ta ou)k a)\n ei)/h mo/non par' u(mi=n ou(/tws e)gnwsme/na, a)ll) e)n a(pa/sh| th=| *(ella/si . 31.4: ei)rhkw\s a)\n ei)/hn , (In that case) I should prove to have spoken.

PLATO, Charm. 157C: e(/rmaion . . . gegono\s a)
 ei)/h h( th=s kefalh=s a)sqe/neia tw=| neani/skw|, ei) a)nagkasqh/setai kai\ th
 dia/noian dia\ th
 kefalh
 belti/wn gene/sqai. Legg. 670 E. 678 E. 696 D. 753 E. 782 A. 800 A. 880 E. 892 A. 896 C. Ibid. D. 907 C: kalw=s h(mi=n ei)rhme/non a)
 ei)/h to\ prooi/mion, Our introduction must have been a good thing. Meno, 85 D. Phaedr. 262 D. 263 C.
XEN. Cyr. 1.2.13: e)peida\n . . . ta\ pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosin e)/th diatele/swsin, ei)/hsan . . . a)\n ou(=toi plei=o/n ti gegono/tes h)\ ta\ penth/konta e)/th a)po\ genea=s.
EUR. Hipp. 349: h(mei=s a)\n ei)=men qate/rw| kexrhme/noi (306).

p.hi: Perfect participle parallel with an adjective.

div2.p: The adjectival character of the perfect participle is not infrequently shown by parallelism with the adjective.
ou(/tws e)sti\n a)no/htos kai\ panta/pasin u(mw=n katapefronhkw/s, LYCURG.68.
LYCURG.68(see above).
LYS.14.2: ou) ga\r mikra\ ta\ a(marth/mata . . . a)ll' ou(/tw pepragme/na kai\ ei)s tosou=to kaki/as a)figme/na .

p.hi: Perfect participle as predicate of the participle of ei)mi/.

div2.p: Even the perfect participle, however, is seldom so purely adjectival as to suffer combination with the participle of ei)mi/.
ou)k ei)wqo\s o)/n, EUR. Hec. 358.
AR. Ran. 721: tou/toisin ou)=sin (where Meineke reads tou/toisi toi=sin) ou) kekibdhleume/nois.
EUR. Hec. 358 (see above).
On the periphrasis with the present participle see 191. To the examples with the present auxiliary, add the following with other tenses.
ISAE. 3.65: ei) h)=n gnhsi/a quga/thr e)kei/nw| kataleipome/nh. Ibid. 72: ei) h)=n guhsi/a quga/thr tw=| h(mete/rw| qei/w| kataleipome/nh.

ISOC.5.110: mi/an . . . pra=cin . . . h(/per h)=n prosh/kousa me
 kai\ pre/pousa . . ., to
 de\ kairo
 e)/xousa ma/lista su/mmetron, One action, which was suitable and becoming and admirably opportune.
LYS.1 3.39: metape/mpontai ei)s to\ desmwth/rion o( me\n a)delfh/n, o( de\ mhte/ra, o( de\ gunai=ka, o( d' h(/ tis h)=n e(ka/stw| au)tw=n prosh/kousa .
ANTIPHON, 2 g 3: a)rkou=sa h)=n. 5.18: h)=n tou=to sumfe/ron.
THUC.2.67.1: ou(= h)=n (there lay) stra/teuma tw=n *)aqhnai/wn poliorkou=n (not periphrastic). 3.2.2: a(\ metapempo/menoi h)=san (Cobet: metapepemme/noi).
PIND. P. 6.28-9: e)/gento kai\ pro/teron *)anti/loxos biata\s | no/hma tou=to fe/rwn (an upholder of this spirit).

p.hi: Present Participle parallel with an Adjective:

div2.p: r(a|qumo/tatoi e)/sesqe kai\ h(/kista e)pi\ toi=s deinoi=s o)rgizo/menoi, LYCURG.27; You will be most easy-going and least resentful of outrages.
LYCURG.27(see above).
DEM.3.25: sw/frones h)=san kai\ sfo/dr' e)n tw=| th=s politei/as h)/qei me/nontes. [35]DEM., 46: bdeluro/s ti/s e)sti kai\ u(perba/llwn a(/pantas a)nqrw/pous tw=| ponhro\s ei)=nai.
LYS.14.2: ou) ga\r mikra\ ta\ a(marth/mata ou)de\ suggnw/mhs a)/cia, ou)d' e)lpi/da pare/xonta w(s kte( .
PLATO , Alc. 11.138 D: ei)si/ tines . . . a)/frone/s te kai\ fro/nimoi, kai\ maino/menoi e(/teroi.

Periphrases with the aorist participle are rare. In most instances the aorist may be regarded as the short-hand of the perfect, or as a manner of characterizing adjective or quasi-substantive. Here and there, however, there seems to be an effort to evolve a more exact aoristic future.

h)=san de/ tines kai\ geno/menoi tw=| *niki/a| lo/goi pro/teron, THUC.4.54.3; Conferences had actually been held with Nikias even before. e)/frazon w(/s sfi qeo\s ei)/h fanei/s, HDT.3.27; They set forth how a god had actually appeared to them.
DEM. [52]DEM., 9: o( *lu/kwn tugxa/nei w)\n kai\ a)/pais kai\ klhrono/mon ou)de/na oi)/koi katalipw/n.See A. J. P. xii (1891), 79.

LYS.2. 13: ou)k ei)do/tes o(poi=oi/ tines a)/ndres e)/sontai geno/menoi (= e)peidh\ a)/ndres ge/nointo). 20. 1: oi( me\n (some)ga\r e)pibouleu/santes h)=san au)tw=n (h)=san au)tw=n is probably belonged to their number).
ANTIPHON, 2 g 8: ou(=tos a)\n kai\ ou)dei\s e(/teros a)poktei/nas au)to\n ei)/h, This man and no other must have been his murderer. (o( a)poktei/nas would be more natural.) Similarly 3 d 4 and 5.

PLATO, Legg. 961B-C: toiou=to/n ti/ pou lexqe
 h(mi=n h)=n e)n toi=s e)/mprosqen lo/gois; (Phileb. 64 B: w(=| mh\ mi/cwmen a)lh/qeian ou)k a)/n pote tou=to a)lhqw=s gi/gnoito ou)d' a)
 geno/menon ei)/h is not to be counted. ou)d' a)
 geno/menon ei)/h = ou)d' a)
 ei)/h ei) ge/noito. In like manner analyze Legg. 739 E.) Politic. 265 D: tau=t' e)/stw tau/th| lexqe/nta. PLAT. Soph. 217C: mh\ . . . a)parnhqei\s ge/nh|.A. J. P. iv (1883), 306.
XEN. An. 7.6.36: h)\n de\ poih/shte . . . katakano/ntes (Dindorf katakekono/tes) e)/sesqe. The reading katakano/ntes is favored by the coincidence of action.)
THUC.4.54.3(see above).

HDT.2.10: e)/rga a)podeca/menoi mega/la ei)si/. 3.27 (see above). 5.69: h)=n . . . to\n dh=mon prosqe/menos pollw=| katu/perqe tw=n a)ntistasiwte/wn, It was true that he had gained over the commons far beyond his rival. 7.206: h)=n ga\r kata\ tw)uto\ *)olumpia\s tou/toisi toi=si prh/gmasi sumpesou=sa (= su)gxronos).
Suppl. 511: e)carke/sas h)=n *zeu\s o( timwrou/menos.

SOPH. Ai. 588: mh\ prodou\s h(ma=s ge/nh| (prove traitor). Ant. 1067: ne/kun nekrw=n a)moibo
 a)ntidou\s e)/sei . O. C. 816: h)= mh
 su\ ka)/neu tou=de luphqei\s e)/sei . O. R. 89-90: ou)/te ga qrasu\s | ou)/t' ou)=n prodei/sas ei)mi\ tw=| ge nu=n lo/gw|. 970: ou(/tw d' a)
 qanw
 ei)/h )c e)mou= (parallel with the periphrastic perfect optative with a)/n, qanw/n being practically the perfect of qnh/|skw). Ph. 772-3: mh\ sauto/n q' a(/ma | ka)/m' . . . ktei/nas ge/nh| [parodied by COM. Phryn. 2.605 (= fr. 20, Gr. N.2): w)= fi/ltat' a)ndrw=n, mh/ m' a)tima/sas ge/nh|].
PIND. P. 2.72: ge/noi' oi(=os e)ssi\ maqw/n (but see B. L. G. ad loc.).
HOM. Il. 4.210-1: a)ll' o(/te dh/ r() i(/kanon, o(/qi canqo\s *mene/laos | blh/menos h)=n is not an example. blh/menos does not go with h)=n.

p.hi: Aorist participle with forms of fai/nomai.

div2.p: The aorist participle with forms of fai/nomai is especially worthy of note as a valuable periphrasis.

au)to\s me
 ou)/te labw
 ou)de
 ou)/t' e)pixeirh/sas labei=n fanh/somai, DEM.21.40.

Often of the future ascertainment of a past action. So 5.10: ou)de\n tou/twn ou)/t' e)capath/sas ou)/te sigh/sas e)gw\ fanh/somai, a)lla\ proeipw\n u(mi=n kte(. 20.80. 21.39. 40 (see above). 22.47, and elsewhere.
ISOC.12.78: tou/tou de\ ka/llion strath/ghma . . . ou)dei\s fanh/setai pra/cas. 83: fanh/setai poihsa/menos. (Cf. 41: fanhso/meqa . . . a)poleloipo/tes. 138: fanei/hn a)\n . . . ei)rhkw/s. 172. 209.)
LYS.25.16: ei)s to\n kata/logon . . . katale/cas ou)de/na fanh/somai , It will appear that I have put no one in the catalogue.

The periphrastic aorist participle with e)/xw emphasizes the maintenance of the result and is therefore an equivalent of the perfect, the double nature of which is thus analyzed, e)/xw representing one end, the participle the other. The periphrasis seems to have originated in the transitive use of e)/xw, I have, hold, though others consider e)/xw to be intransitive and nearly equal to ei)mi/. It is not always possible to feel the original force, and in Herodotus and the tragic poets e)/xw and the participle are used frankly as parallels to the perfect.See also Ph. Thielmann in Abhandlungen Wilhelm von Christ dargebracht von seinen Schülern, München, 1891, pp. 294-306.
to\n lo/gon de/ sou pa/lai qauma/sas e)/xw, PLATO, Phaedr. 257C; I have long been in a state of wonderment about your speech.
DEM.9.12: kai\ mh\n kai\ *fera\s . . . e)/xei katalabw/n.
AESCHIN.1.15: e(ni\ kefalai/w| pa/nta ta\ toiau=ta sullabw\n e)/xei.
PLATO, Gorg. 456A: sullabou=sa . . . e)/xei. Legg. 793 Phaedr. 257 C (see above). Tim. 30 C.
THUC.1.30.1: *korinqi/ous de\ dh/santes ei)=xon. 1.38.6: *)epi/damnon . . . e(lo/ntes bi/a| e)/xousi .

HDT.1.41: e)gw/ se . . . e)ka/qhra kai\ oi)ki/oisi u(podeca/menos e)/xw (in contrast to the aorist). 6.12: a)ndri\ *fwkae/i . . . e)pitre/yantes h(me/as au)tou\s e)/xomen. 7.9, a): e)/xomen de\ au)tw=n pai=das katastreya/menoi (cf. DEM.4.6: pa/nta kate/straptai, kai\ e)/xei).
EUR. Ion, 735-7: w)= qu/gater, a)/ci) a)ci/wn gennhto/rwn | h)/qh fula/sseis kou) kataisxu/nas' e)/xeis | tou\s sou\s palaiou\s e)kgo/nous au)to/xqonas. Phoen. 856-7.

SOPH. Ai. 21-2:
nukto\s ga\r h(ma=s th=sde pra=gos a)/skopon
e)/xei pera/nas, ei)/per ei)/rgastai ta/de
(parallel with the perfect). 676. Ant. 22. 31-2. 180. 192-3. O. R. 577. Ph. 942-3.
PIND. N. 1.31: ou)k e)/ramai polu)n e)n mega/rw| plou=ton katakru/yais e)/xein.
HES. O. et D. 42: kru/yantes ga\r e)/xousi qeoi\ bi/on a)nqrw/poisi.
HOM. Il. 1.356: e(lw\n ga\r e)/xei ge/ras (= ei(=le kai\ e)/xei).
The periphrastic perfect participle with e)/xw is also found.
PLATO, Theaet. 200A: e)pisth/mhn a)/ra oi)h/setai teqhreukw\s e)/xein.
XEN. An. 1.3.14: w(=n . . . polla\ xrh/mata e)/xomen a)nhrpako/tes.
SOPH. Ph. 600: o(/n g' ei)=xon h)/dh xro/nion e)kbeblhko/tes.

div2.head: Epistolary Tenses
div2.p: In letters the aorist is sometimes used from the point of view of the receiver.
*krh/nhs, w(=| e)/dwka th\n e)pistolh/n, e)/sti . . . kai\ soi\ fi/los, PLATO , [PLATO Ep.] 15; Crenes, to whom I gave (give) this letter, is a true friend to you also.
ISOC. Ep. 3.1: h)boulh/qhn = bou/lomai. Ibid. 4.1: proeilo/mhn = proh/|rhmai.
PLATO , [Ep.] 15 (see above).

As there are few genuine Greek letters of the classical period, we have not the material to determine whether there was ever such an extensive permutation of tenses as we find in Cicero's letters. The aorist in the N. T. is clearly due to Roman influence, and is not to be cited.
In the language of classic prose the indicative alone expresses the sphere of time directly (183), the other moods express the sphere of time indirectly.

It must be noticed, however, that in the earlier language the optative appears to have been used as a potential of the past; hence its affinity with the past tenses in oratio obliqua, hence, perhaps, the occasional use of the present optative as a real imperfect. Nor, on the other hand. are we to overlook the fact that the indicative loses its sphere of time in unreal conditional sentences.

Subjunctive and imperative are both future by their nature. So also is the optative outside of oratio obliqua. Under the head of future are included immediate and indefinite present. When we use, then, “present,” “perfect,” and “aorist” of the non-indicative moods, we mean by present “continuance,” by perfect “completion,” and by aorist “attainment.”
In not a few verbs, owing to their sense, some of the modal tenses are not used, some are rare. We should not expect to find a)pollu/oito, and xarei/h (HOM. Il, 6.481) is scarce.

div2.head: Tenses of the Imperative
div2.p: PRESENT (durative):
gi/gnwske sauto/n, AESCHYL. P. V. 309 ; Learn, strive, to know thyself.
AORIST (attainment):
PERFECT (completion):
a)nerri/fqw ku/bos, COM. Men. 4.88; Let the die be cast and stay cast.
For additional examples see under Imperative Mood.

div2.head: Tenses of the Subjunctive
div2.p: PRESENT:
skopw/meqa, PLATO, Protag. 314B; Let us consider (a course of study). mh\ diw/kwmen, HDT.8.109; Let us give up the pursuit.
AORIST:
skeyw/meqa, PLATO, Protag. 330B; Let us consider (each part by itself). ei)/pw . . . soi to\ ai)/tion; Theaet. 149 B; Shall I tell you the reason?
For additional examples see chapters on the Subjunctive and the Imperative Mood.

div2.head: Tenses of the Pure Optative
div2.p: PRESENT:
nikw/|h d' o(/ ti pa=sin me/llei sunoi/sein, DEM.4.51; May that prevail which shall advantage all! e)/rdoi tis h(\n e(/kastos ei)dei/h te/xnhn, AR. Vesp. 1431.
AORIST:
u(mei=s d' e(/loisq) o(/ ti kai\ th=| po/lei kai\ a(/pasi sunoi/sein u(mi=n me/llei, DEM.3.36; May you choose that which shall advantage both the state and all of you!
PERFECT:
Chiefly with such perfects as are equivalent to presents.

au)ti/ka teqnai/hn, HOM. Il. 18.98; May I be dead forthwith! ai)\ ga\r e)moi\ toio/sde po/sis keklhme/nos ei)/h, Od. 6.244 (periphrastic perfect).The analysis which involves the future ascertainment of a past action, while not infrequent in sentences of opinion (optative and a)/n), is naturally rare in sentences of wish, which are not analytical, so that for an example of this form of wish, we must have recourse to the manufactured sentences of a grammarian. ei)/qe nenikh/koi mou o( pai=s, ei)/qe dedocasme/nos ei)/h, APOLLONIUS DYSC. p. 251.25-6 (Bekk.); May my son have conquered (action decided, ascertainment still in suspense); may he have covered himself with glory
For further examples see under the Optative Mood.

div2.head: Tenses of the Optative with a)/n
div2.p: PRESENT (Future ascertainment of a present, future, or past imperfect action):

fau=loi . . . a)\n . . . ei)=en, PLATO, Apol. 28B-C; They must be sorry fellows. ta/xa de\ a)\n kai\ oi( a)pod(o/menoi le/goien (might have told the tale) a)piko/menoi e)s *spa/rthn w(s a)paireqei/hsan u(po\ *sami/wn, HDT.1.70.
AORIST (Future ascertainment of an aoristic action, rarely of the past):

ou)k a)\n a)rnhqei/hn, DEM.21.191; I can't deny it. ta/xa d' a)/n ti kai\ tou= o)no/matos e)pau/roito, HDT.7.180; Perhaps he may to some extent have had his name also to thank for that (as if e)pau ro/menos a)\n ge/noito).
PERFECT (Future ascertainment of a completed action):

le/lhqe/ se . . .; . . . pw=s a)\n . . . lelh/qoi (me); XEN. Conv. 3.6; Has it escaped your observation? How can it have escaped my observation? h(mei=s a)\n ei)=men qate/rw| kexrhme/noi, EUR. Hipp. 349; We must have felt the worser half.
See further the chapter on the Optative with a)/n.

div2.head: Tenses of the Optative as Representative of the Indicative
div2.p: The optative as the representative of the indicative in oratio obliqua after a past tense ordinarily represents the corresponding tenses of the indicative from the point of view of the speaker.
Present Optative (= Present Indicative):

e)/legen o(/ti ei) . . . blabera\ th=| *lakedai/moni pepraxw\s ei)/h (= pe/praxe), di/kaios ei)/h (= di/kaio/s e)sti) zhmiou=sqai, XEN. Hell. 5.2.32; He said that if he had (has) done what was damaging to Lacedaemon, he deserved (deserves) to be punished.
LYS.12.6: e)/legon . . . w(s ei)=e/n tines th=| politei/a| a)xqo/menoi .
PLATO, Euthyd. 276E: a)pekri/nato o(/ti manqa/noien oi( manqa/nontes a(\ ou)k e)pi/stainto.
XEN. Hell. 5.2.32 (see above).
HDT.1.83: h)=lqe a)/llh a)ggeli/h, w(s h(lw/koi to\ tei=xos . . . kai\ e)/xoito *kroi=sos zwgrhqei/s.
SOPH. Tr. 161-2: ei)=pe me\n le/xous o(/ ti | xrei/h m' e(le/sqai kth=sin.
HOM. Only after interrogatives. Od. 15.423: ei)rw/ta dh\ e)/peita ti/s ei)/h kai\ po/qen e)/lqoi. 17.368.A. J. P. iv (1883), 419.
LYCURG.18(see above).

DEM. [34]DEM., 11: e)/legen o(/ti ou)/te ta\ xrh/mata e)/nqoito ei)s th\n nau=n ou(=tos . . . ou)/te to\ xrusi/on ei)lhfw\s ei)/h par' au)tou= e)n *bospo/rw|. [52]DEM., 15(see 312). [59]DEM., 81(see 311).
XEN. An. 4.3.11: e)/legon o(/ti tugxa/noien fru/gana sulle/gontes w(s e)pi\ pu=r, ka)/peita kati/doien . . . ge/ronta/ te kai\ gunai=ka kte(. Hell. 1.7.5 (see 312).
AR. Ach. 648-9: h)rw/thsen . . . tou=ton to\n poih\th\n pote/rous ei)/poi kaka\ polla/. Vesp. 283: katei/poi.
SOPH. Tr. 431-2: h)/kousen w(s tau/ths po/qw| | po/lis damei/h pa=sa.
PIND. O. 6.49: ei)/reto pai=da to\n *eu)a/dna te/koi (where see note).
HOM. Od. 15.423 (307). 17.368 (307). 24.237: w(s e)/lqoi is to be considered interrogative (how he had come).
e)/legon o(/ti e)gw\ pa/nta ei)/hn (= ei)mi/ ) pepusme/nos, LYS. 1.18 ; I said that I had found out everything.
DEM.18.22: e)to/lma le/gein w(s a)/r' e)gw\ . . . kekwlukw\s ei)/hn th\n po/lin . . . tau/thn (= th\n ei)rh/nhn) poih/sasqai. [34]DEM., 11: ei)lhfw\s ei)/h (308).
PLATO , Phaedo 59 E: e)puqo/meqa o(/ti to\ ploi=on e)k *dh/lou a)figme/non ei)/h.
XEN. Hell. 1.1.11: puqo/menos de\ o(/ti ai( tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn nh=es . . . a)nhgme/nai ei)=en ei)s *ku/zikon, . . . h)=lqen ei)s *shsto/n. Hell. 5.2.32: pepraxw\s ei)/h (307).
e)/legon o(/ti . . . ou) dunh/sointo (= ou) dunhso/meqa) mh\ pei/qesqai toi=s *qhbai/ois, XEN. Hell. 6.1.1; They said that they would not be able to refuse to obey the Thebans.
DEM. [50]DEM., 56: a)pekri/nato/ moi o(/ti ou)d' a)karh= danei/soi.

ISAE. 6.23: ei)do/tes d' oi( a)nagkai=oi o(/ti e)c e)kei/nou me\n ou)k a)\n e)/ti ge/nointo pai=des . . ., fanh/sointo d' a)/|llw| tini\ tro/pw|, kai\ e)k tou/twn e)/sointo e)/ti mei/zous diaforai/, e)/peiqon kte(.
ANTIPHON, 1.11: e)peci/oimi (195).
PLATO, Euthyd. 283A: e)pesko/poun ti/na pote\ tro/pon a(/yointo tou= lo/gou kai\ o(po/qen a)/rcointo kte(.

XEN. Hell. 2.3.17: polloi\ dh=loi h)=san . . . qauma/zontes ti/ e)/soito h( politei/a. Ibid.: e)/legen o( *qhrame/nhs o(/ti . . . a)du/naton e)/soito th\n o)ligarxi/an diame/nein. 2.3.56: ei)=pen o( *sa/turos o(/ti oi)mw/coito (= oi)mw/cei). 6.1.1.
AR. Eq. 776: ou) fronti/zwn tw=n i)diwtw=n ou)deno/s, ei) soi\ xarioi/mhn.
AESCHYL. Pers. 356-60: e)/lece paidi\ sw=| *ce/rch| ta/de, | w(s . . . *(/ellhnes ou) menoi=en, a)lla\ . . . bi/oton e)kswsoi/ato.
PIND. O. 9.115-6: e)ke/leusen diakri=nai . . . a(/ntina sxh/soi tis h(rw/wn (earliest example).

p.hi: Retention of imperfect and pluperfect indicative in oratio obliqua.

div2.p: The imperfect and pluperfect having no optative, the retention of the indicative is to be expected.

e)dei=to o( *qeoge/nhs . . . le/gwn o(/ti ou)k h)/|dei *neai/ras au)th\n ou)=san qugate/ra, a)ll' e)capathqei/h u(po\ *stefa/nou, DEM. [59]DEM., 81; Theogenes begged saying that he did not know that she was the daughter of Neaera, but that he had been deceived by Stephanus.
In the absence of an imperfect optative the present optative is not infrequently found to represent an imperfect indicative.

dihgou=nto o(/ti au)toi\ me\n e)pi\ tou\s polemi/ous ple/oien (= e)/pleon), th\n de\ a)nai/resin tw=n nauagw=n prosta/ceian . . . *qhrame/nei kte(., XEN. Hell. 1.7.5; Their story was that they kept sailing after the enemy and had assigned the picking up of the shipwrecked to Theramenes etc.
DEM. [52]DEM., 15: e)to/lmhsan marturh=sai w(s o( me\n *ka/llippos o(/rkon tw=| patri\ doi/h (= e)/dwke), o( de\ path\r ou)k e)qe/loi (= ou)k h)/qelen) o)mo/sai.
LYS. 1.14: e)rome/nou d' e)mou= ti/ ai( qu/rai nu/ktwr yofoi=en (cf. § 17: a)namimnh|sko/menos . . . o(/ti . . . e)yo/fei ). 1.20: kathgo/rei . . . w(s meta\ th\n e)kfora\n au)th=| prosi/oi .
XEN. An. 4.3.11: tugxa/noien (see 308). Hell. 1.7.5 (see above).
See further on this whole subject Oratio Obliqua and Object Sentences.

div2.head: Tenses of the Infinitive
div2.p: , The infinitive as a verbal noun is used chiefly in the present and aorist, more rarely in the perfect. The temporal relation is that of the kind of time.

div2.head: Infinitive as a subjectOr quasi-subject. See Infinitive.
div2.p: PRESENT:
a. Without the article:
r(a=|on parainei=n h)\ paqo/nta karterei=n, EUR. Alc. 1078; 'T is easier to preach than suffer and be strong.
LYS.8.2: a)niaro\n me\n ou)=n a)nagka/zesqai le/gein peri\ tou/twn, a)du/naton de\ mh\ le/gein .
ANDOC.1.8: kra/tiston ou)=n moi ei)=nai dokei= e)c a)rxh=s u(ma=s dida/skein pa/nta ta\ geno/mena kai\ paralipei=n mhde/n.
PLATO, Rpb. 555C: plou=ton tima=n kai\ swfrosu/nhn a(/ma i(kanw=s kta=sqai . . . a)du/naton.
THUC.1.5. 2: ko/smos kalw=s tou=to dra=n.
COM. Archipp. 2.727: w(s h(du\ th\n qa/lattan a)po\ th=s gh=s o(ra=n | w)= mh=te/r e)sti.
EUR. Alc. 1078 (see above).
AESCHYL. P.V. 751: pa/sxein (see 316).
THEOGN. 211: oi)=no/n toi pi/nein poulu\n kako/n.
HOM. Il. 1.274: pei/qesqai a)/meinon. 2.453: toi=si d' a)/far po/lemos gluki/wn ge/net' h)e\ ne/esqai. 10.174.
b. With the article:
kako\n to\ pi/nein, AR. Vesp. 1253; A bad thing this drinking. to\ bou/lesqai/ m' e)/knize, EUR. I. A. 330.

ISOC.2.2: tou\s me
 ga i)diw/tas e)sti\ polla\ ta\ paideu/onta, ma/lista me
 to\ mh\ trufa=n a)ll' a)nagka/zesqai peri\ tou= bi/ou kaq) e(ka/sthn bouleu/esqai th
 h(me/ran.
PLATO , Alc. 11.143 E: kako\n a)/r), w(s e)/oiken, e)sti\n h( tou= belti/stou a)/gnoia kai\ to\ a)gnoei=n to\ be/ltiston.
XEN. Cyr. 5.1.11: to\ . . . e)ra=n e)qelou/sio/n e)stin.
AR. Vesp. 1253 (see above). fr. 2.1133: to\ ga\r fobei=sqai to\n qa/naton lh=ros polu/s.

EUR. Alc. 693: to\ de\ zh=n mikro/n, a)ll' o(/mws gluku/. Bacch. 389-90: o( de\ . . . bi/otos kai\ to\ fronei=n . Heracl. 240: to\ suggene/s te kai\ to\ proufei/lein. 476: sigh/ te kai\ to\ swfronei=n. I. A. 330 (see above).
SOPH. El. 265: to\ thta=sqai (316). 770: deino\n to\ ti/ktein e)sti/n (136). fr. 239: a)lla\ tw=| gh/ra| filei= | xw( nou=s o(martei=n kai\ to\ bouleu/ein a(\ dei=.
PIND. O. 9.38: to\ kauxa=sqai. P. 2.56: to\ ploutei=n. N. 5.18: to\ siga=n.
SIMON, C. 100.1: to\ kalw=s qnh/|skein a)reth=s me/ros e)sti\ me/giston.
AORIST:
a. Without the article:

krei=sson ga\r ei)sa/pac qanei=n
h)\ ta\s a(pa/sas h(me/ras pa/sxein kakw=s,
AESCHYL. P. V. 750-1 : 'T is better once for all to die than suffer on forever and forever more.
DEM.3.18: eu)/casqai me\n . . . r(a/|dion . . ., e(le/sqai d' . . . ou)ke/q) o(moi/ws eu)/poron.
ANDOC.1.8: paralipei=n (see 314).
PLATO, Theaet. 187E: krei=tton ga/r pou smikro\n eu)= h)\ polu\ mh\ i(kanw=s pera=nai.

THUC.1.22.1: xalepo
 th
 a)kri/beian au)th
 tw=n lexqe/ntwn diamnhmoneu=sai.
AR. Vesp. 367: diatragei=n toi/nun kra/tisto/n e)sti/ moi to\ di/ktuon.
SOPH. El. 264-5: (e))k tw=nde/ moi | labei=n q' o(moi/ws kai\ to\ thta=sqai pe/lei.
PIND. P. 4.272: r(a/|dion me\n ga\r po/lin sei=sai.
BACCHYL.111.47: qanei=n glu/kiston.
HOM. Od. 9.241: a)rgale/on, basi/leia, dihneke/ws a)goreu=sai.
Il. 2.5-6: h(/de de/ oi( kata\ qumo\n a)ri/sth fai/neto boulh/: | pe/myai e)p' *)atrei+/dh| *)agame/mnoni ou)=lon o)/neiron.
b. With the article:
to\ . . . katagelasqh=nai i)/sws ou)de\n pra=gma, PLATO, Euthyph. 3C; To get laughed at is perhaps a matter of no great consequence.
DEM.1.23: polla/kis dokei= to\ fula/cai ta)gaqa\ tou= kth/sasqai xalepw/teron ei)=nai.
ANDOC.2.5: mega/lh de\ dh/pou kai\ to\ e)camartei=n duspraci/a e)sti/.
ANTIPHON, 5.91: to\ a)di/kws a)polu=sai o(siw/teron a)\n ei)/h tou= mh\ dikai/ws a)pole/sai.
PLATO, Euthyph. 3C (see above).
THUC.3.58.2: braxu\ ga\r to\ ta\ h(me/tera sw/mata diafqei=rai.
AR. Lys. 884: oi(=on to\ tekei=n .
COM. Antiphan. 3.150: to\ proi=k' a)poqanei=n e)sti fanera\ zhmi/a.
EUR. fr. 854: to\ me\n sfagh=nai deino/n.
PIND. O. 8.60: a)/gnwmon de\ to\ mh\ promaqei=n.
ALCAE. 30: to\ ga\r | *)/areui+ katqa/nhn ka/lon.
PERFECT:
a. Without the article:
po/lei . . . a)na/gkh bebouleu=sqai ti/ xrh\ dra=n, PLATO, Legg. 949E; A city must needs have a settled policy as to what is to be done.
DEM.19.179: h(lwke/nai prosh/kei. Ibid. 282: a)polwle/nai. 21.120: a)nhrpa/sqai. 36.13: dedwke/nai.
LYS.30.27: tou/tw| ge prosh/kei dia\ me\n au(to\n teqna/nai, dia\ de\ tou\s progo/nous pepra=sqai .
PLATO, Legg. 949E (see above). PLAT. Soph. 222B: ei)rh=sqai.
HDT.5.18: no/mos . . . h(mi=n ge/ e)sti . . . kexwri/sqai a)/ndras gunaikw=n.
BACCHYL. XIV, 1: eu)= me\n ei(ma/rqai para\ dai/[mosin a)n] qrw/pois a)/riston.
THEOGN. 181-2: teqna/menai, fi/le *ku/rne, penixrw=| be/lteron a)ndri/, | h)\ zw/ein xaleph=| teiro/menon peni/h|.
HOM. Od. 3.209: nu=n de\ xrh\ tetla/men e)/mphs (cf. Hymn. Merc. 494-5: ou)de/ ti/ se xrh\ . . . kexolw=sqai).
b. With the article:
to\ di/khs . . . a)fei=sqai mega/lh dwreia\ . . . h)=n, DEM.23.185; To have been allowed to go free of punishment was a great boon.
DEM.23.185(see above).
AESCHIN.3.236: tou= ga\r tau=t' e)cergasqh=nai kalw=s to\ gegenh=sqai tou/twn ai)/tion mei/zw kathgori/an e)/xei.
ISAE. 11.18: ou)k i)/sxuse . . . to\ pronenikhke/nai.
XEN. Hiero, 8.6: au)to\ ga\r to\ tetimh=sqai . . . sunepikosmei=.
HDT.5.6: to\ me\n e)sti/xqai eu)gene\s ke/kritai, to\ de\ a)/stikton a)genne/s.
AR. Pl. 354-5: to\ d' au)= dedoike/nai | pro\s a)ndro\s ou)de\n u(gie/s e)st' ei)rgasme/nou.
EUR. Med. 122-3: to\ ga\r ei)qi/sqai zh=n e)p' i)/soisin krei=sson .
SOPH. Ant. 437-8: to\ me\n ga\r au)to\n e\k kakw=n pefeuge/nai h(/diston .

div2.head: Infinitive as an object
div2.p: PRESENT:
a. Without the article:
nu=n au)to\n a)delfi/zein e)pixeirh/sousin, ISOC.19.30; Now they will undertake to “brother” him.
ISOC.5.87: polemei=n (see 211). 19.30 (see above).
PLATO, Gorg. 474A: ou)k h)pista/mhn e)piyhfi/zein.
XEN. Hiero, 3.3: tou\s moixou\s nomi/zousi pollai\ tw=n po/lewn nhpoinei\ a)poktei/nein. Ibid. 4.11: tre/fein (see 324).
HDT.3.83: ou)/te . . . a)/rxein ou)/te a)/rxesqai e)qe/lw.
COM. Philem. 4.56.68: ai)tw= d' u(gi/eian prw=ton, ei)=t' eu)praci/an, | tri/ton de\ xai/rein, ei)=t' o)fei/lein mhdeni/.
AR. fr. 2.1038: a)ll' ou) ga\r e)/maqe tau=t' e)mou= pe/mpontos, a)lla\ ma=llon | pi/nein, e)/peit' a)/|dein kakw=s, *surakosi/an tra/pezan.
SOPH. El. 345-6: e(lou= ge qa/ter), h)\ fronei=n kakw=s, | h)\ tw=n fi/lwn fronou=sa mh\ mnh/mhn e)/xein.
PIND. O. 3.36: toi=s ga\r e)pe/trapen *ou)lumpo/nd' i)w\n qahto\n a)gw=na ne/mein.
HOM. Il. 10.116: soi\ d' oi)/w| e)pe/treyen pone/esqai.
b. With the article:
to\ e(llhni/zein para\ tou/twn e)/gwge e)/maqon, PLATO , Alc. 1.111 A; I learned speaking Greek from them.
DEM. [33]DEM., 4: to\ . . . plei=n katale/luka (202). 57.18: to\ ceni/zein au)tou= kathgorh/kasin.
PLATO , Alc. 1.111 A (see above). Legg. 847 A: to\ zh=n kta/sqw. Theaet. 185 C: ou)si/an le/geis kai\ to\ mh\ ei)=nai.
XEN. R. L. 2.7: e)fh=ken au)toi=s to\ mhxana=sqai th\n trofh/n.
AR. Pax, 454: a)/fele to\ pai/ein.

SOPH. O. C. 1125-7:
to/ g' eu)sebe\s
mo/nois par' u(mi=n eu(=ron a)nqrw/pwn e)gw\
kai\ tou)pieike\s kai\ to\ mh\ yeudostomei=n
.
AORIST:
a. Without the article:
ou)k w)/knhse th\n de/spoinan gh=mai, DEM.45.74; He did not stick at marrying his mistress.
DEM.45.74(see above). [50]DEM., 57: ou)k h)/qele paralabei=n th\n nau=n.
PLATO, Euthyph. 3D: ou) pa/nu e)piqumw= peiraqh=nai.
XEN. Hell. 1.6.10: ou)k e)duna/mhn e)mauto\n pei=sai (151).
COM. Pherecr. 2.280: su\ de\ tra/pezan ei)/sfere, | kai\ ku/lika ka)ntragei=n.
EUR. Alc. 669: ma/thn a)/r' oi( ge/rontes eu)/xontai qanei=n.
PIND. O. 6.25-6: kei=nai ga\r e)c a)lla=n o(do\n a(gemoneu=sai | tau/tan e)pi/stantai.
HOM. Il. 1.18-9: u(mi=n me\n qeoi\ doi=en *)olu/mpia dw/mat' e)/xontes | e)kpe/rsai *pria/moio po/lin, e)u\ d' oi)/kad' i(ke/sqai.
b. With the article:
tlh/somai to\ katqanei=n, AESCHYL. Ag. 1290; I will endure the dying of the death.
DEM.18.93: to\ *xerro/nhson kai\ *buza/ntion sw=sai . . . h( proai/resis h( e)mh\ kai\ h( politei/a diepra/cato.
ISAE. 1.42: ou(=toi ga\r to\ a)nelei=n au)ta\s (= ta\s diaqh/kas) e)kei/nou boulome/nou diekw/lusan.
ANTIPHON, 2 g 6: to\ me\n a(lw=nai kai\ a)pofugei=n . . . e)n i)/sais e)lpi/si qw=men au)tw=| ei)=nai.
PLATO, Euthyd. 275C: qarrei= to\ a)pokri/nasqai.
THUC.3.40.3: e)k tou= eu)= ei)pei=n to\ paqei=n eu)= a)ntilh/yontai.
HDT.5.101: to\ de\ mh\ lehlath=sai . . . th\n po/lin e)/sxe to/de.
EUR. Alc. 694: su\ gou=n a)naidw=s diema/xou to\ mh\ qanei=n.
AESCHYL. Ag. 1290 (see above).
PIND. O. 2.107: to\ lalagh=sai qe/lwn.See A. J. P. xv (1894), 509.
PERFECT:
a. Without the article:
a)nagka/zontai stra/teuma tre/fein h)\ a)polwle/nai, XEN. Hiero, 4.11; They are compelled to keep an army or perish (be ruined).
DIN.1.112: bou/letai . . . sugkexu/sqai pa/nta ta\ e)n th=| po/lei di/kaia.
DEM.8.49: kai\ teqna/nai ma=llon a)\n h)\ tau=t' ei)rhke/nai bouloi/mhn.
ISOC.5.29: a(\ me\n ou)=n h)boulo/mhn moi proeirh=sqai tau=t' e)sti/n.

PLATO, Rpb. 351A-B: po/lin fai/hs a)\n a)/dikon ei)=nai kai\ a)/llas po/leis e)pixeirei=n doulou=sqai a)di/kws kai\ katadedoulw=sqai. Ibid. 406 D: a)cioi= . . . e)ceme/sai to\ no/shma . . . h)\ kau/sei h)\ tomh=| xrhsa/menos a)phlla/xqai.
XEN. Hell. 5.4.7: ei)=pon th\n qu/ran keklei=sqai. Hell. 6.2.15; e)kh/rucen . . . pepra=sqai. Hiero, 4.11 (see above).
COM. Pherecr. 2.262: bouloi/mhn ga\r ka)\n a)kalh/fais to\n i)/son xro/non e)stefanw=sqai.
AESCHYL. Sept. 461-2: i(/ppous . . . qelou/sas pro\s pu/lais peptwke/nai.
b. With the article:

to\ me\n ga\r po/ll' a)polwleke/nai kata\ to\n po/lemon th=s h(mete/ras a)melei/as a)/n tis qei/h dikai/ws, DEM.1.10; This (thing of) having suffered many losses during the war may justly be charged to our negligence.
DEM.1.10(see above). 23.7: tou=to . . . *)aristokra/ths h)di/kei, to\ toiou/tou, oi(=on e)gw/ fhmi dei/cein to\n *xari/dhmon o)/nta, tosau/thn pepoih=sqai pro/noian.
The future infinitive as the object of verbs of creation comes from the blending of the sphere of thought and the sphere of will. Some of the examples are much disputed.
pu=r e)nh/sein dienoou=nto e)s ta\ cu/lina parafra/gmata, THUC.4.115.2; They intended (thought that they would) hurl fire into the wooden ramparts.
See further the Infinitive.

div2.head: Infinitive as the representative of the indicative
div2.p: The infinitive as the representative of the indicative takes all the tenses. See Accusative and Infinitive.
Present (= Present Indicative):
to\n eu)tuxou=nta kai\ fronei=n nomi/zomen, COM. Men. 4.354.497; Him who is lucky we think to have sense withal. fhsi\n e)pilh/smwn ei)=nai, PLATO, Prot. 336D; He says that he is forgetful.
Present (= Imperfect Indicative):

a)ntile/gein fh\|s toi=s boulome/nois h(ma=s a)pole/sai, LYS.12.26 ; You declare that you undertook to oppose (a)nte/leges) those who wished to destroy us.
a)pofhna/sqw mh\ mete/xein, DEM.19.117 ; Let him declare that he had no part in it.
Aorist (= Aorist Indicative):On the aorist as a future, see Accusative and Infinitive.
ou) fh/sw h(ma=s o)rqw=s o(mologh=sai h(ni/ka w(mologh/samen, PLATO, Theaet. 191A; I will not say that we were right to acknowledge (it) when we acknowledged it.
Perfect (= Perfect Indicative):
fhsi\ . . . e)gkw/mion gegrafe/nai, ISOC.10.14; He says that he has written an encomium.
Perfect (= Pluperfect Indicative):

kai\ o(do/n te [le/getai] ou)/pw pollh\n dihnu/sqai au)toi=s kai\ to\n *mh=don h(/kein pa/lin, XEN. Cyr. 1.4. 28; It is said that not much of their journey had been accomplished yet when the Mede returned.
Future (= Future Indicative):
ou)k e)/fh o)mei=sqai, XEN. Hell. 1.3.11; He said that he would not take an oath.
Future Perfect (= Future Perfect Indicative):
u(polamba/nw . . . ma/thn e)rrayw|dhko/tas h(ma=s e)/sesqai, DEM.25.2; I understand that we shall have delivered our screed to no purpose.

p.hi: Articular infinitive as the representative of the indicative.

div2.p: The infinitive as the representative of the indicative may take the article.
e(\n me\n ou)=n o(mologei=tai to\ kratei=n tw=n klhronomiw=n tou\s a)/rrenas, DEM. [44]DEM., 12: One thing then is agreed on, namely, the males' holding (that the males hold) the inheritance.
to\ . . . a)noi=cai th\n qu/ran ou)x o(mologei=, DEM. [42]DEM., 8: The opening of the door (the statement that he opened the door) he does not agree to.
to\ de\ se\ a)porh/sein, ou)k oi)=mai (sc. mantikw=s se ei)rhke/nai), PLATO, Conv. 198B; As to the statement that you will be at a loss, I don't think that you have said that in a spirit of prophecy.

DEM. [42]DEM., 8: to\ me\n a)felei=n to\ shmei=on o(mologei=, to\ d' a)noi=cai th\n qu/ran ou)x o(mologei=. [44]DEM., 12(see above). 57.63: e)k . . . ga\r tou= o(/rkou e)ch/leiyan to\ yhfiei=sqai (= yhfiou=mai) gnw/mh| th=| dikaiota/th|.

PLATO, Conv. 198B (see above). Phaedo 61 D: pw=s tou=to le/geis . . . to\ mh\ qemito
 ei)=nai e(auto
 bia/zesqai; Phaedr. 244 A: to\ (the statement that) mani/an kako
 ei)=nai. PLAT. Soph. 231C: to\ . . . mh\ r(a/|dion ei)=nai.
HDT.1.86: to\ tou= *so/lwnos . . . to\ mhde/na ei)=nai tw=n zwo/ntwn o)/lbion.

SOPH. Ant. 264-7:
h)=men d' e(/toimoi . . . qeou\s o(rkwmotei=n
to\ mh/te dra=sai mh/te tw| cuneide/nai
to\ pra=gma bouleu/santi
.

div2.head: Tenses of the Participle
div2.p: The participle as a verbal adjective is chiefly used in the present, aorist, and perfect tenses. The temporal relation is that of the kind of time.This temporal element is deeply imbedded in the nature of the participle and the use is universal, so that it is not necessary to draw examples from different ranges of classic Greek. The sphere of time depends on the context.

div2.head: Present participle
div2.p: The present participle is generally used of contemporaneous action, either total or partial.

e)me\ . . . le/geis to\n new/taton le/gwn, PLATO, Parmen. 137C ; You mean me when you speak of the youngest.
douleu/ousi/ ge mastigou/menoi kai\ sfatto/menoi, DEM.9.66 ; They lead the lives of slaves, being scourged and butchered.
lo/gous prosfe/rwn a)pw/lesen au)th/n, LYS. 1.8 ; (By) making proposals he ruined her.
DEM.9.66(see above).
PLATO, Parmen. 137C (see above).
EUR. Andr. 373: a)ndro\s d' a(marta/nous' a(marta/nei bi/ou (coincident action), A woman failing of a husband fails of life.
DEM.54.9: h)=|de . . . tou\s a)lektruo/nas mimou/menos tou\s nenikhko/tas (coincident action).
PLATO, Meno 90 C: pe/mpontes to/nde kalw=s a)\n e):pe/mpomen (coincident action).
HDT.9.21: oi( *megare/es piezo/menoi (finding themselves pinched) e)/pempon e)pi\ tou\s strathgou\s tw=n *(ellh/nwn kh/ruka .
DEM.14.12: ou)de\n ou)=n a)ll' h)\ r(ayw|dh/sousin oi( pre/sbeis periio/ntes .
XEN. Hiero, 11.15: eu)daimonw=n ga\r ou) fqonhqh/sei (174).
HDT.4.98: tau=ta de\ poieu=ntes e)moi\ mega/lws xariei=sqe (coincident action).
LYS. 1.8 (see above).
XEN. Hell. 7.5.9: o(rw=n . . . to\n . . . xro/non probai/nonta e)no/mise prakte/on ti ei)=nai .
HDT.1.68: o)ru/sswn e)pe/tuxon sorw=| e(ptaph/xei+ .
DEM.8.34: nu=n de\ dhmagwgou=ntes u(ma=s kai\ xarizo/menoi kaq' u(perbolh/n, ou(/tw diateqh/kasin w(/ste kte( .
XEN. Hell. 6.5.21: dh|ou=nti th\n xw/ran ou)dei\s h)qelh/kei ma/xesqai .
The action of the present participle is sometimes prior to that of the leading verb. An adverb of time often makes the relation plain.
oi( *ku/reioi pro/sqen su\n h(mi=n tatto/menoi nu=n a)festh/kasin, XEN. An. 3.2.17 ; The troops of Cyrus, who were formerly marshalled with us, have now deserted us.
DEM.18.61: kai\ pro/teron kakw=s tou\s *(/ellhnas e)/xontas pro\s e(autou\s kai\ stasiastikw=s, e)/ti xei=ron die/qhke .
PLATO, Rpb. 518D: ai( . . . a)/llai a)retai\ kalou/menai yuxh=s kinduneu/ousin . . . ou)k e)nou=sai pro/teron u(/steron e)mpoiei=sqai .
HDT.8.62: shmai/nwn de\ tau=ta tw=| lo/gw| die/baine e)s *eu)rubia/dhn, le/gwn ma=llon e)pestramme/na . 9.27: kai\ ga\r a)\n xrhstoi\ to/te e)o/ntes w(utoi\ nu=n a)\n ei)=en a)mei/nones.
AR. Av. 75: pro/teron a)/nqrwpo/s pot' w)/n .
SOPH. Ant. 1192: e)gw/, fi/lh de/spoina, kai\ parw\n e)rw= .

MIMNERM. 3:
to\ pri
 e)w

ou)de\ path paisi

.
HOM. Od. 13.401: knuzw/sw de/ toi o)/sse pa/ros perikalle/) e)o/nte .
The present participle may imply conative action, and thus simulate a future (see 193). So fe/rwn and a)/gwn are used almost to the exclusion of oi)/swn and a)/cwn.
h( de\ *pa/ralos ei)s ta\s *)aqh/nas [a)pe/pleuse] a)pagge/llousa ta\ gegono/ta, XEN. Hell. 2.1.29 ; The Paralos sailed off to Athens with a report of (= to report) what had happened.
ANDOC. 1.104-5: h(/kousi . . . oi( me\n ei)so/menoi . . . oi( de\ a)popeirw/menoi .
AR. Ach. 178: e)gw\ me\n deu=ro/ soi sponda\s fe/rwn e)/speudon .
EUR. Suppl. 120: tou/tous qano/ntas h)=lqon e)caitw=n po/lin .

PIND. O. 7.13-4:
kate/ban ta\n ponti/an
u(mne/wn pai=d' *)afrodi/tas
. P. 4.105-6:
i(ko/man
oi)/kad', a)rxa\n a)gkomi/zwn
.See B. L. G., Introd. Ess., cxii.

HOM. Il. 1.371-2:
h)=lqe qoa\s e)pi\ nh=as *)axaiw=n xalkoxitw/nwn
luso/meno/s te qu/gatra fe/rwn t' a)perei/si) a)/poina
. (Here both resemblance and difference between present and future are manifest.The examples cited for Homer do not seem to be very cogent. See Bolling, The Participle in Hesiod, Reprint from Catholic University Bulletin, Vol. III, p. 439.) Compare Il. 1.431: i(/kanen a)/gwn with ibid. 442-3: pro/ m' e)/pemyen . . . pai=da . . . a)ge/men .

div2.head: Aorist participle
div2.p: The action of the aorist participle is ordinarily prior, but it may be coincident, so especially when the leading verb is aorist or future.

a)naba/ntes ei)s to\ u(perw=|on e)deipnou=men, LYS. 1.22 ; Going up to the second story, we supped.
to\ sw=ma sw/sas tou\s lo/gous sw/seis e)moi/, EUR. I. T. 765 ; Saving thy body thou wilt save my words.
a)pw/lesas to\n oi)=non e)pixe/as u(/dwr, TRAG. Aristias, fr. 4 ; You spoiled the wine by adding water.

HDT.6.37: pi/tus . . . e)kkopei=sa blasto\n ou)de/na meti/ei
(134).
COM. Men.4.340.10: a)xa/ristos o(/stis eu)= paqw\n a)mnhmonei=.
LYS. 1.22 (see above). Ibid. 24: paralabw\n d' w(s oi(=o/n te h)=n plei/stous . . . e)ba/dizon .

THUC.6.69.1: a)nalabo/ntes ta\ o(/pla eu)qu\s a)nteph=|san
(206).
EUR. I. T. 27: metarsi/a lhfqei=s' e)kaino/mhn ci/fei .
HDT.2.5: katei\s katapeirhthri/hn phlo/n te a)noi/seis kte( . (258).
EUR. I. T. 765 (see 339). Med. 383: qanou=sa qh/sw toi=s e)moi=s e)xqroi=s ge/lwn .
DEM.54.20: u(gih\s e)celqw\n fora/dhn h)=lqon oi)/kade .
LYS.1.27: plhgei\s kate/pesen eu)qu/s , He was stabbed and fell at once.

PLATO, Euthyd. 273C: ei)pw\n ou)=n tau=ta katefronh/qhn u(p' au)toi=n
(174).

div2.p: ISOC.19.9: *qra/sullos . . . tou/tous mo/nous pai=das gnhsi/ous katalipw\n . . . to\n bi/on e)teleu/thsen .
DEM.18.208: ou)k e)/stin o(/pws h(ma/rtete ... to\n u(pe\r th=s a(pa/ntwn e)leuqeri/as kai\ swthri/as ki/ndunon a)ra/menoi .

BACCHYL. VI 15:
sta/dion krath/sas
*ke/on eu)kle/i+cas

HOM. Il. 1.434: i(sto\n d' i(stodo/kh| pe/lasan proto/noisin u(fe/ntes .
DEM.36.18: ta\ gra/mmaq' h( mh/thr h)fa/niken peisqei=s) u(po\ tou/tou .
DEM.36.8: o( *pasi/wn e)teteleuth/kei tau=ta diaqe/menos .

div2.head: Perfect participle
div2.p: The perfect participle expresses completion.
DEM.24.6: ti/ dh/ pot' e)gw\ metri/ws . . . to\n a)/llon xro/non bebiwkw/s, nu=n e)n a)gw=si kai\ grafai=s dhmosi/ais e)ceta/zomai .
DEM.14.36: koino\n e)xqro\n e)kei=non u(peilhfo/tes w(mono/oun a)llh/lois . 23.127: *ko/tun eu)qu\s a)pektonw\s ou)k a)sfale\s h(gei=t' a)pelqei=n o(/poi tu/xoi .
DEM.37.10: a)fiko/mhn sxedo/n ti pa/nt' a)polwlekw\s o(/s) e)/xwn e)ce/pleusa .
DEM.55.23: ou)de\n a)polwlekw\s . . . thlikau/thn moi di/khn ei)/lhxe .
DEM.28.16: ta\ xrh/mata pa/nt' a)pesterhkw\s . . . e)leei=sqai nu=n u(f) u(mw=n a)ciw/sei .
DEM.1.8: h(/komen (= plupf.) *eu)boeu=sin bebohqhko/tes , We had returned from having reinforced the Euboeans.

div2.head: Participle as the representative of the indicative
div2.p: The participle as the representative of the indicative takes all the tenses, the future as well as the present, the perfect, and the aorist.
The participle represents the indicative only after verbs of intellectual perception and those that are causative of the same. For actual perception, see Object Sentences.
The present participle represents durative action, regularly contemporaneous, occasionally prior.

p.emph: Contemporaneous Action after a Principal Tense = Present Indicative:

div2.p: DEM.29.25: bou/lomai . . . e)cele/gcai . . . au)to\n yeudo/menon (= o(/ti yeu/detai), I wish to prove him to be a liar, that he is a liar.

p.hi: Contemporaneous Action after an Historical Tense = Imperfect Indicative:

div2.p: DEM. [34] 13: h)|sqo/mhn au)to\n diakrouo/meno/n me (= o(/ti diekrou/eto/ me, or, by repraesentatio, o(/ti diakrou/etai/ me), I perceived that he was trying to cheat me.
oi)=da/ se le/gonta (= o(/ti e)/leges), XEN. Cyr. 1.6.6 ; I know that you used to say.
DEM.21.12: *meidi/as d' e)n au)tai=s tau/tais tai=s h(me/rais a)/cia tou= dou=nai th\n e)sxa/thn di/khn poiw=n (= o(/ti e)poi/ei) deixqh/setai .
LYS.10.4: fai/nomai ou)=n triskaideke/ths w)\n o(/te o( path\r u(po\ tw=n tria/konta a)pe/qnh|ske .
XEN. Cyr. 1.2.2: fu/sin . . . th=s morfh=s kai\ th=s yuxh=s toiau/thn e)/xwn diamnhmoneu/etai . Ibid. 1.6.6 (see above).
HDT.6.121: fai)nontai misotu/rannoi e)o/ntes .
AORIST PARTICIPLE = Aorist Indicative.
eu(rh/set' au)to\n th\n . . . po/lin dia\ *lakedaimoni/wn a)sqenh= poih/santa, DEM.15.24 ; You will find that he made the city weak by means of the Lacedaemonians.
PERFECT PARTICIPLE = Perfect Indicative.
oi)=da/ se . . . e)gw\ kai\ i)diw/thn gegenhme/non kai\ nu=n tu/rannon o)/nta, XEN. Hiero, 1.2 ; I know that you have been a private citizen and are now an absolute ruler.
FUTURE PARTICIPLE = Future Indicative.
safw=s . . . h)/|dei o(lwso/menos, ANTIPHON, 2 a 8 ; He knew clearly that he would be convicted.
THUC.3.67.1: i(/na u(mei=s . . . ei)dh=te dikai/ws au)tw=n katagnwso/menoi .
HDT.5.42: eu)= . . . e)pi/stato kat' a)ndragaqi/hn au)to\s sxh/swn th\n basilhi/hn .
SOPH. Ai. 1155: i)/sqi phmanou/menos .
On the Future Participle after Verbs of Motion, see Index.

div2.head: Indicative Mood
div2.p: The indicative mood represents the predicate as a reality. It is sometimes called the declarative mood or mood of direct assertion. fhmi/, I say.

The use of the Greek indicative is in the main the same as that of the English indicative. It must, however, be noticed that the English indicative and the English subjunctive (optative) coincide to a considerable extent in form. Hence the apparent coincidence in syntax, where there is real diversity. In “I had fainted, unless I had believed,” PS. 27.13, both “I had fainted” and “I had believed” are subjunctives, or rather optatives.

p.hi: Expression of possibility, power, obligation, and necessity.

div2.p: The differences to be specially noted are these:
The Greek language expresses possibility and power, obligation and necessity, and abstract relations generally, as facts; whereas our translation often implies the failure to realize.

sune/plei . . . ta\ . . . a)ndra/poda a(\ e)/dei au)to\n a)polu=sai, ANTIPHON, 5.20 ; The slaves whom he was to release were on board with him.
oi( . . . e)n tai=s tessara/konta nausi\ *peloponnh/sioi, ou(\s e)/dei e)n ta/xei paragene/sqai, . . . e)ndie/triyan, THUC.3.29.1 ; The Peloponnesians in the forty ships whose business it was to get (who ought to have got) there quickly, loitered on the way.
to/te cunalgei=n xrh=n s' o(/t' w)llu/mhn e)gw/, EUR. Alc. 633 ; tum aequius dolere FUERAT fata cum me tollerent (Buchanan).
DIN.1.81: o(/te me\n e)/dei ma/xesqai . . . w)/|xet' a)piw\n oi)/kade, e)peidh\ de\ prosh=ken oi)/koi kinduneu/ein . . . w)/|xet' e)k th=s po/lews a)podra/s .
DEM.18.191: e)xrh=n . . . e)/dei. 29. 41: polu\ ka/llion h)=n . . . diw/kein. [46]DEM., 5: e)/dei. [47]DEM., 76: gewrgw= de\ pro\s tw=| i(ppodro/mw|, w(/ste ou) po/rrw e)/dei au)to\n e)lqei=n.
LYS.12.32: xrh=n de/ se . . . ei)/per h)=sqa xrhsto/s . . . toi=s me/llousin a)di/kws a)poqanei=sqai mhnuth\n gene/sqai .
ANDOC.1.20: h)\ e)me\ h)\ e)kei=non e)/dei a)poqanei=n, aut mihi aut illi moriendum erat.
PLATO, Apol. 34A: kai\ a)/llous pollou\s e)gw\ e)/xw u(mi=n ei)pei=n, w(=n tina e\xrh=n . . . parasxe/sqai *me/lhton ma/rtura.
HDT.3.66: ou) ga\r h)=n oi( a)sfale\s . . . fa/nai to\n *ku/rou ui(o\n a)polwleke/nai. 8.6. 8.68, a): a)ph/llacan ou(/tw w(s kei/nous e)/prepe.
AR. Nub. 963: prw=ton me\n e)/dei paido\s fwnh\n gru/cantos mhde/n' a)kou=sai . Ibid. 973: e)/dei .
EUR. Alc. 633 (see above).
HOM. Il. 1.353: timh/n pe/r moi o)/fellen *)olu/mpios e)gguali/cai.

p.hi: e)/dei, e)xrh=n, etc., of the present.

div2.p: When e)/dei, e)xrh=n, and the like refer to the present and not to the past, a modal sense is set up, and the dependent infinitive becomes unreal.MSS and editors often fluctuate between e)/dei and dei=, xrh=n and xrh/. The present indicative gives the simple statement, the imperfect indicative surprise or disappointment. Cf. ANTIPHON, 5.91, where the codices have xrh/, Blass xrh=n; Andoc. [4]Andoc., 16, where Blass has e)/dei for MS dei=.
e)xrh=n . . . o(/sion ei)=nai tou=to pra/ttein, LYCURG.141; It ought to be consonant with piety to do this (but it is not).
LYCURG.141(see above).
DEM.15.32: e)xrh=n . . . th\n au)th\n e)/xein dia/noian u(ma=s (= a)ll' ou)k e)/xete) peri\ th=s e)n th=| politei/a| ta/cews, h(/nper peri\ th=s e)n tai=s stratei/ais e)/xete.
THUC.6.78.4: kai\ ma/lista ei)ko\s h)=n u(ma=s . . . mh\ malakw=s w(/sper nu=n cummaxei=n.
HDT.3.80: kai/toi a)/ndra ge tu/rannon a)/fqonon e)/dee ei)=nai, e)/xonta/ ge pa/nta ta\ a)gaqa/. to\ de\ u(penanti/on tou/tou e)s tou\s polih/tas pe/fuke: fqone/ei ga\r kte(.
COM. Hermipp.2.399: tou\s me\n a)/r' a)/llous oi)kourei=n xrh=n.
EUR. Or. 1030: zh=n e)xrh=n s', o(/t' ou)ke/t' ei)= .
In generic sentences the Greek has a tendency to other modal constructions. In practical questions, personal argument, as in poetry and proverbs, the indicative may be used as in English and Latin.

ei)/ tis ei)dw\s . . . prou)/dwken h)\ e)capata=|, ou(=to/s e)st' e)/noxos th=| a)ra=|, DEM.23.97; If any one has wittingly betrayed or wittingly deceives, he is obnoxious to the curse. a(\ mh\ kate/qou, mh\ a)ne/lh|, PROV.; What you didn't deposit, you mustn't draw. tw=| . . . a)sqenou=nti pikra\ fai/netai a(\ e)sqi/ei kai\ e)/sti, PLATO, Theaet. 166E; To the sick man what he eats seems bitter, and is bitter.
PROV. h(/n tis e)/mace ma=zan tau/thn kai\ e)sqie/tw. (See also above.)
DEM.23.97(see above).
AESCHIN.3.196: ei) ga/r tis e)n dhmokrati/a| tetimhme/nos . . . tolma_| bohqei=n toi=s para/noma gra/fousi, katalu/ei th\n politei/an. Ibid. 198: o(/stis . . . ai)tei= (twice).
HDT.3.127: e)/nqa . . . sofi/hs de/ei, bi/hs e)/rgon ou)de/n.
EUR. Tro. 400: feu/gein me\n ou)=n xrh\ po/lemon o(/stis eu)= fronei=.
AESCHYL. Sept. 596: deino\s o(\s qeou\s se/bei.
PIND. N. 3.41-2: o(\s de\ dida/kt' e)/xei, . . . muria=n . . . a)reta=n a)telei= no/w| geu/etai.
HOM. Od. 14.156-7: e)xqro\s ga/r moi kei=nos o(mw=s *)ai/dao pu/lh|sin | gi/gnetai, o(\s peni/h| ei)/kwn a)path)lia ba/zei.

p.hi: Non-use of certain tenses of the indicative with temporal particles.

div2.p: As a rule, temporal particles are not used with the indicative in future relations. Here the subjunctive with a)/n is regularly employed, which becomes optative in oratio obliqua.
Temporal particles with the present and perfect tenses of the indicative are regularly causal or conditional. See Temporal Sentences.

The indicative of the past tenses is used in hopeless wishes. Here some introductory particle, such as ei)/qe, ei) ga/r, is used to show the baselessness of the wish. Or the form w)/felon (w)/fellon), I ought, with the infinitive, is employed. Here there is also, as a rule, an introductory particle: ei)/qe (ai)/qe), ei) ga/r, w(s. The negative is mh/.
The imperfect indicative after ei)/qe, ei) ga/r, denotes a wish for continuance, regularly in opposition to the present, the aorist a wish for attainment, regularly in opposition to the past.
When w)/felon is used, the tenses of the infinitive are employed in the same way, the present infinitive like the imperfect indicative, the aorist infinitive like the aorist indicative.
e)boulo/mhn a)/n (ken) and h)/qelon a)/n (ken) are not infrequent forms of indicating a hopeless wish.In large stretches of prose literature, there is scant occasion for the expression of wish.
a)ll' w)/fele . . . *ku=ros zh=n, XEN. An. 2.1.4; Ah! Cyrus ought to be alive = would that Cyrus were alive.

LYS.3.21: e)boulo/mhn d' a)
 . . . *si/mwna th
 au)th
 gnw/mhn e)moi\ e)/xein .
PLATO , Crito 44 D: ei) ga\r w)/felon . . . oi(=oi/ te ei)=nai oi( polloi\ ta\ me/gista kaka\ e)cerga/zesqai. Rpb. 432 C: ei) ga\r w)/felon (sc. i)dei=n), e)/fh.
XEN. An. 2.1.4 (see above). Cyr. 4.6.3: h(/marten, w(s mh/pote w)/felen.
HDT.1.111: o)/felon. 3.65: ei)=don o)/yin e)n tw=| u(/pnw|, th\n mhdama\ o)/felon i)dei=n.

AR. Nub. 24: ei)/q' e)ceko/phn pro/teron to\n o)fqalmo\n li)qw| . Pax, 1068-9:
ei)/qe sou ei)=nai
w)/felen, w)=lazw/n, ou(twsi\ qermo\s o( pleu/mwn
(mock heroics).

EUR. Alc. 536: ei)/q' eu(/rome/n s), *)/admhte, mh\ lupou/menon. Cycl.186-7: mhdamou= ge/nos pote\ | fu=nai gunaikw=n w)/fel), ei) mh\ )moi\ mo/nw|. El. 282: ei)/q' h)=n *)ore/sths plhsi/on klu/wn ta/de. Ibid. 1061: ei)/q' ei)=xes, w)= tekou=sa, belti/ous fre/nas. I. A. 70: mh/pot' w)/felen labei=n.
SOPH. El. 1021-2: ei)/q' w)/feles toia/de th\n gnw/mhn patro\s | qnh/|skontos ei)=noi: pa=n ga\r a)\n kateirga/sw (ei) h)=sqa, hadst thou been).
PIND. P. 3.1-3: h)/qelon *xei/rwna/ ke *filuri/dan, | . . . | zw/ein to\n a)poixo/menon.
HOM. Od. 5.308-9: w(s dh\ e)gw/ g' o)/felon qane/ein kai\ po/tmon e)pispei=n | h)/mati tw=|, o(/te kte(. 11.548: w(s dh\ mh\ o)/felon nika=n toiw=|d' e)p) a)e/qlw|.

Il. 3.173-4: w(s o)/felen qa/nato/s moi a(dei=n kako/s, o(ppo/te deu=ro | ui(e/i sw=| e(po/mhn. 4.315-6: a)lla/ se gh=ras tei/rei o(moi/ion: w(s o)/fele/n tis | a)ndrw=n a)/llos e)/xein, su\ de\ kourote/roisi metei=nai. 6.345-6: w(s . . . o)/fele c. inf. 7.390: w(s pri\n w)/fell' a)pole/sqai. 11.380-1: w(s o)/felon c. inf.

p.hi: Indicative in other than simple sentences.

div2.p: The following summary embraces the chief uses of the indicative as shown in other than simple sentences.
I. Incomplete Sentences: Questions.

Indicative questions expect or anticipateAnticipation and expectation are not to be confounded. Anticipation treats the future as if it were present. Expectation postpones the realization. To anticipate payment and to expect payment are by no means the same thing, even in popular parlance, and grammarians should be at least as exact as the ungrammatical herd. See A. J. P. xv (1894), 399 and 523; Plat. Apol.1.2.4. indicative answers.
II. Semi-dependent Sentences:
1. Object Sentences.—Sentences introduced by o(/ti, that, and w(s, how that, often retain the indicative after past tenses, as always after principal tenses.
2. Sentences of Result.—Sentences of result with w(/ste (seldom w(s) take the indicative as a statement.
III. Dependent Sentences:
1. Causal Sentences.—The indicative is the only mood used in causal sentences, except as in oratio obliqua.
2. Temporal Sentences.—The indicative in temporal clauses is used chiefly of specific actions.
3. Conditional Sentences.—The indicative in conditional clauses is used either as in indicative questions or as in hopeless wishes.
4. Relative Sentences of Design.—In relative sentences of design the future indicative is used, whereas other languages lean towards optative or subjunctive expressions.
On the Indicative with a)/n, see 428-33.

div2.head: Subjunctive Mood
div2.p: The subjunctive mood is the mood of anticipation. It anticipates the realization of the predicate, which anticipation1 appears chiefly as an act of the will.
The subjunctive derives its name from the notion of the old grammarians that it is always subjoined (subordinate). Such phrases as i)/wmen, Let us go, were explained by bou/lei i)/wmen;

In certain spheres of early Greek, the subjunctive appears as a future with the negative of denial, ou). Hence the theory that the subjunctive was originally a simple future. But it is easier to make the futural subjunctive a deadened imperative than it is to get the imperative notion out of a simple future of prediction. The fact that mh/ is the native negative of the subjunctive (injunctive) seems decisive. Compare the larger use of shall in Early English. See Mätzner, II, p. 87.
In the standard language, the subjunctive is used only in an imperative sense. The tenses follow the general rule (301).
The subjunctive is used as the imperative of the first person, positive and negative. The negative particle is mh/.
skopw/meqa, PLATO, Protag. 314B (304). skeyw/meqa, Ibid. 330 B (304). mh\ diw/kwmen, HDT.8.109; Let us not keep up the chase, let us give up the pursuit (304).
DEM.9.71: tou\s a)/llous h)/dh parakalw=men, kai\ tou\s tau=ta dida/contas e)kpe/mpwmen pre/sbes pantaxoi=. 14.36: mhd' a)dikw=men.
PLATO, Legg. 683C: genw/meqa . . . tai=s dianoi/ais e)n tw=| to/te xro/nw|. 861 A: e)rwtw=men h(ma=s au)tou/s (151). Protag. 314 B (quater). 330 B (see above).
HDT.8.109(see above).
AR. Vesp. 1516: fe/re nun h(mei=s au)toi=s o)li/gon cugxwrh/swmen a(/pantes. Lys. 1096: fe/re to\ e)/sqos a)mbalw/meqa .
SOPH. Ph. 1060-1: ti/ dh=ta sou= dei=; xai=re th\n *lh=mnon patw=n. | h(mei=s d( i)/wmen.
ION (El.), 2.7 (Bgk.4): pi/nwmen, pai/zwmen, i)/tw dia\ nukto\s a)oidh/.

THEOGN. 1133-4:
*ku/rne, parou=si fi/loisi kakou= katapau/somen a)rxh/n,
zhtw=mes d' e(/lkei fa/rmaka fuome/nw| . 1047: nu=n me\n pi/nontes terpw/meqa, kala\ le/gontes.
TERP. fr. 3: spe/ndwmen tai=s *mna/mas paisi\n *mw/sais.
HOM. Od. 1.76-7: a)ll' a)/geq) h(mei=s oi(/de perifrazw/meqa pa/ntes | no/ston.
Il. 1.141-4: nu=n d' a)/ge . . . e)ru/ssomen . . . a)gei/romen . . . qei/omen . . . bh/somen.
The first person singular is less common than the plural, and is usually preceded by fe/re, instead of which Homer uses a)/ge.
DEM.18.267: fe/re dh\ kai\ ta\s tw=n lh|tourgiw=n marturi/as . . . u(mi=n a)nagnw=. 19.169: fe/re dh\ . . . ei)/pw. alib.
PLATO , Phaedo 63 B: fe/re dh\ . . . peiraqw= piqanw/teron . . . a)pologh/sasqai.
HDT.2.14: fe/re de\ nu=n kai\ au)toi=si *ai)gupti/oisi w(s e)/xei fra/sw.
AR. Ach. 4: fe/r' i)/dw (very common). Vesp. 1497: fe/re nun a)nei/pw ka(i\) . . . kalw=. alib. (Aorist much more common than present.)
SOPH. O. C. 174: w)= cei=noi, mh\ dh=t' a)dikhqw= . Ph. 1452: fe/re nun stei/xwn xw/ran kale/sw . Tr. 802.
HOM. Od. 13.215: a)ll' a)/ge dh\ ta\ xrh/mat' a)riqmh/sw kai\ i)/dwmai.
Il. 1.26: mh/ se, ge/ron, koi/lh|sin e)gw\ para\ nhusi\ kixei/w. 21.475: mh/ seu . . . a)kou/sw.

p.hi: Imperative subjunctive of second person positive.

div2.p: The second person positive as an imperative occurs just once in the literary language, and that in a disputed passage.

fe/r' w)= te/knon nu=n kai\ to\ th=s nh/sou ma/qh|s, SOPH. Ph. 300.Nauck reads ma/qe with inferior MSS, Seyffert ka)\n to\ th_s nh/sou ma/qois. The simple imperative optative (394) ma/qois would also be possible, but fe/re seems to require an imperative or subjunctive, and fe/re ma/qh|s may have been generated by fe/re ma/qw.
The subjunctive is used as the negative imperative or prohibitive of the second and third persons in the aorist.
mh\ qauma/sh|s, PLATO, Rpb. 517C; Do not wonder. mhdei\s . . . qauma/sh|, DEM.18.199; Let no one wonder.
ORATORES ATTICI.—There are about 133 instances of the second person and 29 of the third. See A. J. P. xiii (1892), 425.
PLATO, Gorg. 470C: a)lla\ mh\ ka/mh|s fi/lon a)/ndra eu)ergetw=n. Legg. 868 A: fugw\n mhke/ti kate/lqh|. Rpb. 517 C (see above).
THUC.1.140.4: u(mw=n de\ mhdei\s nomi/sh| peri\ braxe/os a)\n polemei=n, ei) kte(. 3.40.7: mh\ ou)=n prodo/tai ge/nhsqe u(mw=n au)tw=n .
HDT.3. 53: mh\ dw=|s ta\ sewutou= a)gaqa\ a)/lloisi.
AR. Ach. 496: mh/ moi fqonh/sht', a)/ndres oi( qew/menoi. Eccl. 588: mh/ nun pro/teron mhdei\s u(mw=n a)ntei/ph| mhd' u(pokrou/sh|.
EUR. Heracl. 271: mh\ pro\s qew=n kh/ruka tolmh/sh|s qenei=n. 273: kai\ su\ tou=de mh\ qi/gh|s, a)/nac. Frequent in the tragedians.
THEOGN. 101: mhdei/s s' a)nqrw/pwn pei/sh| kako\n a)/ndra filh=sai.
HIPPON.49: mhke/ti gra/yh|s.
ALCAE. 44: mhde\n a)/llo futeu/sh|s pro/teron de/ndrion a)mpe/lw.
HOM. Od. 3.55. 11.251. 15.263: ei)pe/ moi ei)rome/nw| nhmerte/a mhd' e)pikeu/sh|s. 22.213-4: *me/ntor, mh/ s' e)pe/essi paraipepi/qh|sin *)odusseu\s | mnhsth/ressi ma/xesqai.
Il. 5.684-5: *priami/dh, mh\ dh/ me e(/lwr *danaoi=sin e)a/sh|s | kei=sqai, a)ll' e)pa/munon. 9.33. 522. 15.115. 23.407. 24.568. 778-9.

p.hi: Theory of mh/ with the aorist subjunctive in prohibitions.

div2.p: The shifting from imperative to subjunctive in the prohibitive is found in other languages, and some scholars have seen a certain urbanity in the change from the second person imperative to the second person subjunctive in the pungent aorist form; but it is noteworthy that a like limitation is found in Sanskrit, in which the corresponding negative particle mA is prevalently used with a form that answers to the Greek aorist subjunctive.See C. W. E. Miller, A. J. P. xiii (1892). 422.

p.hi: Present subjunctive third person as negative imperative.

div2.p: In a few passages the present subjunctive is found as the negative imperative of the third person, when the third person represents the first.
mh\ . . . tis . . . oi)/htai (= mh\ oi)w/meqa), PLATO, Legg. 861E; Let no one think, let us not think.
PLATO, Epin. 989B: mei=zon me\n ga\r a)reth=s mhdei\s h(ma=s pote pei/qh| th=s eu)sebei/as ei)=nai tw=| qnhtw=| ge/nei. Legg. 816 E (see above).

The subjunctive question expects an imperative answer. The question is chiefly in the first person; in the second, only when the speaker puts himself in the place of the person addressed; in the third, chiefly when it represents the first.
Here bou/lei often precedes. qe/leis, thus used, is poetical.

*s*w. w)= *xairefw=n, e)rou= au)to/n. *x*a*i. ti/ e)/rwmai; PLATO, Gorg. 447C; Chaerephon, ask him. What shall I ask? bou/lei tolmh/sw ei)pei=n oi(=o/n e)sti to\ e)pi/stasqai; PLATO, Theaet. 197A; Do you wish me to undertake to say what manner of thing knowing is?
DEM.3.22: “ti/ bou/lesqe; ti/ gra/yw; ti/ u(mi=n xari/swmai;” 14.27: a)lla\ qw= bou/lesqe dwdeka/thn h(ma=s ei)soi/sein; [33]DEM., 37.

PLATO, Conv. 213A: e)pi\ r(htoi=s ei)si/w h)\ mh/; sumpi/esqe h)\ ou)/; Ibid. 214 B: *e*r. ti/ poiw=men; *a*l*k. o(/ ti a)\n su\ keleu/h|s . . . e)pi/tatte ou)=n o(/ ti bou/lei. Gorg. 447 C (see above). Phaedo 115 C: qa/ptwmen de/ se ti/na tro/pon; Theaet. 149B, 161 E. 197 A (see above).
AR. Eq. 36: bou/lei to\ pra=gma toi=s qeatai=sin fra/sw; Vesp. 760-1: *b*d*e. e)moi\ piqou=. | *f*i*l. ti/ soi pi/qwmai; Lys. 529-30: *l*u*s. siw/pa. *p*r*o. soi/ g), w)= kata/rate, siwpw= 'gw/;

EUR. Cycl. 149. Ion, 758 (268). I. T. 1321. Or. 218: bou/lei qi/gw sou;
fr. 1036: po/tera qe/leis soi malqaka\ yeudh= le/gw | h)\ sklh/r' a)lhqh=;
HOM. Od. 15.509: ph=| t' a)/r) e)gw/, fi/le te/knon, i)/w; te/o dw/maq) i(/kwmai;
Il. 18.188: pw=s t' a)/r) i)/w meta\ mw=lon; e)/xousi de\ teu/xe) e)kei=noi.
The second person of the deliberative subjunctive occurs only in echo-questions, and is virtually indirect.
*e*p. ti/ soi piqw/meq'; *p*e*i. o(/ ti pi/qhsqe; AR. Av. 164 ; Wherein shall we follow your advice? Wherein you shall follow my advice?
SOPH. Ph. 974: *n*e. ti/ drw=men, a)/ndres; *o*d. w)= ka/kist' a)ndrw=n, ti/ dra=|s; (Dost ask) what thou art to do?More dramatic than as an indicative. Odvsseus overhears Neoptolemos.
The third person of the deliberative subjunctive is used more commonly when the third person represents the first, or when an action of the first person is involved.
o( toiou=tos . . . mh\ dw=| . . . di/khn; (= mh\ la/bwmen para\ tou= toiou/tou di/khn;) DEM.21.35; Shall not such an one get his due? (= Shall we not punish him?)
DEM.18.124: po/tero/n se/ tis *ai)sxi/nh th=s po/lews e)xqro\n h)\ e)mo\n ei)=nai qh=|; (= po/teron . . . qw=;) 20.117. 21.35 (see above). 22.64. 29.37: ti/ soi poih/swsin oi( ma/rtures;
PLATO, Phileb. 15D: po/qen ou)=n tis tau/ths a)/rchtai pollh=s ou)/shs kai\ pantoi/as peri\ ta\ a)mfisbhtou/mena ma/xhs; (= po/qen a)rcw/meqa;)
AR. Pl. 438: a)/nac *)/apollon kai\ qeoi/, poi= tis fu/gh|;

SOPH. Ai. 403-4: poi= tis ou)=n fu/gh| poi= molw\n menw=;
O. C. 170-1:
*o*i. qu/gater, poi= tis fronti/dos e)/lqh|
*a*n. w)= pa/ter, a)stoi=s i)/sa xrh\ meleta=n
.
THEOGN. 772: ti/ sfin xrh/shtai (sc. *mousw=n qera/pwn = *qe/ognis = e)gw/) mou=nos e)pista/menos;
HOM. Od. 5.465: w)/ moi e)gw/, ti/ pa/qw; ti/ nu/ moi mh/kista ge/nhtai; (= ti/ ge/nwmai;)
Il. 1.150: pw=s ti/s toi pro/frwn e)/pesin pei/qhtai *)axaiw=n; (= pw=s peiqw/meqa;)
Instead of the subjunctive, we find the future also (268), or dei=, xrh/ with the infinitive, or the verbal in -te/on.
ti/ dh=ta dei= skopei=n; SOPH. Ph. 428 (cf. O. R. 364). a)/ge dh/, ti/ xrh\ dra=n; AR. Av. 809 (cf. vv. 812. 814. 817). a)/ge dh/, ti/ nw=|n e)nteuqeni\ poihte/on; AR. Pax 922 (cf. Av. 1640).
Notice the frequent use of ti/ pa/qw; What am I to submit to in order to a certain end? What is to become of me? is one side, What am I to do? is another.
to\ me/llon, ei) xrh/, pei/somai. ti/ ga\r pa/qw; EUR. Phoen. 895; What is to come. I'll bear, if need be. What's the odds? (Let fate do her worst.)

AR. Av. 1432: ti/ ga\r pa/qw; ska/ptein ga\r ou)k e)pi/stamai . Lys. 884: oi(=on to\ tekei=n: katabate/on. ti/ ga\r pa/qw; 954. Eccl. 860. Pl. 603. (Cf. Nub. 461: ti/ pei/somai;
Ibid. 791. Vesp. 1000. Eccl. 911.)
EUR. Phoen. 895 (see above).
SOPH. Tr. 973: ti/ pa/qw; ti/ de\ mh/somai; oi)/moi.
HOM. Od. 5.465: w)/ moi e)gw/, ti/ pa/qw; ti/ nu/ moi mh/kista ge/nhtai;
Il. 11.404-5: w)/ moi e)gw/, ti/ pa/qw; me/ga me\n kako/n, ai)/ ke fe/bwmai | plhqu\n tarbh/sas.

In Plato , but rarely elsewhere in Attic, we find a number of hesitating half-questions with mh/ or mh\ ou) and the present subjunctive. These seem to depend on the state of apprehension engendered by the situation. The effect is that of a doubtful affirmation, or negation, as the case may be. See mh/ and mh\ ou).A. J. P. xvii (1896), 516-7.

mh\ a)groiko/teron h)=| to\ a)lhqe\s ei)pei=n, PLATO, Gorg. 462E; It's rather bad form, I fear, to speak the truth. a)lla\ mh\ ou) tou=t' h)=| xalepo\n . . . qa/naton e)kfugei=n, PLATO, Apol. 39A; But that's not the trouble, I apprehend, the escaping death.
DEM.1.26: mh\ li/an pikro\n ei)pei=n h)=| (but Blass: mh\ li/an pikro\n ei)pei=n;).

PLATO, Apol. 39A (see above). Gorg. 462 E (see above).According to Weber, Entwickelungsgeschichte der Absichtssätze, p. 192, there are in Plato 31 instances of this use, which are distributed as follows: Apology 1, Symposium 2, Cratylus 8, Crito 3, Gorgias 1, Laws 1, Lysis 3, Meno 3, Parmenides .4, Phaedo 2, Lovers 1, Theaetetus 1, Theages 1. This does not include four, more or less disputed, passages in which the sentence may be interrogative: Parmen. 163D. Phaedo, 64 C. Rpb. 603 C. Sisyph. 387 D. (Weber, ibid.)
HDT.5.79: a)lla\ ma=llon mh\ ou) tou=to h)=| to\ xrhsth/rion .
For the suppression of a verb of fear or apprehension, see Verbs of Fear.

The Homeric subjunctive is not so clearly defined in its use as the Attic subjunctive, and is often indistinguishable from a future. In fact, it serves as a missing aorist future where prose would employ the optative with a)/n.
ou) ga/r pw toi/ous i)/don a)ne/ras ou)de\ i)/dwmai, HOM. Il. 1.262; Never as yet have I seen such men, and never shall see them.
HYMN. HOM. 1.1: mnh/somai ou)de\ la/qwmai *)apo/llwnos e(ka/toio.
HOM. Od. 6.201: ou)k e)/sq' ou(=tos a)nh\r diero\s broto/s, ou)de\ ge/nhtai. 16.437: ou)k e)/sq' ou(=tos a)nh\r ou)d' e)/ssetai ou)de\ ge/nhtai.

Il. 1.262 (see above). 6.459: kai/ pote/ tis ei)/ph|sin i)dw\n kata\ da/kru xe/ousan . 7.87: kai/ pote/ tis ei)/ph|si kai\ o)yigo/nwn a)nqrw/pwn. 197: ou) ga/r ti/s me bi/h| ge e(kw\n a)e/konta di/htai.
On a)/n (ken) with the subjunctive in simple sentences, see 451-6.

All the uses of the subjunctive in dependent clauses may be referred ultimately to the imperative sense so conspicuous in the leading clause, but in prose the pure subjunctive is confined to the final sentence, which is necessarily imperative in its nature. In other classes of sentences a)/n (ken) with the subjunctive is the rule, though there are many exceptions in the older language and in poetry. See 456.

div2.head: Optative Mood
div2.p: In principal clauses, the use of the optative, or wishing, mood in standard Greek is confined to the expression of wishes the fulfilment of which is still in suspense. The negative is mh/.

diarragei/hs, AR. Av. 2 ; May you burst in two!
mh\ pau/saio mhde/pot' e)sqi/wn, AR. Pax 31 ; May you never stop eating!

The optative is the ideal mood of the Greek language, the mood of the fancy. The wish is father to the thought, and “fancy” has a double signification, moral as well as intellectual. But the intellectual use, the use in qualified assertions or the so-called potential use, is confined to the optative with a)/n, except in poetry. The prose examples are comparatively few, and are either doubtful or occur in fixed formulae. The negative of the potential optative is ou).
For examples, see Optative with a)/n.

As the mood of the question is the mood of the expected or anticipated answer, no direct question can be put in the pure optative of wish, inasmuch as no question expects a wish for an answer, though it may get one. Whenever, then, the optative is found in a direct question, it is a potential optative, and, like other potential optative questions, implies a wish of the speaker. Corruption of the text is often indicated.
h)= r(a/ nu/ moi/ ti pi/qoio; HOM. Il. 4.93 = 7.48; Ah, wouldst thou not yield to me somewhat? (= ei)/qe pi/qoio).
See under Optative with a)/n.
The pure optative is used in two tenses, present and aorist. Certain perfects and periphrastic perfects count as presents. See also 305.
DEM.1.28. 4.51: nikw/|h d' o(/ ti pa=sin me/llei sunoi/sein (305).
PLATO, Legg. 923B: poreu/oisqe h(=|per kata\ fu/sin nu=n poreu/esqe th\n a)nqrwpi/nhn. 941 C: eu)tuxoi=.
HDT.3.65: gh= te karpo\n e)kfe/roi kai\ gunai=ke/s te kai\ poi=mnai ti/ktoien. 6.69: ti/ktoien.
AR. Eq. 770: e(yoi/mhn. 772: e(lkoi/mhn. Nub. 520: ou(/tw nikh/saimi/ t' e)gw\ kai\ nomizoi/mhn sofo/s .
EUR. El. 231: eu)daimonoi/hs. Hipp. 1191: *zeu=, mhke/t( ei)/hn, ei) kako\s pe/fuk' a)nh/r. fr. 369 (three times).
SOPH. O. C. 642: w)= *zeu=, didoi/hs toi=si toiou/toisin eu(= .
AESCHYL. Pers. 228: e)kteloi=to dh\ ta\ xrhsta/. Sept. 188: ei)/hn.
PIND. O. 4.11-2: qeo\s eu)/frwn | ei)/h. P. 1.29: ei)/h, *zeu=, ti\n ei)/h *fanda/nein.
SOLON, 19: nai/ois . . . pe/mpoi . . . o)pa/zoi.
HOM. Od. 13.44-6: u(mei=s d' au)=qi me/nontes e)ufrai/noite gunai=kas . . . kai\ mh/ ti kako\n metadh/mion ei)/h.
Il. 2.259: mhke/t' . . . e)pei/h. 6.480: fe/roi d' e)/nara broto/enta .
DEM.3.36(see 305). 18.324: mh\ dh=t', w)= pa/ntes qeoi/, mhdei\s tau=q' u(mw=n e)pineu/seien, a)lla\ ma/lista me\n kai\ tou/tois belti/w tina\ nou=n kai\ fre/nas e(nqei/hte.
LYS.21.21: ou(=toi me\n ou)=n . . . katei/poien u(mi=n ta\ sfe/ter' au)tw=n e)pithdeu/mata .
ANTIPHON, 1.13: di/kh de\ kubernh/seien.
PLATO, Legg. 712B: o( de\ (sc. qeo/s) a)kou/seie/ te kai\ a)kou/sas i(/lews eu)menh/s te h(mi=n e)/lqoi. 913 A: mhd' au)= kinh/seie.
AR. Eq. 768: a)poloi/mhn kai\ diaprisqei/hn katatmhqei/hn te le/padna. 771: kataknhsqei/hn. Nub. 520: nikh/saimi (see 391). Vesp. 630: a)poloi/mhn ei)/ se de/doika.
EUR. Or. 130: qeoi/ se mish/seian (blast you with their hate), w(/s m' a)pw/lesas .
SOPH. Ai. 550: w)= pai=, ge/noio patro\s eu)tuxe/steros .
AESCHYL. P.V. 864: toia/d' e)p) e)xqrou\s tou\s e)mou\s e)/lqoi *ku/pris.
PIND. P. 9.89-90: *xari/twn keladenna=n | mh/ me li/poi kaqaro\n fe/ggos.
SOLON, 21: mhde/ moi a)/klaustos qa/natos mo/loi.
HOM. Od. 6.180: soi\ de\ qeoi\ to/sa doi=en o(/sa fresi\ sh=|si menoina=|s. 13.45: o)pa/seian.
Il. 1.42: ti/seian *danaoi\ e)ma\ da/krua soi=si be/lessin. 6.481: xarei/h .
THEOGN. 343-4: teqnai/hn d', ei) mh/ ti kakw=n a)/mpauma merimne/wn | eu(roi/mhn.

The optative at times comes very near the imperative.This imperative use of the optative offers a solution for a number of passages where the optative with a)/n might be expected. See B. L. G. on PINDAR, O. 3.45, and P. 10.21.

Il. 3.74: nai/oite. 159-60: e)n nhusi\ nee/sqw | mhd(e\) . . . li/poito. 407: mhd' e)/ti . . . u(postre/yeias. 17.340-1: i)/omen, mhd' oi(/ ge . . . pelasai/ato. 24.139: th=|d' ei)/h. 149: kh=ru/c ti/s oi( e(/poito gerai/teros.
The optative may have, but does not require, ei)/qe (ai)/qe), ei) ga/r (ai)\ ga/r), and the like.Explained by many grammarians as elliptical conditional sentences. See Conditional Sentences.

In poetry we find a simple ei), the exclamatory w(s. and in one passage an unriddled ba/le.

Il. 10.111: a)ll' ei)/ tis kai\ tou/sde metoixo/menos kale/seien. 15.571: ei)/ tina/ pou *trw(wn e)ca/lmenos a)/ndra ba/loisqa. 16.559-62: a)ll' ei)/ min a)eikissai/meq) e(lo/ntes | teu/xea/ t' w)/moiin a)feloi/meqa kai/ tin) e(tai/rwn | au)tou= a)munome/nwn damasai/meqa nhle/i xalkw=|. 18.107: w(s e)/ris e)/k te qew=n e)/k t' a)nqrw/pwn a)po/loito. 22.286: w(s dh/ min sw=| e)ni\ xroi+\ pa=n komi/saio.
The pure optative seems to us strangest in relative sentences. Here the English idiom requires the expression of the notion of wish, if the relative form is to be retained.

oi(=) au)toi=s tu/xoi, SOPH. Ph. 275: Which manner of things I wish Fortune may send to them, Fortune send them the like! o(\ mh\ ge/noito, AESCHYL. Sept. 5; May it not come to pass, Heaven forbid! (a common formula).
