EUR. Heracl. 512: a(\ mh\ tu/xoi pote/. 714: o(\ mh\ ge/noito. Phoen. 571: o(\ mh\ tu/xoi pote/.
SOPH. Ph. 275 (see above). 315-6: w)= pai=, dedra/kas), oi(=) *)olu/mpioi qeoi\ | doi=e/n pot' au)toi=s a)nti/poin) e)mou= paqei=n.
AESCHYL. Sept. 5 (see above). 426: a(\ mh\ krai/noi tu/xh.
HOM. Od. 4.699: o(\ mh\ tele/seie *kroni/wn.

The optative is more or less passionate, and is little used in the conventional language of the orators. A favorite substitute is bouloi/mhn a)/n (Lat. velim) with the infinitive. Cf. e)boulo/mhn a)/n (Lat. vellem) 367.
DEM.24.8: bouloi/mhn d' a)\n e)me/ te tuxei=n w(=n bou/lomai, tou=to/n te paqei=n w(=n a)/cio/s e)sti.
LYS.7.12: nu=n de\ pa/ntas a)\n u(ma=s bouloi/mhn peri\ e)mou= tau/thn th\n gnw/mhn e)/xein . 8.2.
ANDOC.2.28: bouloi/mhn me/nt' a)\n . . . (sc. u(ma=s) a)telh= th\n gnw/mhn au)tw=n poih=sai.

PLATO, Apol. 19A: bouloi/mhn me
 ou)=n a)
 tou=to ou(/tw gene/sqai . . . oi)=mai de\ au)to\ xalepo
 ei)=nai.
AESCHYL. Suppl. 787: qe/loimi d' a)\n morsi/mou bro/xou tuxei=n.
BACCHYL.17.41-3: ou) ga\r a)\n qe/loim' a)mbro/toi) e)ranno\n a)ou=s i)dei=n fa/os (= mh\ i)/doimi).
For pw=s a)/n with the Optative in Wishes, see Optative with a)/n.

p.hi: Optative in semi-dependent and in dependent clauses.

div2.p: Outside of the Ideal (Optative) Condition the main uses of the optative in semi-dependent (368) and dependent sentences are these:
I. Optative after Historical Tenses:
The optative is used to represent both the indicative and the subjunctive in oratio obliqua after historical tenses.
1. Optative for Indicative.—When the optative represents the indicative, it takes all the corresponding tenses of the indicative. For examples, see 307-310 and 312.

2. Optative as Representative of the Subjunctive.—When the optative represents the subjunctive, it is of course limited to the subjunctive tenses—present, aorist, and perfect. For examples, see Oratio Obliqua.

The optative is also said to represent the subjunctive with a)/n in oratio obliqua, but in the class of sentences in which this is said to take place, a)/n was not required in the early language, so that there is no violation of the rule.See A. J. P. iii (1882), 441.
II. Optative in Complementary Clauses:
The optative is used in complementary clauses, often when we should expect a form of the subjunctive. For examples, see Relative Sentences.

p.hi: Parallelism of the optative and the infinitive.

div2.p: The optative may be called the finite form of the infinitive, and it is noteworthy that the two run closely parallel in wishes, in commands, in oratio obliqua, and in complementary clauses.

div2.head: Imperative Mood
div2.p: The imperative demands realization. The tone of the demand varies, and may appear as an order, an exhortation, a permission, an entreaty, an assumption.On the Imperative Mood, see C. W. E. Miller, The Limitation of the Imperative in the Attic Orators, A. J. P. xiii (1892), 399-436. The negative is mh/.

The imperative, like the infinitive, is used chiefly in two tenses, the present and the aorist.Out of a total number of 2445 imperatives in the Attic Orators, exclusive of the letters, the fragments, the laws, the bracketed portions of the text, all of Hyperides, and the Demosthenean collection of prooemia, there are only seven—or, counting teqna/tw, eight—real perfects. The ratio of presents to aorists is that of 55 to 45. (See l. c., pp. 402 and 425.)
PRESENT IMPERATIVE:
ISOC.2.There are 55 present imperatives of the second person out of a total of 58 imperatives of the second person, exclusive of the bracketed ones.
LYS.1.18: yeu/sh| de\ mhde/n, a)lla\ pa/nta ta)lhqh= le/ge .

p.hi: Additional remarks on the use of the present and aorist tenses.

div2.p: As a descriptive adverb is. often associated with the imperfect indicative, so a descriptive adverb is often associated with a present imperative. So also adverbs denoting speed. AR. Eq. 495: speu=de taxe/ws. Ibid. Vesp. 180: ba/dize qa=tton. 187: u(/felke qa=tton.

The present imperative often produces the effect of an action that is watched. See the cooking scene in the Acharnians cited 403, and Pax, 842: a)ll' ei)/sag) w(s ta/xista followed by kata/kluze . . . qe/rmain(e) . . . sto/rnu. So also 960 sqq.: sei/ou . . . pro/teine . . . xerni/ptou . . . r(i=pte, whereas in a prayer, Ibid. 987-98: a)po/fhnon . . . lu=son . . . pau=son . . . mi=con . . . ke/rason.See Justin Martyr, Apol. I, 16.6.
The perfect active imperative is little used, even when the perfect is employed as a present, except i)/sqi, i)/stw, i)/ste, from oi)=da. Nor is the periphrastic common.

“kai\ a)/timos,” fhsi/n, “teqna/tw,” DEM.9.44. o( qewro\s . . . gegonw\s (fully adjective) e)/stw pleio/nwn e)tw=n h)\ penth/konta, PLATO, Legg. 951C (but in the same breath of the same subject, e)/stw gegenhme/nos, Ibid. D).
DEM.9.44(see above).
PLATO, Legg. 874C: nhpoinei\ teqna/tw (= passive) u(po\ . . . tou= u(brisqe/ntos bi/a|. 938 C: e)a/n tis filoniki/a| kriqh=| di\s to\ toiou=ton dra=n, teqna/tw. 951 C (see above).

A similar observation applies to the perfect middle.
me/mnhso/ mou, AR. Pax, 719; Remember me.

The perfect imperative passive is not unfrequently used in judicial sentences, in harsh orders, in philosophical definitions, of something that is to be settled and to stay settled, but in the third person only. The second person is so rare that it is not safe to generalize.
a)nerri/fqw ku/bos, COM. Men. 4.88 (303). tau=ta . . . pepai/sqw . . . u(mi=n, PLATO, Euthyd. 278C: Let this be the end of your fun. ei)rh/sqw, Let it be said and settled, is especially common.
Pr.18: mh\ pa/nq), w(s e(/kastos e)/xei gnw/mhs u(mw=n peri\ tw=n paro/ntwn, o)rqw=s e)gnwke/nai pepei/sqw.

p.hi: a)/ge, i)/qi, fe/re with the imperative.

div2.p: In exhortations a)/ge, i)/qi, fe/re, and the like (usually with dh/ or nun) often precede the imperative.
a)/ge dh/, ka/teipe/ moi su\ to\n sautou= tro/pon, AR. Nub. 478. i)/qi dh/, ka/teipe , Pax, 405. fe/re dh\ pro\s qew=n ka)kei=no ske/yasqe, DEM.21.58.
a)/ge, a)/gete:

PLATO , Phaedo 86 E: a)ll' a)/ge, h)= d' o(/s, w)= *ke/bhs, le/ge. Phaedr. 237 A: a)/gete dh/, w)= *mou=sai, . . . cu/m moi la/besqe tou= mu/qou. Phileb. 39 E: a)/ge dh/, . . . kai\ to/de a)po/krinai.

XEN. An. 2.2.10: a)/ge dh/, . . . ei)pe\ ti/na gnw/mhn e)/xeis. 7.6.33: a)/gete dh\ pro\s qew=n kai\ ta\ e)ma\ ske/yasqe w(s e)/xei. Apol. 14: a)/ge dh\ a)kou/sate kai\ a)/lla . Conv. 2.21: a)/ge dh/, e)/fh o( *fi/lippos, kai\ e)moi\ au)lhsa/tw. Cyr. 7.5.24: a)ll' a)/gete lamba/nete ta\ o(/pla.
AR. Ach. 111: a)/ge dh\ su\ fra/son e)moi\ safw=s pro\s toutoni/. Nub. 478 (410), and frequently.
SOPH. Ai. 1097: a)/g), ei)/p' a)p) a)rxh=s au)=qis . Tr. 1255: a)/g' e)gkonei=t', ai)/resqe.
AESCHYL. Cho. 803-4: a)/gete, tw=n pa/lai pepragme/nwn | lu/sasq' ai(=ma prosfa/tois di/kais.
PIND. O. 1.77-80: a)/g(e) . . . pe/dason . . . po/reuson . . . pe/lason.
ARCHIL.4: a)ll' a)/ge, su\n kw/qwni qoh=s dia\ se/lmata nho\s | foi/ta kai\ koi/lwn pw/mat' a)/felke ka/dwn.
TYRTAE. 15: a)/get', w)= *spa/rtas eu)a/ndrou | kou=roi pate/rwn poliata=n, | laia=| me\n i)/tun proba/lesqe.
HOM. Od. 3.17: a)ll' a)/ge nu=n i)qu\s ki/e *ne/storos i(ppoda/moio.
Il. 1.337: a)ll' a)/ge, diogene\s *patro/klees, e)/cage kou/rhn.
i)/qi, i)/te:
DEM.36.56: i)/qi dh\ labe\ ta\s pro\s *)apollo/dwron th=s ponhri/as. [40]DEM., 19: i)/qi dh\ labe\ . . . to\n . . . no/mon.

PLATO, Gorg. 489E: a)ll' i)/qi ei)pe/. Phaedr. 228 E: a)ll' i)/qi dei/knue. 262 D: i)/qi dh/ moi a)na/gnwqi th\n tou= *lusi/ou lo/gou a)rxh/n. PLAT. Soph. 239B: i)/qi . . . peira/qhti. Theaet. 195 E: i)/qi ou)=n dh/, su\ a)pokri/nou.
AR. Nub. 497: i)/qi nun, kata/qou qoi)ma/tion . Pax, 405 (410). Pl. 255: i)/t' e)gkonei=te, speu/deq). saepe.

SOPH. Ai. 988: i)/q', e)gko/nei . 1003: i)/q', e)kka/luyon . O. R. 46-7:
i)/q', w)= brotw=n a)/rist', a)no/rqwson po/lin:
i)/q', eu)labh/qhq'
, and elsewhere.
HOM. Od. 22.157: a)ll' i)/qi, di=) *eu)/maie, qu/rhn e)pi/qes qala/moio.
Il. 1.32: a)ll' i)/qi, mh/ m' e)re/qize. 10.53: a)ll' i)/qi nu=n, *ai)/anta kai\ *)idomenh=a ka/lesson.
fe/re:

DEM.15.26: fe/re ga\r pro\s qew=n skopei=te. 19.174: fe/re dh\ . . . qea/sasqe. 251: fe/re dh\ . . . ske/yasqe. 21.58: fe/re dh\ pro\s qew=n ka)kei=no ske/yasqe. 25. 73 (id.). Pr. 53.3: fe/re dh\ ske/yasqe .
PLATO, Cratyl. 385B: fe/re dh/ moi to/de ei)pe/.
AR. Nub. 1088: fe/re dh/ moi fra/son . Ran. 1417: fe/re pu/qesqe/ mou tadi/. Eccl. 710: fe/re nun fra/son moi, tau=t' a)re/skei sfw=|n;
SOPH. Ant. 534: fe/r' ei)pe\ dh/ moi . El. 310. 376: fe/r' ei)pe\ dh\ to\ deino/n. O. R. 390. 536. 1142. Ph. 433. Tr. 890.

AESCHYL. P. V. 294-5:
fe/re ga\r
sh/main' o(/ti xrh/ soi sumpra/ssein
.

The imperative in prohibitions takes the negative mh/. The tenses employed are the present, the aorist, and the perfect, the perfect chiefly as a present perfect (303). The first person is represented by the subjunctive (373). In the second person aorist, the subjunctive is used practically to the exclusion of the imperative. In the third person aorist, the subjunctive is preferred in standard prose.

p.hi: Difference between present and aorist in prohibitions.

div2.p: mh/ with the present imperative has to do with a course of action and means sometimes “keep from” (RESIST!), sometimes “cease to” (DESIST!). In the one case a negative course of actióon is prescribed, in the other the negative of a course of action. Compare with this construction the negative with the imperfect (resistance to pressure).
mh/ with the aorist imperative or subjunctive gives a total prohibition.

mh\ la/lei, AR. Vesp. 1135, may mean, according to circumstances, “stop talking” (compare pau=sai kai\ mh\ pate/rize, AR. Vesp. 652; Stop and cease “fathering” me) or “keep mum.”
a)ntibolh/sei kai\ i(keteu/sei u(ma=s: mh\ e)leei=te, LYS. [6] 55 ; He will beg and beseech you. Don't pity him. Steel your hearts against him. mh\ qauma/sh|s, ISOC. [1] 44: Don't be astonished (one of three aorists in a host of presents). qauma/zw, h)=n d' e)gw/, kai\ au)to/s. a)lla\ mh\ qau/maz), e)/fh, PLATO, Conv. 205B; I am astonished . . . Well, suppress your astonishment. . . .
PRESENT IMPERATIVE IN PROHIBITIONS:
DIN.1.109: mh\ . . . a)/xqesq(e). 113: mh\ a)pode/xesq(e). 3.11: mh\ . . . h(gei=sqe.
ISAE. 3.79: mh\ a)mnhmonei=te. 8.20: mh\ oi)/esq(e).
LYS. 6.55(see 415). 12.91: mhd' oi)/esqe . 13.83: mh/te . . . a)pode/xesqe . 19.10: mh\ . . . prokatagignw/skete .

PLATO, Conv. 205B (see 415). Legg. 871 D: mh\ . . . qapte/sqw. 936 C: mhdei\s . . . gigne/sqw. Phaedo 117 A: mh\ . . . poi/ei. Theaet. 146 B: a)ll), w(/sper h)/rcw, mh\ a)fi/eso tou= *qeaith/tou, a)ll' e)rw/ta. 167 E: poi/ei me/ntoi ou(twsi/: mh\ a)di/kei e)n tw=| e)rwta=n.
XEN. Cyr. 3.1.35: pro\s tw=n qew=n, e)/fh, w)= *ku=re, mh\ ou(/tw le/ge.
THUC.1.86.4: w(s h(ma=s pre/pei bouleu/esqai a)dikoume/nous mh dei\s didaske/tw. Ibid. 5: mh/te tou\s *)aqhnai/ous e)a=te mei/zous gi/gnesqai mh/te tou\s cumma/xous kataprodidw=men.

HDT.1.9: qa/rsee, *gu/gh, kai\ mh\ fobeu=. 85: w)/nqrwpe, mh\ ktei=ne *kroi=son. 5.40: mh\ a)nti/baine. 8.140, a): mh\ . . . bou/lesqe. 9.111: gunaiki\ dh\ tau/th| th=| nu=n sunoike/eis mh\ sunoi/kee . . . th\n de\ nu=n e)/xeis . . . mh\ e)/xe gunai=ka.
AR. Ach. 1054: mh/ . . . di/dou. Vesp. 652: pau=sai kai\ mh\ pate/rize (415). 1135: mh\ la/lei (415).
COM. 4.341.39: a(\ mh\ prosh/kei mh/t' a)/koue mh/q) o(/ra. 4.356.578: mhde/pote dou=lon h(donh=s sauto\n poi/ei. Crat. 2.231: th\n xei=ra mh\ )pi/balle, mh\ kla/wn kaqh=|.
EUR. Ion, 257: mh\ fro/ntiz(e). 367: mh\ )ce/legxe. Med. 807: mhdei/s me fau/lhn ka)sqenh= nomize/tw . Phoen. 18: mh\ spei=re.
SOPH. Ai. 115: fei/dou mhde/n . El. 395-6: H. mh/ m' e)kdi/daske . . . | X. a)ll' ou) dida/skw.
AESCHYL. Eum. 133: mh/ se nika/tw po/nos. P. V. 44: mh\ po/nei . Sept. 262: si/ghson w)= ta/laina, mh\ fi/lous fo/bei.
PIND. O. 1.5: mhke/t(i) . . . sko/pei. 117: mhke/ti pa/ptaine. 4.14: mh\ ma/teue.
XENOPHANES, 6.4 (Bgk.): pau=sai mhde\ r(a/piz(e).
THEOGN. 31-2: kakoi=si de\ mh\ prosomi/lei | a)ndra/sin a)ll' ai)ei\ tw=n a)gaqw=n e)/xeo (31). 578: mh/ me di/dask): ou)/ toi thli/kos ei)mi\ maqei=n.

HOM. Od. 1.315: mh\ . . . kate/ruke. 4.543-4: mhke/ti . . . klai=(e). 594: mh\ . . . e)/ruke. 7.303: mh\ . . . nei/kee. 10.266: mh/ m' a)/ge kei=s) a)e/konta, diotrefe/s, a)lla\ li/p) au)tou=. 14.387: mh/te . . . xari/zeo mh/te . . . qe/lge. 19.42: si/ga . . . mhd' e)re/eine.

Il. 1. 210: mhde\ . . . e(/lkeo. 3.82: i)/sxesq), *)arge/ioi, mh\ ba/llete, kou=roi *)axaiw=n. 6.264: mh/ moi oi)=non a)/eire (as she had offered to do) meli/frona po/tnia mh=ter . 23.735: mhke/t' e)rei/desqon (149).
AORIST SUBJUNCTIVE IN PROHIBITIONS.—For the aorist subjunctive in prohibitions, see 376.
AORIST IMPERATIVE IN PROHIBITIONS:

DEM.19.77: mh\ . . . mh\ do/tw di/khn. [42]DEM., 31: o(\ mhdamw=s nuni\ gene/sqw. [49]DEM., 1: mhdeni\ u(mw=n a)/piston gene/sqw. Pr. 35.2: kai\ mhdemia=s loidori/as o(\ me/llw le/gein a)rxh\ gene/sqw .

AESCHIN.1.19-20: mhde\ sundikhsa/tw . . . mhde\ a)rca/tw . . . mhde\ khrukeusa/tw, mhde\ presbeusa/tw . . . mhde\ . . . ei)pa/tw mhde/pote (5 instances in the provisions of a law quoted by Aeschines). 3.60: o(/stis ou(/tw dia/keitai mh/t' a)pognw/tw mhde

> a)kou/sh|.
ISAE. 9.35: kai\ ei) le/gein e)mou= du/natai *kle/wn ka/llion, tou=to au)tw=| . . . mhde\n i)sxusa/tw. (The above are about the only occurrences in the Orators. See A. J. P. xiii (1892), 425 f.)
PLATO, Apol. 17C: pisteu/w ga\r di/kaia ei)=nai a(\ le/gw, kai\ mhdei\s u(mw=n prosdokhsa/tw a)/llws. Legg. 924 C: kai\ tou=to e)klipe/tw mhde/pote kata\ du/namin.

XEN. Ages. 10.3. Cyneg. 2.2: kai\ mhdei\s au)ta\ fau=la nomisa/tw ei)=nai. Cyr. 7.5.73: kai\ mhdei/s ge u(mw=n e)/xwn tau=ta nomisa/tw a)llo/tria e)/xein. 8.7.26: ei)/ tis ou)=n u(mw=n . . . o)/mma tou)mo\n zw=ntos e)/ti prosidei=n e)qe/lei, prosi/tw: o(/tan d' e)gw\ e)gkalu/ywmai, ai)tou=mai u(ma=s, w)= pai=des, mhdei\s e)/t' a)nqrw/pwn tou)mo\n sw=ma i)de/tw, mhd' au)toi\ u(mei=s.
SOPH. Ai. 1180-1: mhde/ se kinhsa/tw tis . 1334: mhd' h( bi/a se mhdamw=s nikhsa/tw . O. R. 1449-50: e)mou= de\ mh/pot' a)ciwqh/tw to/de | patrw=|on a)/stu zw=ntos oi)khtou= tuxei=n.
AESCHYL. P.V. 332: kai\ nu=n e)/ason mhde/ soi melhsa/tw. 1002-3: ei)selqe/tw se mh/poq' w(s e)gw\ . . . qhlu/nous genh/somai. Sept. 1036: mh\ dokhsa/tw tini/, but v. 1040: mhde/ tw| do/ch| pa/lin.
PIND. O. 8.56: mh\ bale/tw me li/qw| traxei= fqo/nos. P. 5.23: tw=| se mh\ laqe/tw.
HOM. Od. 16.301: mh/ tis e)/peit' *)odush=os a)kousa/tw e)/ndon e)o/ntos.
Il. 16.200: *murmido/nes, mh/ ti/s moi a)peila/wn lelaqe/sqw.
ORATORES ATTICI: Apparently no examples. See A. J. P. xiii (1892), 426.
AR. Thesm. 870: mh\ yeu=son, w)= *zeu=, th=s e)piou/shs e)lpi/dos (parody of SOPH. fr. 453, cited below).
COM. Thugenides, 4.593: mh\ no/mison, according to Porson's emendation of Photius and Suidas. Eupol. 2.464, is doubtful, and would be disposed of by the adoption of Elmsley's conjecture.

SOPH. fr. 453: mh\ yeu=son, w)= *zeu=, mh/ m' e(/lh|s a)/neu doro/s. apud Bekk. Antiatt. 107.30: mh\ no/mison a)nti\ tou= mh\ nomi/sh|s. *sofoklh=s *phlei=. (This is probably a mistake on the part of the author of the Antiatt.)
HOM. Od. 24.248: a)/llo de/ toi e)re/w, su\ de\ mh\ xo/lon e)/nqeo qumw=|.
Il. 4.410: tw=| mh/ moi pate/ras poq' o(moi/h| e)/nqeo timh=|. 18.134: a)lla\ su\ me\n mh/ pw katadu/seo mw=lon *)/arhos.
PERFECT IMPERATIVE:
THUC.7.77.4: mh\ katape/plhxqe a)/gan.
AR. Vesp. 373: mhde/n, w)= ta/n, de/diqi, mhde/n. 415: mh\ kekra/gate. Av. 206: mh/ nun e(/staqi .

SOPH. Ai. 1182-3:
u(mei=s te mh\ gunai=kes a)nt' a)ndrw=n pe/las
pare/stat', a)ll' a)rh/gete
.
HOM. Od. 3.313: mh\ dhqa\ do/mwn a)/po th=l' a)la/lhso. 4.825: mhde\ . . . dei/diqi. 16.302: mh/t(e) . . . i)/stw. 18.62-3: mh\ . . . dei/diq(i). 22.488-9: mhd' . . . e(/staq(i).
Il. 4.303-4: mhde/ tis . . . mema/tw. 5.827: mh/te . . . dei/diqi. 12.2723: mh/ tis o)pi/ssw | tetra/fqw poti\ nh=as. 14.342: mh/te . . . dei/diqi. 20.354: mhke/ti . . . e(/state. 366: mh\ dei)dite.
Equivalents of the imperative are:
1. The Subjunctive. So necessarily in the first person, and regularly in the negatived second and third persons aorist. See 373 and 376.
2. The Future (familiar) and the Future Perfect Indicative. See 269 and 282.
3. o(/pws with the future indicative, for which see under o(/pws.
4. Optative with a)/n. See 443.
5. Infinitive (chiefly in poetry and legal language). See under Infinitive.
6. The Optative. See 394.
7. Impatient or Passionate Questions. See 198.261, and 269.

8. dei=, xrh/, a)/cion, de/omai u(mw=n, with the infinitive, and similar expressions, are often found as a more temperate or a more convenient imperative. See A. J. P. xiii (1892), 402 f., on avoidance of imper. in proems.

p.hi: Representatives of the imperative in oratio obliqua.

div2.p: In continuous oratio obliqua, the imperative may be represented by the infinitive, but ordinarily the imperative notion is more explicitly conveyed through the medium of some periphrastic expression. See Object Sentences. For rare examples of the retention of the imperative, see 422.

p.hi: Imperative in dependent and in interrogative sentences.

div2.p: As the imperative is equivalent to dei= or xrh/ with the infinitive, it is occasionally used in dependent and interrogative sentences. Familiar is the phrase oi)=sq' o(\ dra=son;

w(=| . . . e)ce/stw kai\ mh/, tou=to nomoqethsw/meqa, PLATO, Legg. 935E; Let us regulate by law to whom this is to be allowed and to whom not. oi)=sq' ou)=n o(\ dra=son; AR. Eq. 1158; Knowest thou what thou must do? (Cf. v. 1160: dra=n tau=ta xrh/.) mh\ e)ce/stw dh\ para\ tau=ta e(/tera prosta/ttein; PLATO, Politic. 296A; He is not to be permitted, then, to make other additional regulations?

DEM.1.20: le/gousin de\ kai\ a)/llous tina\s a)/lloi po/rous, w(=n e(/lesq' o(/stis u(mi=n sumfe/rein dokei=. 20.14: ou)de\ ga\r ei) pa/nu xrhsto/s e)sq), w(s e)mou= g' e(/nek) e)/stw, belti/wn e)sti\ th=s po/lews to\ h)=qos. [42], 31: o(\ mhdamw=s nuni\ gene/sqw (417).
LYS. fr. 75.3: e)deh/qh h(/kein au)to\n e)pi\ kw=mon, le/gwn o(/ti meq' au(tou= kai\ tw=n oi)ketw=n pie/tw.
PLATO, Legg. 800E: to\ de\ tosou=ton h(ma=s au)tou\s e)panerwtw= pa/lin . . . ei) prw=ton e(\n tou=q' h(mi=n a)re/skon kei/sqw. Politic. 296 A (see above).

THUC.4.92.7: w(=n xrh\ mnhsqe/ntas h(ma=s . . . o(mo/se xwrh=sai toi=sde kai\ dei=cai o(/ti w(=n me\n e)fi/entai pro\s tou\s mh\ a)munome/nous e)pio/ntes kta/sqwn, oi(=s de\ gennai=on th\n . . . au(tw=n a)ei\ e)leuqerou=n ma/xh| . . . a)nantagw/nistoi a)p' au)tw=n ou)k a)pi/asin.
HDT.1.89: ka/tison tw=n dorufo/rwn e)pi\ pa/sh|si th=|si mu/lh|si fula/kous, oi(\ lego/ntwn kte(.
SOPH. O. C. 731: o(\n mh/t' o)knei=te mh/t' a)fh=t' e)/pos kako/n . O. R. 543: oi)=sq' w(s poi/hson;

div2.head: Its use and etymology
div2.p: The particle a)/n is largely used to color the moods of the Greek language.

p.hi: Distinctions in the use of a)/n.

div2.p: Two sets of distinctions are necessary as to the use of the particle a)/n.
I. 1. It may be used in the leading clause, chiefly with the indicative and the optative or their representatives.
2. It may be used in a dependent sentence, chiefly with the subjunctive.
II. 1. It may be used with a definite reference, contained in the same sentence, or implied in the context.
2. It may be used without a definite reference, in which case no definite ellipsis is to be supplied.

The shifting from definite to indefinite is not peculiar to the particle a)/n. Other simple demonstratives change in the same way. Compare to\n kai\ to/n, ta\ kai\ ta/, and notice especially te/ws and e(/ws. te/ws is used more frequently without its correlative e(/ws than with it, so long being for a while, and e(/ws is sometimes employed after the same fashion.A. J. P. iv (1883), 418 note.

A similar function is exercised in epic and lyric poetry by ken (ke), and in Doric by ka. The two particles a)/n and ken are sometimes combined as a)/n ken. A common origin once suspected is now seldom maintained.See A. J. P. iii (1882), 446 foll. The accented a)/n may originally have been more clearly demonstrative, the unaccented ken more surely indefinite, but the whole matter is obscure, and a sharp discrimination between a)/n and ken often attempted has never been successfully established. a)/n is everywhere distinctly preferred in negative sentences, enters more readily into close combinations, and on common ground gradually thrusts ken to the wall. So in Pindar a)/n nearly balances ken, whereas in Homer ken greatly preponderates, ken being to a)/n in the Iliad as 4 to 1.

The etymology of a)/n is still unsettled. With a definite reference it may be translated then, in that case, or, when opposition is implied, else. (Compare Lat. an.) Without definite reference, it sometimes gives a potential coloring, and in combination with the subjunctive and the optative is little more than a sharper future. ken (ka) is also an unsolved riddle.

div2.head: Indicative with a)/n
div2.p: The particle a)/n belongs to that which is other than the present, and is found only in past and future relations.

The past tenses of the indicative with a)/n may denote unreality (the most common use) in such a way that the imperfect denotes opposition to a continued action either in the present or in the past; the aorist denotes opposition to attainment, chiefly in the past, very rarely in the present; and the pluperfect indicative with a)/n denotes opposition to completion, more frequently in the present.

e)gw\ ga\r . . . ei) me\n mh\ w)/|mhn h(/cein . . . par' a)nqrw/pous teteleuthko/tas a)mei/nous tw=n e)nqa/de, h)di/koun a)\n [I should be in the wrong (I am not)] ou)k a)ganaktw=n tw=| qana/tw|, PLATO , Phaedo, 63

p.emph: Imperfect in opposition to the past:

div2.p: me/nein ga\r e)ch=n tw=| kathgorou=nti tw=n a)/llwn, ei) de\ tou=t' e)poi/ei e(/kastos, e)ni/kwn a)/n [they would have been victorious (they were not)], DEM.3.17.

p.emph: Aorist in opposition to the past:

div2.p: ei) to\ kai\ to\ e)poi/hsen a(/nqrwpos, ou)k a)\n a)pe/qanen, DEM.18.243; If the man had done so and so, he would not have died (he did die).

ei) me
 ou)=n a)/nqrwpos, o(
 dei= po/ll' a)kou=sai kai\ kaka/, | au)to\s h)=n e)/ndhlos, ou)k a)
 a)ndro\s e)mnh/sqhn fi/lou [I should not mention the name of a friend (as I am doing)], AR. Eq. 1276-7.

p.emph: Pluperfect in opposition to present completion:

div2.p: ei) de/ ge mhdei\s a)/llos h)\ *zeu=cis e)/grafe, kalw=s a)/n soi a)peke/krito; PLATO, Gorg. 453D; But if there were no other painter than Zeuxis, would your reply hold good?

p.emph: Pluperfect in opposition to past completion:

div2.p: ei) . . . o( a)nh\r . . . a)pe/qanen . . . dikai/ws . . . a)\n e)teqnh/kei, ANTIPHON, 4, b, 3; If the man had been killed, he would have been justly killed (his death would have been justifiable).
For further examples, see Unreal Conditional Sentences.
For e)boulo/mhn (h)/qelon) a)/n with infinitive antithetical to the dependent verb, see 367.

p.hi: Indicative with a)/n as potential of the past.

div2.p: The indicative of the historical tenses with a)/n also serves to express potentiality, or guarded assertion, in the past, chiefly with the ideal second person or tis, but by no means limited to it.

Ellipses are often easily supplied, but are not necessary. The translation is freer than in an elliptical conditional sentence. The protasis is sometimes contained in a participle or otherwise intimated.
DEM.18.225: a(\ mh/te proh/|dei mhdei\s mh/t' a)\n w)|h/qh th/meron r(hqh=nai.
ISOC.5.64: kai/toi ti/s a)\n prosedo/khsen u(p' a)ndro\s ou(/tw tapeinw=s pra/cantos a)nastrafh/sesqai ta\ th=s *(ella/dos pra/gmata;

LYS.1.27: pw=s ga a)/n (sc. kate/fuge); Ibid.: ou)/te si/dhron . . . ou)/te a)/llo ou)de

p.hi: Indicative with a)/n of intermittent action.

div2.p: The indicative of the historical tenses with a)/n is also used to express habitual or intermittent action in the past, a)/n being used without definite reference (424, II, 2).

p.hi: a)/n with the future indicative and its representatives.

div2.p: The future indicative with a)/n, theoretically a legitimate construction, has been kept out of use by the optative with a)/n and by a)/n with the subjunctive, and was counted a solecism even in antiquity.LUCIAN, III, 555 R. B. L. G. on [JUSTIN MART. ], Ep. ad Diogn. 2.4. A number of instances occur, however, in MSS and editions, but most of them have been corrected, or are easily corrigible. The same is true of the representatives of the indicative, the future optative, infinitive, and participle.

Sometimes there is an anacoluthon, as in PLATO, Apol. 29C. Sometimes the future indicative is confounded with the aorist optative, as PLATO, Euthyd. 275A: protre/yete for protre/yaite, the future infinitive with the aorist infinitive, as PLATO, Phaedr. 227B: poih/sesqai for poih/sasqai, the future participle with the aorist participle, as PLATO, Apol. 30B: poih/sontos for poih/santos. Sometimes a)/n is for a)n- or a)na- and belongs to the verb, as AESCHIN.3.155: ti/ pot' a)
 e)rei=; Cf. PIND. N. 7.68 and A. J. P. III (1882), 452. Sometimes there is confusion between present and future infinitive, as in XEN. An. 2.3.18: e(/cein for e)/xein. Sometimes there is confusion between a)/n and dh/,See Cobet, N. L. 501; Blass, Mus. 36.221; H. Richards, Rev. vi (1892), 338. and easy corrections are almost always at hand.Famous is PLATO, Rpb. 615D: ou)x h(/kei, fa/nai, ou)d' a)
 h(/cei deu=ro, where h(/coi cannot stand, and where ou)d' a)
 h(/koi would mean he can't have come. Here Richards applies his panacea dh/, but if ever a)/n was needed with the future indicative, it is needed here. This being the case, it is not worth while to multiply examples, most of which have disappeared from critical texts.

HOM. Il. 1.139: o(\ de/ ken kexolw/setai, o(/n ken i(/kwmai. 523: e)moi\ de/ ke tau=ta melh/setai, o)/fra tele/ssw. 3.138: tw=| de/ ke nikh/santi fi/lh keklh/sh| a)/koitis. 4.176: kai/ ke/ tis w(=d' e)re/ei. 8.405: a)palqh/sesqon. 419: id. 14.268: dw/sw. 15.215: pefidh/setai. 17.241: kore/ei. 22.67: e)ru/ousin. 71: kei/sont(ai).

p.hi: Non-use of a)/n with present and perfect indicative.

div2.p: The present and perfect indicative are not used with a)/n, but owing to the great variation in the position of a)/n beginners sometimes make a mistake in this regard. In ANDOC. 1.117 read bou/loisqe for bou/lesqe. In PLATO, Legg. 712E, read with Schanz a)nerwthqei/s (cf. 793 A).

div2.head: Optative with a)/n
div2.p: The optative with a)/n is the potentialObjections have been raised to the term potential, but nothing better has been suggested. Potentiality has to do with character, not with possibility merely, and the estimate of character goes back to the opinion of the one who makes the estimate. Compare A. J. P. xix (1898), 231. of the Greek language. It is used mainly in leading clauses. It expresses the opinion of the speaker as an opinion, and may be called the mood of qualified assertion. The verification of the opinion or assertion is postponed to another time (a)/n).

p.hi: Time and tenses of the potential optative.

div2.p: Both action and ascertainment may be future, or only the ascertainment. The present is often used of the future ascertainment of a present action, far more rarely of the future ascertainment of a past state. The aorist is very seldom used of the future ascertainment of a past action. The simple perfect optative with a)/n is found chiefly in those verbs in which the perfect is equivalent to the present. In the periphrastic perfect optative with a)/n, the participle is often treated almost like an adjective.

p.hi: a)/n with the Present Optative not of the Past: used of what will be, or what will prove to be.

PLATO , Phaedo 76 E: ei) de\ mh\ e)/sti tau=ta, a)/llws a)
 o( lo/gos ou(=tos ei)rhme/nos ei)/h. Politic. 264 C: e)n me
 ga krh/nais ta/x' a)

 ei)/h, We may look upon the strongest redoubt as having been taken.

The future optative with a)/n is not in use. It could arise only from the future indicative with a)/n, and the future indicative with a)/n had gone out, if it had ever come in, before the future optative came in. Still it is found in many texts, and is not to be discarded in the later time.B, L. G. on [JUSTIN MART.], Ep. ad Diogn. 2.4.

The optative with a)/n varies in tone from strong assurance (must) to faint presumption (might).A. J. P. xiv (1893), 499, xix (1898), 231. May be is often a convenient rendering for the positive, can't for the negative. Even shall and will sometimes serve to reproduce the impression, while would and should give the regular translation in formulated conditional sentences. So far from necessarily denoting uncertainty, it is the combination most frequently used to indicate moral certainty, and sometimes serves as a climax to the indicative. Especially common is the aorist optative with a)/n to express total negation, which cannot be brought out so well by the future indicative.JUSTIN MARTYR, Apol. 1.4.10.

p.hi: Imperative use of a)/n with optative.

div2.p: a)/n with the optative is sometimes used to suggest a command.
proa/gois a)/n, PLATO, Phaedr. 229B; You may lead on, Lead on, pray. (Cf. 229 A: pro/age dh/.)
PLATO, Phaedr. 227C: le/gois a)/n, Say on. 229 B (see above).

AR. Eq. 1160-1: dra=n tau=ta xrh/. | a)/piton . . . qe/oit' a)/n. Vesp. 725-6: h)= pou sofo\s h)=n o(/stis e)/fasken, pri
 a)
 a)mfoi=n mu=qon a)kou/sh|s, | ou)k a)
 dika/sais.
EUR. Ion, 1335-6: *p*u. par' h(mw=n d' e)/klab) ou(\s e)/xw lo/gous. | *i*w*n. le/gois a)/n: eu)/nous d' ou)=s) e)rei=s o(/s) a)\n le/gh|s.

HOM. Il. 2.250: tw=| ou)k a)\n basilh=as a)na\ sto/m' e)/xwn a)goreu/ois. 9.141-2: ei) de/ ken *)/argos i(koi/meq' *)axaiiko/n, ou)=qar a)rou/rhs, | gambro/s ke/n moi e)/oi.

p.hi: a)/n with the optative combined with the indicative.

div2.p: The optative with a)/n is often used in combination with the indicative, sometimes as a climax, giving, as it does, the warmth of personal conviction.
DEM.21.189: ou)/te fu/goim' a)\n ou)/t' a)rnou=mai tou)/noma tou=to. 191: e)gw\ d' e)ske/fqai . . . fhmi\ kou)k a)\n a)rnhqei/hn.

p.hi: The optative with a)/n in questions.

div2.p: The optative with a)/n in the question expects the optative with a)/n in the answer. The speaker virtually answers himself, shows his own opinion, or his own desire.

trw/gois a)
 e)rebi/nqous; AR. Ach. 801; Would you eat pease? pw=s a)
 a)fi/kointo/ pote e)/nqa dei=; XEN. Hell. 2.3.31; How could they ever get to the right place? (= ou)k a)
 a)fi/kointo).
ISAE. 3.64: ti/s a)\n a)/meinon h)\ o( path\r bouleu/saito; (*ou)dei\s a)/n.)
PLATO, Gorg. 475D-E: de/caio a)\n ou)=n su\ ma=llon to\ ka/kion kai\ to\ ai)/sxion a)nti\ tou= h(=tton; . . . a)ll' ou)k a)\n decai/mhn.

XEN. Conv. 3.6: le/lhqe/ se o(/ti kai\ oi( r(ayw|doi\ pa/ntes e)pi/stantai tau=ta ta\ e)/ph; kai\ pw=s a)/n, e)/fh, lelh/qoi a)krow/meno/n ge au)tw=n o)li/gou a)n' e(ka/sthn h(me/ran; Cyr. 5.1.28: a)nqrwpi/nh| de\ gnw/mh| ti/s a)\n h)\ feugo/ntwn tw=n polemi/wn a)potre/poito h)\ o(/pla paradido/ntwn ou)k a)\n lamba/noi; Hell. 2.3.31 (see above).
AR. Ach. 797: h)/dh d' a)/neu th=s mhtro\s e)sqi/oien a)/n; 801 (see above). Eq. 88: pw=s d' a)\n mequ/wn xrhsto/n ti bouleu/sait' a)nh/r; 91: oi)/nou ga\r eu(/rois a)/n ti praktikw/teron; 773. 1324.
PIND. O. 2.109-10: kai\ kei=nos o(/sa xa/rmat: a)/llois e)/qhken, | ti/s a)\n fra/sai du/naito; [ou)dei/s.]

HOM. Od. 4.443: ti/s ga/r k' ei)nali/w| para\ kh/tei+ koimhqei/h(; 6.57: pa/ppa fi/l), ou)k a)\n dh/ moi e)fopli/sseias a)ph/nhn (= e)fo/plison); 7.22-3: w)= te/kos ou)k a)/n moi do/mon a)ne/ros h(gh/saio | *)alkino/ou;

p.hi: pw=s a)/n with the optative to express a wish.

div2.p: pw=s a)/n with the optative is frequently found in the dramatic poets to express a wish. Compare utinam in Latin.

pw=s a)\n e)me\ kai\ se/ tis *)/erws cunaga/goi labw/n; AR. Ach. 991; How could an Eros (would that an Eros might) take and bring us together? Utinam me et te copulet amor aliquis! w)= gai=a patri/s, pw=s a)\n e)nqa/noimi/ soi; EUR. [Rh. ] 869; O fatherland, would I could die upon thy breast.
AR. Ach. 991 (see above). Eq. 460: pw=s a)/n s' e)paine/saimen ou(/tws w(/sper h(do/mesqa; Vesp. 166: pw=s a)/n s' a)poktei/naimi; pw=s; do/te moi ci/fos.
Il. 6.281-2: w(/s ke/ oi( au)=qi gai=a xa/noi .
On the difference between pw=s a)\n ou) and pw=s a)\n mh/, see the chapter on Negatives.

p.hi: Optative with a)/n in dependent discourse.

div2.p: The optative with a)/n is less frequently used in dependent discourse, chiefly in relative, interrogative, and conditional sentences. In these combinations, the optative with a)/n is often a semi-quotation or reference to a known or imagined state of mind.

e(/kasto/s ti u(mw=n e)/xei pro\s o(\ bou/loito a)/n me prw=ton a)pologei=sqai, ANDOC.1.8; Each of you has some point which he would wish me to meet first in my defence. bouleuo/menoi *qhbai=oi o(/pws a)
 th
 h(gemoni/an la/boien th=s *(ella/dos, XEN. Hell. 7.1.33; The Thebans planning how they could (saying: pw=s a)
 la/boimen; how can we?) gain the primacy of Greece. ei) me
 ou)=n a)/llous e)/xete oi(=stisin a)
 doi/hte au)tou/s (sc. tou\s i(/ppous), . . . e)kei/nois di/dote: ei) me/ntoi h(ma=s a)
 bou/loisqe parasta/tas ma/lista e)/xein, h(mi=n au)tou\s do/te, XEN. Cyr. 4.5.47; If you have others to whom you would give the horses, offer them to them; if, however, you would like most to have us as your stand-bys, give them to us.
For other examples, see Relative, Conditional, and Interrogative Sentences.

Carefully to be distinguished from these semi-quotations are those instances in which the a)/n adheres to the leading particle and yet the subjunctive is changed into the optative. This is really anacoluthic and does not count.

tou/tous de\ e)pimelei=sqai th=s po/lews, e(/ws a)\n (del. Dobr.; au)= W.) oi( no/moi teqei=en, ANDOC.1.81; These were to take charge of the citizens until the laws should be made. (If a)/n goes with teqei=en: until such time as in all likelihood the laws would be made.)
ANDOC.1.81(see above).
AR. Eq. 1056: kai/ ke gunh\ fe/roi a)/xqos, e)pei/ ken a)nh\r a)naqei/h.
Examples will be given under the different categories.

p.hi: e)a/n, o(/tan, etc., with the optative.

div2.p: The particles which coalesce with a)/n, such as e)a/n, o(/tan, o(po/tan, e)peida/n, rarely forget their belongings, and in good Greek the optative is more than suspicious.

p.hi: Omission of a)/n with the optative.—the pure optative as a potential.

div2.p: The pure optative (optative without a)/n) is sometimes used in the early language as a potential, the negative being ou). The instances cited, however, are not all free from doubt, and outside of these early examples all pure optatives used as potentials are more or less open to suspicion. Sometimes a)/n has been dropped by haplography, sometimes there has been a confusion with other words, an au)= (*a*u) or a dh/ (*d*h), sometimes the a)/n is to be understood from a preceding passage, or anticipated from a succeeding passage, sometimes euphony may have prompted the omission,See A. J. P. xii, 387. AESCHYL. Cho. 595. SOPH. Ant. 604-5. THEOGN. 125: ou/de\ ga\r ei)dei/hs a)ndro\s no/on, where edd. ou) ga\r a)\n ei)dei/hs. although the Greeks generally are not very sensitive to the cacophony of recurrent sounds,PINDAR, I. E. cxiv. AR. Nub. 776: o(/pws a)postre/yais a)\n a)/ntidi/kwn di/khn . Still notice the rarity of compounds in a)/nan-. or the ear may have been cheated, sometimes the syntax of the editors may have been at fault, and the optative being equivalent to an imperative may be considered as an equivalent to the optative with a)/n.B. L. G. on PIND. O. 3.45: keino\s ei)/hn. P. 10.21-2: qeo\s ei)/h | a)ph/mwn ke/ar. Many passages once freely cited have been corrected by editors, sometimes unnecessarily, and the tendency is decidedly towards the norm. Similar is the case of the omitted ken (ke), and there are not a few passages in which the presence of a ge suggests a restoration of the regular modal construction.

Marcianus, Cauer) e)gw\ kai\ kth/mata doi/hn. 14.122-3: ou)/ tis kei=non a)nh\r a)lalhme/nos e)lqw\n | a)gge/llwn pei/seie gunai=ka/ te kai\ fi/lon ui(o/n.

Il. 4.318-9: ma/la me/n toi (“libri plurimi et optimi, ken duo, ge unus,” Cauer) e)gw\n e)qe/loimi kai\ au)to\s | w(\s e)/men. 5.303: o(\ ou) du/o g) (libri fere omnes; k) Heyne, Naber, Cauer) a)/ndre fe/roien. 10.246-7: tou/tou ge spome/noio kai\ e)k puro\s ai)qome/noio | a)/mfw nosth/saimen. 556-7: r(ei=a qeo)s g' e)qe/lwn kai\ a)mei/nonas, h)e/ per oi(/de, | i(/ppous dwrh/sait(o). 15.45: au)ta/r toi kai\ kei/nw| e)gw\ paramuqhsai/mhn. 197-8: qugate/ressin ga/r te kai\ ui(a/si be/lteron ei)/h | e)kpa/glois e)pe/essin e)nisse/men. 19.321: ou) me\n ga/r ti kakw/teron a)/llo pa/qoimi. 20.286: o(\ ou) du/o g) (du/o k) Cauer) a)/ndre fe/roien (= 5.303).

div2.head: Subjunctive with a)/n
div2.p: The subjunctive with a)/n is not employed as a form of independent statement in Attic prose. In dependent clauses it is either a future or good for all time.

p.hi: Subjunctive with ken or a)/n as a form of independent statement.

div2.p: The subjunctive with ken or a)/n is occasionally used in HOMER as a form of independent statement. The negative is ou).
e)gw\ de/ ken au)to\s e(/lwmai, HOM. Il. 1.137; I will take it myself. ou)k a)/n toi xrai/smh| ki/qaris, 3.54; Of no avail to thee shall the cithern be.
a. Present:

The aorist is the tense used in all the above examples, and all except two are negative.

p.hi: Omission of a)/n in subjunctive dependent clauses.

div2.p: Subjunctive dependent clauses, outside of the pure final sentence, regularly take a)/n except in the older language. The omission of a)/n is sometimes due to clerical error, sometimes perhaps to a sense of euphony, sometimes to a survival of the older construction. See Final, Temporal, Conditional, and Relative Sentences.
The imperative with a)/n does not occur. When a)/n is used with an infinitive, or participle, the clause must be resolved by an indicative or an optative, according to the context.

Some of these ellipses have become mere formulae, such as w(s a)/n and ka)/n, for which see Conditional and Concessive Sentences.

a)/n and ke(n) are both postpositive. Both are apt to combine with some leading modifier, conjunction, relative, adverb, only certain monosyllabic particles, such as me/n, de/, ga/r, te, being allowed to intervene. a)/n sometimes goes so far as to coalesce sooner or later. So we find ei) a)/n (h)/n, e)a/n, a_)/n), ei)/ ke(n), o(/t' a)/n (later o(/tan), o(/te ke(n), pri\n a)/n, o(\s a)/n, o(/s ke(n), ta/x' a)/n, ou)k a)/n, ou)/ ke(n). This tendency to combine with some leading word sometimes removes both a)/n and ke(n) to a considerable distance from the verb to which they properly belong.

For examples of the normal position of a)/n in Temporal, Conditional, Concessive, and Relative Sentences, see Temporal, Conditional, Concessive, and Relative Sentences.

a)/n is not unfrequently repeated in the same clause, sometimes in order to resume a distant a)/n, sometimes for rhetorical emphasis, especially with the negative or equivalent interrogative. ke(n) is also repeated, though rarely, and both a)/n and ke(n) are occasionally found in the same clause.

THE first part of this Greek Syntax is a fragment of a larger scheme of a Greek Series, which was abandoned for good and sufficient reasons, and it lay in print for some time unpublished. Finally, yielding to the representations of those who were interested in my grammatical work, I gave it to the scholarly world as a specimen of my method of treating a subject about which my studies had revolved for many years. That method demands repeated reading and repeated sifting, and the utmost bound of my hope was the continuation of the general plan by other hands and the acceptance by competent judges of the results already gained. The framework, as constituted in my Latin Grammar, which was built on the same lines, has been in use for a lifetime. The details of my special Greek studies are accessible in various publications, so that any one who finds aught worth adopting either in general plan or in individual formula can readily avail himself of what I have done for the furtherance of syntactical study.

This second part, like the first, is based on the manuscript of the original work and the text is with some slight exceptions my own; but whereas in the first part the contributions of Professor MILLER were merely supplementary, in the second part, and especially in the treatment of the article, the collection and the sorting of the examples have been carried out with his characteristic fulness and accuracy, so that I desire that all credit be given to him for the value of this segment of the work as a repository of facts. The disparateness of the two parts was inevitable under the circumstances, and the delay occasioned by the coöperation has been so great that it has seemed best at this point to dissolve the partnership, maintained for so many years, as it would have been dissolved at any rate in the natural course of things. An outline of what remains is in progress, and though it is high time that I cut down long hope to match the brief space of human life, I do not hesitate to commit myself to a plan that involves little more than the shaping of material already in hand.
div2.signed: BASIL L. GILDERSLEEVE, THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, BALTIMORE.

div2.p: The sentence may be expanded by the Multiplication or by the Qualification
A. of the Subject.
B. of the Predicate.

div2.head: Concord of the Predicate
div2.p: The common verbal or adjective predicate of two or more subjects is put in the plural. The substantive predicate follows the rules given 93 and 96.

*brasi/das kai\ to\ stra/teuma e)xw/roun e)ggute/rw th=s qala/sshs, THUC.4.73.1; Brasidas and his army moved nearer to the sea. o)li/gou katage/lastoi e)geno/meqa . . . e)gw/ te kai\ su/, w)= pai= *)acio/xou, PLATO, Euthyd. 279D. xruso\s de\ kai\ a)/rguros . . . e)sti\n e)pi/fqonon kth=ma, Legg. 955 E.

When the combined subjects are neuter, the verb is in the singular, while the predicate adjective is in the plural.

p.hi: Singular predicate agreeing with nearest or most important subject.

div2.p: The common predicate may agree with a singular subject when that subject is the nearest or the most important. The mobility of the Greek often makes it hard to decide between 473 and 477.

au)to/s te kai\ h( stratia\ pezh=| . . . a)fiknei=tai e)s *kalxhdo/na, THUC.4.75.2; The general and the army arrive(s) by land at Chalcedon. e)c e)sxa/ths d' w)=n o( kassi/teros h(mi=n foita=| kai\ to\ h)/lektron, HDT.3.115. kai\ gh=ras . . . kai\ neo/ths xaleph\ tw=| toiou/tw| cumbai/nei, PLATO, Rpb. 329D.

Od. 5.184: i)/stw nu=n to/de gai=a kai\ ou)rano\s eu)ru\s u(/perqen. 11.10: th\n d' a)/nemo/s te kubernh/ths t' i)/qunen. 61: a)=se/ me dai/monos ai)=sa kakh\ kai\ a)qe/sfatos oi)=nos. 202-3: a)lla/ me so/s te po/qos sa/ te mh/dea, fai/dim' *)odusseu=, | sh/t' a)ganofrosu/nh melihde/a qumo\n a)phu/ra. 13.59-60: xai=re/ moi, w)= basi/leia, diampere/s, ei)s o(/ ke gh=ras | e)/lqh| kai\ qa/natos. 15.307: ke/kluqi nu=n, *eu)/maie kai\ a)/lloi pa/ntes e(tai=roi. 22.246: tou\s d' h)/dh e)da/masse bio\s kai\ tarfe/es i)oi/.

Il. 1.177: ai)ei\ ga/r toi e)/ris te fi/lh po/lemoi/ te ma/xai te. 255: h)= ken ghqh/sai *pri/amos *pria/moio/ te pai=des. 2.144-6: ku/mata makra\ qala/sshs | . . . ta\ me/n t' eu)=ro/s te no/tos te | w)/ror' e)pai+/cas. 3.54-5: ou)k a)/ntoi xrai/smh| ki/qaris ta/ te dw=r' *)afrodi/ths, | h(/ te ko/mh to/ te ei)=dos. 4.164-5: e)/ssetai h)=mar, o(/t' a)/n pot' o)lw/lh| *)/ilios i(rh\ | kai\ *pri/amos kai\ lao\s e)ummeli/w *pria/moio. 9, [320]: ka/tqan' o(mw=s o(/ t' a)ergo\s a)nh\r o(/ te polla\ e)orgw/s. 10.562-3: to/n r(a . . . | *(/ektwr te proe/hke kai\ a)/lloi *trw=es a)gauoi/. 12.93: tw=n d' e(te/rwn: *pa/ris h)=rxe kai\ *)alka/qoos kai\ *)agh/nwr. 13.14: fai/neto de\ *pria/moio po/lis kai\ nh=es *)axaiw=n. 14.120: w(\s ga/r pou *zeu\s h)/qele kai\ qeoi\ a)/lloi. 17.251: e)k de\ *dio\s timh\ kai\ ku=dos o)phdei=.
The common predicate of two subjects that are compared by means of the particle h)/ agrees with the last.
h(/per (sc. h( tu/xh) a)ei\ be/ltion h)\ h(mei=s h(mw=n au)tw=n e)pimelou/meqa, DEM.4.12; (Fortune) always (takes) better care of us than we take of ourselves.
DEM.4.12(see above).
PLATO, Theaet. 209A: w(=n (sc. tw=n koinw=n) ou)de\n su\ ma=llon h)/ tis a)/llos e)/xei.
A singular subject combined with another word by meta/ (su/n) rarely takes the plural.

*)alkibia/dhs e)k *sa/rdewn meta\ *mantiqe/ou tou= a(lo/ntos e)n *kari/a| i(/ppwn eu)porh/santes nukto\s a)pe/drasanei)s *klazomena/s, XEN. Hell. 1.1.10; Alcibiades and Mantitheus . . . ran off to Clazomenae.
XEN. Hell. 1.1.10 (see above).
THUC.3.109.2: kru/fa de\ *dhmosqe/nhs meta\ tw=n custrath/gwn *)akarna/nwn spe/ndontai *mantineu=si.
Observe the attraction of the copula by the predicate. Cf. 124.
xruso\s de\ kai\ a)/rguros . . . e)stin e)pi/fqonon kth=ma, PLATO, Legg. 955E; Gold and silver is an invidious possession.
PLATO, Euthyd. 279B: a)lla\ mh\n eu)ge/neiai/ te kai\ duna/meis kai\ timai\ e)n th=| e(autou= dh=la/ e)stin a)gaqa\ o)/nta. Legg. 732 E (124). 955 E (see above).
AESCHYL. Ag. 650-1: cunw/mosan ga\r o)/ntes e)/xqistoi . . . | pu=r kai\ qa/lassa (personification).
Close union often amounts to unity.

o( . . . xro/nos kai\ h( e)mpeiri/a . . . e)kdida/skei tou\s a)nqrw/pous, ANTIPHON, 5.14; Time and experience teach(es) men full well. a)/nemos kai\ xeimw\n diekw/lusen au)tou/s, XEN. Hell. 1.6.35; Wind and storm prevented them.

DEM.2.9: h( prw/th pro/fasis kai\ mikro\n ptai=sma pa/nt' a)nexai/tisen kai\ die/lusen. 14: h( *makedonikh\ du/namis kai\ a)rxh\ . . . au)th\ . . . kaq' au(th\n a)sqenh\s kai\ pollw=n kakw=n e)sti mesth/. 18.65: h)=n a)/n tis . . . me/myis kai\ kathgori/a.
LYS. [20] 8: to\ de/os kai\ o( fo/bos tw=n peponqo/twn a)pe/trepe pa/ntas .
ANTIPHON, 5.14 (see above).

PLATO, Euthyd. 291C: e)/doce ga\r dh\ h(mi=n h( politikh\ (sc. te/xnh) kai\ h( basilikh\ te/xnh h( au)th\ ei)=nai. Legg. 926 D: tw=| de\ h(tthqe/nti para\ tou= nomoqe/tou yo/gos kai\ o)/neidos kei/sqw, pollw=n xrhma/twn nou=n kekthme/nw| zhmi/a barute/ra. Rpb. 332 A-B: ou) ta\ o)feilo/mena a)podi/dwsin, o(\s a)/n tw| xrusi/on a)podw=| parakataqeme/nw|, e)a/nper h( a)po/dosis kai\ h( lh=yis (giving and taking practically the same act) blabera\ gi/gnhtai, fi/loi de\ w)=sin o(/ te a)polamba/nwn kai\ o( a)podidou/s (two separate persons).
XEN. Hell. 1.1.26: dia\ tau=ta de\ eu)ergesi/a te kai\ politei/a *surakosi/ois e)n *)anta/ndrw| e)sti/. 1.6.35 (see above).
THUC.6.17.1: kai\ tau=ta h( e)mh\ neo/ths kai\ a)/noia para\ fu/sin dokou=sa ei)=nai e)s th\n *peloponnhsi/wn du/namin lo/gois te pre/pousin w(mi/lhse kai\ o)rgh=| pi/stin parasxome/nh| e)/peise.

HDT.4.115: h(me/as e)/xei fo/bos te kai\ de/os. 7.198: a)/mpwti/s te kai\ r(hxi/h a)na\ pa=san h(me/rhn gi/netai. 8.70: tou\s de\ *(/ellhnas ei)=xe de/os te kai\ a)rrwdi/h. 106: *paniw/nion me/n nun ou(/tw perih=lqe h(/ te ti/sis kai\ *(ermo/timos.
AR. Vesp. 590-1: e)/ti d' h( boulh\ xw) dh=mos o(/tan kri=nai me/ga pra=gm' a)porh/sh|, | e)yh/fistai tou\s a)dikou=ntas toi=si dikastai=s paradou=nai.
SOPH. Ph. 336: a)ll' eu)genh\s me\n o( ktanw/n te xw) qanw/n.

PIND. O. 5.15. 9.15. P. 2.9-10: e)pi\ ga\r i)oxe/aira parqe/nos xeri\ didu/ma| | (o(/t' e)nagw/nios *(erma=s ai)gla/enta ti/qhsi.ko/smon. 4.66: tw=| me\n *)apo/llwn a(/ te *puqw\ ku=dos e)c a)mfiktio/nwn e)/poren. 10.10. 11.45.
THEOGN. 291-2: a)naidei/h de\ kai\ u(/bris | nikh/sasa di/khn gh=n kata\ pa=san e)/xei.
ARCHIL.16: pa/nta tu/xh kai\ moi=ra, *peri/klees, a)ndri\ di/dwsin.
HOM. Od. 2.338: nhto\s xruso\s kai\ xalko\s e)/keito. 3.299-300: ta\s pe/nte ne/as . . . | *ai)gu/ptw| e)pe/lasse fe/rwn a)/nemo/s te kai\ u(/dwr.
Il. 3.255: tw=| de/ ke nikh/santi gunh\ kai\ kth/maq' e(/poito. 10.523: *trw/wn de\ klaggh/ te kai\ a)/spetos w)=rto kudoimo/s.For English, compare Fitzedward Hall, A.J. P. iii (1882), 424 f.
In poetry the plural or dual sometimes anticipates the plural or dual result and thrusts itself between the subjects.
h)= me\n dh\ qa/rsos moi *)/arhs t' e)/dosan kai\ *)aqh/nh, HOM. Od. 14.216; Courage to me (did) Ares (give—nay) they did give, for I count Athena too.
AESCHYL. fr. 381: o(/pou ga\r i)sxu\s suzugou=si kai\ di/kh, | poi/a cunwri\s th=sde karterwte/ra;

Cf. PIND. P. 4.178-9: pe/mpe d' *(erma=s xruso/rapis didu/mous ui(ou\s e)p' a)/truton po/non, | to
 me
 *)exi/ona, kexla/dontas h(/ba|, to
 d' *)/eruton (half-epic).See B. L. G. ad loc.
ALCMAN, 9: *ka/stwr te pw/lwn w)ke/wn dmath=res, i(ppo/tai sofoi/, | kai\ *pwludeu/khs kudro/s (apposition).
HOM. Od. 10.513-4: e)/nqa me\n ei)s *)axe/ronta *puriflege/qwn te r(e/ousin | *kwkuto/s q). 14.216 (see above).

Il. 5.774: h(=xi r(oa\s *simo/eis sumba/lleton h)de\ *ska/mandros. Cf. 20.138-9: ei) de/ k' *)/arhs a)/rxwsi (so La Roche with most MSS. and Aristarchus; Cauer reads a)/rxh|si with several MSS. and Zenodotus) ma/xhs h)\ *foi=bos *)apo/llwn, | h)\ *)axilh=' i)/sxwsi kai\ ou)k ei)w=si ma/xesqai.
When singular subjects are connected by disjunctives the singular is the rule, but the plural is sometimes found.
ou)/q' h( *(ella\s ou)/q) h( ba/rbaros th\n pleoneci/an xwrei= ta)nqrw/pou, DEM.9.27; (No land) neither Greek nor non-Greek can hold the greed of this creature.
DEM.1.6: ou)de\ ga\r lo/gos ou)de\ skh=yis u(mi=n . . . u(polei/petai. 9.27 (see above).

PLATO, Phaedr. 245D: a)rxh=s ga\r dh\ a)polome/nhs ou)/te au)th/ pote e)/k tou ou)/te a)/llo e)c e)kei/nhs genh/setai. Rpb. 342 B: ou)/te ga\r ponhri/a ou)/te a(marti/a ou)demi/a ou)demia=| te/xnh| pa/restin.
THUC.1.93.5: e)nto\s de\ ou)/te xa/lic ou)/te phlo\s h)=n.
HDT.2.41: ou)/te a)nh\r *ai)gu/ptios ou)/te gunh\ a)/ndra *(/ellhna filh/seie a)\n tw=| sto/mati (438).
AR. Ach. 308: oi(=sin ou)/te bwmo\s ou)/te pi/stis ou)/q' o(/rkos me/nei.
SOPH. O. R. 1020: a)ll' ou)/ s' e)gei/nat' ou)/t' e)kei=nos ou)/t' e)gw/. fr. 511.2: oi(=s ou)/te dai/mwn ou)/te tis qew=n . . . pot' a)\n nei/meien a)ci/an xa/rin.
AESCHYL. Pers. 14-5: kou)/te tis a)/ggelos ou)/te tis i(ppeu\s | a)/stu to\ *persw=n a)fiknei=tai.
SIMON. C. 4.4-5: e)nta/fion de\ toiou=ton ou)/t' eu)rw\s | ou)/q' o( pandama/twr a)maurw/sei xro/nos.
HOM. Il. 8.7-8: mh/te tis ou)=n qh/leia qeo\s to/ ge mh/te tis a)/rshn | peira/tw diake/rsai e)mo\n e)/pos.

ei) . . . peri\ tou/twn e)/mellon a)pologh/sesqai mo/non *lewxa/rhs h)\ *dikaioge/nhs, h)/rkei a)/n moi ta\ ei)rhme/na, ISAE. 5.5: If it were on these lines only that Leochares or Dicaeogenes was expected to make the defence, I should consider what has been said sufficient.
ISAE. 5.5 (see above).
PLATO, Legg. 838A: o(/tan a)delfo\s h)\ a)delfh/tw| ge/nwntai kaloi/.
EUR. Alc. 360-2: kai/ m' ou)/q' o( *plou/twnos ku/wn | ou)/q' ou(pi\ kw/ph| yuxopompo\s a)\n *xa/rwn | e)/sxon.
BACCHYL.36(Bgk.): qnatoi=si d' ou)k au)qai/retoi | ou)/t' o)/lbos ou)/t' a)/kamptos *)/arhs ou)/te pa/mfqersis sta/sis.
PIND. P. 6.10-3: to\n ou)/te xeime/rios o)/mbros . . . ou)/t' a)/nemos e)s muxou\s a(lo\s a)/coisi.

p.hi: Adjective predicate with combined subjects of different genders.

div2.p: When the genders of combined subjects are different, the adjective predicate takes either the strongest gender or the nearest. In things with life the masculine gender is the strongest, in things without life the neuter. In poetry personification has a wide range.

h( me\n *tu/xh kai\ *fi/lippos h)=san tw=n e)/rgwn ku/rioi, AESCHIN.2.118; Fortune and Philip had the control of the issues in their hands, were responsible for the actual results. timwme/nou dh\ plou/tou e)n po/lei kai\ tw=n plousi/wn a)timote/ra a)reth/ te kai\ oi( a)gaqoi/, PLATO, Rpb. 550E-551 A; When in any state wealth and the wealthy are valued, virtue and the virtuous are undervalued. ai)dw= de\ kai\ fo/bon . . . ou)x o(ra=|s e)/mfuta . . . a)nqrw/pois o)/nta; XEN. Mem. 3.7.5; Do you not see that reverence and fear are things inborn in mankind?
LYCURG.30: e)gw\ me\n e)boulo/mhn . . . e)n toi=s *lewkra/tous oi)ke/tais kai\ qerapai/nais basanisqei=si to\n e)/legxon gene/sqai.
DEM.25.68: tw=n u(parxo/ntwn no/mwn kai\ politei/as meno/ntwn ou)k e)/ni tw=n ai)sxrw=n au)tw=| tou/twn a)pallagh/.

PLATO, Conv. 179C: o)/ntwn au)tw=| patro/s te kai\ mhtro/s. Legg. 835 D: ei)=don ne/ous te kai\ ne/as o(milou=ntas filofro/nws a)llh/lois. 892 B: do/ca dh\ kai\ e)pime/leia kai\ nou=s kai\ te/xnh kai\ no/mos sklhrw=n kai\ malakw=n ... pro/tera a)\n ei)/h. Rpb. 329 D: kai\ gh=ras ... kai\ neo/ths xaleph\ tw=| toiou/tw| cumbai/nei (473). 550 E-551 A (see above).
XEN. An. 1.4.8: kai/toi e)/xw ge au)tw=n kai\ te/kna kai\ gunai=kas e)n *tra/llesi frourou/mena (women being treated as chattels). Mem. 3.7.5 (see above).
THUC.8.63.1: puqo/menos ... to\n *strombixi/dhn kai\ ta\s nau=s a)pelhluqo/ta (masc.).
HDT.3.57: toi=si de\ *sifni/oisi h)=n to/te h( a)gorh\ kai\ to\ prutanh/ioi *pari/w| li/qw| h)skhme/na.
AR. Pl. 160-1: te/xnai de\ pa=sai dia\ se\ kai\ sofi/smata | e)n toi=sin a)nqrw/poisi/n e)sq' eu(rhme/na.
AESCHYL. Ag. 527: bwmoi\ d' a)/i+stoi (sc. ei)si\n) kai\ qew=n i(dru/mata.
HOM. Od. 4.79: a)qa/natoi ga\r tou= ge do/moi kai\ kth/mat' e)/asin.
Il. 1.177: ai)ei\ ga/r toi e)/ris te fi/lh po/lemoi/ te ma/xai te. 18.567-8: parqenikai\ de\ kai\ h)i/qeoi a)tala\ frone/ontes | ... fe/ron melihde/a karpo/n.
When the persons of combined subjects are different, the first person is preferred to the second, the second to the third, or else the person is determined by the nearest subject.

a)ei\ ga\r e)gw\ kai\ o( so\s path\r ... fi/lw h)=men, PLATO, Lach. 180E; Your father and I were always good friends. e)gw\ ou)=n kai\ su\ mh\ pa/qwmen o(\ a)/llois e)pitimw=men, Phaedr. 237 C; Let you and me not get into the predicament which we find so much fault with in others.
ISAE. 7.45: e)gw\ de\ kai\ o( e)mo\s pa/ppos eu)erge/tai gego/namen au)tou=.

PLATO, Euthyd. 279D: o)li/gou katage/lastoi e)geno/meqa u(po\ tw=n ce/nwn e)gw/ te kai\ su/ (469). 286 A: ti/ ou)=n dh\ tou=to; ... h(=tto/n ti a)ntile/gomen e)gw/ te kai\ su/; Gorg. 515 E: a)lla\ oi)=da safw=s kai\ e)gw\ kai\ su\ o(/ti kte(. Lach. 180 E (see above). Legg. 770 C: *me/gillos me
 ga kai\ e)gw\ kai\ *kleini/as ei)rh/kame/n te au)ta\ a)llh/lois ou)k o)liga/kis o(mologou=me/n te le/gesqai kalw=s. Lys. 223B (60). Phaedr. 237 C (see above). Theaet. 154 D-E: ei) ... deinoi\ kai\ sofoi\ e)gw/ te kai\ su\ h)=men ... h)/dh a)
 ... a)llh/lwn tou\s lo/gous toi=s lo/gois e)krou/omen. Ibid. 163 A: a)ll' ou) di/kaion ... ou)/te su\ ou)/te a)
 h(mei=s fai=men.

XEN. An. 2.1.16: su/ te ga\r *(/ellhn ei)= kai\ h(mei=s. An. 7.7.16: a)ll' e)gw\ me\n le/gw, e)/fh, kai\ *seu/qhs tau)ta/. Cyr. 7.4.5: tou/tois *ku=ro/s te kai\ h(mei=s pole/mioi e)so/meqa. Mem. 4.4.7: ou)/te su\ ou)/t' a)\n a)/llos ou)dei\s du/nait' a)nteipei=n.
AR. Av. 131: o(/pws pare/sh| moi kai\ su\ kai\ ta\ paidi/a . Pl. 620-1: e)gw\ de\ kai\ su/ g' w(s ta/xista to\n qeo\n | e)gkataklinou=nt' a)/gwmen ei)s *)asklhpiou=.

SOPH. El. 622-3: h)= s' e)gw\ kai\ ta)/m' e)/ph | kai\ ta)/rga ta)ma\ po/ll' a)/gan le/- gein poiei=. 795: ou)/koun *)ore/sths kai\ su\ pau/seton ta/de; O. R. 401-2: kla/wn dokei=s moi kai\ su\ xw) sunqei\s ta/de | a(ghlath/sein. 1020: a)ll' ou)/ s' e)gei/nat' ou)/t' e)kei=nos ou)/t' e)gw/.
AESCHYL. Suppl. 938-9: e)n xro/nw| maqw\n | ei)/sh| su/ t' au)to\s xoi) cune/mporoi se/qen.

In AESCHIN. 2.184: to\ de\ sw=ma h)/dh touti\ paradi/dwsin u(mi=n kai\ e)gw\ kai\ o( no/mos, the speaker has in mind the familiar formula ou)k e)/gwge a)ll' o( no/mos, ANAXIM. Gr. 1, p. 236 (Spengel). Cf. LYS. 1.26: ou)k e)gw/ se a)poktenw=, a)ll' o( th=s po/lews no/mos , and AR. Eccl. 1055-6: a)ll' ou)k e)gw/, | a)ll' o( no/mos e(/lkei s(e).

div2.head: Attributes of the subject
div2.p: The subject may be qualified by giving it an attribute. An attribute is that which serves to give a specific character.
The chief forms of the attribute are:
I. The adjective (including the participle) and its equivalents.
II. Apposition.
Equivalents of the adjective are:
1. The Pronouns including the Article.
2. Substantives denoting Rank, Age, Trade.
3. The Genitive Case.
4. The Dative Case.
5. Prepositions with their cases.
6. Adverbs.
7. Relative Clauses.
1. For the Article and the Pronouns, see the sections treating of these.
w)= a)/ndres bouleutai/, XEN. Hell. 2.3.24 ; Gentlemen of the Senate.

Poets are very free in this regard, and the substantives thus used have a wider range. Especially common is the use of a)nh/r in every sphere,Men and brethren is a portentous mistranslation of Acts xxiii, 1. with more weight in prose than in poetry. a)/nqrwpos is as disrespectful as a)nh/r is respectful.

DEM.9.31: ou)x *(/ellhnos o)/ntos ... a)ll' o)le/qrou *makedo/nos. 18.127: o)/leqros grammateu/s. 19.4: w)= a)/ndres dikastai/, and the same phrase very often elsewhere. 19.22: w)= a)/ndres pre/sbeis. 172: a)nqrw/pous poli/tas.
AESCHIN.2.87: kat' a)ndro\s poli/tou. 3.152: toi=s drape/tais posi/. 233: a)nh\r ... i)diw/ths. 253: a)nh\r r(h/twr.
Cf. 1.15: presbu=tis a)/nqrwpos. Cf. 4.19: dou/lhn a)/nqrwpon. 12.1 and elsewhere: w)= a)/ndres dikastai/. 26.21: w)= a)/ndres bouleutai/.
ANTIPHON, 3 a 1: w)= a)/ndres poli=tai. b 2: w)= a)/ndres dikastai/. 4 a 6: a)/ndra presbu/thn.

PLATO , Critias, 118E: a)/ndra h(gemo/na. Ion 540 D: a)ndri\ ... strathgw=|. Phaedr. 260 B: lo/gon e)/painon. Protag. 312 C: a)ndri\ ... sofisth=|. Rpb. 620 B: a)qlhtou= a)ndro/s. Theaet. 195 B: a)nh\r a)dole/sxhs.

XEN. An. 3.2.2: w)= a)/ndres stratiw=tai ... a)ndrw=n strathgw=n. 4.1.6: su\n toi=s o)pisqofu/lacin o(pli/tais. 28: tw=n gumnh/twn tacia/rxwn. 7.8: tw=n o)pisqofula/kwn loxagw=n. 6.5.9: w)= a)/ndres strathgoi/. Cyr. 5.3.31: a)ndri\ eu)erge/th|. 5.11: a)/ndra a)/rxonta. Hell. 2.3.24 (see above). 4.13: a)/ndres poli=tai.

THUC.1.74.1: a)/ndra strathgo/n.
6.85.1: a)ndri\ ... tura/nnw|.
8.98.3: a)ndri\ strathgw=| .
HDT.3.52: a)lh/thn bi/on. 6.83: e)/peita de\ e)s tou\s dou/lous h)=lqe a)nh\r ma/ntis *kle/andros.

AR. Ach. 328: a)/ndres dhmo/tai. Eq. 242: a)/ndres i(pph=s. Vesp. 360: a)/ndres o(pli=tai. 908: a)/ndres dikastai/. Pax, 9: a)/ndres koprolo/goi. Thesm. 345: grau=s gunh/. Ran. 858: a)/ndras poihta/s. 1008: a)/ndra poihth/n. 1041: a)/ndra poli/thn.

EUR. Alc. 679: neani/as lo/gous. Hec. 921: nau/tan ... o(/milon. Heracl. 699: o(pli/thn ko/smon. 800: o(pli/thn strato/n. H. F. 26: ge/rwn de\ dh/ tis e)/sti *kadmei/wn lo/gos. 190: a)nh\r o( pli/ths dou=lo/s e)sti tw=n o(/plwn. Hipp. 1006: parqe)non yuxh/n. Ion, 1373: oi)ke/thn bi/on. Or. 529: dakru/ois ge/ront' o) fqalmo\n e)kth/kw ta/las . Phoen. 838: parqe/nw| xeri/.
AESCHYL. Ag. 1627: a)ndri\ strathgw=|. Cf. Cho. 3.14: trige/rwn mu=qos. Sept. 605: cu\n poli/tais a)ndra/sin. 717: a)/ndr' o(pli/thn.
PIND. O. 10 (11), 49: meta\ dw/dek' a)na/ktwn qew=n. P. 11.33: ma/ntin t' o)/lesse ko/ran. N. 2.13: fw=ta maxata/n.
HOM. Od. 3.267: a)oido\s a)nh/r. 9.391: a)nh\r xalkeu/s. 508: ma/ntis a)nh/r. 24.2: a)ndrw=n mnhsth/rwn. 253: basilh=i ga\r a)ndri\ e)/oikas.
Il. 4.216: xalkh=es ... a)/ndres. 6.315: te/ktones a)/ndres. 390: gunh\ tami/h. 9.477: fu/lakas ... a)/ndras. 11.514: i)htro\s ... a)nh/r. 17.65: a)/ndres ... nomh=es. 21.574: a)ndro\s qhrhth=ros.

div2.head: The oblique cases
div2.p: dokei= ge/ moi (sc. h( xlai=na) | e)oike/nai ma/lista *moru/xou sa/gmati, AR. Vesp. 1141-2; It looks most like a cloak of Morychus' to me. (Compare e)n th=|de th=| ... oi)ki/a| th=| *moruxi/a|, PLATO, Phaedr. 227B; In this house of Morychus.) w)= pai= *kleini/ou, Alc. 1.103 A; Sonof Clinias. (Compare o( ... *kleini/eios ou(=tos, Gorg. 482 A; This (son) of Clinias.)
For further examples, see Genitive Case.

boh/qeia e(autw=|, PLATO, Gorg. 522D; Self-help. th
 e)mh
 tw=| qew=| u(phresi/an, Apol. 30 A. to
 de\ tau/rw| xalke/w| kauth=ra ... | e)xqra\ *fa/larin kate(xei panta=| fa/tis, PIND. P. 1.95-6.
For other examples, see Dative Case.
DEM.2.12: oi( par: h(mw=n pre/sbeis. 16: tw=n e)mpori/wn tw=n e)n th=| xw/ra|.
PLATO, Phaedr. 249A (see above). Rpb. 426 E: ta\ e)n toi=s cumbolai/ois kakourgh/mata. 506 C: ta\s a)/neu e)pisth/mhs do/cas. Theaet. 148 D: th\n peri\ tw=n duna/mewn a)po/krisin.
XEN. Cyr. 1.6.38: tw=n pro\s tou\s polemi/ous mhxanhma/twn. 39: th=s pro\s tou\s polemi/ous pleoneci/as.

THUC.1.100.1: h( e)p' *eu)rume/donti potamw=| ... pezomaxi/a kai\ naumaxi/a.
2.6.2: ta\ peri\ tw=n *plataiw=n gegenhme/na.
2.7.1: tou= e)n *plataiai=s e)/rgou .
AR. Ach. 202: ta\ kat' a)grou\s ... *dionu/sia. Eq. 709: ta)n prutanei/w| siti/a. Nub. 218: fe/re ti/s ga\r ou(=tos ou(pi\ th=s krema/qras a)nh/r;
SOPH. Ant. 95: th\n e)c e)mou= dusbouli/an . O. R. 595: ta\ su\n ke/rdei kala/ .
These are chiefly preceded by the article and involve the participle of ei)mi/.
e)n ... tw=| te/ws xro/nw|, LYS. 7.12 ; Up to date.
DEM.18.26: to\n metacu\ xro/non. 29.14: to\n o(mologoume/nws dou=lon.
ISOC.6.28: tou\s w(s a)lhqw=s *messhni/ous.
LYS.7.12(see above).

7. For Relative Clauses as equivalents of adjectives, see Relative Clauses.
For the substantive in apposition, see Apposition.

div2.head: The normal rule
div2.p: The adjective attribute agrees with its substantive in gender, number, and case.

i(ero\s lo/xos, Sacred Band. i(era\ po/lis, Sacred city. i(ero
 ptoli/eqron, Sacred citadel. i(eroi\ do/moi, Sacred abodes. i(era\ xrh/mata, Sacred money. tami/as ... tw=n ... i(erw=n xrhma/twn, PLATO, Legg. 759E. klai+/des (= klei=des) ... i(era=n (= i(erw=n) filota/twn, PIND. P. 9.39. to
 a)/ndra. th
 gunai=ka. to\ paidi/on. ou(=tos o( a)nh/r. au(/th h( gunh/. tou=to to\ paidi/on. o( parw
 xro/nos. th
 meta\ tau=t' e)cai/fnhs gegonui=an pi/stin, DEM.19.27. h( boulh\ d' h( mh\ kwluqei=s' a)kou=sai ta)lhqh= par' e)mou=, Ibid. 31. e)k toi=n lo/goin toi=n a)ndroi=n e(kate/roin toi=n basanisqe/ntoin, ANTIPHON, 5.49.

div2.head: Exceptions.
div2.p: Exceptions to the above rule are found in the matter of dual concord and in the employment of the constructio ad sensum instead of formal agreement.
Occasionally a plural adjective is used with a dual substantive, but not in prose.
HOM. Od. 11.211-2: o)/fra ... fi/las peri\ xei=re balo/nte | a)mfote/rw krueroi=o tetarpw/mesqa go/oio. 12.228-9: du/o dou=re | makr(a/).

Il. 13.434-5: to\n ... *poseida/wn e)da/massen | qe)lcas o)/sse faeina/. Cf. 616-7: tw\ de/ oi( o)/sse | pa\r posi\n ai(mato/enta xamai\ pe/son. 16.139: ei(/leto d' a)/lkima dou=re. 21.115-6: o(\ d' e(/zeto xei=re peta/ssas | a)mfote/ras.

From HOMER on du/o (du/w) is found with plural substantives as well as with dual substantives, and the plural is the rule for du/o (nominative and accusative) in Attic Prose. Uncommon is the use of duoi=n with a plural,See Keck, Ueber den Dual bei den griechischen Rednern, Würzburg, 1882, p. 47, and Roeper, De dualis usu Platonico, Gedani, 1878, p. 25 sq. For a list of examples, see Ernst Hasse, Der Dualis im Attischen, Hannover und Leipzig, 1893, p. 6. and the use of du/o (indeclinable) with a substantive in the genitive or the dative plural is rare in the ATTIC ORATORS and in PLATO.According to Keck, l.c., p. 39, only twice in the ORATORS: DEM.41.3 and [42]DEM., 23; according to Roeper, l.c., p. 20, only twice in PLATO : Legg. 848 A and 908 B (Tim. Locr. 96 A, 97 C, and Epin. 984 E are excluded as non Platonic); according to Zander apud Keck, l.c., the form du/o is found with the genitive plural 7 times in THUCYDIDES and 6 times in XENOPHON, with the dative plural 5 times in THUCYDIDES and once in XENOPHON.

du/o me\n ui(ei=s, du/o de\ qugate/res, ISAE. 2.3. du/o ploi=a, LYS. 13.25.
du/o ... tra/pezai 37.
du/w nu/ktas du/o t' h)/mata, HOM. Od. 9.74.
oi( de\ du/w sko/peloi, 12.73. du/o ... geneai/, Il. 1.250. du/w kh/rukas, 3.116.
proselqo/ntwn d' au)tw=| duoi=n a)ndrw=n, LYCURG.86. pleonekthma/twn duoi=n, DEM.5.23.
ou)sw=n d' au)tw=| du/o qugate/rwn, DEM.41.3. tw=n de\ du/o merw=n, PLATO, Legg. 848A. du/w potamw=n, HOM. Od. 10.515. du/w kano/ness(i), Il. 13.407.

p.hi: Masculine dual forms used generically for the feminine.

div2.p: The use of the forms tw/, toi=n, tou/tw, tou/toin, au)tw/, au)toi=n, tw/de, and the like, with feminine substantives is no exception to the rule, as these forms are common to all the genders, though there are also special feminine forms, which are preferably used in the genitive and dative.See Ernst Hasse, Der Dualis im Attischen, Hannover und Leipzig, 1893, p. 19. In like manner, the masculine dual forms of descriptive adjectives and of participles are sometimes used generically for the feminine.See Keck, p. 37 infra and p. 38 supra; also Hasse, l.c., pp. 26.36, and 37, where, however, no instance of a feminine simple adjective in oin or of a feminine participle in oin is cited.

e)rei/sat', w)= pai=, pleuro\n a)mfide/cion
e)mfu/nte (sc. Antigone and Ismene)tw=| fu/santi,
SOPH. O. C. 1112-3 . a)qana/twn meta\ fu=lon i)/ton prolipo/nt' a)nqrw/pous | *ai)dw\s kai\ *ne/mesis, HES. O. et D. 199-200.
There is no recorded exception in prose. In poetry there are occasional exceptions, the real gender, and not the grammatical, being regarded.
w)= xai=re, kollikofa/ge *boiwti/dion, AR. Ach. 872.
AR. Ach. 872 (see above).
AESCHYL. Cho. 893: te/qnhkas, fi/ltat' *ai)gi/sqou bi/a.
HOM. Il. 22.84: fi/le te/knon.For 11.244-5, see 503.

For deviations in the concord of the participle, which in its ordinary use differs from the adjective in that it conveys the notion of predication, see 122-4 and other sections under Agreement of the Predicate with the Subject.

Pronouns that have different forms for different genders and numbers, agree in gender and number with the substantives they represent. But there are frequent variations according to sense, the name of a town, for example, suggesting the inhabitants, or a plural pronoun being used of a generic singular (sometimes the reverse).

The tendency of the Greek language to sudden changes of subject without the mention by name of the new subject (compare 71), is largely responsible for the few instances that are cited of the agreement of a pronoun with the gender of some synonymous word, instead of with the natural or the grammatical gender of the word that the pronoun represents.

SOPH. Ph. 755-9: NE. deino/n ge tou)pi/sagma tou= nosh/matos. | *f*i. deino\n ga\r ou)de\ r(hto/n: a)ll' oi)/ktire/ me. | NE. ti/ dh=ta dra/sw; *f*i. mh/ me tarbh/sas prodw=|s: | h(/kei ga\r au(/th dia\ xro/nou pla/nois i)/sws | w(s e)ceplh/sqh. (Philoctetes does not take up the no/shma idea, but returns with the word au(/th to the no/sos of 734: th=s parestw/shs no/sou. So 765: th=s no/sou. The no/sos of our passage is personified as elsewhere in Sophocles.) Tr. 984-7: poi= ga=s h(/kw; para\ toi=si brotw=n | kei=mai peponhme/nos a)llh/ktois | o)du/nais; oi)/moi e)gw\ tla/mwn. | h( d' au)= miara\ (sc. no/sos. Cf. no/son, 981) bru/kei.

HOM. Il. 11.237-8: e)tra/pet' ai)xmh/: | kai\ to/ ge (sc. e)/gxos. Cf. 233) xeiri\ labw/n. 21.166-8: tw=| d' e(te/rw| (sc. douri/) min ... ba/le ... h(\ (sc. meli/h. Cf. 162 and 169) d' u(pe\r au)tou= | gai/h| e)nesth/rikto, lilaiome/nh xroo\s a)=sai.

p.hi: Neuter pronouns referring to masculine or feminine substantives.

div2.p: Not an exception to the rule of concord is the case of a neuter pronoun referring to a masculine or feminine substantive regarded as a thing. Cf. 126. In most of the instances cited, however, the reference is rather to some thought implied in the substantive than to the substantive itself.

e)peidh\ toi/nun h( au)th\ a)reth\ pa/ntwn e)sti/, peirw= ... a)namnhsqh=nai, ti/ au)to/ fhsi *gorgi/as ei)=nai, PLATO , Meno, 73 C; Since the same virtue belongs to all (resides in all), try to recall what Gorgias says it (the thing itself, the essence of it) is. do/chs e)piqumei= kai\ tou=t' e)zh/lwke, DEM.2.15; He is eager for glory, and has made that his passion.

 nou=n e)mbale/sqai. 20.140: fu/sei kaki/as shmei=o/n e)stin o( fqo/nos, kai\ ou)k e)/xei pro/fasin di' h(

p.hi: Plural of neuter pronouns for the singular.

div2.p: Neuter pronouns are often used in the plural where we might expect the singular.For Neuter Plural of Adjectives instead of Singular, see 37.

e)fie/ntwn (sc. h(mw=n) duoi=n qa/tera, h)\ pei/qein h(ma=s h)\ poiei=n, tou/twn ou)de/tera poiei=, PLATO , Crito, 52 A; Although we leave it to him to do one of two things, either to persuade us or to do (our bidding), he does neither.
DEM.19.72: e)sti\ de\ tau=taFor the absence of attraction by the predicate in the above and similar examples, see 129. ge/lws, ma=llon d' a)naisxunti/a deinh/.

Il. 8.362-3: ou)de/ ti tw=n me/mnhtai, o(/ oi( ma/la polla/kis ui(o\n | teiro/menon sw/eskon u(p' *eu)rusqh=os a)e/qlwn.
For kai\ tau=ta, see under ou(=tos.
For Attraction of the Demonstrative by the Predicate, see 127.
For Attraction of the Article, see 574.635.
The common adjective attribute of two or more substantives agrees with the nearest. Exceptions are explicable.
si=tos polu\s kai\ pro/bata, XEN. An. 2.4.27; Much bread-stuff and small cattle (sheep). pollai\ kriqai\ kai\ puroi/, Ibid. 7.1.13; Much barley and wheat.
DEM.18.271: deina\ pepo/nqasi ... kai\ po/leis o(/lai kai\ e)/qnh. 1.19: mhdemi/an mh/te xa/rin mh/t' a)/ndra. 25.68: tw=n u(parxo/ntwn no/mwn kai\ politei/as (481).
LYS.[6]. 47: a)namnh/sqhte de\ kai\ au)toi\ e)co(/swn kakw=n kai\ pole/mou u(ma=s au)tou\s periepoih/sate . 13.95: mhdamw=s ... mh/te te/xnh| mh/te mhxanh=| mhdemia=| .

THEOGN. 87: mh/ m' e)/pesin me\n ste/rge, no/on d' e)/xe kai\ fre/nas a)/llas. 860: pollou\s a)spasmou\s kai\ filo/thtas e)/xw.
HOM. Od. 2.123: bi/oto/n te teo\n kai\ kth/mat' e)/dontai. 19.406: gambro\s e)mo\s quga/thr te (12).

Il. 2.136: h(me/terai/ t' a)/loxoi kai\ nh/pia te/kna. 6.211: tau/ths toi geneh=s te kai\ ai(/matos eu)/xomai ei)=nai . 9.466: polla\ de\ i)/fia mh=la kai\ ei)li/podas e(/likas bou=s. But 11.244-5: prw=q' e(kato\n bou=s dw=ken, e)/peita de\ xi/li' u(pe/sth, | ai)=gas o(mou= kai\ o)/is, ta/ oi( a)/speta poimai/nonto, xi/li(a) agrees with mh=la understood, which becomes more evident by comparing Od. 9.183-4: e)/nqa de\ polla\ | mh=l), o)/ie/s te kai\ ai)=ges, i)au/eskon. 13.287: ou)de/ ken e)/nqa teo/n ge me/nos kai\ xei=ras o)/noito (78). 14.73: h(me/teron de\ me/nos kai\ xei=ras e)/dhsen.
The common attribute may be repeated for emphasis or rhetorical balance. So with kai\ ... kai/, me\n ... de/.

w)/|eto kth/sesqai e)k tou/twn o)/noma me/ga kai\ du/namin me ga/lhn, XEN. An. 2.6.17; He thought that he should acquire from this a great name and great power. e)cwpli/zeto (sc. o( strato/s) polloi=s me\n kai\ kaloi=s xitw=si, polloi=s de\ kai\ kaloi=s qw/raci kai\ kra/nesin, Cyr. 6.4.1; The army accoutred itself with many fine tunics, many fine corselets and helmets.

div2.head: Position of the adjective attribute.
div2.p: The adjective attribute precedes the substantive. This, which is the original position, so often yields to rhythmical and rhetorical considerations that a sharp difference between the order, attribute and substantive, and the order, substantive and attribute, cannot be formulated.

mikra=s zhmi/as a)ci/ous LYS. 1.3 ; Deserving [only] a SLIGHT penalty.
oi)kono/mos deinh/, Ibid. 7 ; A clever HOUSEKEEPER. e(\n ... sw=m' e)/xwn kai\ yuxh\n mi/an, DEM.19.227; Having (but) ONE body and ONE soul (504, chiasm). e)pe/wn matai/wn, HDT.7.11, but ma/taia e)/peaHDT., 15. lo/gon ou)de/na e)poie/eto, HDT.7.13, but e)n ou)deni\ lo/gw| poih/setaiHDT., 16. ei)=s a)nh\r ou)dei\s a)nh/r, PROV.

Cf. ibid.: ei) a)/ra o( di/kaios a)rgu/rion deino\s fula/ttein, kai\ kle/ptein deino/s). 343 D: di/kaios a)nh\r a)di/kou pantaxou= e)/latton e)/xei. 353 E: a)na/gkh a)/ra kakh=| yuxh=| kakw=s a)/rxein. Ibid.: e)/xwn stratih/n te pollh\n kai\ polla\s ne/as (504). 64: u(pe\r tessera/konta a)/ndras (27). 96: pa=n xrh=ma (40). 7.8, g): dou/lion zugo/n. 11 (see above). 13: lo/gon ou)de/na ... ou)de/na xro/non. 15 (see above). 16, g) (see above). 41: xi/lioi me\n ... r(oia\s ei)=xon xruse/as ... oi( de\ ei)nakisxi/lioi ... a)rgure/as r(oia\s ei)=xon.

A. 78: o(/rkous palaiou/s. 315: e)k xerw=n e)mw=n. I. T. 365: numfeu/mat' ai)sxra/. Or. 70: a)/poron xrh=ma (40). Phoen. 78: pollh\n ... a)spi/d(a) (56). fr. 243: o)li/gon a)/lkimon do/ru (56).

w)= di=os ai)qh\r kai\ taxu/pteroi pnoai/
potamw=n te phgai\ ponti/wn te kuma/twn
a)nh/riqmon ge/lasma, pammh=to/r te gh=
(12). 210: pollw=n o)noma/twn morfh\ mi/a . 329: glw/ssh| matai/a| zhmi/a prostri/betai .

ARCHIL.4.3: a)/grei d' oi)=non e)ruqro
 a)po\ trugo/s. 9.3: polufloi/sboio qala/sshs. 5: a)nhke/stoisi kakoi=sin. 6: kraterh
 tlhmosu/nhn. 8: ai(mato/en d' e(/lkos. 10: gunaikei=on pe/nqos. 11.1: polih=s a(lo/s. 2: glukero

HOM. Od. 11.61: a)=se/ me dai/monos ai)=sa kakh\ kai\ a)qe/sfatos oi)=nos (473). 323: *)aqhna/wn i(era/wn (49). 12.341: deiloi=si brotoi=si (45). 24.249: a)gaqh\ komidh/. 286: ceni/h| a)gaqh=|.

Il. 1.418: kakh=| ai)/sh|. 2.235: ka/k' e)le/gxe(a) (41). 3.17: kampu/la to/ca (52). 108: o(plote/rwn a)ndrw=n (31). 14.238: kalo\n qro/non (52). 16.3: da/krua qerma\ xe/wn w(/s te krh/nh mela/nudros. For details of Homeric usage, see La Roche, W. St., xix (1897), pp. 161-88.
The attribute may be separated from its substantive by one or more words.

Removal often increases the emphasis, the mind being thus forced to recall or await the substantive. So numerals are often put at a distance as if for the convenience of adding. The interval is seldom excessive in prose. In poetry, on the other hand, it is sometimes very considerable, and sometimes the conception seems rather predicative than attributive, but the rhythm aids in bridging the chasm. The beginnings of verses are really near. So PIND. O. 6.1-2, cited below. But compare P. 9.5-6, O. 11.19-21 (both cited below), and especially O. 12.5-6, and see the editor's notes on those passages.
pleone/kthm' a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi me/g' u(ph=rcen *fili/ppw|, DEM.18.60; An advantage, a great advantage did Philip have to start with. e)/docan polemi/ous o(ra=n i(ppe/as, XEN. An. 2.2.14.

N. 8.2: parqenhi+/ois pai/dwnt' e)fi/zoisa glefa/rois.

HES. O. et D. 178: xalepa\s de\ qeoi\ dw/sousi meri/mnas.

HOM. Od. 3.161: e)/rin w)=rse kakh/n. 9.12-3: soi\ d' e)ma\ kh/dea qumo\s e)petra/peto stono/enta | ei)/resq(ai). 9.116-9: nh=sos e)/peit' e)laxei=a pare\k lime/nos teta/nustai, | gai/hs *kuklw/pwn ou)/te sxedo
 ou)/t' a)/po thlou=, | u(lh/ess' (rather felt predicatively than attributively) ˙ e)

 me
 ga leimw=nes a(lo\s polioi=o par' o)/xqas | u(drhloi\ malakoi/.

Il. 7.251: dia\ me\n a)spi/dos h)=lqe faeinh=s o)/brimon e)/gxos. 264-5: a)ll' a)naxassa/menos li/qon ei(/leto xeiri\ paxei/h| | kei/menon e)n pedi/w| me/lana, trhxu/n te me/gan te (the three adjectives are predicative rather than attributive). 299: dw= ra d' a)/g' a)llh/loisi perikluta\ dw/omen a)/mfw.
Adjectives used partitively regularly precede.
peri\ me/sas nu/ktas, XEN. An. 1.7.1; About midnight.

EUR. El. 840: o)/nuxas e)p' a)/krous sta/s (adjective follows). I. T. 49: beblhme/non pro\s ou)=das e)c a)/krwn staqmw=n. 266: a)/kroisi daktu/loisi. 283: w)le/nas tre/mwn a)/kras (adjective follows). 297: mo/sxous o)rou/sas ei)s me/sas (adjective follows).

SOPH. Ai. 238: glw=ssan a)/kran (adjective follows). 285: a)/kras nukto/s . Ant. 415-6: e)n ai)qe/ri me/sw| (adjective follows). El. 748: ei)s me/son dro/mon. 1476: e)n me/sois a)rkusta/tois. O. When the attribute belongs to two or more words, it is generally put before them all, sometimes after them all, sometimes after the first, occasionally after one of the intermediate substantives.

p.hi: After one of the intermediate substantives:

div2.p: XEN. An. 4.7.14: e)nteu=qen a)/nqrwpoi me\n pa/nu o)li/goi e)lh/fqhsan, bo/es de\ kai\ o)/noi polloi\ kai\ pro/bata. Mem. 1.1.14: tou\s de\ kai\ li/qous kai\ cu/la ta\ tuxo/nta kai\ qhri/a se/besqai.

div2.head: Peculiar forms of the adjective attribute
div2.p: The demonstrative and other adjective pronouns present important peculiarities. Of these pronouns the most common is the article.

The function of the article, which was originally a demonstrative, and always has more or less demonstrative force, is to fix a floating adjective or substantive. In the earlier stages of the language i(/ppos means ‘the horse’ (literally ‘the swift one’)But cf. A. J. P. xxiii (1902), 22. Oertel, Study of Language, p. 306. as well as ‘a horse,’ and we have an implicit article as well as an explicit article (o(, h(, to/). This implicit article served at first as particular or generic. Afterwards the particular use required the reinforcement of the explicit article, but in the generic use the employment of the explicit article was optional. Particular: (a)/nqrwpos), o( a)/nqrwpos, the man; generic: a)/nqrwpos, o( a)/nqrwpos, man.
Proper names being in their nature particular do not require the explicit article, and when the article is used with them, it retains much of its original demonstrative force.

It is impossible to draw a sharp line of demarcation between the uses of the attributive article at different stages. The Homeric demonstrative use passes over into the articular use, and the Attic articular use approaches the Homeric demonstrative use. In the one case we have the germ of a new life; in the other, the survival of the old. To the Attic the Homeric o( ge/rwn could hardly have been distinguishable from the everyday o( ge/rwn of prose. Much depends on the position in the verse. Sometimes there may be apposition, sometimes the article may be used for contrast. When Pindar said a)/riston me\n u(/dwr, o( de\ xruso/s, the verse brings out the pause, the feeling of antithesis. We say that there is no articular infinitive in Homer, because in the only apparent example, Od. 20.52: a)ni/h kai\ to\ fula/ssein, the appositional explanation brings the passage in line with the use elsewhere (Od. 1.370; 11.358-9) and with the later use of tou=to, which is the demonstrative article ‘writ large’ (PLATO, Gorg. 449C).

In the older language and in the higher poetry that follows the older norm the article proper is not so much used as in Attic prose and as in comic poetry, which approaches the language of everyday life. Homer gives the norm, which is followed closely by Pindar. The lyric parts of tragedy are more anarthrous than the dialogue. The dialogue of comedy differs decidedly from that of tragedy in this respect. Old phrases, especially prepositional phrases, retain in the heyday of Attic their anarthrous forms. Dialects vary, and the Doric is said to have affected the hearty homely article. See the Lacedaemonian chorus in the Lysistrate. Authors vary, and whereas some eschew the article with proper names or use it gingerly, others, like Plato , are exceedingly free with it. On the other hand, the familiar use of the article has led to exactness and finesse, and the subtle variations in the employment of it add a special charm to Attic prose.Cf. A. J. P. xxiii (1902), 121.
The substantive use of the article is in Attic prose a survival, and is found chiefly in fixed phrases and certain old-fashioned turns of expression.

div2.head: Substantive Use

p.hi:
o(\ me
 . . . o(\ de/, o(\ me
 . . . de/, me
 . . . o(\ de/.

div2.p: Very common is o(\ me\n . . . o(\ de/, now used with definite reference to persons or things mentioned, the one . . . the other, the former . . . the latter, the latter . . . the former, now used indefinitely simply in contrast to each other. One or the other (more commonly the latter) of the two articles may also be replaced by a substantive or a pronoun.
Here belong also the adverbial uses of the article to\ (ta\) me\n . . . to\ (ta\) de/, th=| me\n . . . th=| de/.

p.hi: Substantive article preceded by me/n or de/.

div2.p: Prepositions generally attract me/n and de/ and change the order. The same thing occurs in other contrasted groups.
