p.hi: o(\ de/ without an expressed o(\ me/n.

div2.p: o(\ de/ without expressed o(\ me/n is sometimes used in the sense of the other, another, plural the others, others, just as though a o(\ me/n preceded.
du/o dh\ le/gw tou/tw ei)/dh kinh/sews, a)lloi/wsin, th\n de\ perifora/n, PLATO, Theaet. 181D; There are two kinds of motion then that I mean, alteration (the one), the other rotation.
DEM.9.64: ei)sfe/rein e)ke/leuon, oi(\ d' ou)de\n dei=n e)/fasan: polemei=n kai\ mh\ pisteu/ein, oi(\ d' a)/gein ei)rh/nhn, e(/ws e)gkatelh/fqhsan. 54.9: h)=|de . . . oi(\ de/.

PLATO, Cratyl. 385B: kalei=s ti a)lhqh= le/gein kai\ yeud\h=; *)/egwge. *ou)kou=n ei)/h a)\n lo/gos a)lhqh/s, o(\ de\ yeudh/s. Politic. 291 E: monarxi/an me\n prosagoreu/ousin w(s du/o parexome/nhn ei)/dh duoi=n o)no/masi, turanni/di, to\ de\ basilikh=|. Theaet. 181 D (see above).

AR. Eq. 599-600: ei)s ta\s i(ppagwgou\s ei)seph/dwn a)ndrikw=s, | pria/menoi kw/qwnas, oi(\ de\ kai\ sko/roda kai\ kro/mmua. Av. 490-492: a)naphdw=sin pa/ntes e)p' e)/rgon … oi(\ de\ badi/zous' u(podhsa/menoi nu/ktwr . 529-30:
ei)=ta labo/ntes pwlou=s' a(qro/ous:
oi(\ d' w)nou=ntai blima/zontes
.

EUR. H. F. 568-72: *kadmei/wn d' o(/sous | kakou\s e)feu=ron . . . xeirw/somai: | tou\s de\ pterwtoi=s diaforw=n toceu/masi | nekrw=n a(/pant' *)ismhno\n e)mplh/sw fo/nou. 635-6: xrh/masin de\ dia/foroi: | e)/xousin, oi(\ d' ou)/.

SOPH. Ant. 201-2:
h)qe/lhse d' ai(/matos
koinou= pa/sasqai, tou\s de\ doulwsas a)/gein
. Cf. O. R. 1227-9:
oi)=mai ga\r ou)/t' a)\n *)/istron ou)/te *fa=sin a)\n
ni/yai kaqarmw=| th/nde th\n ste/ghn, o(/sa
keu/qei, ta\ d' au)ti/k' e)s to\ fw=s fanei= kaka/
, where also see commentators.

PIND. O. 9.67-8: a)fi/konto de/ voi ce/noi | e)/k t' *)/argeos e)/k te *qhba=n, oi(\ d' *arka/des, oi(\ de\ kai\ *pisa=tai. 86-7: a)/llai de\ du/) e)n *kori/nqou pu/lais e)ge/nont' e)/peita xa/rmai, | tai\ de\ kai\ *neme/as *)efarmo/stw| kata\ ko/lpon. P. 3.91-2: o(po/q' *(armoni/an ga=men (sc. o(\ me/n) bow=pin, | o(\ de\ *nhre/os eu)bou/lou *qe/tin pai=da kluta/n. I. 5.60-1: a)/ranto ga\r ni/kas a)po\ pagkrati/ou | trei=s, a)p' *)isqmou=, ta\s d' a)p' eu)fu/llou *neme/as.
HOM. Od. 9.466-7: a)spa/sioi de\ fi/lois e(ta/roisi fa/nhmen, | oi(\ fu/gomen qa/naton: tou\s de\ stena/xonto gow=ntes.
Il. 22.157: th=| r(a paradrame/thn feu/gwn, o(\ d' o)/pisqe diw/kwn.

p.hi: o(\ de/ without reference to o(\ me/n

div2.p: o(\ de/ may be used by itself without reference to an expressed or an implied o(\ me/n, rarely, however, in Attic of the subject of the preceding sentence. Especially common in Plato is to\ de/, which is often unnecessarily treated as if it were an adverbial phrase, as for that matter, whereas. (C. W. E. M., JAPA., xxxix, 121 ff.)

p.emph: not same as subject of preceding sentence:

div2.p: kai\ e)gw\ th\n gunai=ka a)pie/nai e)ke/leuon . . . h(\ de\ . . . ou)k h)/qelen, LYS.1.12 ; And I bade my wife go away but she would not (refused).
DEM.18.140: e(\n d' e)peceirga/sat' a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi . . . peri\ ou(= tou\s pollou\s a)nh/lwsen lo/gous, . . . w(s diastre/ywn ta)lhqe/s. to\ d' ou) toiou=to/n e)sti.

ISAE. 1.14: prose/tace *poseidi/ppw| th
 a)rxh
 ei)sagagei=n. o(\ de\ ou) mo/non ou)k ei)sh/gagen, a)lla\ kai\ to
 e)lqo/nta tw=n a)rxo/ntwn . . . a)pe/pemyen.

LYS.1.12 (see above). 12. 8-9: e)gw\ de\ *pei/swna me\n h)rw/twn . . . o(\ d' e)/fasken . . . ei)=pon ou)=n . . . o(\ d' w(molo/ghse tau=ta poih/sein . 11: e)deo/mhn au)tou= . . . o(\ d' . . . e)/fasken . 12. 14.

PLATO, Apol. 23A: to\ de/. 37 A: i)/sws ou)=n u(mi=n . . . dokw= le/gein . . . a)pauqadizo/menos: to\ de\ ou)k e)/stin, w)= *)aqhnai=oi, toiou=ton, a)lla\ toio/nde ma=llon. 39 C. Conv. 183 D. 198 D. Legg. 630 D, elsew. Meno, 97 C. Phaedr. 228 B: o(\ de\ e)pei/qeto proqu/mws. 247 C: au)ta\s . . . ai(\ de/. Protag. 315 C: e)fai/nonto de\ peri\ fu/sews . . . dierwta=n to\n *(ippi/an, o(\ d(e\) . . . diech/|ei ta\ e)rwtw/mena. 344 E: to\ d(e/). Rpb. 340 D, elsew. Soph.244A. Theaet. 157 A.

XEN. An. 1.3.21: a)kou/santes de\ tau=ta . . . a)nagge/llousi toi=s stratiw/tais: toi=s de\ u(poyi/a . . . h)=n. Cyr. 1.3.13: e)dei=to au)th=s o( *)astua/ghs katalipei=n to\n *ku=ron, h(\ de\ a)pekri/nato kte(. 15.

THUC.1.37.2: fasi\ de\ cummaxi/an dia\ to\ sw=fron ou)deno/s pw de/casqai: to\ d' e)pi\ kakourgi/a| kai\ ou)k a)reth=| e)peth/deusan.
1.81.1-2: ta/x' a)/n tis qarsoi/h o(/ti toi=s o(/plois au)tw=n . . . u(perfe/romen, w(/ste th\n gh=n dh|ou=n e)pifoitw=ntes. toi=s de\ a)/llh gh= e)sti pollh\ kte(.
1.102.2: ma/lista d' au)tou\s e)pekale/santo o(/ti teixomaxei=n e)do/koun dunatoi\ ei)=nai, toi=s de\ poliorki/as makra=s kaqesthkui/as tou/tou e)ndea= e)fai/neto.
1.104.2: oi(\ de/ . 2.4.1, Elsew.
HDT.2.30: didou=si sfe/as au)tou\s tw=| *ai)qio/pwn basile/i: o(\ de/ sfeas tw=|de a)ntidwre/etai. 169: ai(\ de/. 6.69: e)gw\ de\ . . . o(\ de/. Often.

AR. Eq. 626. 651: oi(\ (de/). 652. 663-4: e)karado/khsen ei)s e)/m' h( boulh\ pa/lin. | o(\ de\ tau=t' a)kou/sas . . . e)flhna/fa. 666: oi(\ d(e/). 667. 670: oi(\ d(e/). 680: oi(\ d(e/). Vesp. 116-30 (sexies). 568-70: ta\ paida/ri' eu)qu\s a)ne/lkei . . . e)gw\ d' a)krow=mai: ta\ de\ . . . a)mblhxa=tai. Pax, 623: oi(\ d(e/).
COM. Cratin. 2.183: kai\ ga\r e)bli/mazon au)th/n, h(\ d' e)fro/ntiz) ou)de\ e(/n.

EUR. Alc. 264-5: oi)ktra\n fi/loisin, e)k de\ tw=n ma/list' e)moi\ | kai\ paisi/n (516). Heracl. 290-1: ma/la d' o)cu\s *)/arhs o( *mukhnai/wn, | e)pi\ toi=si de\ dh\ ma=llon e)/t' h)\ pri/n. I. T. 296. 333-5: pro\s d' a)/nakta th=sde gh=s | komi/zome/n nin. o(\ d' . . . o(/son ta/xos | . . . e)/pempe/ soi. Or. 877: o(\ de . Suppl. 207-8 (516).

SOPH. O. C. 741-2:
pa=s se *kadmei/wn lew\s
kalei= dikai/ws, e)k de\ tw=n ma/list' e)gw/
. 1607-11: e)s de\ gou/nata patro\s pesou=sai kla=on . . . o(\ d' w(s a)kou/ei fqo/ggon . . . ei)=pen .
PIND. O. 1.74-6: a)/puen baru/ktupon | *eu)tri/ainan: o(\ d' au)tw=| | pa\r podi\ sxedo\n fa/nh. 6.52: toi\ d(e/). 13.92: to\n d(e/). P. 4.41: tw=n d(e/). 133: oi(\ d(e/).

HOM. Od. 9.399-401: au)ta\r o(\ *ku/klwpas mega/l' h)/puen . . . | oi(\ de\ . . . e)foi/taon a)/lloqen a)/llos. 9.407-9: tou\s d(e\) . . . prose/fh . . . *polu/fhmos . . . oi(\ d' a)pameibo/menoi e)/pea ptero/ent' a)go/reuon. 471: oi(\ d(e/). 480: oi(\ d(e/).

Il. 1.43: w(\s e)/fat' eu)xo/menos: tou= d' e)/klue *foi=bos *)apo/llwn. 313-4: laou\s d' *)atrei+/dhs a)polumai/nesqai a)/nwgen. | oi(\ d' a)pelumai/nonto. 446-7: w(\s ei)pw\n e)n xersi\ ti/qei/, o(\ d' e)de/cato xai/rwn | pai=da fi/lhn. 22.141: h(\ de/.

p.emph: same as subject of preceding sentence:

div2.p: e)ntau=q' e)/menon w(s to\ a)/kron kate/xontes. oi(\ d' ou) katei=xon, a)lla\ masto\s h)=n u(pe\r au)tw=n, XEN. An. 4.2.5-6 ; There they remained fancying that they were in possession of the summit. Not they, but there was a knoll above them.
THUC.1.87.1-2: toiau=ta de\ le/cas e)peyh/fizen au)to\s e)/foros w)/n. o(\ de/, kri/nousi ga\r boh=| kai\ ou) yh/fw|, ou)k e)/fh diagignw/skein th\n boh\n o(pote/ra mei/zwn.

HDT.1.17 HDT., 1.66 HDT., 1.107 HDT., 1.171 HDT., 1.196 HDT., 3.126 HDT., 5.35 HDT., 5.120 HDT., 6.3 HDT., 6.9: ei) de\ tau=ta me
 ou) poih/sousi, oi(\ de\ pa/ntws dia\ ma/xhs e)leu/sontai, ta/de h)/dh sfi le/gete. 133. 7.13. 125. 163: *ge/lwn de\ . . . tau/thn me
 th
 o(do
 h)me/lhse, o(\ de\ a)/llhs ei)/xeto. 218. 8.40. 9.52. 108.
SOPH. El. 711-3: xalkh=s u(pai\ sa/lpiggos h)=|can: oi(\ d' a(/ma | i(/ppois o(moklh/santes h(ni/as xeroi=n | e)/seisan.

HOM. Od. 9.398-9: to
 me
 (sc. moxlo/n) e)/peit' e)/rriyen a)po\ e(/o . . . | au)ta o(\ *ku/klwpas mega/l' h)/puen. 13.219: tw=n me
 a)/r' ou)/ ti po/qei: o(\ d' o)du/reto patri/da gai=an.

o(\ ga/r as a substantive is not found in Attic prose.It is claimed by Classen for THUC.1.69.2: oi( ga\r drw=ntes bebouleume/noi pro\s ou) diegnwko/tas h)/dh kai\ ou) me/llontes e)pe/rxontai, and 6.36.2: oi( ga\r dedio/tes i)di/a| ti bou/lontai th\n po/lin e)s e)/kplhcin kaqista/nai.
o(\ ga\r h(=lqe qoa\s e)pi\ nh=as *)axaiw=n, HOM. Il. 12.
HDT.1.172: toi=si ga/r. 2.124: th=s . . . ga/r. 148: o( de\ dh\ labu/rinqos kai\ ta\s purami/das u(perba/llei. tou= ga\r duw/deka me/n ei)si au)lai\ kte(.
SOPH. El. 45-6: o(\ ga\r | me/gistos au)toi=s tugxa/nei doruce/nwn. O. R. 1082: th=s ga/r. 1102: tw=| ga/r. Ph. 154: to\ ga/r.
AESCHYL. Ag. 1478-9: e)k tou= ga\r e)/rws ai(matoloixo\s | . . . tre/fetai. Sept. 17: h(\ ga/r. Suppl. 358: tw=n ga/r. 970: tou= ga/r.
THEOGN. 392: h(\ ga\r kai\ xaleph\n ti/ktei a)mhxani/hn.
HOM. Od. 1.359: tou= ga\r kra/tos e)/st' e)ni\ oi)/kw|.
Il. 1.9-10: o(\ ga\r basilh=i xolwqei\s | nou=son . . . w)=rse kakh/n. 12 (see above). 55: tw=| ga/r. 404: o(\ ga/r.
In Attic prose kai\ to/n, kai\ th/n are used in oratio obliqua where kai\ o(/s, kai\ h(/ (see 522) would be used in oratio recta. In poetry and in HERODOTUS, the use is not limited to oratio obliqua.
e)/fh ga\r . . . e)re/sqai au)to\n o()poi i)/oi . . . kai\ to\n ei)pei=n o(/ti e)pi\ dei=pnon, PLATO, Conv. 174A; He said that he asked him whither he was going and he made answer, To a banquet.
PLATO, Conv. 174A (see above).
XEN. An. No example. (See Joost, Sprachgebr. Xenophons in der Anabasis, p. 61.) Cyr. 1.3.9: kai\ to\n keleu=sai dou=nai . 4.2.13: kai\ to\n a)pokri/nasqai le/getai .

HDT.1.24: kai\ toi=si e)selqei=n . . . h(donh/n. 86: kai\ tou\s . . . e)peirwta=n. 2.162: kai\ tw=| . . . e)gi/neto. 4.5: kai\ tw=n . . . kai\ to/n. 9: kai\ to\n . . . e)qe/lein. 6.61: kai\ th\n fra/sai. 8.88: kai\ to/n . . . kai\ tou/s.
SOPH. O. C. 1699: o(po/te ge kai\ to\n e)n xeroi=n katei=xon .
AESCHYL. Eum. 174: kai\ to\n ou)k e)klu/setai.
PIND. I. 7(8), 15: i)ata\ d' e)/sti brotoi=s su/n g' e)leuqeri/a| kai\ ta/.

p.hi: o(/s, h(/, o(/ used like the substantive article.

div2.p: The use of o(/s, h(/, o(/ as a demonstrative is almost confined in Attic prose to the combinations kai\ o(/s, kai\ h(/, kai\ oi(/, and the phrases h)= d' o(/s, h)= d' h(/. In poetry the use is more free.
DEM.18.71: *fi/lippos po/leis *(ellhni/das a(\s me\n a)nairw=n, ei)s a(\s de\ tou\s fuga/das kata/gwn e)/lue th\n ei)rh/nhn.
ANTIPHON, 1.16: h)rw/ta ou)=n au)th\n ei) e)qelh/soi diakonh=sai/ oi(, kai\ h(\ u(pe/sxeto w(s ta/xista.
PLATO, Conv. 201E: kai\ h(/, ou)k eu)fhmh/seis; e)/fh. 205 C (= 206 A. C): h)= d' h(/. 208 C: kai\ h(/. Rpb. 437 B (see above). 437 D and often: h)= d' o(/s.
THUC.4.33.2: tou\s de\ yilou\s . . . e)/trepon, kai\ oi(\ u(postre/fontes h)mu/nonto.
HDT.4.68: ta\s basilhi+/as i(sti/as e)piw/rkhke o(\s kai\ o(/s. 7.18: kai\ o(/s. 8.56: kai\ oi(/. 87: kai\ h(/.
EUR. I. T. 419-20: gnw/ma d' oi(=s me\n a)/kairos o)/lbou, toi=s d' ei)s me/son h(/kei.
THEOGN. 169: o(\n de\ qeoi\ timw=s', o(\n kai\ mwmeu/menos ai)nei=. 800: a)ll' o(\s lw/i+\os, o(\s mh\ pleo/nessi me/lh|.
PHOCYL. 1: *ae/rioi kakoi/: ou)x o(\ me/n, o(\s d' ou)/.
HOM. Od. 1.286: o(\s ga\r deu/tatos h)=lqen. 17.172: o(\s ga/r. 24.190: o(\ (= to/) ga\r ge/ras e)sti\ qano/ntwn.
Il. 6.59: mhd' o(\s fu/goi . 12.357-8: o(\ ga/r k' o)/x' a)/riston a(pa/ntwn | ei)/h. 21.198: a)lla\ kai\ o(\s dei/doike. 22.201: ou)d' o(/s. 23.9 (= Od. 24.190 cited above).

p.hi: to\n kai\ to/n, to\ kai\ to/, ta\ kai\ ta/.

div2.p: to\n kai\ to/n, to\ kai\ to/, ta\ kai\ ta/ occur chiefly in familiar discourse.

a)fiknou=mai w(s to\n kai\ to/n, LYS. 1.23 ; I go to this man ('s house) and that man('s). ei) to\ kai\ to\ e)poi/hsen a(/nqrwpos [ou(tosi/], ou)k a)\n a)pe/qanen, DEM.18.243; If the poor fellow had done this and that (thus and so), he would not have died.

DEM.9.68: e)/dei ga\r to\ kai\ to\ poih=sai, kai\ to\ mh\ poih=sai. 18.243 (see above). 19.74: dia\ to\ kai\ to/. 21.141: ta\ kai\ ta/. 45.45. 54.26. Cf. Prooem. 50.3: o(/pws mh\ ta\ h)\ ta\ genh/setai, a)ll' o(/pws ta/.
LYS.1.23 (see above). 19.59: kai/ moi ka/lei to\n kai\ to/n .

PLATO , Legg. Cf. 701 E: ou) sunh/negken ou)/te toi=s ou)/te toi=s. 784 C-D: o)mo/santes h)= mh
 a)dunatei=n to
 kai\ to
 belti/w poiei=n. 874 A (= 948 A): to
 kai\ to/n.
Not found in the Anabasis (Joost, Sprachgebr. p. 62).
HDT.2.138: th=| de\ kai\ th=| th=s o(dou= de/ndrea ou)ranomh/kea pe/fuke. Cf. 4.68: o(\s kai\ o(/s (522).
AESCHYL. Cf. Suppl. 439-40: h)\ toi=sin h)\ toi=s po/lemon ai)/resqai me/gan | pa=s' e)/st' a)na/gkh.
PIND. O. 2.59: tw=n te kai\ tw=n. P. 7.22: ta\ kai\ ta/. N. 1.30: tw=n te kai\ tw=n xrh/sies. I. 4.52: *zeu\s ta/ te kai\ ta\ ne/mei.
THEOGN. 398: to\n d' a)gaqo\n tolma=n xrh\ ta/ te kai\ ta\ fe/rein.
HES. Sc. [209-10]: polloi/ ge . . . | delfi=nes th=| kai\ th=| e)qu/neon i)xqua/ontes.
Compare the similar adjective use.
PLATO, Legg. 721B: zhmiou=sqai xrh/masi/ te kai\ a)timi/a|, xrh/masi me\n to/sois kai\ to/sois, th=| kai\ th=| de\ a)timi/a|.
pro\ tou=, formerly, sometimes written protou=, is equivalent to pro\ tou/tou ( DEM.21.117. 36.16).
dia\ tau=t(a) . . . mikra/, a(\ pro\ tou= mega/l' h)=n, fai/netai, DEM.23.203.
ISAE. 8.34: ou)k oi)=d' ei)/ tini pro\ tou= . . . toiou=tos a)gw\n sumbe/bhken.
ISOC.4.112: pro\ tou= . . . e)pausa/meq' a)llh/lous e)leou=ntes.
LYS.12.2: e)n tw=| pro\ tou= xro/nw| .
PLATO, Conv. 172D. Phaedo, 96 C. Phaedr. 252 A. Protag. 315 D.
AR. Nub. 5: a)ll' ou)k a)\n pro\ tou= . Thesm. 418.
AESCHYL. Ag. 1204. Eum. 462: to\n pro\ tou= feu/gwn xro/non.
For e)n toi=s with the superlative see the Superlative.
tw=| = therefore.
tw=| toi, w)= fi/le *qeo/dwre, ma=llon skepte/on, PLATO, Theaet. 179D.
PLATO, Soph. 230B: tw=| toi tau/ths th=s do/chs e)pi\ e)kbolh\n a)/llw| tro/pw| ste/llontai. Theaet. 179 D (see above).
SOPH. O. R. 510-1: tw=| a)p' e)ma=s | freno\s ou)/pot' o)flh/sei kaki/an.
AESCHYL. P.V. 237: tw=| toi toiai=sde phmonai=si ka/mptomai.
HOM. Od. 2.281: tw=|In Homer some write tw=. to/ is also found. nu=n mnhsth/rwn me\n e)/a boulh/n te n:o/on te. 8.548-9: tw=| nu=n mhde\ su\ keu=qe . . . | o(/tti ke/ s' ei)/rwmai. Often.
Il. 2.250: tw=| ou)k a)\n basilh=as a)na\ sto/m' e)/xwn a)goreu/ois. 354. Often.
o(/ ge, to/ ge.
pa/ssofoi a)texnw=s tw/ ge, PLATO, Euthyd. 271C; All wise, absolutely so, this couple.
PLATO, Euthyd. 271C (see above). 291 A: a)lla\ mh\n to/ ge eu)= oi)=da, o(/ti kte(.
HDT.2.173: la/qoi a)\n h)/toi manei\s h)\ o(/ ge a)po/plhktos geno/menos.
HOM. Od. 1.4: polla\ d' o(/ g' e)n po/ntw| pa/qen. 26. 31. 331: a(/ma th=| ge. 370: to/ ge. 443. Often.

p.hi: Substantive article unsupported by a particle.

div2.p: HOMER uses the article as a substantive demonstrative with more freedom than the
a)lla\ ta\ me\n poli/wn e)\c e)pra/qomen, ta\ de/dastai, HOM. Il. 1.125.

HDT. 1.51: kai\ ta/de a)/lla (sc. a)pe/pempe)a(/ma toi=si . 5.97: kai\ pro\s toi=si . 7.8, b: deu/tera de\ h(me/as oi(=a e)/rcan . . . ta\So Stein, who, however, states in the critical note that ta/ is omitted by Dionysius, and rightly so. Krüger and Abicht both omit the ta/. e)pi/stasqe/ kou pa/ntes .
SOPH. The to/n of O. C. 1574 (Hermann) and of O. R. 200 is regarded as demonstrative by Ellendt, Lexicon Sophocleum, but as relative by Jebb.

AESCHYL. Eum. 137-8: su\ d' ai(mathro\n pneu=m' e)pouri/sasa tw=| | e(/pou. 338: toi=s o(martei=n. Sept. 197: a)nh\r gunh/ te xw)/ ti tw=n metai/xmion. Suppl. 1047: o(/ ti/ toi mo/rsimo/n e)stin, to\ ge/noit' a)/an.
PIND. O. 6.74-6 (see 529). P. 3.88-91: le/gontai ma\n brotw=n | o)/lbon u(pe/rtaton oi(\ sxei=n, oi(/te . . . | a)/ion.

HOM. Od. 1.55: tou= quga/thr du/sthnon o)duro/menon kateru/kei. 74: e)k tou= dh/. 212: e)k tou=, from that time. 215: mh/thr me/n te/ me/ fhsi tou= e)/mmenai. 220: tou=. 11.144: ei)pe/, a)/nac, pw=s ke/n me a)nagnoi/h to\n e)o/nta; Elsewhere.

p.hi: Article as antecedent of the relative.

div2.p: Wherever the article is used as a full demonstrative, it may be used as the antecedent of the relative, but the regular antecedent of the relative is ou(=tos. In Attic prose the few examples cited are mainly in the neuter gender, and may be explained and have been explained on the same principle as the ordinary article with any word or group of words.

ou)/ tis | tw=n oi(\ nu=n brotoi/ ei)sin, HOM. Il. 1.271-2. But in Attic: ta\ e)n toi=s u(/dasi fanta/smata kai\ e)n toi=s o(/sa pukna/ te kai\ lei=a kai\ fana\ cune/sthke, PLATO, Rpb. 510A (o(/sa . . . cune/sthke parallel with u(/dasi). to/n te *eu)qu/kriton . . . kai\ to\n o(\s e)/fh despo/ths tou/tou ei)=nai, ma/rturas pare/comai, LYS. 23.8 (o(\s e)/fh . . . ei)=nai parallel with *eu)qu/kriton).

DEM.22.64: kai\ misei=n tou\s oi(=o/sper ou(=tos. 25.30: ei)/ tis . . . ei)/poi toi=s biazome/nois e)cei=nai le/gein h)\ toi=s e)k tou= desmwthri/ou h)\ toi=s w(=n a)pe/kteinen o( dh=mos tou\s pate/ras. Ibid.: pro/sesti toi=s oi(=os ou(=to/s e)sti th\n fu/sin.
LYS. 23.8(see above).

kai\ meta\ toi=sin pi=ne kai\ e)/sqie, kai\ meta\ toi=sin
i(/ze, kai\ a(/ndine toi=s, w(=n mega/lh du/namis .

HOM. Od. 1.219-20: o(\s a)potmo/tatos ge/neto . . . | tou= m' e)/k fasi gene/sqai. 2.116: ta\ frone/ous' a)na\ qumo/n, a(/ oi( pe/ri dw=ken *)aqh/nh. 6.28: ta\ de\ toi=si parasxe/men, oi(/ ke/ s' a)/gwntai. 7.211-2: ou(/s tinas . . . toi=sin. 17.383: tw=n oi(/. 19.7-8: toi=sin . . . | oi(=a.
Il. 1.271-2 (see above). 4.232-3: ou(\s me\n speu/dontas i)/doi . . . | tou\s ma/la qarsu/neske. 9.74-5: tw=| pei/seai o(/s ken a)ri/sthn | boulh\n bouleu/sh|.

Out of the demonstrative use grows the relative use, for which see Relative Sentence. The ancient grammarians called the demonstrative article a)/rqron protaktiko/n, the relative a)/rqron u(potaktiko/n, and relative and article were blended in the consciousness of the people.

div2.head: Adjective use
div2.p: The article is commonly treated under two heads, that of the individual or specific article and that of the generic article.

div2.head: Individual or Specific Article
div2.p: The use of the Individual or Specific Article is so much like the English that only divergencies need be noticed at length.

p.hi: Article with objects present to the mind.

div2.p: Like the English the Attic article is used of objects that are present to the mind or senses, well-known, notorious, expected, recurring, customary — the Anaphoric Article or Article of Reference.

oi( ma/rtures memarturh/kasin, ANDOC.1.25; The witnesses have testified.
o( . . . a)/nqrwpos e)/ndon h)=n, Lys. 1.11 ; The fellow was within. o( po/lemos e(rpe/tw, Ar. Lys. 129 and 130; On with the war. sta/seis e)n tai=s po/lesin . . . e)gi/gnonto, THUC.1.12.2; Factions kept breaking out in the (different) cities. qa/natos . . . h( zhmi/a, DEM.20.167; The (regular) penalty is death. diekwlu/qhsan de\ u(po\ tou= genome/nou seismou=, THUC.1.101.2; They were prevented by the occurrence of the well-known (great) earthquake. *ce/rchs o(/te e)k th=s *(ella/dos h(tthqei\s th=| ma/xh| [after having been defeated in the (famous) battle] a)pexw/rei, XEN. An. 1.2.9.

The article is used very freely in prose, in orators, philosophers, historians alike, to intimate possession. So especially in family relations, parts of the body, personal belongings. In elevated poetry this possessive article is very little used. The language is content with the anarthrous substantive. But as possession is more freely emphasized in poetry than in prose, the possessive pronoun and possessive genitive are often employed where prose would be satisfied with the article. (See Possessive Pronouns.) Comedy admits the prose use without difficulty.

The Greek language uses the article with numerals more freely than the English, as, for instance, of fractions, ro&udot;nd numbers, accepted standards, and the like.

HOM. Od. 6.62-3: pe/nte de/ toi fi/loi ui(=es e)ni\ mega/rois gega/asin, | oi( du/' o)pui/ontes, trei=s d' h)i/qeoi qale/qontes.
Il. 5.271-2: tou\s me\n te/ssaras au)to\s . . . a)ti/tall(e) . . . | tw\ de\ du/' *ai)nei/a| dw=ken.

Proper Names for the most part do not require the article. The conditions under which the article is used are set forth in the following sections. In connection with these, see also Blass, Rhein. Mus. 44 (1889), pp. 6-17; Carolus Schmidt, De articulo in nominibus propriis apud Atticos scriptores pedestres, Kiliae, 1890; H. Kallenberg, Philologus 49 (1890), pp. 515-47; id., Studien über den gr. Artikel, Berlin, 1891, Pr.; B. L. Gildersleeve, A. J. P. xi (1890), 483-7; Uckermann, Über den Artikel bei Eigennamen in den Komödien des Aristophanes, Berlin, 1892, Pr.; Zucker, Beobachtungen über den Gebrauch des Artikels bei Personennamen in Xenophons Anabasis, Nürnberg, 1899; A. J. P. xxiv (1903), 482; Völker, Syntax der griechischen Papyri: I. Der Artikel, Münster, 1903, Pr.

The Article with the Names of Persons belongs to popular diction, and may be considered a norm of familiar style. It is not found in epic poetry, the examples usually cited being demonstrative rather than articular. It is rare in the higher lyric, more common in comedy than in tragedy. In prose some authors use it steadily for anaphora or for contrast. Plato uses it freely. The orators vary. With them the rule is not to use the article with the name of the opponent, who, as is natural, is often mentioned.

Names of opponents anarthrous (Schmidt, l.c.). 1.58: *polu/eukton de\ . . . tou= dh/mou prosta/cantos zhth=sai th\n boulh/n . . . , a)pe/fhnen h( boulh/ . . . a)pelu/saq' u(mei=s, o(mologou=nto:s tou= *polueu/ktou badi/zein ei)s *me/gar(a).

In the first three orations *fi/lippos and its forms occur 29 times without the article; with the article they are found 1.9: tapeinote/rw| nu=n a)
 e)xrw/meqa tw=| (your high and mighty) *fili/ppw|. 2.5. 6. 22. 3.5. 7. 21: to

 *perikle/a. 9.59: *eu)frai=os de/ tis a)/nqrwpos, but afterwards articular 60. 61. 62 (twice). 66. See also A. J. P. xi (1890), 486, note.

In the genuine portion of the first oration (Blass' text), the name *ti/marxos occurs 67 times. Only one of these instances is articular (§ 60), 2 instances are vocatives, and once poi=os is the modifier.
ANTIPHON, 1: *filo/news is anarthrous when first mentioned § 14, thereafter articular.
PLATO. The articular form is used with the utmost freedom.

XENOPHON In the Agesilaus (Dindorf's text) *)aghsi/laos occurs 51 times without the article, 18 times with the article. According to Joost, Sprachgebrauch Xenophons in der Anabasis, Berlin, 1892, *ku=ros occurs 196 times in the Anabasis, o( *ku=ros 28 times. Cf. also Zucker, l.c.
THUC.1.128-38: *pausani/as and o( *pausani/as, *qemistoklh=s and o( *qemistoklh=s vary. See Herbst in A. J. P. ii (1881), 541, and Schmidt, A. J. P. xi (1890), 485.
HDT.3.39-46 and 120-5 (Stein): *polukra/ths 23 times, o( *polukra/ths 15 times.

AR. The article is exceptional and chiefly deictic. *swkra/ths without article occurs Nub. 144. 147. 154. 174, but 182: kai\ dei=con w(s ta/xista/ moi to\n *swkra/thn , And show me without delay (your great hero) Socrates. For other exx. see Fuller, de articuli in antiquis Graecis comoediis usu, Leipzig diss., 1888.
PIND. P. 10.57: to\n *(ippokle/an (see commentators).
ANACR.21: o( perifo/rhtos *)arte/mwn.
HOM. Il. 1.11: to\n *xru/shn h)ti/mhs' (h)ti/masen v. l.) a)rhth=ra.

Names of nations, inhabitants of cities, etc., as such do not require the article. *(/ellhnes, however, in the course of time came to be viewed as an adjective, in contrast with ba/rbaroi, and regularly took the article, but in Herodotus it is treated like any other national appellative.

*)olunqi/ous a)ph/launo/n tines e)nqe/nde, DEM.2.6. *fwkei=s a)polw/lasiDEM., 19.125. tettara/kont' e)/th tw=n *(ellh/nwn h)=r|canDEM., 3.24. ou(=toi de\ u(po\ me\n *(ellh/nwn kale/ontai *su/rioi, u(po\ de\ tw=n barba/rwn *)assu/rioi e)klh/qhsan, HDT.7.63(*(ellh/nwn without article in spite of contrast with tw=n barba/rwn).

DEM.2.6(see above). 7: th\n d' *)olunqi/wn fili/an . . . *qettalou\s de\ kte(. 3.24: e)kei=noi toi/nun . . . tettara/kont' e)/th tw=n *(ellh/nwn h)=rcan . . . u(ph/kouen . . . au)toi=s basileu/s, w(/sper e)sti\ prosh=kon ba/rbaron (a barbarian) *(/ellhsi (to Greeks). 6.2: *fi/lippon . . . pa=si toi=s *(/ellhsin e)pibouleu/onta.
LYS.13.8: e)/legon e)f' oi(=s e(/toimoi ei)=en th\n ei)rh/nhn poiei=sqai *lakedaimo/nioi . 19.48: *kalli/as toi/nun o( *(ipponi/kou . . . plei=sta tw=n *(ellh/nwn e)do/kei kekth=sqai .

PLATO, Legg. 698B: o(/te h( *persw=n e)pi/qesis toi=s *(/ellhsin . . . e)gi/gneto. Menex. 240 C: ou)/t' *)eretrieu=sin e)boh/qhsen *(ellh/nwn ou)dei\s ou)/te *)aqhnai/ois plh\n *lakedaimoni/wn. E: oi( *(/ellhnes. 241 A: toi=s *(/ellhsin. B: tw=n *(e. and so regularly. 242 C: pa/ntwn tw=n *(ellh/nwn. Rpb. 471 B: pro\s de\ tou\s barba/rous w(s nu=n oi( *(/ellhnes pro\s a)llh/lous.

XEN. Cyr. 1.4.27: kai\ ga\r nu=n e)/ti tou=to poiou=si *pe/rsai . Hell. 1.6.14: ou)k e)/fh e(autou= ge a)/rxontos ou)de/n' a)\n *(ellh/nwn a)ndrapodisqh=nai (ou)dei\s *(ellh/nwn, no one that is a Greek, very different from ou)dei\s tw=n *(e., none of the Greeks). 6.1.8: eu)petw=s a)\n e)gw\ tago\s *qettalw=n a(pa/ntwn katastai/hn . 10: *boiwtoi/ ge . . . *lakedaimoni/ois . . . kai\ *)aqhnai=oi . 5.34: a)namimnh/|skontes de\ w(s *)aqhnai=oi/ te u(po\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn h(|re/qhsan h(gemo/nes tou= nautikou= . . . au)toi/ te kata\ gh=n o(mologoume/nws u(f' a(pa/ntwn tw=n *(ellh/nwn h(gemo/nes prokriqei/hsan .

According to Schmidt, l.c. p. 21, *(/ellhnes is used with the article 90 times (15 of the 90 with a modifier), and seven times without the article where the article might have been expected. 1.25.4: toi=s *(ellh/nwn plousiwta/tois. [So 1.31.2: h)=san ga ou)deno\s *(ellh/nwn e)/nspondoi. 41.1: kata\ tou\s *(ellh/nwn (v. l. with art.) no/mous. 69.4: h(suxa/zete ga mo/noi *(ellh/nwn. 89.2: *mh=doi . . . nikhqe/ntes . . . u(po\ *(ellh/nwn. 137.4: kaka\ . . . plei=sta *(ellh/nwn (v. l. w. art.) ei)/rgasmai to
 u(me/teron oi)=kon. 138.2: ou)dei/s pw *(ellh/nwn (v. l. w. art.)]. 1.54.2: e(ka/teroi . . . *kori/nqioi . . . *kerkurai=oi . . . kai\ e)peidh\ *)aqhnai=oi h)=lqon. 6.69.3: *surako/sioi me
 . . . tw=n de\ e)nanti/wn *)a qhnai=oi me
 . . . *)argei=oi de\ kte(.

HDT.1.1: to\ kai\ *(/ellhnes le/gousi. 2: le/gousi *pe/rsai ou)k w(s *(/ellhnes . . . *(ellh/nwn tina/s. 3: toi=si *(/ellhsi. 4: *(/ellhnas dh\ . . . *(/ellhnas de\ *lakedaimoni/hs ei(/neken gunaiko\s sto/lon me/gan sunagei=rai. 5: e)s tou\s *(/ellhnas (twice). 6: tou\s me
 katestre/yato *(ellh/nwn . . . tou\s de\ fi/lous prosepoih/sato . . . pro\ de\ th=s *kroi/sou a)rxh=s pa/ntes *ellhnes h)=san e)leu/qeroi. 7: *kandau/lhs, to
 oi( *(/ellhnes *mursi/lon o)noma/zousi. (In the more than 30 occurrences of *(/ellhnes in book 1, the article is omitted three times as often as it is used. In the seventh, in which *(/ellhnes is used more than 100 times, there is a slight preponderance of the articular form due to its frequent use in referring to the Greek army or navy as opposed to the Persian invaders.) 1.82: bohqhsa/ntwn de\ *)argei/wn th=| sfete/rh| a)potamnome/nh| . . . u(pelei/ponto . . . *)argei/wn me
 *)alkh/nwr te kai\ *xro/mios, *lakedaimoni/wn de\ *)oqrua/dhs. 7.63 (see above).

AR. Ach. 177: dei= ga/r me feu/gont' e)kfugei=n *)axarne/as. Nub. 413: e)n *)aqhnai/ois kai\ toi=s *(/ellhsi . Ran. 724: e)/n te toi=s *(/ellhsi kai\ toi=s barba/roisi pantaxou=. So *(/e. regularly with article except with pa/ntes, Ach. 529: *(/ellhsi pa=sin, elsew., and the rare exception Pax, 203-4: e)cw|ki/santo d' oi( qeoi\ ti/nos ou(/neka; | *(/ellhsin o)rgisqe/ntes. (See Uckermann, l.c., pp. 5 ff.)
For the Articular National Appellative in the singular used collectively, or used of the king, ruler, or general, see §§ 57 and 58.
In combination with appositive proper names, the article is used to identify by demonstration (resumption).
*sofai/netos o( *)arka/s, XEN. An. 1.2.9 ; Sophaenetus the Arcadian as distinguished from *sofai/netos . . . o( *stumfa/lios, Ibid. 3 ; Sophaenetus the Stymphalian.

DEM.23.124: *mene/stratos . . . o( *)eretrieu/s . . . *fa/u+llos o( *fwkeu/s. 24.134: *qrasu/boulon to
 *kollute/a . . . *file/yion to
 *lamptre/a . . . *)agu/rrion to
 *kollute/a. 138: *eu)/dhmon to

Names of gods as such do not require the article, but the articular form is very common, especially in familiar language. When the name of a god in the genitive depends upon an articular substantive it is generally accompanied by the article, but if the governing substantive is without the article, the name of the god is anarthrous too.

In oaths the article is required except with the name of Zeus. With the name of Zeus familiarity has brought about the fading of the oath, and the article is usually omitted.

p.hi: Use of article in complex of name of god and epithet.

div2.p: When an epithet is added to the name of a god, both take the article or neither (fixity of religious phrases the world over).For the usage of the ISS, see Meisterhans3, § 86.3 and 4.

Adjectival names of countries and of urban territories require the article, but names of countries in -i/a that are identical with the feminines of related adjectives fluctuate.
The general exceptions hold good as to the predicate (666), enumerations (568), and the common article (603).

*la/kaina: Xen. *lakwnikh/: Xen. Thuc. Hdt. Ar. *leonti/nh: Thuc. *leukadi/a: Thuc. (exc. 4.42.3 where K. would read *leuka/di). *lokri/s: Xen. Thuc. Ar. *ludi/a (unsteady): Dem. Isoc. Xen. Hdt. *luki/h: Hdt. (without article except 1.182 where the chorographic genitive requires the article).

*magnhsi/a (article rare): Dem. Aeschin. Hdt. *malea=tis: Xen. *mantinikh/: Xen. Thuc. *megarikh/: [Lys. ], Xen. *megari/s: Thuc. *mhdikh/: Xen. Hdt. *mhqumnai/a: Antiphon. *mhli/s: Hdt. *milhsi/a: Thuc. Hdt. *mugdoni/h: Hdt. *musi/a: Xen. Hdt.
*naupakti/a:
*)olunqi/a: Xen. *)oresqi/s:
*paionikh/: Hdt. *paktui*kh/: Hdt. (once without article in enumeration) *palaisti/nh: Hdt. *parrasikh/: Thuc. *paflagonikh/: Xen. *persikh/: Hdt. *persi/s: Plato , Xen. *plataii/s: Hdt. *pteri/h:
*(rhgi/nh: Thuc. *(rodi/a: [Aeschin. ], Thuc. *(rupikh/:

*salamini/h: Hdt. *sami/h: Hdt. *sikuwni/a: Thuc. *sindikh/: Hdt.4.86 e)k th=s *sindikh=s (so Wesseling for *)indikh=s). *skiri=tis: Xen. Thuc. *skuqikh/: Plato , Hdt. *surakosi/a: Thuc. *suri/a (does not require the article): Plato ,
*tanagrai/a: Thuc. *taurikh/: Hdt. *tegea=tis: Thuc. *traxini/a: Thuc.3.92.1 *(hra/kleian th\n e)n *traxini/a| (“CG; *traxini/ais ABEFM suprascr. GI” — Hude); Hdt. *trw|a/s: Xen. Hdt.
*ulai/h:

*fanoti/s: Thuc.4.76.3 th=| *fano/tidi (so the MSS., Poppo and Krüger; but most editors *fanoti/di). *fqiw=tis: Thuc. *fleiasi/a: Thuc. *frugi/a (fluctuates): Dem. Isoc. Xen. Hdt. *fwkai/s: Thuc. *fwki/s: [Dem. ], Aeschin. Isoc. Xen. Thuc. Hdt.
*xalkidikh/:
*wrwpi/a: Plato ,

p.hi: Addition Thuc. of xw/ra, gh=, moi=ra.

div2.p: xw/ra, gh=, and moi=ra sometimes accompany proper names, especially in Herodotus. Such proper names are frankly adjectival and gh= and xw/ra often retain the full sense of “soil.”

th=s *)arabi/hs xw/rhs, HDT.2.11. th=s xw/rhs th=s *)arabi/hs, HDT.3.113. th=s *)argoli/dos moi/rhs, HDT.1.82. h(me/ras ga\r tessara/konta ma/lista e)n th=| gh=| th=| *)attikh=| e)ge/nonto, THUC.2.57.2; They were on Attic soil about forty days. (Cf. § 1: h(=san e)n th=| gh=| th=| *)aqhnai/wn, which differs from 56.6: e)n th=| *)attikh=| o)/ntas.)
DEM. *)attikh/n 18.141 (religious formula). *)indikh/n [Ep.] 4.7. *kirrai/a 18.149 (xw/ra is necessary in this passage).
AESCHIN. [Ep.] 10.3: e)n th=| *trw|a/di gh=|.

HYPERID. h( xw/ra . . . h( *molotti/a 3.25, but the reading is doubtful and Blass has the following note: “h( *molossi/a (sic enim A) ut manifestum emblema eicit Cb. . . .; at JBL. monuit formam tantum suspectam esse. Kallenberg Philol. 49.516 in h( x. h( *m. haeret, sed v. Eur. Andr. 1244 (LL.).”

XEN. *)andri/as (Cobet del. xw/ras) Hell. 1.4.22. *)armeni/as Cyr. 3.2.18. *)attikh/n (gh=n not otiose) [R.A.] 2.16. *kolxi/di An. 5.3.2. *lakwnikh/n Hell. 6.2.9. *mhdi/as Cyr. 3.3.22; *mhdi/an 2.1.1. *musi/a| An. 1.2.10. *persi/di Cyr. 8.5.25; *persi/da 2.1.1. *tegea/tidi Hell. 6.5.15.

THUC. *(alia/da 2.56.5; 4.45.2. *)attikh=| 2.57.2 (only instance in Th. in which *)attikh/ has gh=). *boiwti/as 1.108.3. *)epidauri/an 4.45.2. *(ermioni/da 2.56.5. *qespikh=s 4.76.3. *qesprwti/dos 1.46.3. *qouria/dos (*qouri/dos *h, *qourida/tidos *b) 7.35.1. *qurea=tis 2.27.2. *plataii/da 2.71.4; 74.3; 3.58.5. *troizhni/an 4.45.2. *troizhni/da 2.56.5. *fwki/dos 1.108.3.

Names in h=tis, i=tis, and w=tis are used only as adjectives. e)k de\ th=s *(istiaiw/tidos 1.56 is a solitary exception, but adjectival *(istiaiw=tin immediately precedes, *ai)oli/da 7.176. *ai)twli/dos 6.127. *)apollwni/hs [xw/rhs] 9.93. *)arabi/hs 2.11; 3.113. *)argoli/dos 1.82; *)argoli/da 6.92. *)assuri/h [om. Rdz] 1.192. *)atarnei/tidos 6.29. *)attikh/ etc. 4.99; 5.64; 6.73; 7.10 b; 7.143; 8.65; 9.4; 9.13 (twice). *babulwni/h etc. 1.106; 1.192; 1.193 (twice); 4.198. *baktri/hs . . . *baktri/h| 4.204. *boiwti/h 9.87; *boiwti/hs 8.44. *bottiaii/da 7.123; 127. *dwri/dos . . . *dwri/da 8.31. *(ella/dos 1.152. *)eretrikh=s 6.101. *)eruki/nhn 5.45. *)hlei/h| 4.30. *qhbai+/di 9.65. *)idria/dos 5.118. *)ilia/dos 5.94; *)ilia/da 7.42. *)indikh=s 3.98. *(istiaiw/tidos 7.175 (gh=s om. Rsv); 8.23. *karusti/hs 9.105. *kiliki/hn 3.90. *kimmeri/hn 4.11. *kissi/h etc. 5.49; 52; 6.119. *knidi/h 1.174. *krhstwnikh=s 8.116. *krotwnih/tidi 5.45. *kuqhri/h 1.82: h(/ te e)n th=| h)pei/rw| xw/rh kai\ h( *kuqhri/h [nh=sos]. (nh=sos must be omitted and xw/rh is undoubtedly understood with K.) *kurhnai/h 4.199. *la/kainan 7.235. *ludi/h 1.93. *magnhsi/hs 7.183. 188. *makedoni/da (om. B) 7.127. *matihnh/n 5.52. *megari/da 9.14. *mhdikh/ etc. 1.73; 103; 110 (twice); 4.12 (twice, but in one of exx. gh=n is bracketed); 7.20. *mhli/dos 8.31; *mhli/da 7.198. *milhsi/hs 1.19; 6.20 (but ABC *milhsi/wn). *milua/da 1.173. *mugdoni/hs 7.124; *mugdoni/hn 7.123 (twice). *musi/hs 1.160; *musi/hn 7.42; 8.106. *naupli/hn 6.76. *neuri/dos 4.125; *neuri/da 4.51. *oi)nwtri/hs 1.167. *paktui+kh=s 4.44; *paktui+kh=| 3.102. *persi/s etc. 3.97; 7.8 g; 29; 53. *plataii/da 9.15; 25. *pteri/h| 1.76. *salamini/hs 8.95. *sauroma/tidos 4.123. *skuqikh/ etc. 1.105; 2.22; 4.48; 51; 61; 99 (twice); 123; 129 (twice). *tanagrikh/n 5.57. *teukri/da 2.118. *tirunqi/hn 6.76. *trhxini/hn 7.199. *trw|a/di 5.26. *fqiw=tin 1.56. *frugi/h is never used with gh=, xw/rh, or moi=ra. *fwki/dos 8.31; *fwki/da 8.32. *xi/hs 6.26.
AR. Thesm. 109-10: o(\s (sc. *foi=bos) i(dru/sato xw/ras | gu/ala *simounti/di ga=| (lyric).
Examples like e)n th=| nu=n *(ella/di kaleome/nh| xw/rh|, HDT.1.1, have been excluded from the above exhibit because in such instances the proper name is predicative.

Of the grand divisions of the earth, *)asi/a, which is never adjectival in prose, and *eu)rw/ph, which is everywhere a substantive, require the article, whilst *libu/h varies. The rule is subject to the same exceptions as in 547.

h)=lqen e)k th=s *)asi/as, THUC.1.9.2; He came from Asia. a)nexw/rhsan e)k th=s *eu)rw/phs, Ibid. 1.89.2; They retreated from Europe. a)fikome/nous a)po\ th=s *libu/hs, Ibid. 7.50.1; Having arrived from Libya, but immediately thereafter, Ibid. 2: a)penexqe/ntes ga\r e)s *libu/hn, Carried out of their course to Libya. e)n tw=| metacu\ *)asi/hs te kai\ *libu/hs, HDT.2.16; In the space between Asia and Libya (enumeration). h)\ *)asi/h| h)\ *eu)rw/ph|, Ibid. 4.198; To either Asia or Europe. th=s ga\r gh=s a(pa/shs . . . di/xa tetmhme/nhs, kai\ th=s me\n *)asi/as, th=s d' *eu)rw/phs kaloume/nhs, ISOC.4.179; The whole earth being divided into two parts, the one called Asia, the other Europe (article omitted because *)asi/as and *eu)rw/phs are predicates).

ORATORES ATTICI. The rule is always observed, e.g. ISOC.4.82: pro\s tou\s e)k th=s *)asi/as. 83. 133. 135. 137. Elsew. But ISOC.4.186: tou\s o(/lhs th=s *)asi/as koath/santas, there is a v. l. o(/lhs *)asi/as.

PLATO, Crit. 108E: *libu/hs kai\ *)asi/as mei/zw (enumeration). 112 E: e)pi\ pa=san *eu)rw/phn kai\ *)asi/an (enumeration). Gorg. 523 E: du/o me
 e)k th=s *)asi/as . . . e(/na de\ e)k th=s *eu)rw/phs. 524 A: kai\ tou\s me
 e)k th=s *)asi/as *(rada/manqus krinei=, tou\s de\ e)k th=s *eu)rw/phs *ai)ako/s. *e: oi( me
 e)k th=s *)asi/as. Menex. 239 D: h(goume/nous th=s *)asi/as kai\ douloume/nous th
 *eu)rw/phn . . . pa=sa me
 h( *)asi/a . . . Ibid. E: kai\ th=s a)/llhs *)asi/as. Tim. 24 E: e)pi\ pa=san *eu)rw/phn kai\ *)asi/an (enumeration) . . . h( de\ nh=sos a(/ma *libu/hs h)=n kai\ *)asi/as mei/zwn (enumeration).
XEN. According to Kallenberg, the rule is always observed. In the Hellenica alone *)asi/a, according to Keller's index, occurs 26 times. The article is used each time.
THUCYDIDES always uses the article. 1.9.2. 109.3. 2.67.1. 97.6. 4.75.2. 5.1. 8.39.3 (chorographic genitive in postposition). 58.2 (partitive gen. in predication).

The article may be omitted only when three or at least two grand divisions are named together [Kallenberg, Philol. 46 (1887), 729 = 49 (1890), 525]. 2.16: oi(/ fasi tri/a mo/ria ei)=nai gh=n pa=san *eu)rw/phn te kai\ *)asi/hn kai\ *libu/hn (predication) . . . e)n tw=| metacu\ *)asi/hs te kai\ *libu/hs (enumeration), but in the same section ei) mh/te ge/ e)sti th=s *)asi/hs mh/te th=s *libu/hs: ou) ga dh\ o( *nei=lo/s ge/ e)sti . . . o( th
 *)asi/hn ou)ri/zwn th=| *libu/h|. 2.17: ou)/risma de\ *)asi/h| kai\ *libu/h| oi)/damen ou)de/n (enumeration). 4.37: *pe/rsai oi)ke/ousi kath/kontes e)pi\ th
 noti/hn qa/lassan (Schweighaeuser, followed by Stein, wrongly reads *)asi/hn *pe/rsai kte(. 42: qwma/zw w)=n tw=n diourisa/ntwn kai\ dielo/ntwn *libu/hn te kai\ *)asi/hn kai\ *eu)rw/phn (enumeration), but ibid. plh
 o(/son au)th=s pro\s th
 *)asi/hn ou)ri/zei. 198: doke/ei de/ moi ou)d' a)reth
 ei)=nai/ tis h( *libu/h spoudai/h w(/ste h)\ *)asi/h| h)\ *eu)rw/ph| parablhqh=nai (enumeration). 6.24: e)k de\ tau/ths parh=n e)s th
 *)asi/hn (th
 om. AB'Cd).
*eu)rw/ph:
ORATORES ATTICI. The rule is always followed as, e.g. ISOC.4.68: kaq' o(\n (sc. xro/non) e(ka/teroi th=s *eu)rw/phs e)ph=rxon. 117. 187. Elsew.

PLATO , Alc. II, 141 B: pa/shs *eu)rw/phs (exceptional). Criti.112E (enumeration, see 550). Gorg. 523 E (see 550). 524 A (see 550). Menex. 239 D (see 550). Tim. 24 E (enumeration, see 550). 25 B: *libu/hs (no article) me\n h)=rxon me/xri pro\s *ai)/gupton, th=s de\ *eu)rw/phs me/xri *turrhni/as.

XEN. The only exception to the rule is An. 7.8, [25]: tw=n e)n *eu)rw/ph| *qra|kw=n (Kallenberg, l.c., p. 525), and this passage is spurious. *eu)rw/ph is not nearly so common as *)asi/a, occurring only four times (see Keller's index) in the Hellenica, viz., 3.2.9. 4.2.6. 3.15. 8.5.
THUC.1.89.2: e)peidh\ *mh=doi a)nexw/rhsan e)k th=s *eu)rw/phs. 2.97.5. 6. All three exx. follow the rule.

In 2.26 and 2.33, all Mss., and in 4.49 ABC, omit the article in the phrase dia\ pa/shs th=s *eu)rw/phs. In 3.115: ta\ e)pe/keina th=s *eu)rw/- phs, only R has the article. In all the passages the article should be read unless, as is likely, dia\ pa/shs *eu)rw/phs in 2.33 is to be bracketed. For the omission of the article in 2.16. 4.42. 198, see 4.45: e)s th\n gh=n tau/thn h(/tis nu=n u(po\ *(ellh/nwn *eu)rw/ph (predicate) kale/etai. Elsewhere with the article: 1.4 (twice). 103. 209 (twice). 2.26 (part. gen.). 33 (twice). 103. 3.96. 115. 116. 4.36. 42. 45 (twice). 49 (twice). 89. 143. 5.1. 12. 6.33. 7.5. 8 (twice). 9. 10. 20. 33. 50. 56. 126. 148. 174. 185. 8.51. 97. 108 (ter). 109. 9.14 (part. gen.).
*libu/h:
ORATORES ATTICI. Apparently the only passage is DEM. [52]DEM., 3: ou(=tos e)peidh\ e)kplei=n e)/mellen ei)s th\n *libu/hn.

PLATO, Criti. 108E: *libu/hs kai\ *)asi/as mei/zw. Menex. 239 E: o( de\ ui(o\s au)tou= *ai)gu/ptou te kai\ *libu/hs (sc. h)=rcen). Tim. 24 E: h( de\ nh=sos a(/ma *libu/hs h)=n kai\ *)asi/as mei/zwn. 25 B: *libu/hs (no article) me\n h)=rxon me/xri pro\s *ai)/gupton, th=s de\ *eu)rw/phs (article) me/xri *turrhni/as.
XEN. Mem. 2.1.10: e)n de\ th=| *libu/h| *karxhdo/nioi me\n a)/rxousi, *li/bues de\ a)/rxontai (apparently the only occurrence in XEN. ).

THUC.1.110.1: poreuo/menoi dia\ th=s *libu/hs. 2.48.1: h)/rcato de\ to\ me\n trw=ton . . . e)c *ai)qiopi/as th=s u(pe\r *ai)gu/ptou, e)/peita de\ kai\ e)s *ai)/gupton kai\ *libu/hn kate/bh. (This passage seems to show that by THUCYDIDES *libu/h was regarded as a country rather than a grand division.) 4.53.3: tw=n te a)p' *ai)gu/ptou kai\ *libu/hs o(lka/dwn. 6.2.3: e)s *libu/hn prw=ton, e)/peita e)s *sikeli/an. 7.50.1: a)po\ th=s *l. 2: e)s *l. 58.2: to\ pro\s *libu/hn me/ros tetramme/non. There are two cases of the use of the article against five of the omission.

HDT. The word occurs about 59 times, 34 times without the article, 25 with it. Of the latter number a few instances may be charged to the partitive gen. The following examples are illustrative. 2.16: e)n tw=| metacu\ *)asi/hs te kai\ *libu/hs, but in the same section ei) mh/te ge/ e)sti th=s *)asi/hs mh/te th=s *libu/hs, and 3.96: a)po\ th=s te *)asi/hs kai\ th=s *libu/hs. 4.41: toiau/th me
 . . . h( *)asi/h e)sti/, h( de\ *libu/h (with art.) e)n th=| a)kth=| th=| e(te/rh| e)sti/: a)po\ ga *ai)gu/ptou *libu/h (without art.) h)/dh e)kde/ketai. 42: *libu/h me
 ga dhloi= (without art., though in the same sentence th
 *)asi/hn is found and in the preceding sentence h( *eu)rw/ph occurs) . . . i(/na e(ka/stote th=s *libu/hs (part. gen.) ple/ontes ginoi/ato . . . periple/ontes th
 *libu/hn (with art.). 43: ou) perie/plwse *libu/hn (without art.) . . . *libu/hn ga/r oi( a)na/gkhn e)/sesqai periple/ein . . . to\ a)krwth/rion th=s *libu/hs (part. gen.) . . . tou= de\ mh\ periplw=sai *libu/hn. 44: a)pe/steile periple/ein *libu/hn (without art.) . . . ta\ a)/lla a)neu/rhtai o(/moia parexome/nh th=| *libu/h| (with art.).

AR. AV. 710: spei/rein me\n o(/tan ge/ranos krw/zous' e)s th\n *libu/hn metaxwrh=| (“nach dem als Winterheimat der Kraniche bekannten Libyen,” says Uckermann, l.c., p. 20), but 1136-7: e)k me/n ge *libu/hs h(=kon w(s trismu/riai | ge/ranoi.

p.hi: Article with chorographic genitive and partitive genitive of name of country.

div2.p: The Chorographic Genitive (cf. “Bethlehem of Judaea”) generally takes the article and so does the Postpositive Partitive Genitive of the name of a country.

e)n *mhqu/mnh| th=s *le/sbou, XEN. Hell. 1.2.12. th=s *le/sbou e)pi\ *mh/qumnan, XEN. Hell. 1.6.12. ou)damoi= th=s *qra/|khs, DEM.23.166. *ai)gu/ptou ta\ plei/w, THUC.1.104.1.But *foini/khs e)s *sidw=na po/lin, HDT.3.136, and very exceptional: me/ros te/tarton *eu)boi/as, DEM.23.213.
ORATORES ATTICI: The Orators follow the rule, but names that would take the article at any rate do not count. Exception: DEM.23.213(see above).

DEM.9.35: *xerronh/sou th\n megi/sthn e)/xei po/lin *kardi/an. 23.166: ou)k e)pi\ th=s *qra/|khs to/pon ou)de/n' ou)de\ xwri/on . . . ou)damoi= th=s *qra/|khs. But different ibid. h(\ *xerronh/sou me/n e)sti kai\ h)=n u(mete/ra. Cf. 23.182: w(/sper *xalki\s tw=| to/pw| th=s *eu)boi/as pro\s th=s *boiwti/as kei=tai, ou(/tw *xerronh/sou kei=tai pro\s th=s *qra/|khs h( *kardianw=n po/lis (on the Boeotian side of Euboea — on the Thracian side of the Chersonesus). 23.213 (exception; see above). [50], 46: e)k *meqw/nhs th=s *makedoni/as.
AESCHIN. [Ep.] 1.1: ei)s *korhsso\n th\n *kei/wn (v. l. *ke/w; th=s *ke/w, Taylor).

ISAE. 5.42: th=s *)olusi/as e)n *spartw/lw|. (Example doubtful. *)olusi/a not known; “*)olunqi/as Palmer, cf. Thuc.2.79.” If *)olunqi/as be the correct reading, the ex. does not belong here, as *)ol. of itself would require the article.)
ISOC.8.24: kai\ me\n dh\ kai\ th=s *qra/|khs h(mi=n e)ce/stai tosau/thn a)poteme/sqai xw/ran. (Doubtful. *qra/|khs might be gen. of separation.) 9.27: swqei\s ei)s *so/lous th=s *kiliki/as.
AND.3.9: *eu)boi/as ple/on h)\ ta\ du/o me/rh.

XEN. Hell. 1.2.12 (see above). 1.4.1: th=s *frugi/as e)n *gordiw|. 8: e)/pleuse th=s *kari/as e)s to
 *kerameiko
 ko/lpon. 1.6.12 (see above). 16: ei)s *mutilh/nhn th=s *le/sbou. 26: th=s *le/sbou e)pi\ th=| *male/a| a)/kra|. 2.1.13: e)n *qamnhri/ois th=s *mhdi/as. 15: a)nh/xqh th=s *kari/as ei)s to
 *kera/meion ko/lpon. 20: th=s *xerronh/sou e)n *)elaiou=nti. 3.2.19: ei)s *tra/lleis th=s *kari/as. 4.4.16: pollaxo/se kai\ th=s *)arkadi/as e)mbalo/ntes. 5.2.38: th
 mei/zw du/namin *makedoni/as is not partitive. 6.1.5: e)/xw me
 *qettali/as ta\s plei/stas kai\ meli/stas po/leis summa/xous. 7.1.28: strateusa/menos ei)s *parrasi/ous th=s *)askadi/as. 7.4.21: e)dh/|ou kai\ th=s *)arkadi/as o(/sa e)du/nato.

THUCYDIDES follows the rule strictly. [Cf. Kallenberg, Philol.49 (1890), Philol., 534.] 1.2.3: *peloponnh/sou . . . ta\ polla/. 1.10.2: *p. tw=n pe/nte ta\s du/o moi/ras. 1.12.4. 1.104.1 (see above). 1.111.1: e)stra/teusan th=s *qessali/as e)pi\ *fa/rsalon. 3: th=s *)akarnani/as ei)s *oi)nia/das e)stra/- teusan. 2.56.4: e)s *)epi/danron th=s *peloponnh/sou. 6.62.2: e)n tou/tw| tw=| me/rei th=s *sikeli/as. 7.34.1: kata\ *)erineo\n th=s *)axai:/as. 51.1: a)/llose/ poi th=s *sikeli/as. Elsew.

HDT. The usage is still unsettled. 2.15: ta\ de\ a)/lla . . . th=s *ai)gu/ptou. 16: *ai)gu/ptou to\ *de/lta. 18: *ai)gu/ptou ta\ pro/soura *libu/h|. 2.26: th=s *libu/hs ta\ a)/nw. 32: peri\ tw=n e)rh/mwn th=s *libu/hs . . . ta\ e)/rhma th=s *libu/hs. 43: ou)damh=| *ai)gu/ptou (exception). 97: ta\ . . . a)/lla th=s *ai)gu/ptou. 113: e)s *ai)/gupton kai\ *ai)gu/ptou (no article) e)s to\ nu=n *kanwbiko\n kaleu/menon sto/ma tou= *nei/lou. 149: au)th=s *ai)gu/ptou to\ para\ qa/lassan. 157: *)/azwton th=s *suri/hs mega/lhn po/lin. 3.3: *ai)gu/ptou ta\ me\n a)/nw ka/tw qh/sw. 17: oi)khme/nous de\ *libu/hs e)pi\ th=| noti/h| qala/ssh|. 3.136 (see above). 4.151: e)s *l. kai\ *libu/hs (no article) e)s *plate/an nh=son. 4.154: e)/sti th=s *krh/ths *)oaco\s po/lis. 156: *kurh/nhn th=s *libu/hs. 157: e)/ktisan au)th=s th=s *libu/hs xw=ron. 5.123: *)iwni/hs (no article) me/n nun *klazomena\s ai(re/ousi. 6.47: th=s *qa/sou metacu\ *ai)nu/rwn te xw/rou kaleome/nou kai\ *koinu/rwn. 7.30: po/lin mega/lhn *frugi/hs (exception). Elsew.
In Av. 152: th=s *lokri/dos and 1704: th=s *)attikh=s the proper names of themselves require the article.

p.hi: Ommission of article with proper names in prepositional phrases.

div2.p: As with common nouns, so with proper nouns, Prepositional Phrases sometimes show a tendency to resist the article.
tw=n me\n e)n *qra/|kh| kakw=n, DEM.8.44. ta)pi\ *qra/|khs, Ibid. 64. But ku/rios th=s *qra/|khs, DEM.18.27(not a prepositional phrase).
DEM.8.44(see above). 64 (ibid.). 18.87: parelqw\n e)pi\ *qra/|khs. 19.161: ta)n *qra/|kh|. 219: ta)pi\ *qra/|khs.
AESCHIN.2.9: to\n e)pi\ *qra/|khs to/pon. 98: peri\ . . . th=s e)pi\ *qra/|khs o(dou=.

HDT.2.28: e)p' *ai)gu/ptou r(e/ein . . . e)p' *ai)qiopi/hs. 73: komi/zein . . . e)p' *ai)gu/ptou. 75: pe/tesqai e)p' *ai)gu/ptou. 6.33: ta\ tei/xea ta\ e)pi\ *qrhi:/khs.
Names of Towns do not require the article, and even the anaphoric use is sometimes due merely to the desire for the avoidance of hiatus.

The word po/lis may be added by way of explanation. It is omitted with well-known cities, with names preceded by the article, in attributive prepositional phrases, and sometimes when the same name is repeated in close proximity. When po/lis has been used with the first of two or more coördinate names, it need not be repeated with the succeeding ones.

*peiraieu/s regularly takes the article, but the article may be omitted in prepositional phrases, and in the Attic Orators this omission is the rule for articular phrases with e)n and e)c. (Cf. Kallenberg, l.c. 543.)

*po/ntos always has the article even when it designates the country along the Black Sea. When *eu)/ceinos is expressed, the forms are o( *eu)/ceinos to/ntos and o( po/ntos o( *eu)/ceinos. *maiw=tis and *proponti/s always take the article, the former being accompained by the word li/mnh. For the Aegaean, the Greeks said to\ *ai)gai=on pe/lagos, o( *ai)gai=os po/ntos, and to\ *ai)gai=on. o( *)adri/as and h( *su/rtis are the rule. Other names of seas are adjectival; hence regularly h( *)eruqra\ qa/latta, h( *kaspi/h qa/lassa (HDT. ), etc. *(ellh/|spontos prefers the article, which, however, is frequently omitted in prepositional phrases. *)wkeano/s and *bo/sporos seem to require the article, but *bo/sporos = Panticapaeum follows the usage of towns.

AR. Nub. 271: *)wkeanou= patro\s e)n th/po\is (name of divinity; similarly 277: patro\s a)p' *)wkeanou= ). 273: *maiw=tin li/mnhn e)/xete (poetic). Vesp. 700: po/lewn a)/rxwn plei/stwn a)po\ tou= *po/ntou me/xri *sardou=s. Ran. 664-5: *po/seidon . . . | o(\s *ai)gai/ou prw=nas . . . me/deis (poetic).

p.hi: Omission and use of article and potamo/s with names of rivers.

div2.p: I. As a general rule when the name of a river is mentioned for the first time, the type o( *nei=los is used of well-known rivers, the type o( *strumw\n potamo/s of fairly well-known rivers, and the type *bro/ggos potamo/s or potamo\s *bro/ggos of obscure rivers.

tou= *nei/lou, HDT.2.10. oi(\ de\ . . . e)/frazon w(s . . . ei)/h . . . h( *paioni/h e)pi\ tw=| *strumo/ni potamw=| pepolisme/nhHDT., 5.13. e)c *)illuriw=n de\ r(e/wn . . . *)/aggros potamo\s e)sba/llei . . . e)s potamo\n *bro/ggonHDT., 4.49.

II. When a river that has once been mentioned is referred to again by name in the same context, the article is used with the second name, but to this in the case of obscure rivers the word potamo/s is generally attached.

kata\ to
 *nei=lon, HDT.2.10 follows tou= *nei/lou mentioned a few lines preceding. e)pi\ tw=| *strumo/ni potamw=| . . . o( de\ *strumw/n, HDT.5.13. e)s potamo
 *bro/ggon, o: de\ *bro/ggos, HDT.4.49. kath/kontes e)pi\ potamo
 tw=| ou)/noma ke/etai *pantika/phs, HDT.4.18; but diaba/nti to
 *pantika/phn potamo/n, Ibid. 19.
III. All rivers are anarthrous and are sometimes accompanied by the word potamo/s
I. In the predicate.
to\n de\ dh\ potamo\n tou=ton . . . suneba/lleto ei)=nai *nei=lon, HDT.2.33.
2. In enumerations.

a)/lloi mega/loi . . . e)sba/llousi e)s au)to/n, *)/atlas kai\ *au)/ras kai\ *ti/bisis. dia\ de\ *qrhi/khs . . . r(e/ontes *)/aqrus kai\ *no/hs kai\ *)arta/nhs e)kdidou=si e)s to\n *)/istron, HDT.4.49.
3. In dependence upon the word pedi/on.
e)n *maia/ndrou pedi/w|, HDT.1.18.

th=| e)pi\ *qermw/donti ma/xh|, HDT.4.110. me/xri *)/istrou potamou=, HDT.4.89. a)po\ ga\r *)/istrou e)pi\ *borusqe/nea, HDT.4.101. au)tou= peri\ *)/acion potamo\n kai\ po/lin *qe/rmhn, HDT.7.124(*)/acios already mentioned in 123).
5. When the name is emphatically placed at the head of the sentence.
*nei/lou me/n nun pe/ri tosau=ta ei)rh/sqw, HDT.2.35.
6. When an articular attributive expression is attached to the name.

*nei=lo/s te o( *ai)gu/ptios potamo\s . . . kai\ *fa=sis o( *ko/lxos, HDT.4.45. plh\n *nei/lou tou= *ai)gupti/ou, Ibid. 53.For further details, see Hermann Kallenberg, Studien über den griechischen Artikel, Berlin, 1891.
DEM. [59]DEM., 99: o( ga\r *)aswpo\s potamo\s me/gas e)rru/h.
AESCHIN.2.124: ei)splei=n me/ fhsin . . . kata\ to\n *loidi/an potamo/n. 3.183: e)pi\ tw=| *strumo/ni potamw=| e)ni/kwn maxo/menoi *mh/dous.
ISOC.4.144: th=s e)nto\s *(/aluos xw/ras. 7.80: e)nto\s *(/aluos potamou=. 11.12: tw=| *nei/lw|. 31: to\n . . . *nei=lon teri\ th\n xw/ran perie/rrhce. 12.59: e)nto\s *(/aluos.

PLATO, Phaedr. 229A: deu=r' e)ktrapo/menoi kata\ to\n *)ilisso\n i)/wmen. 257 E: tou= makrou= a)gkw=nos tou= kata\ *nei=lon. But Politic. 264 C: tai=s e)n tw=| *nei/lw| tiqasei/ais tw=n i)xqu/wn kai\ tw=n e)n tai=s basilikai=s li/mnais. Tim. 21 E: to\ tou= *nei/lou r(eu=ma.

In the Anabasis potamo/s is regularly added to the articular name, and even the most obscure rivers often take the article, but the following rule is observed: In introducing a comparatively unknown river, Xenophon uses the article when narrating the march of his own army, but omits it in merely geographical descriptions. 1.2.11: ei)s *kau+/strou pedi/on. 1.4.1: e)celau/nei . . . e)pi\ to\n *pu/ramon potamo/n. 2.5.1: a)fiknou=ntai e)pi\ to\n *zapa/tan potamo/n. 5.3.8: e)/tuxe de\ diarre/wn . . . potamo\s *selinou=s. kai\ e)n *)efe/sw| de\ . . . *selinou=s potamo\s pararrei=. 5.6. 36: plei=n ei)s *fa=sin and so regularly because the name of the city is included. 7.8.8: ei)s *kai:/kou pedi/on.

In the Hellenica the articular name without potamo/s is more commonly used, the rivers of the Hellenica being for the most part well known. So the Alpheus, Eurotas, Attic and Boeotian Cephisus, and the Maeander. In the case of the Eurymedon, the Pactolus, and the Cladaus, the articular name is followed by potamo/s. See Kallenberg, l.c., p. 11.

THUCYDIDES in general follows the same rules as Herodotus, but for obvious reasons the anarthrous name with potamo/s is much less common than in Herodotus. The names of insignificant rivers of Sicily and Lower Italy, which had become familiar to the Athenians as a result of the Sicilian expedition, follow the type o( *)axelw=|os potamo/s. 1.46.4: dia\ de\ th=s *qesprwti/dos *)axe/rwn potamo\s r(e/wn . . . r(ei= de\ kai\ *qu/amis potamo/s. 98.1: *)hio/na th
 e)pi\ *strumo/ni. 100.1: h( e)p' *eu)rume/donti potamw=| . . . pezomaxi/a. 100.3: e)pi\ de\ *strumo/na (omission of the article exceptional) pe/myantes . . . oi)kh/toras. 2.5.2: o( ga *)aswpo\s potamo/s. 96.3: me/xri . . . tou= *strumo/nos potamou= (but 2.97.2. 4.102.4. 108.1. 6. 5.7.4. 7.9, with the article alone). 2.96.4: me/xri tou= *)oski/ou potamou=. (The Oscius had become so familiar to Thucydides that he unwittingly presupposes general acquaintance with the river on the part of the Athenians.) 97.1: me/xri *)/istrou potamou= . . . e)c *)abdh/rwn e)s *)/istron. 99.4: pe/ran *)aci/ou me/xri *strumo/nos. 102.2: o( ga *)axelw=|os potamo/s (but ibid. 3. 3.7.4. 106.1 without potamo/s). 3.19.2: dia\ tou= *maia/ndrou pedi/ou. 6.4.1: u(pe *pantaku/ou . . . potamou=. 7.80.5: o(/pws e)peidh\ ge/nointo e)pi\ tw=| potamw=| tw=| *kakupa/rei, para\ to
 potamo
 i)/oien a)/nw dia\ mesogei/as (tw=| potamw=| gloss?). 7.82.3: a)fiknou=ntai e)pi\ to
 potamo
 to
 *)erineo/n (to
 potamo/n gloss?). 8.58.1: e)n *maia/ndrou pedi/w|.
For Herodotus, see the boldface examples above and Kallenberg, l.c.

p.hi: Omission and use of article and o)/ros with names of mountains.

div2.p: The use of the names of mountains follows in general the same rules as prevail in the case of names of rivers. But between the article and the word o)/ros, the name of a mountain is found only when it is distinctly adjectival, and ordinary apposition, which occurs rarely, if at all, in classic authors in the case of rivers, cannot be questioned with names of mountains.

e)s *di=on . . . o(\ u(po\ tw=| *)olu/mpw| . . . kei=tai, THUC.4.78.6(well-known mountain). a)p' *)olu/mpou de\ o)/reos (Mysian mountain) kale/ontai *)olumpihnoi/, HDT.7.74. to\ *ai)ga/lewn (adjective) o)/ros, THUC.2.19.2. to\ *kro/nion (adjective used subst.), XEN. Hell. 7.4.14. u(po\ tw=| o)/rei th=| *geranei/a|, THUC.4.70.1. u(po\ tw=| o)/rei: . . . to\ kale/etai *ai)ga/lews (predicate), HDT.8.90. *dih=s . . . oi( e)n *)/aqw| (attrib. prepositional phrase), THUC.5.82.1. me/xri *kauka/sios o)/reos (improper preposition), HDT.3.97(but ta\ de\ pro\s bore/hn a)/nemon tou= *kauka/sios, Ibid., and o: *kau/kasos, 1.203. 204). th\n pro\s *kiqairw=na kai\ *druo\s kefala/s (double locality), THUC.3.24.1.

p.quote: le/getai . . . e)k th=s *ai)/tnhs r(u/aka puro\s gene/sqai.

div2.p: DEM.19.141(=148): to\ *Tilfwsai=on. 148: e)pi\ tw= *(hdulei/w.
AESCHIN.2.90: *(iero\n o)/ros (city name). 3.86: to\ *kotu/laion o)nomazo/menon o)/ros. 132: to\n *)/aqw. 161: e)k me/sou tou= *kiqairw=nos.
ISOC.4.89: to\n . . . *)/aqw.
LYS. [2]. 29: to\n *)/aqw . 49: *gera/neian (locality).
ANDOC.1.38: e)pi\ *lauri/w|. 39: e)pi\ *lau/rion (mines referred to in both cases).
PLATO, Legg. 699A: a)kou/ontes *)/aqw te diorutto/menon kai\ *(ellh/sponton zeugnu/menon (enumeration).

XEN. An. 5.3.10: e)k th=s *folo/hs. 7.8.7: th\n *)/idhn. Cyn. 11.1: peri\ to\ *pa/ggaion o)/ros . Hell. 1.2.9: tou\s o(pli/tas tou\s e)n *korhssw=|. 4.3.9: metacu\ *pranto\s kai\ *narqaki/ou. 5.2.17: e)n tw=| *paggai/w|. 6.5.51: to\ *)/oneion. 7.4.14 (see above). Oec. 19.6: peri\ to\n *lukabhtto/n.

THUC.1.101.2: e)s *)iqw/mhn a)pe/sthsan (both mountain and locality). 2.19.2 (see above). 23.1: metacu\ *pa/rnhqos kai\ *brilhssou= o)/rous. 55.1: me/xri *laurei/ou. 75.2: e)k tou= *kiqairw=nos. 96.3: e)k tou= *skomi/ou (some MSS.: *sko/mbrou) o)/rous. 99.3: u(po\ to\ *pa/ggaion . . . u(po\ tw=| *paggai/w|. 102.2: e)k *pi/ndou o)/rous. 3.19.2: me/xri tou= *sandi/ou lo/fou. 24.1 (see above). 85.4: e)s to\ o)/ros th\n *)istw/nhn (Istone also name of region). 116.1: e)pi\ th=| *ai)/tnh| tw=| o)/rei (Kallenberg agrees with Herw, in cancelling tw=| o)/rei). 4.44.4: u(po\ tou= o)/rous tou= *)onei/ou (adj.). 70.1 (see above). 78.6 (see above). 96.7: pro\s *pa/rnhqa to\ o)/ros (Herw. would strike out to\ o)/ros). 5.16.3: e)s *lu/kaion (temple is meant). 82.1 (see above). 8.108.4: dia\ th=s *)/idhs tou= o)/rous (Gen. th=s *)/idhs may depend on tou= o)/rous).

HDT.1.43: e)s to\n *)/olumpon to\ o)/ros (Cobet would strike out to\ o)/ros). 69: e)n *qo/rnaki (name includes temple and locality). 72: e)c *)armeni/ou o)/reos, from a mountain of Armenia. 104: to\ *kauka/sion o)/ros. 2.8: e)k tou= *)arabi/ou o)/reos. 3.97 (see above). 4.49: e)k de\ *paio/nwn kai\ o)/reos *(rodo/phs. 7.42: *ka/nhs o)/ros (compare *maia/ndrou pedi/on). 74 (see above). 188: pro\s *)/ipnous kaleome/nous tou\s e)n *phli/w|. 8.90 (see above). 116: e)s to\ o)/ros th\n *(rodo/phn. 9.93: e)k *la/kmonos o)/reos (obscure mountain). There are also numerous instances of the articular name without o)/ros. So Athos, Parnassus, Cithaeron, Haemus, Ida, Caucasus, etc.

In addition to the mere anarthrous and articular names of islands, occur also the following types: ai( *kukla/des nh=soi, ai( nh=soi ai( *)exina/des, h( *yutta/leia nh=sos, h( nhsi\s h( *yutta/leia, *pa/tmos h( nh=sos, h( nh=sos *dh=los, nh=sos *ski/aqos, *plate/a nh=sos.

SHRINES and SACRED INCLOSURES, being substantivized adjectives, have the article, but the FESTIVALS of the gods fluctuate as do also the names of the MONTHS whether accompanied by mh/n or not. The names of the TRIBES vary. The Greek says of SHIPS h( *)argw/, h( *salamini/a, h( *pa/ralos, just as we say “The Etruria,” “The Umbria”; and the article is used with STATUES as in English.

div2.head: Generic article.
div2.p: The principle of the generic article is the selection of a representative or normal individual. So in English to a certain extent: “He played the villain,” “acted the simpleton,” “was not the gentleman”; “the horse,” “the cow,” “the ox,” and the animals generally. The plural is foreign to our idiom.

Of this article little use is made in the highest range of Greek poetry, and almost all the examples have been, or can be, explained on other principles, sometimes on the principle of resumption (anaphora), sometimes on the principle of contrast.

ou) mo/non a)/r' . . . o( ge/rwn di\s pai=s gi/gnoit' a)/n, a)lla\ kai\ o( mequsqei/s, PLATO, Legg. 646A ; It would appear, then, that not only the old man becomes a child the second time, but also the drunken man.
di\s paides oi( ge/rontes, AR. Nub. 1417 ; Old men are twice children.
ponhro\n . . . ponhro\n o( sukofa/nths, DEM.18.242 ; A mischievous thing, a mischievous thing, is the informer.

p.hi: Article of a Type or Class:Prov. ap. AR. Vesp. 1291: ei)=ta nu=n e)chpa/thsen h( xa/rac th\n a)/mpelon, shows how the particular article and the particular aorist become generic (gnomic). Compare ‘The poor cat i' the adage.’

div2.p: For the sake of convenience there are here included names of material, and kindred words like qa/latta, gh=, pu=r, u(/dwr, xro/nos, h(me/ra, nu/c, qe/ros, xeimw/n, etc., and even h(/lios and selh/nh, which also mean sunshine and moonlight, and ou)rano/s by contrast with gh=.
o( me/n ge a)nh/r . . . h( de\ gunh/, XEN. Mem. 2.2.5; The man . . . the woman, the husband . . . the wife (of a typical pair).

PHOCYL. 6: xrh/ toi to\n e(tai=ron e(tai/rw| | fronti/zein a(/ss' a)\n perigoggu/zwsi poli=tai.
HOM. II. 3.109-10: oi(=s d' o( ge/rwn mete/h|sin, a(/ma pro/ssw kai\ o)pi/ssw | leu/ssei.

Under this head the influeńce of the original personification is to be considered, and the article with the abstract is almost on a line with the articular names of the gods (A. J. P. xi, 53), the h( a)reth/ of EURIPIDES (Suppl. 596) with the h( *)adra/steia of AESCHYLUS (P. V. 936). In fact it is often doubtful whether we have a personification or an abstract noun, especially in the nominative.

h( . . . e)lpi\s kai\ o( e)/rws . . . plei=sta bla/ptousi, THUC.3.45.5; Hope and Desire do no end of harm. ou) di/kaion . . . th=s r(w/mhs kathgorei=n, ISOC.3.4; It is not fair to bring charges against strength.

HES. O. et D. 287-9: th\n me/n toi kako/thta ... e)/stin e(le/sqai | r(hidi/ws . . . | th=s d' a)reth=s i(drw=ta qeoi\ propa/roiqen e)/qhkan. (Both contrast and personification.)
Everywhere, as in English, from HOMER to DEMOSTHENES, and even in the subtle language of philosophy differences that have been set up by grammarians are often imaginary.

PIND O. 4.16: dia/peira/ toi brotw=n e)/legxos.
THEOGN. 571: do/ca me\n a)nqrw/poisi kako\n me/ga, pei=ra d' a)/riston, Opinion is a mighty ill to men, trial a mighty boon.
HOM. Od. 22.374: kakoergi/hs eu)ergesi/h me/g' a)mei/nwn.

p.hi: Difference between articular and anarthrous abstract nouns.

div2.p: That no vital difference was felt is shown by the easy passage from the articular to the non-articular (anarthrous) form, and by the occasional combination of the anarthrous abstract noun with the articular infinitive, the article simply serving to give the infinitive a case-prefix.

h( a)reth/, PLATO , Meno, 99 A; a)reth/, Ibid. E; h( a)reth\ . . . a)reth/, 100 B. ou)si/an le/geis kai\ to\ mh\ ei)=nai kai\ o(moio/thta kai\ a)nomoio/thta, Theaet. 185 C; Being, you mean, and not-being, and likeness and unlikeness. ta\s meq' u(giei/as kai\ tou= swfronei=n (sc. h(dona/s), Phileb. 63 E; The pleasures attendant upon health and temperance.

div2.head: Absence of the article.
div2.p: Prepositional phrases and other formulae may dispense with the article as in the earlier language. So also proverbs, enumerations, the ordinal in expressions of time, and basileu/s of the Persian king. Compare wife and child, out of sight, out of mind, out of window, in harbor, to town; sun, moon, stars. But anaphora or contrast may bring back the article at any time and there is no pedantical uniformity.
To prove the variations in detail would be impossible here and unprofitable. Nor is it necessary to cite examples from poetry, which fall under the rule already given.

ei)s a)/stu, LYS.12.16 ; To town (but ei)s to\ a)/stu, Ibid. 54 ). pai=das kai\ gunai=kas (usual Greek order), LYS.12.69 ; Wives and children (usual English order). h(/lios e)du/eto, XEN. An. 1.10.15; The sun was setting, e(/kth| . . . h(me/ra|, DEM. [47]DEM., 67; On the sixth day (but regularly: meta\ . . . th\n deute/ran e)sbolh/n, THUC.2.59.1; After the second invasion). basileu\s kai\ pa/ntes oi( *(/ellhnes, DEM.9.16; The (Persian) king and all the Greeks.
AESCHIN.1.43: e)n a)/stei. 2.125: meq' h(me/ran. 3.143: kata\ qa/lattan . . . kata\ gh=n.
LYS.12.16 (568). 13.24: ei)s a)/stu , but 81: ei)s to\ a)/stu . 31.8: e)n a)grw+|, but ibid.: oi( e)k tw=n a)grw=n.
ANDOC.1.8: e)c a)rxh=s. 45: e)n a)/stei ... ei)s th\n a)gora/n ... ei)s a)kro/polin . . . ei)s to\ prutanei=on.

PLATO, Crat. 440E: ei)s a)gro/n. Gorg. 447 B: e)n a)gora=|. Legg. 844 C: e)n a)/stei ... e)n a)grw=|. Menex. 234 A: e)c a)gora=s (twice). Phaedr. 227 B: e)n a)/stei, in town, but Rpb. 327 B: a)ph=|men pro\s to\ a)/stu, towards the city. Theaet. 142 A: e)c a)grou= ... kat' a)gora/n ... kata\ po/lin ... ei)s lime/na.

XEN. a(/ma h(me/ra| (kne/fa|, dei/lh|, metopw/rw|, meshmbri/a|), me/xri dei/lhs, pro\s h(me/ran, pro\ h(me/ras, a(/m' h(li/w| a)ne/xonti, a(/ma h(li/w| a)nate/llonti (du/nonti), a)mfi\ (peri\) h(li/ou dusma/s, a)f' e(spe/ras, dia\ nukto/s, peri\ (a)mfi\) me/sas nu/ktas, a)mfi\ me/son h(me/ras, e)n me/sw|, kata\ me/son, a)mfi\ (peri\) a)gora\n plh/qousan, a)mfi\ dorphsto/n (dei/lhn, kne/fas), a(/ma o)/rqrw|, kata\ gh=n, kata\ qa/lattan, e)pi\ gh=s, ei)s gh=n, para\ gh=n, a)po\ qala/tths, e)n (e)pi\, para\) qala/tth|, e)pi\ (para\) qa/lattan, e)n decia=|, e)n a)ristera=|, e)c a)ristera=s, e)pi\ do/ru, par' a)spi/da, a)po\ i(/ppou, e)k xw/ras, kata\ xw/ran, e)k xeiro/s, e)/cw belw=n, pro\ qew=n, su\n qeoi=s, e)n nw=| (ma/xh|, pole/mw|, r(uqmw=|, o(rmh=|), e)pi\ qana/tw| (ga/mw|, pole/mw|), e)pi\ qa/naton (po/lemon, ma/xhn, dei=pnon, ce/nia, staqmo/n), ei)s ma/xhn (po/lemon, a)gora/n, kri/sin), para\ po/ton, pro\s au)lo/n, are some of the prepositional phrases used in Xenophon according to Joost, Sprachgebrauch Xenophons, pp. 66-8, which see for particulars.

THUC.4.109.1: kate/skayan . . . e)s e)/dafos. 6.2.2: ta\ pro\s e(spe/ran 5: ta\ pro\s borra=n. 6: kata\ qa/lassan. 6.6.2: kai\ kata\ gh=n kai\ kata\ qa/lassan. 7.2: u(po\ . . . nu/kta. 8.1: a(/ma h)=ri.

AR. Ach. 21: e)n a)gora=|, and so often, but Ach. 728: e)n ta)gora=|, and so elsewhere. Eq. 267: e)n po/lei (= a)kropo/lei). Nub. 69: pro\s po/lin (= a)kropolin). For statistics of local expressions, see Starkie on Vesp. 492.
PROV. e)kto\s phlou= po/das e)/xeis. potamo\s qala/tth| e)ri/zei. spodo\n feu/gwn ei)s pu=r e)mpe/ptwkas.

PLATO, Conv. 220D: o(\ de\ ei(sth/kei me/xri e(/ws e)ge/neto kai\ h(/lios a)ne/sxen, but in the same breath: e)/peita w)/|xet' a)piw\n proseuca/menos tw=| h(li/w| (564). Crat. 397 D: h(/lion kai\ selh/nhn kai\ gh=n kai\ a)/stra kai\ ou)rano/n. Gorg. 325 C: kai\ trofo\s kai\ mh/thr kai\ paidagwgo\s kai\ au)to\s o( path/r.

 . . . u(pe gunaikw=n te kai\ te/knwn kte(.
THUC.2.72.3: u(mei=s de\ po/lin me\n kai\ oi)ki/as h(mi=n para/dote. 3.3.3: *mutilhnai/ois ei)pei=n nau=s te paradou=nai kai\ tei/xh kaqelei=n.
In expressions of time, the ordinal commonly lacks the article.Compare John Thompson, Cl. Rev. xx (1906), 304.

[42]DEM., 2(= 26. 28): deute/rw| mhni/. 10: th=| prw/th| h(me/ra| meta\ ta\s a)ntido/seis. 11: th=| e(ndeka/th| tou= bohdromiw=nos mhno/s. [46]DEM., 13: deka/tw| e)/tei u(/steron h)\ o( path\r h(mw=n a)pe/qanen. [47]DEM., 67: e(/kth| toi/nun h(me/ra| u(/steron h)\ ou(=toi ei)sh=lqon ei)s th\n oi)ki/an.

XEN. An. 3.4.31: teta/rth| d' h(me/ra| . Hell. 1.2.7: e(bdo/mh| kai\ deka/th| h(me/ra| meta\ th\n ei)sbolh/n .

THUC.1.18.2: deka/tw| . . . e)/tei met' au)th/n (sc. th\n ma/xhn). 2.2.1: mhni\ e(/ktw|. 47.1: prw=ton e)/tos tou= pole/mou tou=de e)teleu/ta. 3.116.2: penthkostw=| e)/tei . . . meta\ to\ pro/teron r(eu=ma. 3: e(/kton e)/tos tw=| pole/mw| e)teleu/ta tw=|de. 4.90.3: h(me/ra| tri/th|.

HDT.5.42(= 6.40): tri/tw| e)/tei+. 6.46: deute/rw| . . . e)/tei: tou/twn. 7.1: teta/rtw| . . . e)/tei+. 7: deute/rw| me\n e)/tei+ meta\ to\n qa/naton. 191: teta/rth| h(me/rh|. 192: teta/rth| h(me/rh| . . . deute/rh| h(me/rh|.
AR. Ach. 80: e)/tei teta/rtw|. 266 (= 890): e(/ktw| . . . e)/tei. Lys. 612: e)s tri/thn gou=n h(me/ran . 881: a)/louton o)\n ka)/qhlon e(/kthn h(me/ran .

basileu/s for King of Persia is the official name of the great King. So always in ISS., but authors vary as in the case of proper names, with which basileu/s is to be classed. The orators have basileu/s, but also basileu\s o( me/gas, o( me/gas basileu/s, o( *persw=n basileu/s.
DIN.1.18: para\ tou= *persw=n basile/ws. 32: pro\s to\n *persw=n basile/a.
LYCURG.24: *mene/laos o( presbeu/sas pro\s basile/a.
DEM. [7]DEM., 29: basileu\s o( *persw=nDEM., 9.16: basileu\s kai\ pa/ntes oi( *(/ellhnes. 14.41: basile/a. 15.7 (= 8. 23): basileu/s.
AESCHIN.3.132: o( . . . tw=n *persw=n basileu/s. 163: o( tw=n *persw=n basileu/s.

LYS.[2] 21: o( . . . th=s *)asi/as basileu/s (so 27. 60). 45: basile/ws . 56: o( me/gas basileu/s . 19.25: para\ basile/ws tou= mega/lou . 33.5: tw=n de\ xrhma/twn basileu\s tami/as , The (great) King is the comptroller of the exchequer.
ANDOC.1.107: basileu/s. 3.15: ou)/te basileu\s ou)/te oi( su/mmaxoi. 29: basilei= tw=| mega/lw| . . . th\n me\n basile/ws du/namin.
PLATO, Euthyd. 274A: me/gan basile/a. Also o( me/gas basileu/s and basileu/s.
XEN. An. Basileu/s 158 times, to which may be added a few examples of me/gas basileu/s, basileu\s me/gas, o( *persw=n basileu/s and basileu\s o( *persw=n. Sce Joost, l.c., p. 64.

THUC.8.37(treaty): basileu/s (quater), basile/ws (sexies), basile/ws . . . *darei/ou (semel), basilei= (twice), basile/a (semel), basile/a *darei=on (semel), *darei=on basile/a (semel). The article is omitted or bracketed by Stahl in the few instances cited by Bétant, Lex. Thuc. , of the use of the article with basileu/s referring to the Persian King.

HDT.3.84: h)\n mh\ tugxa/nh| eu(/dwn meta\ gunaiko\s basileu/s but ibid.: game/ein de\ mh\ e)cei=nai a)/lloqen tw=| (anaphoric) basile/i. 3.117: tou= b. o( b. tou= b. o( b. 3.118: tw=| basile/i . . . para\ basile/a . . . basileu/s . . . to\n basile/a.
AR. Ach. 61: oi( pre/sbeis oi( para\ basile/ws. 94: o( basile/ws o)fqalmo/s. 98: basileu/s. 113: basileu\s o( me/gas .(= Av. 486) 124: to\n basile/ws o)fqalmo/n . Pl. 170: me/gas de\ basileu/s.

div2.head: The article with substantivized adjectives and participles.
div2.p: Adjectives and participles when used as substantives regularly take the article in prose. The omission of the article is governed by the same principles as in the case of substantives. For examples and other details, see 28.29.30.31.36.39, and 40.

p.hi: Attraction of articular participle or adjective.

div2.p: The articular participle or adjective is commonly attracted into the gender of its predicate.

ou)/te plh=qo/s e)stin ou)/te i)sxu\s h( e)n tw=| pole/mw| ta\s vi/kas poiou=sa, XEN. An. 3.1.42; It is neither numbers nor strength that win victories in war. nou=s e)stin o( diakosmw=n te kai\ pa/ntwn ai)/tios, PLATO , Phaedo, 97 C; Mind is the regulative principle and the cause of all things.

HDT.2.16: ou) ga dh\ o( *nei=lo/s ge/ e)sti . . . o( th

p.hi: Article with adverbs and prepositional and other expressions used as substantives.

div2.p: The article serves to make substantives of adverbs, prepositional phrases, and other expressions.
o( plhsi/on, DEM.54.15; One's neighbor, fellow-man. oi( to/te, PLATO, Politic. 272C; The men of that day.

PLATO, Menex. 241D: u(po\ tw=n u(/steron. Politic. 272 C: eu)/kriton o(/ti tw=n nu=n oi( to/te muri/w| . . . die/feron. Ibid. D: oi( to/te. Rpb. 371 A: ta\ oi)/koi. 372 E: oi( nu=n (26). 425 A: oi( pro/teron. Tim. 20 A: ou)deno\s u(/steros w)\n tw=n e)kei=.

Hell. 1.4.10: strathgou\s ei(/lonto *)alkibia/dhn me\n feu/gonta kai\ *qrasu/boulon a)po/nta, *ko/nwna de\ tri/ton e)k tw=n oi)/koqen.
THUC.1.62.4: tou\s e)kei=qen. 5.10.8: kai\ peso/nta au)to\n . . . oi( . . . plhsi/on a)/rantes a)ph/negkan. 8.5.4: strathgo\s h)=n tw=n ka/tw.
AR. Nub. 1015: oi( nu=n . Eccl. 16: kai\ tau=ta sundrw=n ou) lalei=s toi=s plhsi/on.

SOPH. Ai. 1151: tw=n pe/las . Ant. 74-5:
e)pei\ plei/wn xro/nos
o(\n dei= m' a)re/skein toi=s ka/tw tw=n e)nqa/de
. O. R. 916: ta\ kaina\ toi=s pa/lai tekmai/retai . 1267: ta)nqe/nde . Tr. 677: pro\s ou)deno\s tw=n e)/ndon . Elsewhere.
THEOGN. 221-3: o(/stis toi doke/ei to\n plhsi/on i)/dmenai ou)de/n, | . . . | kei=no/s g' a)/frwn e)sti/ (cf. TYRT.12.19: to\n plhsi/on a)/ndra).
For neuters like to\ pri/n, to\ pro/sqen, to\ pro/sw, to\ pe/ran, etc., see the lexica.

oi( e)k tw=n a)grw=n, LYS.31.8 ; The country people.
oi( e)pi\ tw=n new=n, THUC. 7.71.5 ; The men on shipboard (= o( . . . nautiko\s strato/s, ibid. 6).
DEM.1.12: to\ kat' a)rxa/s. 18.151: tw=n *qettalw=n kai\ tw=n e)n tai=s a)/llais po/lesi. 20.128: mhde/n' ei)=nai prose/gray' a)telh= plh\n tw=n a)f) *(armodi/ou kai\ *)aristogei/tonos.
LYS.31.8: oi( e)k tw=n a)grw=n (see above).

XEN. An. 5.4.10: e)k tou= e)pi\ qa/tera. Cyr. 7.5.13: oi( d' e)n tw=| tei/xei. 23: tou\s a)po\ tw=n oi)kiw=n. Hell. 1.2.8: oi( d' e)k th=s po/lews. 9: pro\s tou\s para\ to\ e(/los e)tra/ponto.

THUC.1.50.1: h(/sshnto oi( e)pi\ tw=| deciw=| ke/ra|. 3.36.5: tou\s e)n te/lei. 79.1: tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou (twice). 85.2: tou\s e)n th=| nh/sw|. 4: tou\s e)n th=| po/lei. 7.10: oi( para\ tou= *niki/ou.
AR. Eq. 1201: nh\ to\n *poseidw=, kai\ su\ ga\r tou\s e)k *pu/lou. Nub. 188: zhtou=sin ou(=toi ta\ kata\ gh=s .
EUR. Alc. 950: ta\ me\n kat' oi)=kon toia/d(e). Andr. 430: ta)mfi\ sou=. Hec. 791: tou\s gh=s ne/rqen. H. F. 189: ta)p' e)mou=. Or. 1278: ta)pi\ sou= .
SOPH. Ant. 65: tou\s u(po\ xqono/s . 780: ta)n *(/aidou . El. 659: tou\s e)k *dio/s . 1147: oi( kat' oi)=kon . 1464: ta)p' e)mou= . O. R. 130: to\ pro\s posi/ . Ph. 385: tou\s e)n te/lei .

AESCHYL. Ag. 1618: tw=n e)pi\ zugw=|. Choeph. 579: ta)n oi)/kw|. Eum. 930: ta\ kat' a)nqrw/pous. 952: toi=s . . . u(po\ gai=an. Sept. 313-4: toi=si . . . e)/cw | pu/rgwn. Suppl. 531: to\ pro\s gunaikw=n.

PIND. O. 13.98: ta/ t' e)n *neme/a|. 106: ta\ d' u(p' o)fru/i *parnasi/a|. P. 3.60: to\ pa\r podo/s. 10.63: ta\ d' ei)s e)niauto/n. 11.52: tw=n ga\r a)\m po/lin. N. 4.69: *tadei/rwn to\ pro\s zo/fon. 8.42: ta\ me\n a)mfi\ po/nois.

Especially to be noted are the phrases oi( peri/, oi( a)mfi/ (the latter seldom in Attic prose) with the accusative, which originally mean the suite of a person, then the person and his suite, and finally in later timesE.g. LUC. Conv. § 42: kai\ a)nei/lonto oi( peri\ to
 *)aristai/neton kai\ *eu)/kriton th
 pro\ au(tou= e(ka/teros . 43: oi( de\ a)mfi\ to
 *(/ermwna kai\ *zhno/qemin a(/ma kate/keinto . . . o(\ me
 u(pera/nw o( *zhno/qemis, o(\ d' u(p' au)to/n . the person alone.

oi( . . . peri\ to\n *)epita/dan, THUC.4.33.1; Epitadas and his men. oi( . . . a)mfi\ *peisi/straton, HDT.1.63; Pisistratus and his followers. toi=s peri\ to\n pai=da, AESCHIN.1.18; The boy's surroundings. oi( peri\ *(hra/kleiton, PLATO, Crat. 440C; Heraclitus and his followers.
DEM.39.18: yeudomarturiw=n a(lw/sesqai prosdokw=n e)f' oi(=s e)rani/zei tou/tois toi=s peri\ au(to/n (his friends).

AESCHIN.1.18: toi=s peri\ to\n pai=da (excl.), patri/, a)delfw=|, e)pitro/pw|, didaska/lois kai\ o(/lws toi=s kuri/ois. 3.91: *dhmosqe/nei . . . kai\ toi=s peri\ tou=ton (excl.). (Cf. 165: tou\s peri\ *ko/rragon stratiw/tas.)
