PLATO, Crat. 440C (see above). Meno 99 B: oi( a)mfi\ *qemistokle/a (incl.). Phileb. 44 C: oi( peri\ *fi/lhbon.

XEN. An. 1.8.21: *ku=ros . . . proskunou/menos h)/dh u(po\ tw=n a)mf' au)to/n (excl.). 2.4.2: oi( peri\ *)ariai=on (incl.). Cyr. 7.5.26: oi( d' a)mfi\ to\n *twbru/an (incl.) sunebo/wn au)toi=s. Hell. 3.4.20: oi( me\n peri\ *lu/sandron (incl.) tria/konta oi)/kade a)pe/pleon, dia/doxoi d' au)toi=s oi( peri\ *(hrippi/dan (incl.) parh=san.
THUC.4.33.1(see above). 8.65.1: oi( de\ a)mfi\ to\n *pei/sandron.

HDT.1.63: oi( de\ a)mfi\ *peisi/straton (incl.) e)speso/ntes tou\s *)aqhnai/ous tra/pousi. 3.76: oi( me
 a)mfi\ to
 *)ota/nhn . . . oi( de\ a)mfi\ to
 *darei=on (incl.).
HOM. Od. 22.281-2: toi\ d' au)=t' a)mf) *)odush=a (incl.) ... | mnhsth/rwn e)s o(/milon a)ko/ntisan o)ce/a dou=ra.
Il. 3.146: oi( d' a)mfi\ *pri/amon.

p.hi: Article with Any Word or Phrase used as a Substantive:

div2.p:
to\ d' u(mei=s o(/tan ei)/pw, th\n po/lin le/gw, DEM.18.88 ; When I use the word "you," I mean the state.
to\ e)p' au)tofw/rw|, LYS. 13.85 ; The phrase "in the act."

DEM.3.2: to/te kai\ peri\ tou= ti/na timwrh/setai/ tis kai\ o(\n tro/pon e)ce/stai skopei=n. 18.1: peri\ tou= pw=s a)kou/ein u(ma=s e)mou= dei=. 88 (see above). 19.238: to\ suggnw/mh a)delfw=| bohqei=n. 23.148: ai( a)nagkai=ai xrei=ai tou\s tou= ti/ prakte/on h)\ mh\ logismou\s a)nairou=sin a(/pantas. 37.46: peri\ tou= ti/ xrh\ paqei=n.

LYS.10.17: tou=to to\ e)piorkh/santa o)mo/santa/ e)sti, to\ de\ draska/zein, o(\ nu=n a)podidra/skein o)noma/zomen. 19: to\ me\n pefasme/nws e)sti\ fanerw=s, . . . to\ de\ oi)kh=os qera/pontos. 13.85: ei) me\n to\ e)p' au)tofw/rw| mh\ prosege/grapto (26).

PLATO, Charm. 164E: to\ ga gnw=qi sauto/n kai\ to\ swfro/nei e)sti\ . . . tau)to/n. 165 A: to/ te mhde
 a)/gan kai\ to\ e)ggu/h, pa/ra d' a)/th. Ibid.: to\ gnw=qi sauto/n. Cratyl. 428 A: to\ tou= *(hsio/dou . . . to\ ei) kai/ tis smikro
 e)pi\ smikrw=| kataqei/h. Legg. 880 D: didaxh=s xa/rin tou= ti/na tro/pon o(milou=ntes a)llh/lois a)
 filofro/nws oi)koi=en. Phileb. 20 B: to\ ga ei) bou/lei r(hqe
 lu/ei pa/nta fo/bon. 48 C: to\ gnw=qi sauto/n le/geis, w)= *sw/krates; Protag. 343 B: tou=to to\ r(h=ma . . . to\ xalepo
 e)sqlo
 e)/mmenai. D: e)/peita e)ne/bale to\ me/n. Rpb. 327 E: e)/ti e)llei/petai to\ h)
 pei/swmen u(ma=s. 352 D: peri\ tou= o(/ntina tro/pon xrh\ zh=n.

XEN. Cyr. 5.1.21: to\ d' e)a
 me/nhte par' e)moi/, a)podw/sw, eu)= i)/ste, e)/fh, ai)sxunoi/mhn a)
 ei)pei=n. Oec. 6.14: to\ semno
 o)/noma tou=to to\ kalo/s te ka)gaqo/s. 7.3: gela/sas e)pi\ tw=| ti/ poiw=n kalo\s ka)gaqo\s ke/klhsai.
HDT.8.79: h(me/as stasia/zein xreo/n e)sti . . . peri\ tou= o(ko/teros h(me/wn ple/w a)gaqa\ th\n patri/da e)rga/setai.
COM. Men. 4.361.730: to\ gnw=qi sauto\n pantaxou= 'sti xrh/simon.
EUR. Hipp. 264-5: to\ li/an h(=sson e)painw= | tou= mhde\n a)/gan.
For the Article as the modifier of a Relative Sentence, see 529.

p.hi: Masculine or feminine article with the genitive case.

div2.p: The masculine or feminine article with the genitive merely shows connexion. o( is commonly son, and h( commonly daughter, but the precise relation is to be determined from the context. The construction is not used in official documents except in the genitive case, in which the article is obligatory.

mhtro\s de\ (h)=n) *libu/hs th=s *)epa/fou tou= *dio/s, ISOC.11.10; His mother was Libya, who was the daughter of Epaphus, who was the son of Zeus. *ludo\s o( *ferekle/ous, ANDOC.1.17; Lydus, the Pherecles boy (slave) = Phereclipor. to\n th=s strathgou=, AR. Eccl. 727; The she-captain-general's man (husband). *)acio/xou tou= *)alkibia/dou, CIA. I, 274.8, but *kalli/as *(ipponi/kou, Ibid. 392 (cf. IV, 1.392).
ISAE. 5.4: *dikaioge/nhs w(molo/gei paradw/sein h(mi=n w(=n kate/lipen o( *menece/nou ta\ du/o me/rh.
ISOC.11.10(see above).

ANDOC.1.17: *ludo\s o( *ferekle/ous (sc. dou=los) . . . e)mh/nuse musth/ria gi/gnesqai e)n th=| oi)ki/a| *ferekle/ous tou= despo/tou tou= e(autou=. 19: o( . . . a)pogra/yas au)to\n *ludo\s h)=n o( *ferekle/ous (sc. dou=los). 40 (= 42): *kalli/ou tou= *thlekle/ous. 112: *kalli/as o( *(ipponi/kou.
PLATO, Apol. 33E: *niko/stratos o( *qeozoti/dou . . . *pa/ralos o(/de, o( *dhmodo/kou. 34 A: *)adei/mantos o( *)ari/stwnos. Often.
XEN. An. 1.2.15: ei)=xe . . . to\ . . . eu)w/numon *kle/arxos kai\ oi( e)kei/nou. 5.13: h)/launen e)pi\ tou\s *me/nwnos.

THUC.1.115.4: *pissou/qnh| tw=| *(ysta/spou. 127.1: *perikle/a to
 *canqi/ppou, but 1.24.2: *fali/os *)eratoklei/dou. 2.67.1: *sita/lkhn . . . to
 *th/rew . . . *farna/khn to
 *farnaba/zou, but ibid. 2: *le/arxos *kallima/xou kai\ *)ameinia/dhs *filh/monos. 4.104.4: *qoukudi/dhn to
 *)olo/rou. 5.43.2: *)alkibia/dhs o( *kleini/ou.
HDT.7.2: e)c *)ato/sshs th=s *ku/rou. 3: *dhma/rhtos o( *)ari/stwnos. 10: *)arta/banos o( *(ysta/speos.
AR. Eq. 327: o( d' *(ippoda/mou lei/betai qew/menos. Eccl. 727: to\n th=s strathgou= (sc. a)/ndra) tou=ton ou) qauma/zete;

EUR. El. 930-1: pa=sin d' e)n *)argei/oisin h)/koues ta/de: | o( th=s gunaiko/s (sc. a)nh/r), ou)xi\ ta)ndro\s h( gunh/. Hel. 470: *(ele/nh kat' oi)/kous e)sti\ tou/sd' h( tou= *dio/s. Ion, 1286: ka)=|t' e)/ktanes su\ farma/kois to\n tou= qeou=; Tro. 398: *pa/ris t' e)/ghme th\n *dio/s.
SOPH. Ant. 156: *kre/wn o( *menoike/ws . 892-3: poreu/omai pro\s tou\s e)mauth=s . O. R. 489: tw=| *polu/bou . Ph. 402: tw=| *larti/ou . 628: to\n *laerti/ou .
PIND. O. 2.50-2: pre/pei | to\n *ai)nhsida/mou | e)gkwmi/wn te mele/wn lura=n te tugxane/men.
For the occasional ellipsis of such a noun as gh=, e.g. Thuc.5.26.5: feu/gein th\n e)mautou=, see 33.

p.hi: Neuter article with the genitive case.

div2.p: The neuter article, singular and plural, with the genitive has a varied translation. But the article often serves merely to give especial emphasis, often of dislike, like our English ‘this thing of,’ and may be left untranslated.

ta\ tou= pole/mou, DEM.1.4; War and all that it involves. ta\ tw=n *qettalw=nDEM., 21; The Thessalian business. to\ th=s tu/xhs, 4.12; (The will of) fortune. to\ de\ tw=n xrhma/twn, 28; As for the (matter of) money. to\ tw=n pneuma/twn, 32; The state of the wind.
koina\ ga\r ta\ tw=n fi/lwn (property, possessions, of friends), EUR. Or. 735 . dei= fe/rein ta\ tw=n qew=n (= ta\ qei=a), Phoen. 382; One must bear what is sent by the gods, the dispensations of providence.

DEM.1.4(see above). 21 (see above). 22: ta\ th=s trofh=s. 25: ta\ tw=n *)olunqi/wn. 4.10: ta\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn. 12 (see above). 28 (see above). 32 (see above). 9.45: ta\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn h)=n tw=| barba/rw| fobe/r', ou)x o( ba/rbaros toi=s *(/ellhsin (ta\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn in chiasm with toi=s *(/ellhsin). 19.90: ta\ th=s xw/ras kai\ ta\ tw=n summa/xwn. 20.118: to\ . . . th=s gnw/mhs. 120: to\ th=s ei)ko/nos h)\ th=s sith/sews h)\ to\ th=s a)telei/as.

LYS.19.25: ei)s ta\ th=s trihrarxi/as (so Sch., Frohb., Herw., and, according to Frohb., the only instance in The Ms. reading is ta\s trihrarxi/as with marks above seeming to indicate th\n trihrarxi/an).
PLATO, Legg. 657D: to\ . . . tw=n presbute/rwn (= oi( presbu/teroi) (123). Phaedr. 230 C: pa/ntwn de\ komyo/taton to\ th=s po/as (= h( po/a). Phileb. 45 E (123). Rpb. 563 C (123).
XEN. An. 1.3.9: ta\ me\n dh\ *ku/rou dh=lon o(/ti ou(/tws e)/xei pro\s h(ma=s w(/sper ta\ h(me/tera pro\s e)kei=non. 3.1.20: ta\ . . . tw=n stratiwtw=n. Oec. 16.7: to\ tw=n a(lie/wn.
THUC.2.60.1: ta\ th=s o)rgh=s. 3.59.1: to\ th=s cumfora=s. 4.18.3: to\ th=s tu/xhs. 7.48.5: ta\ . . . *surakosi/wn. 61.3: to\ th=s tu/xhs. 8.89.4: to\ th=s o)ligarxi/as.
AR. Eccl. 624: to\ de\ tw=n a)ndrw=n ti/ poih/sei; (opposed to to\ . . . u(me/teron = to\ tw=n gunaikw=n, The men folk, the women folk).
EUR. Hel. 276: ta\ barba/rwn ga\r dou=la pa/nta plh\n e(no/s. Ion, 1551: ta\ daimo/nwn. Or. 735 (see above). Phoen. 382 (see above). Tro. 27: nosei= ta\ tw=n qew=n. 616: to\ th=s a)na/gkhs deino/n.
SOPH. O. C. 268: ta\ mhtro\s kai\ patro/s . O. R. 498: ta\ brotw=n. Ph. 300: to\ th=s nh/sou. 497: ta\ tw=n diako/nwn (= oi( dia/konoi) (123).
AESCHYL. Ag. 32: ta\ despotw=n. Pers.597(= 1016): ta\ *persa=n. Sept. 68 (= 193): ta\ tw=n qu/raqen. 375: ta\ tw=n e)nanti/wn. 1047: ta\ tou=d(e). Suppl. 600: ta\ tw=n e)gxwri/wn. 1062: ta\ qew=n.
PIND. P. 2.89: o(\s (sc. qeo/s) a)ne/xei pote\ me\n ta\ kei/nwn, to/t' au)=q' e(te/rois e)/dwken me/ga ku=dos. N. 10.4: ta\ *perse/os.
The article is used with the infinitive outside of epic poetry proper. This enables the infinitive to assume all the constructions of the substantive that are not inconsistent with its verbal nature.
Inconsistent with the character of the infinitive as a verb would be the sacrifice of its subject or object.

h( timh\ th=s po/lews becomes to\ tima=sqai th\n po/lin, DEM.18.93. h( swthri/a th=s nh/sou becomes to\ sw=sai th\n nh=son, DEM.18.100. h( tou= belti/stou a)/gnoia kai\ to\ a)gnoei=n to\ be/ltiston, PLATO , Alcib. II, 143 E.
For details of the use of the article with the infinitive, see Articular Infinitive.

div2.head: Article in combination with pronouns.
div2.p: The article is used with sundry pronouns, partly coinciding with our idiom, partly differing from it.

p.hi: Article with personal and reflexive pronouns.

div2.p: Noteworthy is the occasional use, in familiar language, of the article with the personal and the reflexive pronoun.
ge/lwta . . . to\n e)me\ e)n toi=s lo/gois a)pe/deice, PLATO, Theaet. 166A; He made a laughingstock of poor me in the debate.

PLATO, Lys. 203B: deu=ro dh/, h)= d' o(/s, eu)qu\ h(mw=n . . . poi=, e)/fhn e)gw/, le/geis, kai\ para\ ti/nas tou\s u(ma=s (the you mentioned); Phaedr. 258 A: e)/doce/ pou/ fhsi th=| boulh=| . . ., kai\ o(\s ei)=pe, to
 au(to
 dh\ le/gwn ma/la semnw=s . . . o( suggrafeu/s. Phileb. 14 D: tou\s e)me/. 20 B: to
 e)me/. 59 B-C: to
 me
 dh\ se\ kai\ e)me\ kai\ *gorgi/an kai\ *fi/lhbon xrh\ suxna\ xai/rein e)a=n. PLAT. Soph. 239B: to
 me
 toi/nun e)me/ g' e)/ti ti/s a)
 le/goi; Theaet. 166 A (see above).

COM. Men. 4.210: nu=n de\ kata\ po/lin | eu(/rhke to
 e(/teron, to
 se/, to
 e)me\ toutoni/.
The article with substantive and adjective interrogatives is found chiefly in dramatic poetry and in dialogue. So we sometimes colloquially say “the what?”
*s*w. diomologhsw/meqa kai\ to/de. *p*r*w. to\ poi=on; PLATO, Phileb. 11D; Let us agree with one another on this also. On what?

DEM.18.64: a)lla\ nu=n e)/gwge to
 ma/list' e)pitimw=nta toi=s pepragme/nois h(de/ws a)
 e)roi/mhn, th=s poi/as meri/dos gene/sqai th
 po/lin h)bou/let' a)/n.

PLATO, Euthyph. 12D: dei= . . . e)ceurei=n to\ poi=on me/ros a)\n ei)/h tou= dikai/ou to\ o(/sion. Lach. 193 E: to\ poi=on dh\ tou=to; Phaedo 78 B: dei= . . . e)re/sqai . . . tw=| poi/w| tini\ . . . kai\ u(pe\r tou= poi/ou tino\s . . . kai\ tw=| poi/w| tini\ ou)/. Phaedr. 277 A: ta\ poi=a; 279 A: to\ poi=on dh/; Phileb. 11 D (see above). Rpb. 475 E: to\ poi=on; 550 C: th\n poi/an kata/stasin;
XEN. Oec. 10.1: kai\ a)/lla toi/nun, e)/fh . . ., qe/lw soi . . . megalo/frona au)th=s dihgh/sasqai . . . ta\ poi=a; e)/fhn e)gw/.

p.hi: Article with toiou=tos and the like.

div2.p: toiou=tos, toio/sde, thlikou=tos, thliko/sde, tosou=tos, toso/sde, are treated like ordinary adjectives, and, like them, may be used substantively with the article, or adjectively in the attributive position, but tosou=tos and toso/sde in either use are rare.

bebouleume/nws o( toiou=tos u(bri/zwn e)sti\n h)/dh fanero/s, DEM.21.41; It is plain on the face of it that a man like that is guilty of deliberate outrage. pw=s a)\n ou)=n o( toiou=tos a)nh\r diafqei/roi tou\s ne/ous; XEN. Mem. 1.2.8; How could any man of that character debauch the youth? oi( thlikou=toi (i.e. oi( e)/fhboi), Cyr. 1.2.11.

ORATORES ATTICI. — Instances of the article with toiou=tos are very numerous and references need not be given. The words thliko/sde and toso/sde seem not to occur and toio/sde is rare. tosou=tos, though exceedingly common, has furnished no satisfactory instance of the articular use treated in this section.

DEM.18.305: Blass on the best textual authority reads tou/twn (not tw=n) tosou/twn kai\ toiou/twn a)gaqw=n u(mi=n . . . e)/xontes xa/rin. 19.222: e)k tw=n i)di/wn tosou/twn xrhma/twn is not a good example as tosou/twn is a predicate adjective occupying the attributive position (as e.g. au(=tai in ai( me\n tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn au(=tai nh=es, THUC.8.80.3). 23.135 (= 145): ta\ thlikau=t(a). 24.17: peri\ tw=n . . . no/mwn, kaq' ou(/s ei)sin ai( toiai/de grafai/.
AESCHIN.1.76: ta\ thlikau=ta e)pita/gmata. 3.77: ou(=tos . . . o( thlikou=tos to\ me/geqos ko/lac. 141.

ISOC.12.55: kaq' e(/kaston me\n ou)=n diecie/nai peri\ tw=n toiou/twn kai\ tosou/twn to\ plh=qos a)no/hto/n e)stin (tw=n need not be understood with tosou/twn). 117: th=| po/lei, th=| thlikau/th| me\n to\ me/geqos, toiau/thn d' e)xou/sh| do/can.

PLATO, Apol. 25E: w(/ste tou=to to\ tosou=ton kako
 e(kw
 poiw=. AX.370C: th
 tw=n thlikw=nde peri/noian. Conv. 179 A: oi( toiou=toi. Crat. 426 E: e)n toi=s toioi=sde r(h/masin, oi(=on kte(. 427 A: pa/nta ta\ toiau=ta. Euthyd. 277 E: e)pi\ tw=| toiw=|de o(/tan kte(. Gorg. 476 B: to\ toio/nde. Legg. 667 D: h( i)so/ths . . . tou= te tosou/tou kai\ tou= toiou/tou (i.e. quantitatis et qualitatis). 670 D: toi=s thlikou/tois. 672 B: to\ de\ toso/nde oi)=da o(/ti kte(. 755 B: th
 thlikau/t hn a)rxh/n. Phaedr. 261 E: to\ toiou=ton. Phileb. 46 A: tw=n toiw=nde noshma/twn. Rpb. 430 B: th
 . . . toiau/thn du/namin. PLAT. Soph. 236B: ta\ thlikau=ta. Theaet. 167 E: e)n tw=| toiou/tw| o(/tan kte(.

XEN. Cyr. 1.2.11: oi( thlikou=toi (see above). 6.19: o( toiou=tos. 3.3.35: e)n tw=| toiw=|de. Hell. 5.4.13: toi=s thlikou/tois (masc.). Mem. 1.2.8: o( toiou=tos a)nh/r (see above). R. L. 3.2 (= 4.7): toi=s thlikou/tois.
THUC.1.141.4: oi( toiou=toi. 2.42.2: ai( tw=nde kai\ tw=n toiw=nde a)retai/. 3.42.4: e)n tw=| toiw=|de. 6.9.2: o( toiou=tos. 16.2: ta\ toiau=ta. 17.4: to\n toiou=ton o(/milon.
AR. Nub. 812: ta\ toiau=q' . Pax, 1280: ta\ toiauti/. Eccl. 1009: toi=s thlikou/tois. 1010: tai=s . . . thlikau/tais.

SOPH. Ai. 330: oi( toioi/de . Ant.726
oi( thlikoi/de kai\ didaco/mesqa dh\
fronei=n u(p' a)ndro\s thlikou=de th\n fu/sin
. O. C. 1116: tai=s thlikai=sde smikro\s e)carkei= lo/gos . 1208: ta\ toiau=ta . O. R. 674: ai( de\ toiau=tai fu/seis . 895: ai( toiai/de pra/ceis .
AESCHYL. Ag. 1619-20: dida/skesqai baru\ | tw=| thlikou/tw|.
PIND. O. 9.40: mh\ nu=n lala/gei ta\ toiau=t(a).
For toiou=tos, toio/sde, etc. in predicate position, see 627 sqq. The anarthrous use is very common and requires no array of examples.
o( e(/teros, the other, is specific or indefinite (the one of two or of any two); e(/teros in prose is indefinite only.

a)pe/qane de\ kai\ o( e(/teros strathgo\s *proklh=s, THUC.3.98.5; Procles, one of the two generals, was killed also. *pleistoa/nac o( e(/teros basileu\s . . . e)boh/qhse, THUC.5.75.1; Pleistoanax, the other king, started off with reinforcements. e(te/ras po/lews poli/ths, ANTIPHON, 5.78; A citizen of another city. kai\ to
 e)/teron o( e)/teros ou)de
 h(gei=tai ei)de/nai, PLATO, Theaet. 180C; And (the) one thinks the other (indefinite series) knows nothing. xwlo\s d' e(/teron (= to
 e(/teron) po/da, HOM. Il. 2.217; He was lame of one foot.
DEM.23.103: toi=s . . . tw=n e(te/rwn (the other) basile/wn strathgoi=s.
AESCHIN.3.40: ei) toi/nun . . . h)=san du/o kei/menoi no/moi . . ., a)nh/|rht' a)\n o( e(/teros (one of the two) tw=n no/mwn.
ANTIPHON, 5.23: metece/bhmen ei)s to\ e(/teron (the other) ploi=on. 42: o( e(/teros (the other) a)/nqrwpos.
PLATO, Legg. 695B: paralabo/ntes d' ou)=n oi( pai=des . . . prw=ton me\n to\n e(/teron a(/teros a)pe/kteine kte(.

THUC.3.89.3: du/o new=n a)neilkusme/nwn th\n e(te/ran (one of the two) kate/acen. 98.5 (see 587). 5.75.1 (see 587). 7.41.3: du/o de\ nh=es tw=n *surakosi/wn . . . diefqa/rhsan, kai\ h( e(te/ra (one of them) au)toi=s a)ndra/sin e(a/lw.

HDT.1.38: ei(=s ga/r moi mou=nos tugxa/neis e)w
 pai=s: to
 ga dh\ e(/teron diefqarme/non th
 a)koh
 ou)k ei)=nai/ moi logi/zomai.
AR. Nub. 244: a)lla/ me di/dacon to\n e(/teron toi=n soi=n lo/goin .
EUR. Phoen. 951-2: toi=nd' e(lou= duoi=n po/tmoin to\n e(/teron .
SOPH. El. 739-40: h)laune/thn, to/t' a)/llos, a)/lloq' a(/teros | ka/ra proba/llwn i(ppikw=n o)xhma/twn. O.C. 497: sfw=|n d' a(te/ra molou=sa praca/tw ta/de .
AESCHYL. Ag. 343-4: nosti/mou swthri/as | ka/myai diau/lou qa/teron kw=lon pa/lin. P. V. 778: duoi=n lo/goin se qate/rw| dwrh/somai . 867: duoi=n de\ qa/teron boulh/setai .
SOLON, 27.3: tou\s d' e(te/rous o(/te dh\ tele/sh| qeo\s e(/pt' e)niautou/s.
ARCHIL.93: th=| me\n u(/dwr e)fo/rei | dolofrone/ousa xeiri/, th)te/rh| de\ pu=r..

HOM. Od. 5.265-6: e)n de/ oi( a)sko
 e)/qhke qea\ me/lanos oi)/noio | to
 e(/teron, e(/teron d' u(/datos me/gan. 22.183-4: th=| e(te/rh| me
 xeiri\ fe/rwn kalh
 trufa/leian, | th=| d' e(te/rh| sa/kos eu)ru/.

Il. 9.218-9: au)to\s d' a)nti/on i(=zen *)odussh=os qei/oio | toi/xou tou= e(te/roio. 14.272-3: xeiri\ de\ th=| e(te/rh| me\n . . . | th=| d' e(te/rh|. 21.71-2: th=| e(te/rh| me\n . . . | th=| d' e(te/rh|.

PLATO, Protag. 359A: pe/nte o)/ntwn mori/wn th=s a)reth=s ou)de
 e)/fh ei)=nai to\ e(/teron oi(=on to\ e(/teron. Theaet. 180 B-C: ou)de\ gi/gnetai tw=n toiou/twn e(/teros e(te/rou maqhth/s, a)ll' au)to/matoi a)nafu/ontai . . . kai\ to
 e(/t eron o( e(/teros ou)de
 h(gei=tai ei)de/nai.

XEN. An. 5.4.31: a)nabow/ntwn de\ a)llh/lwn sunh/kouon ei)s th
 e(te/ran e)k th=s e(te/ras po/lews. 6.1.5-6: kai\ h(/llonto u(yhla/ te kai\ kou/fws . . . telos de\ o( e(/teros to
 e(/teron pai/ei . . . o(\ d' e)/pese texnikw=s pws . . . kai\ o(\ me
 skuleu/sas ta\ o(/pla tou= e(te/rou e)ch/|ei . . . a)/lloi de\ tw=n *qra|kw=n to
 e(/teron e)ce/feron w(s teqnhko/ta. Hell. 2.2.3: kai\ oi)mwgh\ . . . ei)s a)/stu dih=ken, o( e(/teros tw=| e(te/rw| paragge/llwn.

HDT.1.32: h( e(te/rh au)te/wn th=| e(te/rh| h(me/rh| . . . ou)de
 o(/moion prosa/gei prh=gma. 134: h)
 de\ h)=| ou(/teros u(podee/steros o)li/gw|, ta\s pareia\s file/ontai: h)
 de\ pollw=| h)=| ou(/ teros a)genn|e/steros, prospi/ptwn proskune/ei to
 e(/teron.

DEM.3.18: e(/teros le/gei tis belti/w; 18.201: e(/teroi xwri\s h(mw=n. 219: *)aristofw=n *ke/falos *qrasu/boulos, e(/teroi muri/oi. 19.265: e(/teros de/ tis h(=ken e)/xwn pro/bata. 21.139: kai\ pro\s tou/tois e(/teroi. [33]DEM., 30: o(po/te d' di( me\n e)c a)rxh=s sunqh=kai h)fani/sqhsan, . . . e(/terai de\ mh\ e)gra/fhsan.
PLATO, Legg. 920E: te/xnaisin e(te/rais. Phaedr. 233 D: e)c e(te/rwn e)pithdeuma/twn. Elsew.
XEN. An. 1.4.2: h(gei=to d' au)tai=s *tamw\s . . . e)/xwn nau=s e(te/ras *ku/rou pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosin.
THUC.1.26.3: pleu/santes eu)qu\s pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosi nausi\ kai\ u(/steron e(te/rw| sto/lw|.
HDT.3.100: e(te/rwn de/ e)sti *)indw=n o(/de a)/llos tro/pos.
AR. Ach. 135: e(/teros a)lazw/n. Eq. 134: e(/teros a)nh/r. Vesp. 150: w(s e(/teros ou)dei\s a)nh/r.

EUR. Heracl. 362: po/lin e)lqw\n e(te/ran. H. F. 912: ma/ntin ou)x e(/teron a)/comai. Med. 652-3: ei)/domen, ou)k e)c e(te/rwn | mu=qon e)/xw fra/sasqai. Or. 345-6: ti/na . . . oi)=kon a)/llon e(/teron; Suppl. 573: pollou\s e)/tlhn dh\ xa)te/rous a)/llous po/nous.

SOPH. Ant. 569: a)rw/simoi ga/r ei)si xa)te/rwn gu/ai . O. C. 1192: ei)si\ xa)te/rois gonai\ kakai/ . Tr. 459-60: ou)xi\ xa)te/ras | plei/stas . . . e)/ghme dh/; 835: pw=s o(/d' a)\n a)e/lion e(/teron h)\ tanu=n i)/doi;
AESCHYL. Ag. 147: speudome/na qusi/an e(te/ran. Cho. 403-4: a)/thn | e(te/ran e)pa/gousan e)p' a)/th|. Eum. 176-7: e(/teron . . . | mia/stor(a).

PIND. O. 7.86-7: ou)x e(/teron liqi/na | ya=fos e)/xei lo/gon. P. 2.89: to/t' au)=q' e(te/rois e)/dwken me/ga ku=dos. 4.248: polloi=si d: a(/ghmai sofi/as e(te/rois. N. 8.37: xruso\n eu)/xontai, pedi/on d' e(/teroi.
HOM. Od. 9.299-302: to\n me\n e)gw\ bou/leusa . . . ou)ta/menai pro\s sth=qos . . . e(/teros de/ me qumo\s e)/ruken.

THUC. (after ou)de/, mhde/). 2.67.4: kai\ tou\s meta\ *)aqhnai/wn cumpolemou=ntas kai\ tou\s mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn. 72.1: e)/ste mhde\ meq) e(te/rwn, de/xesqe de\ a)mfote/rous fi/lous, e)pi\ pole/mw| de\ mhd' e(te/rous. 3.64.3. 5.48.1. 6.44.3: oi(\ de\ ou)de\ meq) e(te/rwn e)/fasan e)/sesqai. Elsew.

HES. O. et D. 434: ei)/ x' e(/teron (sc. a)/rotron) a)/cais, e(/tero/n k' e)pi\ bousi\ ba/loio. Theog. 762-4: tw=n (sc. *(/upnou kai\ *qana/tou) e(/teros me\n . . . mei/lixos a)nqrw/poisi, | tou= de\ sidhre/h me\n kradi/h.
HOM. Od. 3.440-1: xe/rniba de/ sf' *)/arhtos . . . | h)/luqen . . . fe/rwn, e(te/rh| d' e)/xen ou)la/s. 5.265-6 (588).
Il. 2.217: folko\s e)/hn, xwlo\s d' e(/teron po/da (587).
e(/teros e(/teron, like a)/llos a)/llon (598), denotes a successive shift of both subject and object. The same relation holds with the other cases.
muri/on me/ntoi (sc. e)gw/ fhmi) diafe/rein e)/teron e(te/rou, PLATO, Theaet. 166D; But I maintain that there is an infinite difference between any two (of us).
ISOC.19.24: ou(/tws au)to\n e)qera/peusa, w(s ou)k oi)=d' o(/stis pw/poq) e(/teros e(/teron.
PLATO, Theaet. 166D (see above). 171 D: to\ ei)=nai sofw/teron e(/teron e(te/rou. 180 B: ou)de\ gi/gnetai tw=n toiou/twn e(/teros e(te/rou maqhth/s.

THUC.2.51.1: w(s e(ka/stw| e)tu/gxane/ ti diafero/ntws e(te/rw| pro\s e(/teron gigno/menon. 4: e(/teros a)f' e(te/rou qerapei/a| a)napimpla/menoi w(/sper ta\ pro/bata e)/qnh|skon. 7.64.2: ei)/ ti/s ti e(/teros e(te/rou profe/rei h)\ e)pisth/mh| h)\ eu)yuxi/a|.

EUR. Alc. 893-4: sumfora\ d' e(te/rous e(te/ra | pie/zei fanei=sa qnatw=n. Bacch. 905-6:
e(/tera d' e(/teros e(/teron
o)/lbw| kai\ duna/mei parh=lqen
. Elsewhere.
SOPH. O. C. 230-2: a)pa/ta d' a)pa/tais e(te/rais e(te/ra paraballome/na .
BACCHYL. fr. 5 (Bl.): e(/teros e)c e(te/rou sofo\s to/ te pa/lai to/ te nu=n.
HES. O. et D. [189]: e(/teros d' e(te/rou po/lin e)calapa/cei.

p.hi: o( e(/teros (e(/teros) in a bad sense.

div2.p: o( e(/teros (e(/teros) is sometimes used in the sense of bad, hostile. Familiar is the phrase ple/on qa/teron poiei=n, to make bad worse. Cf. the English “to laugh on the other side of the mouth.”
DEM.22.12: o(/sa pw/pote th=| po/lei ge/gon' h)\ nu=n e)/st' a)ga/q' h)\ qa/tera. (Cf. LYS. 12.48: a)gaqou= me\n ou)deno\s mete/sxen, a)/llwn de\ pollw=n.)
ISOC.19.25: a)ll' ou)d' e)piskeyo/menos a)fi/keto (sc. ou)dei\s tw=n suggenw=n) plh\n th=s mhtro\s kai\ th=s a)delfh=s, ai(\ ple/on qa/teron e)poi/hsan.

PLATO, Euthyd. 280E: ple/on ga/r pou, oi)=mai, qa/tero/n e)stin, e)a/n tis xrh=tai o(tw|ou=n mh\ o)rqw=s pra/gmati h)\ e)a\n e)a=|. Phaedo 114 E: w(s a)llotri/ous te o)/ntas (sc. tou\s ko/smous) kai\ ple/on qa/teron h(ghsa/menos a)perga/zesqai.
SOPH. Ph. 501-3: ei)sorw=n | w(s pa/nta deina\ ka)pikindu/nws brotoi=s | kei=tai, paqei=n me\n eu)=, paqei=n de\ qa/tera.

PIND. P. 3.34-5: dai/mwn d' e(/teros | e)s kako
 tre/yais e)dama/ssato/ nin. Cf. N. 8.3: to
 me
 a(me/rois a)na/gkas xersi\ basta/zeis, e(/teron d' e(te/rais.
a)/llos means another (a different one); o( a)/llos, the other, the rest. So oi( a)/lloi.

sunhkolou/qhsan de\ . . . kai\ tw=n a)/llwn stratiwtw=n w(s diako/sioi, XEN. An. 2.5.30; There followed also of the other soldiers about two hundred. sunhkolou/qoun de\ kai\ a)/lloi *persw=n . . . ei)s triakosi/ous, XEN. An. 2.5.35; There followed also other (s of the) Persians to the number of three hundred. h)=san de\ kai\ a)/llai kw=mai pollai\ . . . e)n tou/tw| tw=| pedi/w|, XEN. An. 3.5.1; There were also many other villages in the plain.
a)/llos:
XEN. An. 2.5.35 (594). 3.5.1 (594). 7.1.37: kai\ a)/lfita fe/rontes ei(/ponto au)tw=| ei)/kosin a)/ndres kai\ oi)=non a)/lloi ei)/kosi.
THUC.1.67.4: a)/lloi . . . e)gklh/mata e)poiou=nto. 8.86.5: a)/llos . . . ou)dei\s a)\n i(kano\s e)ge/neto katasxei=n to\n o)/xlon.
AR. Av. 808: ou)x u(p' a)/llwn, a)lla\ toi=s au(tw=n pteroi=s .
EUR. fr. 170.1: ou)k e)/sti *peiqou=s i(ero\n a)/llo plh\n lo/gos.
HOM. Od. 2.139: e)/cite/ moi mega/rwn, a)/llas d' a)legu/nete dai=tas.
Il. 6.187: tw=| d' a)/r' a)nerxome/nw| pukino\n do/lon a)/llon u(/fainen .
o( a)/llos:
DEM. [58]DEM., 14: du/o me\n toi/nun ou(=toi no/moi ei)si\n ou(\s parabe/bhken o( tou\s a)/llous parano/mwn grafo/menos.
PLATO , Phaedo 86 C: ai( a)/llai a(rmoni/ai ai(/ t' e)n toi=s fqo/ggois kte(.
XEN. An. 2.5.30 (594). 3.4.49: oi( d' a)/lloi stratiw=tai pai/ousi . . . to\n *swthri/dan.
THUC.5.29.2: a)posta/ntwn de\ tw=n *mantine/wn kai\ h( a)/llh *pelopo/nnhsos e)s qrou=n kaqi/stato.
EUR. Hel. 304-5: ai( me\n ga\r a)/llai dia\ to\ ka/llos eu)tuxei=s | gunai=kes.
HOM. Od. 1.156-7: au)ta\r *thle/maxos prose/fh glaukw=pin *)aqh/nhn, | a)/gxi sxw\n kefalh/n, i(/na mh\ peuqoi/aq' oi( a)/lloi.

quote.l: to/n r(' *(/ektwr kale/eske *skama/ndrion, au)ta\r oi( a)/lloi

div2.p: a)/llos is often used in Homer as o( a)/llos. Cf. the Latin alii for ceteri.
a)/lloi me/n r(a qeoi\ . . . | eu(=don pannu/xioi, *di/a d' ou)k e)/xen h(/dumos u(/pnos, HOM. Il. 2.1-2; The other gods slept all night long, but in sweet sleep's embrace Zeus was not held.

HOM. Od. 3.333-4: o)/fra *poseida/wni kai\ a)/llois a)qana/toisin | spei/santes koi/toio medw/meqa. 4.472: *dii/ t' a)/lloisi/n te qeoi=sin. 10.284-5: ou)de\ se/ fhmi | au)to\n nosth/sein, mene/eis de\ su/ g' e)/nqa per a)/lloi.

Il. 1.17: *)atrei+/dai te kai\ a)/lloi e)uknh/mides *)axaioi/. 397-9: e)/fhsqa . . . *kroni/wni | oi)/h . . . loigo\n a)mu=nai, | o(ppo/te min cundh=sai *)olu/mpioi h)/qelon a)/lloi. 2.1-2 (see above). 211-2: a)/lloi me/n r(' e(/zonto . . . | *qersi/ths d' e)/ti mou=nos . . . e)kolw/|a. 3.298: *zeu= ku/diste me/giste kai\ a)qa/natoi qeoi\ a)/lloi.
a)/llos a)/llon denotes a successive shift of both subject and object. The same relation holds with the other cases and with adverbial forms.

paralamba/nwn a)/llos a)/llon e)p' a)/llon . . . xrei/a|, PLATO, Rpb. 369C; Different persons taking different helpers for different needs. metadi/dwsi dh\ a)/llos a)/llw|, Ibid.; They share with one another. eu)qu\s po/rrwqen h)spa/zonto a)/llos a)/lloqen, Charm. 153 B; They forthwith greeted (me) at a distance from one place and another.

PLATO, Apol. 37D: kalo\s ou)=n a)/n moi o( bi/os ei)/h . . . a)/llhn e)c a)/llhs po/lin po/lews a)meibome/nw| kai\ e)celaunome/nw| zh=n. Charm. 153 B: a)/llos a)/lloqen (see above). C: h)rw/twn de\ a)/llos a)/llo. Conv. 220 C: kai\ qauma/zontes a)/llos a)/llw| e)/legen. Rpb. 369 C: a)/llos a)/llon e)p' a)/llou . . . xrei/a| . . . a)/llos a)/llw| (see above).
XEN. An. 1.6.11: h)/|kazon de\ a)/lloi a)/llws. 2.1.15: ou(=toi . . . a)/llos a)/lla le/gei. 4.8.19: oi( de\ pole/mioi . . . ou)ke/ti e)/sthsan, a)lla\ fugh=| a)/llos a)/llh| e)tra/peto.

THUC.1.16: e)pege/neto . . . a)/llois . . . a)/lloqi kwlu/mata. 2.4.4: a)/lloi de\ a)/llh| . . . a)pw/llunto. 7.71.6: o( me\n nautiko\s strato/s, a)/llos a)/llh| . . . katenexqe/ntes. 8.86.4: gnw/mas a)/lloi a)/llas e)/legon. Elsew.
AR. Av. 1374: pe/tomai d' o(do\n a)/llot' e)p' a)/llan mele/wn (parody).
EUR. Hipp. 104: a)/lloisin a)/llos qew=n te ka)nqrw/pwn me/lei. Ph. 1248-9: parecio/ntes d' a)/llos a)/lloqen fi/lwn | lo/goisi qarsu/nontes e)chu/dwn ta/de.
SOPH. Ai. 58: a)/llot' a)/llon e)mpi/tnwn strathlatw=n . El. 582: ei) ga\r ktenou=men a)/llon a)nt' a)/llou. 728-9: ka)nteu=qen a)/llos a)/llon e)c e(no\s kakou= | e)/qraue.

AESCHYL. Ag. 595-6: o)lolugmo\n a)/llos a)/lloqen kata\ pto/lin | e)/laskon eu)fhmou=ntes. P. V. 276: pro\s a)/llot' a)/llon phmonh\ prosiza/nei . Sept. 1070-1: kai\ po/lis a)/llws | a)/llot' e)painei= ta\ di/kaia.
BACCHYL. 21.13 pa/ntessi qnatoi=si dai/mwn e)pe/tace po/nous a)/lloisin a)/llous.

PIND. O. 1.116: e)p' a)/lloisi d' a)/lloi mega/loi. 7.11: a)/llote d' a)/llon e)popteu/ei *xa/ris. 8.12-13: a)/lla d' e)p' a)/llon e)/ban | a)gaqw=n. P. 2.13-4: a)/llois de/tis e)te/lessen a)/llos a)nh\r | eu)axe/a basileu=sin u(/mnon. Elsew.

HOM. II. 2.75: u(mei=s d' a)/lloqen a)/llos e)rhtu/ein e)pe/essin. 9.311: w(s mh/ moi tru/zhte parh/menoi a)/lloqen a)/llos. 11.486: *trw=es de\ die/tresan a)/lludis a)/llos. 13.279: tou= me\n ga/r te kakou= tre/petai xrw\s a)/lludis a)/llh|.

p.hi: a)/llos and e(/teros with appositive force.

div2.p: Both a)/llos and (more rarely) e(/teros have an appositive force, which the corresponding words lack in English. The rendering is generally “too,” “besides,” but sometimes the translation of the contrast would be too cumbrous.

ou) ga\r h)=n xo/rtos ou)de\ a(/llo ou)de\n de/ndron, XEN. An. 1.5.5; There was no grass nor any tree besides. h(gei=to d' au)tai=s (= the Lacedaemonian ships) *tamw\s . . . e)/xwn nau=s e(te/ras *ku/rou pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosin (with twenty-five additional ships that belonged to Cyrus, not twenty-five others of Cyrus's), XEN. An. 1.4.2.

ISOC.4.26-7: eu(rh/somen ga au)th
 ou) mo/non tw=n pro\s to
 po/lemon a)lla\ kai\ th=s a)/llhs kataskeuh=s e)n h(=| katoikou=men . . . sxedo
 a(pa/shs ai)ti/an ou)=san. 5.148: kai\ ga e)kei/nwn ma=llon a)/gantai th
 h(=ttan th
 e)n *qermopu/lais h)\ ta\s a)/llas ni/kas. 6.16. 10.66.

PLATO, Gorg. 473D: eu)daimonizo/menos u(po\ tw=n politw=n kai\ tw=n a)/llwn ce/nwn. Phaedo 110 E: a(\ kai\ li/qois kai\ gh=| kai\ toi=s a)/llois zw/|ois te kai\ futoi=s ai)/sxh te kai\ no/sous pare/xei.

XEN. An. 1.4.2 (see above). 1.5.5 (see above). 5.2.31-2: kai\ oi( me\n a)/lloi *krh=tes . . . o( *muso\s de/ (who is described § 29 as a)nh\r *muso\s kai\ tou)/noma tou=to e)/xwn). 7.3.48: sunhli/sqhsan a)nsra/poda me\n w(s xi/lia, bo/es de\ disxi/lioi, pro/bata a)/lla mu/ria. Cyr. 1.6.2. 38. 6.3.11. Elsew.

THUC.2.14.1: pai=das kai\ gunai=kas kai\ th
 a)/llhn kataskeuh
 h(=| kat' oi)=kon e)xrw=nto. 4.67.2: oi( de\ meta\ tou= *dhmosqe/nous . . . *plataih=s te yiloi\ kai\ e(/teroi peri/poloi e)nh/dreusan e)s to\ *)enua/lion. 5.75.3: e)/s te malaki/an . . . kai\ e)s th
 a)/llhn a)bouli/an te kai\ braduth=ta.

HDT.1.216: e)pea
 de\ ge/rwn ge/nhtai ka/rta oi( prosh/kontes . . . qu/ousi/ min kai\ a)/lla pro/bata a(/ma au)tw=|. 3.88: ga/mous te tou\s prw/tous e)ga/mee . . . o( *darei=os, *ku/rou me
 du/o qugate/ras . . . e(te/rhn de\ *sme/rdios tou= *ku/rou qugate/ra e)/ghme . . . e)/sxe de\ kai\ th
 tou= *)ota/new qugate/ra.
AR. Eccl. 848-9: *ge/rwn de\ xwrei= . . . kaxa/zwn meq' e(te/rou neani/ou.

SOPH. O. R. 6-7: a(gw\ dikaiw=n mh\ par' a)lle/lwn, te/kna, | a)/llwn a)kou/ein au)to\s w(=d' e)lh/luqa. Ph. 38-9: kai\ tau=ta/ g' a)/lla qa/lpetai | r(a/kh, “And here are some rags withal, drying in the sun.” — Jebb.

HOM. Od. 1.132-4: pa\r d' au)to\s klismo\n qe/to poiki/lon e)/ktoqen a)/llwn | mnhsth/rwn, mh\ cei=nos a)nihqei\s o)rumagdw=| | dei/pnw| a(dh/seien. 6.84: a(/ma th=| ge (sc. *nausika/a|) kai\ a)mfi/poloi ki/on a)/llai.
Il. 2.191: a)ll' au)to/s (i.e. basileu/s or e)/coxos a)nh/r v. 188) te ka/qhso kai\ a)/llous i(/drue laou/s.

oi( polloi/ means the masses, oi( o)li/goi, the few, the aristocracy, to\ polu/, the mass (opposed to the remnant), to\ ple/on, the majority (opposed to the minority), to\ plei=ston, the greatest number (opposed to individuals).

oi( me
 ou)=n polloi\ *makedo/nwn pw=s e)/xousi *fili/ppw|, e)k tou/twn a)/n tis ske/yait' ou) xalepw=s, DEM.2.17. oi( polloi\ kri/nousi ta\s h(dona\s ei)s to\ zh=n h(mi=n eu)= krati/stas ei)=nai, PLATO, Phileb. 67B. tw=n . . . polemi/wn to\ me
 polu\ e)/menen . . ., me/ros d' au)tw=n a)ph/nta toi=s kata\ ta\ a)/kra, XEN. An. 4.6.24. mh\ toi=s me
 o)li/gois h( ai)ti/a prosteqh=|, to
 de\ dh=mon a)polu/shte, THUC.3.39.6. a)pope/mpei de\ kai\ th=s stratia=s to\ ple/on, THUC.3.35.2. tou= . . . i(ppikou= to\ plei=stou au)toi\ *)odru/sai parei/xonto kai\ met' au)tou\s *ge/tai, THUC.2.98.4. kai\ oi( me
 plei=stoi e)ce/fugon . . . o(/sous de\ e)/labe kathko/ntisen a)feidw=s *seu/qhs, XEN. Hell. 7.4.6.

p.hi: oi( polloi/, o)li/goi with demonstrative use of the article.

div2.p: Of course the demonstrative (resumptive) force is not excluded.
to\ . . . prw=ton au)toi=s tou\s o)li/gous i(ppe/as e)/pemyan, THUC.6.88.1; At first they sent them the poor handful of cavalry (above mentioned).
DEM.9.59: kai\ ti/ dei= ta\ polla\ le/gein; And why is it necessary to talk this lot of stuff? (ta\ polla/ contemptuous.)
PLATO, Phaedr. 270A: w(=n dh\ pe/ri to\n polu\n lo/gon (that interminable preachment) e)poiei=to *)anacago/ras.

THUC.1.86.1: tou\s me\n lo/gous tou\s pollou\s tw=n *)aqhnai/wn ou) gignw/skw. 2.51.5: kai\ ta\s o)lofu/rseis tw=n a)pogignome/nwn teleutw=ntes kai\ oi( oi)kei=oi e)ce/kamnon u(po\ tou= pollou= kakou= nikw/menoi. 6.88.1 (see above).

div2.head: Position of the article.
div2.p: The article always precedes in prose. In Homer the article, accompanied by a relative clause, rarely follows in the sense of the reduplicated article ou(=tos.

p.hi: Repetition and non-repetition of the article.

div2.p: The article may be common to a number of copulated substantives, even when they are of different genders or numbers, or it may be repeated with each member. Theoretically the repetition compels a separate consideration while the omission suggests unity. Practically the Greeks were almost as loose as we are prone to be, and a sharp difference cannot be made.See A. J. P. vi (1885), 486.
Thecretically then:

oi( . . . strathgoi\ kai\ oi( loxagoi/, XEN. An. 3.5.14, the generals and the captains (as different classes of officers), but oi( strathgoi\ kai\ loxagoi/ (cf. ibid. 1.7.2), the generals and captains (officers as distinguished from the privates).
Practically:
to\ o(/moion kai\ to\ a)no/moion kai\ to\ tau)to\n kai\ e(/teron, PLATO, Theaet. 186A; The like and the unlike and the identical and different. oi( au)toi\ o(/rkoi kai\ cummaxi/a, THUC.1.102.4.

p.hi: Article with appositions of personal pronouns.

div2.p: Appositions with the personal pronoun take the article, even when the pronoun is involved in the verb. Omission occurs in poetry, rarely in prose. Compare also 13.

div2.head: The Article in the Combination of Article, Adjective, and Substantive
div2.p: In the combination of article, adjective, and substantive five positions are to be noticed. Three of these are attributive and two predicative.

There are three attributive positions. The first, o( a)gaqo\s a)nh/r, is the most simple, natural, and straightforward, and is briefer (su/ntomos) than the second, o( a)nh\r o( a)gaqo/s, which is more deliberate, and somewhat more rhetorical, pompous (o)gkw/dhs), passionate.ARISTOT. Rhet. 3.6 (1407 b, 26-37). The examples given are th=s h(mete/ras gunaiko/s for suntomi/a and th=s gunaiko\s th=s h(mete/ras for o)/gkos. Cf. A. J. P. xx (1899), 459. The third position, a)nh\r o( a)gaqo/s, is the epanorthotic, self-corrective, or slipshod position. In prose, it produces an effect of familiar ease. In poetry, as the substantive is more frequently anarthrous, the difference between a)nh\r o( a)gaqo/s and o( a)nh\r o( a)gaqo/s cannot be insisted on.A. J. P. xxiii (1902), 8.

oi( a)/grioi oi)=es kai\ oi( o)/noi oi( a)/grioi a)sinei=s ei)sin, XEN. Cyr. 1.4.7; The wild sheep and the wild asses are harmless. oi)kh/sete de\ ta\s au)ta\s oi)ki/as kai\ xw/ran th\n au)th\n e)rga/sesqe kai\ gunaici\ tai=s au)tai=s sunoikh/sete, XEN. Cyr. 4.4.10; You will inhabit the same houses and till the same land and live with the same wives (as for land, you will till the same, as for wives, you will live with the same).

ORATORES ATTICI. In the case of the adjective possessive pronoun, according to statistics furnished by Dr. Alfred W. Milden, the first attributive position occurs 1102 times, the second 543 times, and the third only 10 times. It will thus be seen that the second position, on an average, occurs only half as often as the first, and that the third position is very rare. In ANDOCIDES the second position preponderates, and in PS.- DEM.49 it is used to the exclusion of the other two. The third position is limited to ANTIPHON (thrice), LYSIAS (4 times), HYPERIDES (once), AESCHINES (once), and DEMOSTHENES (once). The percentages for the three positions are as follows: DIN. (only 28 instances) 82 / 18 / 0; LYCURG. (only 12 instances) 92 / 8 / 0; HYP. 53/ 42 / 5; DEM. 77/ 23 / 0;As a matter of fact, there is one occurrence of the third position out of a total of 373 occurrences for the three positions. PS.- DEM. 55/ 45 / 0; AESCHIN. 68/ 31 / 1; ISAE. 72 / 28 / 0; ISOC. 63/ 37 / 0; LYS. 71/ 27 / 1; ANDOC. 41/ 59 / 0; ANTIPHON 55 / 41 / 5. The two extremes, not counting DINARCHUS and LYCURGUS, are ANDOCIDES with only 41% of the first position and DEMOSTHENES with 77%.

XEN. An. With adjectives, the first position occurs 113 times, the second position 13 times (Joost, p. 68), the third position 6 times (ibid. p. 72). With possessives, the first position occurs 31 times, the second position 4 times (l.c. p. 69), the third position once (l.c. p. 72).
THUCYDIDES. With possessives, according to Dr. A. W. Milden, the first position occurs 102 times in the speeches, the second position 3 times, and the third position 11 times.

HERODOTUS. According to Heikel,I. A. Heikel, De participiorum apud Herodotum usu, Helsingforsiae, 1884, p. 49 the first position occurs 98 times in the first book of HERODOTUS, the second position 15 times, the third position 12 times.
ARISTOPHANES. The first position is more common than the second, the third is comparatively rare.
EURIPIDES. In the Alcestis the first position predominates, the third is not uncommon, the second very rare.
SOPHOCLES. In the Oedipus Tyrannus the first position is by far the most common, the second is rare, the third is not uncommon.
AESCHYLUS. The second position is very rare, the first and third positions correspond with the use of EURIPIDES and SOPHOCLES.
HOMER. The first position is common enough. The second position, according to Krüger, is wanting. The third position, though not uncommon with other adjectives, is rare with the possessive pronoun.

PIND. O. 5.10-11: a)/lsos a(gno\n | to\teo/n.
THEOGN. 635: a)ndra/si toi=s a)gaqoi=s.
HOM. Od. 7.326: h)/mati tw=| au)tw=|. 12.252: i)xqu/si toi=s o)li/goisi. 14.61: a)/naktes oi( ne/oi. 23.90: toi/xou tou= e(te/rou.
Il. 6.201: pedi/on to\ *)alh/ion . 8.360: path\r ou(mo/s. 9.219: toi/xou tou= e(te/roio. 11.288: a)nh\r w)/ristos. 13.794: h)oi= th=| prote/rh|.

There are a very few examples of the attributive use of the type o( a)nh\r a)gaqo/s. Here the adjective is appositive rather than predicative. In the Homeric examples, some consider the article as still a demonstrative.
EUR. Hipp. 683-4: *zeu/s s' o( (so the Mss.; Wolff se) gennh/twr e)mo\s1 | pro/rrizon e)ktri/yeien.

SOPH. Ai. 571-2:
kai\ ta)ma\ teu/xh mh/t' a)gwna/rxai tine\s
qh/sous' *)axaioi=s mh/q' o( (so Mss.; Schaefer mh/te) lumew\n e)mo/s
.Both seem to be afterthoughts, both represent the objective genitive. There is a proud appropriation of gennh/twr, an agonized appropriation of lumew/n, as if mine, yes, mine.

HOM. Od. 9.378: o( moxlo\s e)la/i:nos (cf. 375: to\n moxlo/n), of olive (and green olive to boot 379). 464: ta\ mh=la, tanau/poda, pi/ona dhmw=|. 11.492: tou= (my) paido/s, a)gauou=. 17.10: to\n cei=non, du/sthnon, the stranger, ill bestead that he is.
Il. 1.340: pro\s tou= basilh=os, a)phne/os. 2.275: to\n lwbhth=ra, e)pesbo/lon. 21.317: ta\ teu/xea, kala/, fine though they be.
The attributive position is the only one of which the adverb is capable when combined directly with an articular substantive.

tai=s ... o)/ntws mai/ais, PLATO, Theaet. 150A; Real midwives. th=s a)melei/as tau/ths th=s a)/gan, DEM.4.17; This carelessness, this over (carelessness). de/ous kai\ taraxh=s th=s to/te, LYS.[6] 35; The terror and unrest then prevailing.
LYCURG.134: tw=n pw/pote. prodotw=n.
DEM.4.17(see above). 23.196: toi=s w(s a)lhqw=s eu)erge/tais.
ISOC.6.28: tou\s w(s a)lhqw=s *messhni/ous. 62: peri\ tw=n e)/cwqen bohqeiw=n.
LYS. [2]6: dia\ th\n e)nqa/de sumfora/n. 26: th/n t' e)nqa/de a)/ficin tw=n barba/own. [6]LYS., 35(see above).

PLATO, Apol. 40C: tou= to/pou tou= e)nqe/nde. Legg. 727 D: tou\s qeou\s tou\s e)kei=. Phaedo 61 E: peri\ th=s a)podhmi/as th=s e)kei=. 117 C: th\n metoi/khsin th\n e)nqe/nde e)kei=se. Polit. 270 E: e)n tw=| to/te xro/nw|. Protag. 343 C: e)n toi=s to/te a)nqrw/pois. Theaet. 150 A (see above).
XEN. An. 2.2.11: e(ptakai/deka ga\r staqmw=n tw=n e)gguta/tw. 3.2.30: dei= ... tou\s a)/rxontas e)pimeleste/rous gene/sqai tou\s nu=n tw=n pro/sqen. Hell. 2.1.9: th\n li/an u(/brin tou/tou.
THUC.3.9.1: cummaxi/an th\n pri/n. 4.77.2: to\ cummaxiko\n to\ e)kei/nh|.
HDT.1.95: *)assuri/wn a)rxo/ntwn th=s a)/nw *)asi/hs. 142: ta\ a)/nw ... xwri/a. 8.8: tw=n to/te a)nqrw/pwn.
AR. Nub. 869: kai\ tw=n kremastrw=n ou) tri/bwn tw=n e)nqa/de . Pax, 607: to\n au)toda\c tro/pon (43). Av. 1533: para\ tou= *dio\s kai\ tw=n *triballw=n tw=n a)/nw .
EUR. Alc. 13: a(/|dhn to\n parauti/k(a). 243: to\n e)/peita xro/non. 309-10: te/knois | toi=s pro/sq(e). Andr. 979: tu/xais tai=s oi)/koqen.
SOPH. O. T. 271-2: tw=| po/tmw| | tw=| nu=n. 515-6: e)n tai=s cumforai=s | tai=s nu=n. 667-8: kakoi=s ... toi=s pa/lai.
AESCHYL. P.V. 404: qeoi=s toi=s pa/ros.

PIND. O. 5.1-2: stefa/nwn ... tw=n *)olumpi/a|. N. 9.15: kre/sswn de\ kappau/ei di/kan ta
 pro/sqen a)nh/r. I. 2.1: oi( me
 pa/lai ... fw=tes. fr. 129.1: ta

HOM. Il. 9.558-9: ka/rtistos e)pixqoni/wn ge/net' a)ndrw=n | tw=n to/te.
For other examples of the first position see 491.

p.hi: Difference between attributive adverb and adjective.

div2.p: The difference between the attributive adverb and the attributive adjective is the difference between the participial element that the adverb requires, and the adjective.

h( pro/teron o)ligarxi/a = h( pro/teron ou)=sa o)ligarxi/a, the oligarchy which formerly existed. h( prote/ra o)ligarxi/a, cf. LYS.12.65, the former of the two oligarchies. h( pro/teron gunh/, the one who was formerly wife (now dead, divorced, or what not). h( prote/ra gunh/, first wife, former wife of two.
DIN.1.69: tou\s pro/teron pole/mous (now at peace) kalw=s diw/|khsas ... kata\ th\n prote/ran ei)sfora/n (another pending).

DEM.2.7: tou\s me\n pro/teron summa/xous. 18.108: kata\ tou\s prote/rous no/mous. 19.84: h( pro/teron boh/qei(a). 163: th\n prote/ran ... presbei/an. 333: e)pi\ th=s u(ste/ras presbei/as. 24.122: kata\ tou\s no/mous tou\s prote/rous.
LYS.12.65: th=s prote/ras o)ligarxi/as ai)tiw/tatos e)ge/neto. 25.9: th\n prote/ran o)ligarxi/an. 19: e)n th=| prote/ra| dhmokrati/a|.
ANTIPHON, 5.37: oi( u(/steroi lo/goi ... tw=n u(ste/rwn lo/gwn ... tou\s de\ prote/rous lo/gous. 42: toi=s me\n prw/tois kai\ toi=s u(/steron lo/gois.
PLATO, Charm. 165A: ta\ u(/steron gra/mmata. Menex. 240 E: ta\s u(ste/ras ma/xas. Rpb. 547 D: th\n prote/ran politei/an. 620 A: kata\ sunh/qeian ga\r tou= prote/rou bi/ou ta\ polla\ ai(rei=sqai.
XEN. An. 7.8.22: kai\ ou(/tw ta\ pro/tera i(era\ a)pe/bh. Hell. 1.2.8: a)po\ tw=n prote/rwn ei)/kosi new=n kai\ a)po\ e(te/rwn pe/nte.
THUC.1.32.5: th=| pro/teron a)pragmosu/nh| e)nanti/a tolmw=men. 3.41: e)n th=| prote/ra| e)kklhsi/a|. 6.6.2: tou= prote/rou pole/mou. 7.43.3: h( prote/ra stratia/, the first of the two armies.
HDT.1.84: o( pro/teron basileu/s. 6.87: tw=n pro/teron a)dikhma/twn. 7.2: e)k th=s prote/rhs gunaiko/s.

AR. Eq. 43: th=| prote/ra| noumhni/a|. 535: dia\ ta\s prote/ras ni/kas. 1355: tai=s pro/teron a(marti/ais. Vesp. 558: dia\ th\n prote/ran a)po/fucin. Ran. 691: ta\s pro/teron a(marti/as. Eccl. 609: toi=si no/mois diexrw/meqa toi=s prote/roisin. 985: e)pi\ th=s prote/ras a)rxh=s.
HOM. Il. 13.794: h)oi= th=| prote/rh| (612).
Like the adverb, prepositional phrases are found in the three attributive positions.

 pro\ *ku/mas. 10.62: tuxw/n ken a(rpale/an sxe/qoi fronti/da ta

The nearer the participle is to an adjective, the more readily does it take the normal attributive position of the adjective.

div2.p: When one or more modifiers are employed, the participle or the modifier may be put outside of the complex.

div2.head: Predicative position of article, substantive, and adjective.
div2.p: When adjective and substantive are associated without the article, it is a mere matter of inference whether the adjective is attributive or predicative. nau=s e)/rhmos may be ‘an empty ship’ or ‘a ship when empty.’ In Il. 4.124: kuklotere\s me/ga to/con e)/teinen, He bent the great bow into a round, kuklotere/s is predicate, me/ga is attribute. At this stage, then, the Greek language presents the same state of things that is familiar to us in Latin.

But when the substantive was used with the article and the adjective without it, inasmuch as the articular substantive represented the old notion and the adjective the new, a predicative relation was set up.Cf. THEON , Progymn. in RHET. GR., II, 83 (Sp.): prosqe/sei a)/rqrwn ou)ke/ti a)mfi/bolos gi/netai h( le/cis: ei)si\ de\ *ai)gu/ptioi oi( *kolxoi/: dh=lon ga\r ge/gonen o(/ti peri\ *kolxw=n le/gei w(/s ei)sin *ai)gu/ptioi. As this position is used only in a few combinations in English, it is often necessary to translate by a relative clause or an abstract noun and often the translation costs more than it comes to.

ou)/toi ta\ xrh/mat' i)/dia ke/kthntai brotoi/, EUR. Phoen. 555; The property that mortals hold is not their own. o(/sa sumbebou/leuka ... a)p' ... a)diafqo/rou th=s yuxh=s (sc. sumbebou/leuka), DEM.18.298; All that I have counselled, I have counselled in the innocency of my heart. tou\s de\ taxei=an th\n a)poxw/rhsin poihsame/nous, LYCURG.96; Those that took their departure quickly, made quick work of their departure. lampra=| th=| fwnh=|, DEM.19.199; With his voice ringing clear, with ringing voice. mega/lh| th=| fwnh=|, DEM.57.11; At the top of his voice, with loud voice.

The popular use of the predicative position seems never to have gone far beyond the more simple combinations, and outside of these it is found most frequently in authors who are given to making points and so becomes a gnomon of artificial style.A. J. P. xvii (1896), 518. See also Milden, The Limitations of the Predicative Position in Greek, Baltimore, 1900, especially p. 43.

thlikau/thn a)poxrh=n oi)=mai th\n du/namin, DEM.4.22; I think that the force (proposed) is sufficient (though) so small. kai\ ga\r th=| le/cei poihtikwte/ra| kai\ poikilwte/ra| ta\s pra/ceis dhlou=si, ISOC.15.47; For the language in which they set forth their themes has a leaning toward the poetical and ornate. a)napeptame/nais au)to\n e)de/xonto tai=s pu/lais, Ibid. 126; They received him with gates wide open.

a)=r' a)/qlion tou)/neidos, w)= ta/las e)gw/
w)nei/dis' e)s se\ ka)me\ kai\ to\ pa=n ge/nos
; O. T. 525-6: tou= pro\s d' e)fa/nqh ... o(/ti | ... o( ma/ntis tou\s lo/gous yeudei=s le/goi;
HIPPONAX, 26: a)kh/raton. de\ th\n a)parti/hn e)/xei.
HOM. Il. 5.715: h)= r(' a(/lion to\n mu=qon u(pe/sthmen *menela/w|. Cf. 6.185: karti/sthn dh\ th/n ge ma/xhn fa/to du/menai a)ndrw=n.

p.hi: Predicative position in phrases that have to do with the person.

div2.p: In determining the stylistic effect of any given instance of the predicative adjective with an articular noun, it must be borne in mind that the predicative use was fostered by the employment of the article as a possessive, and many of the most familiar turns consist of phrases that have to do with the person, such as mega/lh| th=| fwnh=|.
lampra=| th=| fwnh=|, DEM.19.199; With his voice ringing clear, with ringing voice (627). mega/lh| th=| fwnh=|, DEM.57.11; At the top of his voice, with loud voice (627).
DIN.1.67: ti/nas ta\s e)lpi/das e(/comen;
LYCURG.40: dipla= qai)ma/ti) e)mpeporphme/nous.

DEM.1.7: bebai/an ei)ko\s th
 e)/xqran au)tou\s e)/xein. 11: mega/lhn e)/xei th=| tu/xh| th
 xa/rin. 2.1: th
 u(pe tou= pole/mou gnw/mhn toiau/thn e)/xontas. 18.298: a)p' o)rqh=s kai\ dikai/as ka)diafqo/rou th=s yuxh=s (627). 19.199 (see above). 57.11 (see above).
AESCHIN.2.7: i)/sh| th=| eu)noi/a| a)kou/ontas.
ISAE. 6.59: e)a\n ... h(mi=n de\ loidorh/shtai mega/lh| th=| fwnh=|.
ISOC.8.103: th\n fu/sin o(moi/an e)/xei tai=s e(tai/rais. 10.23: ou) ga\r mo/non toi=s o(/plois e)kosmh/santo paraplhsi/ois a)lla\ kai\ toi=s e)pithdeu/masin e)xrh/santo toi=s au)toi=s.
LYS. [2]LYS., 18: e)l euqe/rais tai=s yuxai=s e)politeu/onto.
ANTIPHON, 5.33: meta\ xrhsth=s th=s e)lpi/dos.

PLATO, Conv. 190B: ta\ fronh/mata mega/la ei)=xon. Legg. 880 A: a)mune/sqw kata\ fu/sin a)/neu be/lous yilai=s tai=s xersi/n. Theaet. 144 D: i(/na ka)gw\ e)mauto\n a)naske/ywmai, poi=o/n ti e)/xw to\ pro/swpon. 168 B: i(/lew| th=| dianoi/a|.

XEN. Cyr. 3.3.31: au)/rion e)ci/asi polu\ e)rrwmeneste/rais tai=s gnw/mais. 58: oi(\ de\ qeosebw=s pa/ntes suneph/xhsan mega/lh| th=| fwnh=|. Hell. 3.4.11: ma/la faidrw=| tw=| prosw/pw|, but SOPH. El. 1297: faidrw=| prosw/pw|.

THUC.1.6.1: cunh/qh th
 di/aitan. 3: a)neime/nh| th=| diai/th|. 70.6: toi=s me
 sw/masin a)llotriwta/tois ... xrw=ntai, th=| de\ gnw/mh| oi)keiota/th|. 120.5: o(moi/a| th=| pi/stei. 3.38.1: a)mblute/ra| th=| o)rgh=|. 82.2: a)mei/nous ta\s gnw/mas e)/xousi. 6.68.2: mega/lhn th
 e)lpi/da th=s ni/khs e)/xein. 8.45.2: i(/na au)tw=n mh\ oi( nau=tai ... ta\ sw/mata xei/rw e)/xwsi.

COM. Men. 4.341.56: a)/lupon a)/ceis to
 bi/on xwri\s ga/mou. Philetaer.3.293: w(s takero/n, w)= *zeu=, kai\ malako
 to\ ble/mm' e)/xei. Pherecr.2.281.3: chra
 e)/xousa th

AR. Ach. 120: toio/nde d', w)= pi/qhke, to
 pw/gwn' e)/xwn. Eq. 205: a)gku/lais tai=s xersi
 a(rpa/zwn fe/rei. 280-1: kenh=| th=| koili/a| | e)sdramw
 e)s to\ prutanei=on, ei)=ta pa/lin e)kqei= ple/a|. 1170: w(s me/gan a)/r' ei)=xes, w)= po/tnia, to
 da/ktulon. Nub. 229-30: th
 fronti/da lepth
 katamei/cas ei)s to
 o(/moion a)e/ra . Vesp. 554: e)mba/llei moi th
 xei=r' a(palh/n. Lys. 88: kalo/n g' e)/xousa to\ pedi/on . 1116: kai\ mh\ xaleph=| th=| xeiri\ mhd' au)qadikh=| . Thesm. 583: e(/ws a)
 ou(/tws ta\s gna/qous yila\s e)/xh|s. Pl. 1018: kai\ ta/s ge xei=ras pagka/las e)/xein m' e)/fh. 1022: to\ ble/mma q' w(s e)/xoimi malako
 kai\ kalo/n.
EUR. Cycl. 126: gluku/tata/ fasi ta\ kre/a tou\s ce/nous forei=n. fr. 271: pthna\s diw/keis, w)= te/knon, ta\s e)lpi/das.
SOPH. O. T. 1512-4: nu=n de\ tou=t' eu)/xesqe/ moi, | ... tou= bi/ou de\ lw/|onos | u(ma=s kurh=sai tou= futeu/santos patro/s. Tr. 1252-3: ka)pi\ toi=sde th\n xa/rin | taxei=an, w)= pai=, pro/sqes.
SAPPHO, 72: a)ba/khn ta\n fre/n' e)/xw.
ARCHIL.91: toih/nde d', w)= pi/qhke, th\n pugh\n e)/xwn.
Especially worthy of note is the use of the predicative position in combination with prepositions, a construction which adds to the advantages of the genitive absolute that of greater exactness.

ei)s e(/rhmon th\n xw/ran, LYS. [2], 49 ; Into the country, stripped of its defenders. a)p' . . . a)diafqo/rou th=s yuxh=s, DEM.18.298; In the innocency of my heart. meta\ a)kraifnou=s th=s cummaxi/as, THUC.1.19; With the alliance in its integrity.
DIN.1.37: par' e(ko/ntwn kai\ boulome/nwn tw=n *(ellh/nwn.

Cf. 4.51: e)p' a)dh/lois ou)=si toi=s . . . genhsome/nois. 18.205: e)n douleuou/sh| th=| po/lei. 258: meta\ pollh=s th=s e)ndei/as according to L and some editors; meta\ pollh=s e)ndei/as Blass. 298: a)p' o)rqh=s kai\ dikai/as ka)diafqo/rou th=s yuxh=s (627 and above). 19.120: pro\s [dia]memet rhme/nhn th\n h(me/ran. 21.30: e)p' a)dh/lois me\n toi=s a)dikh/sousin, a)dh/lois de\ toi=s a)dikhsome/nois. 24.76: e)n dhmokratoume/nh| th=| po/lei. 25.99: w(s e)pi\ kuri/ous tou\s no/mous. [35], 22: w(s e)p) e)leuqe/rois toi=s xrh/masi. 36.8: a)po\ koinw=n tw=n xrhma/twn . . . e)k koinw=n tw=n. xrhma/twn. 39: e)k koinw=n . . . tw=n xrhma/twn. 38.28: par' e(ko/ntwn e)/labon tw=n e)pitro/pwn.
AESCHIN.2.126: e)n diamemetrhme/nh| th=| h(me/ra|. 3.58: par' e(ko/ntwn tw=n *(ellh/nwn. 255: mh\ ou)=n w(s u(pe\r a)llotri/as, a)ll' w(s u(pe\r oi)kei/as th=s po/lews bouleu/esqe.

ISOC. [1]ISOC., 34: w(s peri\ a)llotri/ou tou= pra/gmatos. 7.17: par' e(ko/ntwn tw=n *(ellh/nwn. 8.12: w(/sper e)n a)llotri/a| th=| po/lei. 14.40: e)c a)teixi/stou me\n th=s po/lews. Ep. 6.9: pote/ras (sc. xrh\) tw=n timw=n a)gaph=sai, ta\s par' e(ko/ntwn gignome/nas h)\ ta\s par' a)kontwn tw=n politw=n.
LYS. [2]LYS., 49(see above). 12.97: oi(\ me\n e)n polemi/a| th=| patri/di tou\s pai=das katalipo/ntes, oi(\ d' e)n ce/nh| gh=|.
ANDOC.1.88: o(po/sai e)n dhmokratoume/nh| th=| po/lei e)ge/nonto.
ANTIPHON, 5.33: meta\ xrhsth=s th=s e)lpi/dos (629).

PLATO, Apol. 20E: ei)s a)cio/xrewn u(mi=n to\n le/gonta a)noi/sw. Protag. 357 A: e)n o)rqh=| th=| ai(re/sei. Rpb. 515 E: ei) de\ . . . e)nteu=qen e(/lkoi tis au)to\n bi/a| dia\ traxei/as th=s a)naba/sews kai\ a)na/ntous.

XEN. An. 1.3.14: h(gemo/na ai)tei=n *ku=ron o(/stis dia\ fili/as th=s xw/ras a)pa/cei. 5.4.2: e)rwtw=ntes po/teron w(s dia\ fili/as h)\ dia\ polemi/as poreu/sontai th=s xw/ras. Hell. 3.2.9: dia\ fili/as th=s *qra/|khs poreuqei\s . . . a)fiknei=tai ei)s *xerro/nhson.

THUC.1.19(see above). 36.1: pro\s i)sxu/ontas tou\s e)xqrou/s. 74.3: a)po/ te oi)koume/nwn tw=n po/lewn. 84.4: a)ei\ de\ w(s pro\s eu)= bouleuome/nous tou\s e)nanti/ous e)/rgw| paraskeuazw/meqa. 3.43.4: u(peu/qunon th

 kala\ ta\ proeirgasme/na kai\ u(pe kalw=n tw=n mello/ntwn o( a)gw

a)/gria ga\r h(ma=s, w)= gunai=kes, dra=| kaka/
a(/t' e)n a)gri/oisi toi=s laxa/nois au)to\s trafei/s
.

SOPH. Ant. 556: e)p' a)rrh/tois ge toi=s e)moi=s lo/gois.

div2.head: Predicative positions.
div2.p: The first position in which the predicative adjective precedes the articular noun is more common than the second position in which the adjective follows.
These passages are cited in sections 628 and 629.
DIN.1.67, Lycurg.40,Lycurg., 67 Lycurg., 96 Lycurg., 145.
ISAE. 6.59
ISOC.2.7(twice)ISOC., 6.1 ISOC., 45 ISOC., 8.47 ISOC., 104 ISOC., 9.54 ISOC., 15.126.
ANTIPHON, 3 g 6. 5.12 (twice). 38.
PLATO, Apol. 31C. Legg. 880 A, Rpb. 406 Theaet.144D, 168
COM. Men. 4.341.56, Philetaer.3.293, Theop. 2.818.7. Pherecr.2.281.3.
HIPPONAX, 26.
SAPPHO, 72.
In addition to the above references must be added the examples of the prepositional type cited under 630, which, with a single exception (EUR. Phoen. 526), are of the first position.
PLATO, Conv. 190B.
EUR. Cycl. 680. Phoen. 555.

The predicative position is the most common position of the participle. Instances of this position in which the participle is the equivalent of an adjective, have been cited under the preceding sections. Other examples will be given later under the head of Predicative Attribution, the Participle, the Compound Sentence, and the Abridged Sentence. For the predicative position of the attributive participle, see 622 and 623.

p.hi: Seeming attributive or predicative position of kalou/menos, o)nomazo/menos, w)/n, and the like.

div2.p: The articular copulative participle is regularly attracted into the gender and number of the predicate (cf. 124.127 f., 492), and the resulting positions merely simulate attribution or predication.

h( o)nomazome/nh a)ndrei/a, PLATO , Phaedo, 68 C; What is called bravery. e)pi\ th\n gaste/ra nu=n kaloume/nhn, PLATO, Conv. 190E; To what is now called the belly. peri\ ta\s h(dona\s kaloume/nas, PLATO , Phaedo, 64 D; About what are called (so-called) pleasures.
DEM. [26]DEM., 27: e)pei\ kai\ . . . ta\s kaloume/nas w(/ras no/mos kai\. ta/cis . . . dioikei=n fai/netai.
AESCHIN.2.31: tw=n kaloume/nwn *)enne/a o(dw=n. 40: to\ kalou/menon paipa/lhma. 3.122: h(/kein . . . pro\s to\ *qutei=on e)kei= kalou/menon.

ISOC.8.7: ou(/tw ga\r . . . pro\s ta\s dokou/sas ei)=nai pleoneci/as a)plh/stws e)/xomen, w(/st(e) kte(. 94: r(a/|dio/n e)sti katamaqei=n . . . th\n kaloume/nhn me\n a)rxh/n, ou)=san de\ sumfora/n, o(/ti pe/fuke xei/rous a(/pantas poiei=n tou\s xrwme/nous au)th=|.

PLATO, Conv. 190E (see above). Legg. 720 B: qei/hs a)
 tau=ta du/o ge/nh tw=n kaloume/nwn i)atrw=n; PHAEDO, 64 D (see above). 68 C (see above). 86 D: e)n tw=| kaloume/nw| qana/tw|. Phaedr. 243 B: kai\ poih/sas dh\ pa=san th
 kaloume/nhn palinw|di/an paraxrh=ma a)ne/bleyen. Rpb. 404 D: ou)kou=n kai\ *)attikw=n pemma/twn (sc. ye/geis) ta\s dokou/sas ei)=nai eu)paqei/as; 473 C-D: e)a
 mh\ . . . h)\ oi( filo/sofoi ba/sileu/swsin e)n tai=s po/lesin h)\ oi( basilh=s te nu=n lego/menoi kai\ duna/stai filosofh/swsi . . . ou)k e)/sti kakw=n pau=la.

XEN. An. 6.1.7: w)rxou=nto th\n karpai/an kaloume/nhn e)n toi=s o(/plois. 7.1.33: e)/legen o(/ti e(/toimos ei)/h h(gei=sqai au)toi=s ei)s to\ *de/lta kalou/menon th=s *qra/|khs. 5.1: ei)s to\ *de/lta kalou/menon. Mem. 1.1.11: skopw=n o(/pws o( kalou/menos u(po\ tw=n sofistw=n ko/smos e)/fu.

THUC.1.2.1: h( nu=n *(ella\s kaloume/nh. 3: h(/ te nu=n *qessali/a kaloume/nh kai\ *boiwti/a. 32.4: kai\ perie/sthken h( dokou=sa h(mw=n pro/teron swfrosu/nh . . . nu=n a)bouli/a kai\ a)sqe/neia fainome/nh. 2.19.2: peri\ tou\s *rei/tous kaloume/nous. . . . e)s *)axarna/s, xw=ron me/giston th=s *)attikh=s tw=n dh/mwn kaloume/nwn. 8.48.6: tou/s te kalou\s ka)gaqou\s o)nomazome/nous.
HDT.6.61: to\ d' e)sti\ e)n th=| *qera/pnh| kaleome/nh|.
COM. Men. 4.249: h( nu=n u(po/ tinwn xrhsto/ths kaloume/nh.
EUR. Andr. 75-6: o( de\ keklhme/nos | path\r e)/t' e)n *delfoi=si tugxa/nei me/nwn.

p.hi: me/sos, a)/kros, and the like in predicative position.

div2.p: Adjectives of position when used partitively regularly precede the articular substantive. For the anarthrous use, see 507.

(h( sth/lh) kata\ me/shn th\n nh=son e)/keito, PLATO, Criti. 119C; The pillar was situated in the middle of the island. o)/nuxas . . . e)p' a)/krois toi=s kw/lois e)/fusan, Tim. 76 E; They formed, at the extremities of the limbs, nails. sth/sas to\ a(/rma pro\ th=s fa/laggos me/shs, XEN. An. 1.2.17; Halting his chariot before the phalanx, the middle of it. But to\ me/son sti=fos, XEN. An. 1.8.13; The central mass of men, not the centre of the mass of men. o( me/sos (da/ktulos), PLATO, Rpb. 523C; The middle finger, not the middle of the finger.
DIN.1.24: po/lis a)stugei/twn . . . e)k me/shs th=s *(ella/dos a)nh/rpastai.
LYCURG.17: kata\ me/shn th\n a)kth\n dia\ th=s puli/dos e)celqw/n.
HYPER. c. Athen. col. 6.20: e)n me/sh| th=| a)gora=|.
DEM.19.127: ei)s me/sas ta\s *qh/bas kai\ to\ tw=n *qhbai/wn strato/pedon. 29.12: e)n th=| a)gora=| me/sh| pollw=n paro/ntwn.
ISOC.5.90: e)n me/sois geno/menon toi=s polemi/ois a)poqanei=n (sc. o(mologei=tai).

PLATO, Conv. 190E: kata\ me/shn th
 gaste/ra. Critias, 119C (see above). Lach. 183 E: a)/krou tou= stu/rakos. Phaedo 108 E: e)n me/sw| tw=| ou)ranw=|. 109 C: e)n me/sw| tw=| puqme/ni tou= pela/gous. E: diecelqei=n e)p' e)/sxaton to
 a)e/ra. Protag. 352 A: i)dw
 to\ pro/swpon kai\ ta\s xei=ras a)/kras. Tim. 75 C-D: ta\ de\ neu=ra . . . o( qeo\s e)p' e)sxa/thn th
 kefalh
 . . . e)ko/llhsen . . . kai\ ta\s siago/nas a)/kras au)toi=s cune/dhsen. Tim. 76 E (see above).

XEN. Ag. 9.4: e)n me/sais tai=s eu)frosu/nais. An. 1.2.7: dia\ me/sou de\ tou= paradei/sou. 17 (see above). 2.1.11: e)/xwn e)n me/sh| th=| e(autou= xw/ra|. Cyn. 3.4: a)/kra| de\ th=| ou)ra=| sei/ousin. 4.8: e)pi\ de\ tai=s mhriai/ais a)/krais. 5.10: e)p' a)/krous de\ tou\s po/das. 6.7: ei)s me/son to\n kekru/falon. Cyr. 7.1.34: e)n a)/krais tai=s xersi/. 8.8.17: peri\ a)/krais tai=s xersi/. R. Eq. 6.9: ei)s a)/kron to\ sto/ma.

THUC.2.83.3: kata\ me/son to\n porqmo/n. 91.3: th=| *leukadi/a| (sc. nhi\) diwkou/sh| e)mba/llei me/sh|. 3.107.4: ou(=toi de\ e)n tw=| eu)wnu/mw| ma=llon kai\ ou) to\ ke/ras a)/kron e)/xontes a(qro/oi h)=san, a)ll) *eu)ru/loxos e)/sxaton ei)=xe to\ eu)w/numon kai\ oi( met' au)tou=. 4.96.1: me/xri . . . me/sou tou= stratope/dou. 5.9.6: kata\ me/son to\ stra/teuma. 6.97.5: e)p' a)/krois toi=s krhmnoi=s tw=n *)epipolw=n. 101.2: dia\ me/sou tou= e(/lous.

HDT.2.40: ske/lea de\ a)pota/mnousi kai\ th
 o)sfu
 a)/krhn. 4.49: *ki/os potamo\s me/son sxi/zwn to
 *ai(=mon e)kdidoi= e)s au)to/n (sc. to
 *)/istron). 181: e)k me/sou tou= a(lo/s. 5.101: dia\ me/shs th=s a)gorh=s r(e/ei.

AR. Ach. 638: e)p' a)/krwn tw=n pugidi/wn e)ka/qhsqe. 1216. Lys.443-4:
ei) . . . th\n xei=r' a)/kran
tau/th| prosoi/seis
. Thesm. 239: th\n ke/rkon fula/ttou nun a)/kran.
EUR. Cycl. 159: ei)s a)/krous ge tou\s o)/nuxas a)fi/keto. 184: peri\ me/son to\n au)xe/na. 220: e)n me/sh| th=| gaste/ri. 671: mequ/wn kate/peses ei)s me/sous tou\s a)/nqrakas.
SOPH. fr. 689: me/son ei)s to\n au)xe/n' ei)saloi/mhn.
o(/los prefers the first predicative position with its decided emphasis. The second position is a manner of afterthought.

o(/lh . . . h( po/lis, DEM.21.80; (The) WHOLE (of) the city. oi( a)llo/trioi kai\ h( po/lis o(/lh, AESCHIN.1.28; The strangers and the CITY, the whole of it. tau/thn me\n th\n h(me/ran o(/lhn ei)rga/zonto th=| d' u(sterai/a| kte(., THUC.4.69.3; This day they worked the whole day long; but on the following day etc.

INSCRIPTIONES ATTICAE. The predicative position alone is found according to Msth.3 § 86.45. II, 465.10: e)n o(/lw| tw=| e)niautw=| (ante 100 a. Chr.). 467.39: di) o(/lou tou= e)niautou= (circ. 100 a. Chr.). 240, b, 9: o(/lhn th\n po/lin (307/6 a. Chr.). IV, 2.1054 b, 16: par' o(/lon to\n toi=xon (a. 350 a. Chr.).
DIN.1 ex. of 1st pred. pos.DIN., 1 ex. of 2d pred. pos. 1.22: o(/lh| th=| *(ella/di. 44: th=s d' *eu)boi/as o(/lhs.

LYCURG.3 exx. of 1st pred. pos. 7: u(pe o(/lhs th=s patri/dos. 40: kaq' o(/lhn th
 po/lin (th
 add. Suid. , Sch.). 59: h(gou=mai . . . toutoni\ . . . o(/lhn e)/kdoton poih=sai th
 po/lin.
HYPERIDES. No example.

DEMOSTHENES. In the Demosthenean corpus are found 50 exx. of the 1st pred. pos. and 9 exx. of the 2d pred. pos. 18.118: labw
 a)na/gnwqi to\ yh/fism' o(/lon to\ grafe/n moi. 21.80: o(/lh ga h( po/lis . . . th

642. pa=s, a(/pas, su/mpas (suna/pas). — The original difference between a(/pas and pa=s gradually faded and the avoidance of hiatus in artistic prose tended to prevent the employment of a(/pas after a vowel. On the other hand, after a consonant a dislike to pa=s began to manifest itself. kalw= d' e)nanti/on u(mw=n a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi tou\s qeou\s a(/pantas (so all MSS.) kai\ p a/sas, says Demosthenes, 18.141, though in the prooemium he had said toi=s qeoi=s eu)/xomai pa=si kai\ pa/sais. The extent of this discrimination according to position varies with various authors and various spheres. The extremes are found in the Pseudo-Xenophontean *)aqhnai/wn politei/a, which uses pa=s and a(/pas indifferently after vowels and consonants, and in Isocrates, who applies the rule with great rigor.

According to Diels, Gött. gel. Anz. 1894.297 ff., Isocrates uses pa=s 340 times, 287 times after a vowel, and 53 times after a consonant; a(/pas is used 528 times after a consonant and only 14 times after a vowel (12 times after peri/ and twice after pro/). The 53 exceptional cases of the use of pa=s after a consonant are due to other euphonic considerations, to the fixity of stereotyped expressions, such as e)k panto\s tro/pou, to faulty tradition, or to lack of revision. The Panegyricus presents no exception. For further details, see Diels, l.c.

Numerically pa=s, as a rule, far outweighs a(/pas; a(/pas is much more frequent than su/mpas, and suna/pas is rare. In Plato, according to computations based upon the tables of Walbe, Syntaxis Platonicae specimen, Bonn, 1888, pp. 4 sq., pa=s occurs 5714 times, a(/pas 834 times, cu/mpas 372 times, and cuna/pas 13 times. In Isocrates, however, a(/pas is much more common than pa=s (see above), and in Plato 's Sophistes and Politicus cu/mpas occurs more than twice as often as a(/pas (20: 8 and 45: 18).

pa=s, a(/pas, and su/mpas (suna/pas), like o(/los, are used with articular and with anarthrous substantives, and in predicative and attributive position. The first predicative position is by far the most common. Next in the order of frequency is the second predicative position. This is the favorite position of a(/pas in some authors, and the regular position in oi( a)/lloi pa/ntes and kindred forms. The attributive position comes last.
pa=s, a(/pas, su/mpas (suna/pas) in predicative position are generally used like the English all.

pa=s' h( boulh/, DIN.1.15; All the senate. pa=s' h( *(ella/s, Ibid. 31; All Greece. pa/ntes oi( poli=tai, AESCHIN.3.8; All the citizens.
e)k tou= bi/ou panto\s kai\ tw=n e)/rgwn tw=n tou= patro/s, Lys. 19.13 ; From my father's whole life and from his actions. a(/pas o( dh=mos, DEM.20.106; All the people. o( dh=mos a(/pas, 21.2; The people with one accord. cu/mpan de\ to\ o(plitiko\n . . . trisxi/lioi ma/lista, THUC.4.124.1; The aggregate (number of) the hoplite contingent was approximately three thousand. to\ d' o(plitiko\n cu/mpan h)qroi/sqh disxi/lioi ma/lista, THUC.5.6.5; The heavy-armed troops that were mustered amounted in the aggregate to about two thousand.

In the corpus of Isocrates there are about 116 instances of the 1st pos. and only about 6 exx. (not counting 13.19) of the 2d. 3.12: pa/nta to

LYS. There are about 54 instances of the 1st pred. pos. Of the 2d pos. there are only 4 exx., and one of these is not cogent.
There are about 16 instances (including one doubtful one) of the 1st pred. pos., and about 4 of the second (excluding 2 that occur in documents).
ANTIPHON. 10 exx. of the 1st pred. pos. and 6 (including one toi=s a)/llois pa=sin) of the 2d. Five of the latter are in the sixth speech.

PLATO. According to Walbe, l.c., pp. 13 and 31, Plato uses pa=s and forms 830 times in the 1st pos. (318 singulars), and 380 times (91 singulars) in the 2d pos. Specially to be noted is the expression pa=s o( bi/os, which in one form or another occurs about 27 times as compared with only three instances of the 2d pred. pos. pa=n tou)nanti/on is the regular formula; variations are rare. In conjunction with a)/llos, pa=s regularly follows; with toiou=tos it regularly precedes. ta)=lla pa/nta (72), oi( a)/lloi pa/ntes (16); but pa/nta ta)=lla (8), pa/ntes oi( a)/lloi (2). pa/nta ta\ toiau=ta (86), pa/ntes oi( toiou=toi (4); but ta\ toiau=ta pa/nta (20), oi( toiou=toi pa/ntes (2). See Walbe, p. 32.

XEN. In the Anabasis pa=s occurs 39 times in the 1st pos. (13 sing., 26 plur.), and 27 times in the 2d pos. (7 sing., 20 plur.), not including 5 instances of oi( a)/lloi pa/ntes. (Joost, l.c., pp. 78 f.)
Of the nominative singular and plural of all genders, there are 13 instances of the 1st pred. pos. and 8 instances of the 2d (excluding one oi( a)/lloi pa/ntes).

DEMOSTHENES: Of the singular of a(/pas there are in the Demosthenean corpus 33 exx. of the 1st pos and 23 exx. of the 2d. The latter exx. include articular proper names, 6 exx of the type to\n a)/llon a(/panta xro/non (9.22. [10], 51. 22.3. [42], 2. 57.47. 49), one tou=ton a(/panta to\n xro/non (19.57), and a group of three (38.7. 41.5. [49], 11), in which a(/pas, while agreeing with the substantive, is really a modifier of the predicate.
AESCHINES: 12 exx. of the first position, 15 of the second. These include sullh/bdhn a(/pantas (3.18) and 3 exx. of tou\s (d') a)/llous a(/pantas.

ISOCRATES: 230 exx. of first position excluding a(/pas with a)/llos; 55 exx. of the second position, including 9 exx. like 2.37: mh\ perii/dh|s th\n sautou= fu/sin a(/pasan a(/ma dialuqei=san, but excluding a(/pas with a)/llos. In combination with a)/llos, a(/pas is found 3 times in the type a(pa/ntwn tw=n a)/llwn, 35 times in the type toi=s a)/llois a(/pasin, 8 times as in tw=n a)/llwn e)/rgwn a(pa/ntwn and 3 times as in para\ toi=s a)/llois a(/pasin a)nqrw/pois.

LYSIAS: 39 exx of first position and 16 of second, not including a(/pas with a)/llos and 3 doubtful exx. In combination with a)/llos, a(/pas once precedes (31.8: a(/pasi toi=s a)/llois poli/tais) and 10 times follows, 7 times in the type tw=n a)/llwn a(pa/ntwn, 2 times as in 19.64: tw=n a)/llwn . . . a(pa/ntwn tw=n ei)rhme/nwn, and once as in 22.16: e)pi\ me\n toi=s a)/llois w)ni/ois a(/pasi.
ANDOCIDES: 6 exx. of first position and 6 of second, besides 1.56: tou\s a)/llous a(/pantas and 1.131: to\n a)/llon bi/on a(/panta.
ANTIPHON: 6 exx. of first position and 12 (excluding 3 in which a(/pas is used in conjunction with a)/llos) of second.

PLATO. According to Walbe, l.c., pp. 13 and 31, Plato uses a(/pas and forms 101 times in the first position (33 singulars), and 139 times in the second position (48 singulars). Like pa=s, a(/pas generally follows articular a)/llos but precedes articular toiou=tos. ta)=lla a(/panta (17), oi( a)/lloi a(/pantes (6), a(/panta ta\ a)/lla (1); but a(/panta ta\ toiau=ta (6), a(/pantes oi( toiou=toi (1), ta\ toiau=ta a(/panta (3). See Walbe, l.c., p. 32.
XENOPHON: According to Joost, l.c., pp. 78 f. there are 5 exx. of the first position of a(/pas (one plural) and 1 ex. (pl.) of the second position. In addition oi( a)/lloi a(/pantes occurs twice.

THUCYDIDES: 16 exx. of the first position (not incl. 8.43.2: a(/pasai d' h)/dh ou)=sai a(/ma e)n th=| *kni/dw| ai( tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn nh=es), and 24 exx. of the second position, not including two instances of oi( a)/lloi a(/pantes.

HERODOTUS: In the first two books there are about 4 exx. of the first position, and 6 of the second not including 2 exx. of the type oi( a)/lloi a(/pantes a)/nqrwpoi. 1.86. 166. 171. 191. 192. 194. 2.19. 42. 65. 82. 136. 151.

ARISTOPHANES: In about 20 instances examined, the second position is a little more frequent than the first. Ach. 205: tw=n o(doipo/rwn a(pa/ntwn. 577: a(/pasan h(mw=n th\n po/lin. 617: a(/pantes . . . oi( fi/loi. Eq. 170: ta\s nh/sous a(pa/sas.
EUR. fr. 712: a(/pasan h(mw=n th\n po/lin kakorroqei=. 893: to\ d' a)/kairon a(/pan.

SOPH. Ai. 132: a(/panta ta)nqrw/peia . 284: a(/pan . . . tou)/rgon . Tr. 1136: a(/pan to\ xrh=m(a). fr. 84: a(/pan to\ xrhsto/n. 776: a(/panta ta)ge/nhta (so Nauck; Valckenaer, ta)ge/nnhta). 1027: a(/panta ta)pi/geia kai\ meta/rsia.

AESCHYL. Ag. 553-4: ti/s de\ plh
 qew=n | a(/pant' a)ph/mwn to

 de\ ta)nagkai=on e)kfugei=n a(/pan.
PIND. O. 1.31: a(/panta teu/xei ta\ mei/lixa. O. 9.100: to\ de\ fua=| kra/tiston a(/pan.
HOM. Od. 19.372: ai( ku/nes ai(/de . . . a(/pasai. 22.446: ai( de\ gunai=kes a)olle/es h)=lqon a(/pasai.
Il. 14.273-4: a(/pantes | . . . oi( e)/nerqe qeoi/.
DIN. , LYCURG. , HYPER. No ex.
DEM.5.11: h(\n sumpa/shs e)gw\ th=s e)n a)nqrw/pois ou)/shs deino/thtos kai\ sofi/as o(rw= kratou=san. [10]DEM., 41.: sumpa/shs th=s po/lews.
No ex.
ISOC.9 times in first position as 9.65: su/mpasan th\n a)reth/n. Twice in second position, e.g. 4.83: th\n *(ella/da su/mpasan.
LYS. , ANDOC. , No ex.

PLATO. Plato uses cu/mpas and forms 71 times in the first position (42 singulars), and 35 times in the second position (14 singulars) (Walbe, l.c., pp. 13 and 31). With substantive a)/llos, cu/mpas is found in cu/mpantes oi( a)/lloi (3), cu/mpanta ta\ a)/lla (1), and ta)=lla cu/mpanta (3); with substantive toiou=tos, in cu/mpanta ta\ toiau=ta (2), and ta\ toiau=ta cu/mpanta (7) (Walbe, l.c., p. 32).
THUC. Of the 11 exx. recorded in Bétant, all but one are of the first position. 2.65.4: cu/mpasa h( po/lis. 100.2: cu/mpantes oi( a)/lloi basilh=s. 5.6.5 (644).
HDT.7.99: sunapa/shs th=s stratih=s . . . ne/as eu)docota/tas parei/xeto. 9.45: sunapa/shs th=s *(ella/dos.
AR. No ex.
SOPH. , AESCHYL. , TR. FR. No ex.
PIND. No ex.
No ex.
HOM. Il. 22.380: o(\s kaka\ po/ll' e)/rdesken, o(/s' ou) su/mpantes oi( a)/lloi. (No other ex.)
With a generic singular (almost invariably a participle or an adjective), pa=s (a(/pas) regularly means every.

pa=s . . . o( qe/menos th\n yh=fon, DEM.23.97; Every one that casts his vote. a(/panti tw=| boulome/nw|DEM., 21.45; To every one that desires. pa=s o( ponhro/s, 25.7; Every one that is bad. grafikh\ . . . kai\ pa=sa h( toiau/th dhmiourgi/a, PLATO, Rpb. 401A; Painting and every (other) such craft.

pa=s in attributive position means whole, whole number (amount) of. It is often used in an absolute sense, all that there is, are, as, for example, o( pa=s xro/nos, eternity; oi( pa/ntes a)/nqrwpoi, the whole of mankind.

ou)/te oi( e)xqroi\ ou)/te h( pa=sa po/lis, THUC.1.132.1; Neither (his) enemies nor the whole city. e(ch/konta me
 stadi/wn o( a(/pas peri/bolos, to\ d' e)n fulakh=| o)
 h(/misu tou/tou, 2.13.7; The entire wall measured sixty stadia, the part under guard, half this amount. ei(=s te e(/kastos kai\ h( cu/mpasa po/lis, 6.41.2; Each one individually and the city collectively. kai\ ga ou)de
 plei/wn o( pa=s xro/nos fai/netai ou(/tw dh\ ei)=nai h)\ mi/a nu/c, Plato , Plato Ap.40E; For in that case eternity appears to be no greater than a single night. mo/nos ou)=tos tw=n pa/ntwn a)nqrw/pwn, LYCURG.131; He alone of all men.

To the attributive use of pa=n, etc., belongs the use of oi( pa/ntes, to\ su/mpan, etc., with numbers. “In all” is often a convenient translation. The article is regularly omitted in Homer.

die/bhsan e)s th\n nh=son e(cako/sioi ma/lista oi( pa/ntes, THUC.3.85.3; They went across to the island (numbering) about six hundred in all. pe/mpousin . . . e(cakosi/ous kai\ xili/ous tou\s pa/ntas o(pli/tas, THUC.1.60.1; They sent sixteen hundred hoplites in all. fu=sai d' e)n xoa/noisin e)ei/kosi pa=sai e)fu/swn, HOM. Il. 18.470; In the melting pots bellows twenty in all were blowing.

Cf. 6.44: ai( su/mpasai h(me/rai e)ge/nonto au)toi=s ple/on h)\ penth/konta.

Il. 7.161: w(\s nei/kess' o( ge/rwn, oi(\ d' e)nne/a pa/ntes a)ne/stan. 18.373: tri/podas ga\r e)ei/kosi pa/ntas e)/teuxen. 470 (see above). Elsew.

With anarthrous singulars pa=s means every, every kind of; with abstracts, it is often translated by perfect, complete; with anarthrous plurals, it means all, all kinds of; but the translations given do not exhaust the list of possible renderings.

Though the Greek differs from the English in the frequent use of the article with the generic plural, and though this difference is not effaced by the presence of pa/ntes, e.g. DEM. (7)DEM., 3: a(/pantes . . . oi( lh|stai/, all pirates; 14.9: tou\s . . . pole/mous a(/pantas, all wars, yet the almost invariable formula is pa/ntes (a(/pantes) a)/nqrwpoi, all that are men, all men, mankind, unless the whole of mankind is to be forcibly contrasted with a portion of itself, in which case the attributive form is used, oi( pa/ntes a)/nqrwpoi (649).

The partitive genitive plural accompanied by pa=s regularly omits the article, except, of course, when it is modified by another adjective or a participle, or is itself an adjective or a participle, or designates not the whole genus but a definite group thereof.
pa=s is rarely used, except in the neuter plural, to modify an anarthrous adjective or participle used substantively.

pa=s . . . a)nh/r, PLATO, Legg. 856C; Every man, everybody. ste/fanos me\n a(/pas, ka)\n mikro\s h)=|, DEM 22.75; A wreath of any kind, even if it be small. a(/pas . . . lo/gos, DEM.2.12; Every assertion.
pa=san a(/deian, DEM.19.149; Complete immunity. a(/pasa . . . a)sfa/lei(a), Ibid. 164; Perfect (absolute) safety. pa/sh| ponhri/a|, DEM.25.80; With every kind of villainy.

pa/ntes a)/nqrwpoi, DEM.23.123; All men, everybody. a)/dhlon to\ me/llon a(/pasin a)nqrw/pois, DEM.15.21; All men are in the dark as to the future. pa=si/n ei)si pra/gmasi kai\ lo/gois du/o prosqh=kai, DEM.23.75; Everything that is done or said admits of two predications. h(\ (sc. *eu/nomi/a) pa/sas kai\ po/leis kai\ xw/ras sw/|zei, DEM.25.11; Eunomia is the saviour of all cities and countries.

pasw=n a)\n ei)/h dustuxesta/th gunaikw=n, ISOC.19.47; She would be the most unfortunate of all women. ba/sanon a)kribesta/thn pasw=n pi/stewn nomi/zete, DEM.30.37; Torture is considered by you the most perfect of all means of persuasion. o( de\ pai=s pa/ntwn qhri/wn e)sti\ dusmetaxeiristo/taton, PLATO, Legg. 808D (135). (But mou=nos . . . pa/ntwn dh\ tw=n genome/nwn basile/wn e)n *spa/rth|, HDT.6.70. to/ ge ma/lista e)n timh=| a)/gontai pa/ntwn tw=n (their = Egyptian) manthi/wn, *lhtou=s e)n *boutoi= po/li e)sti/, Ibid. 2.83.)
pa=s . . . ne/os, mh\ o(/ti presbu/ths, PLATO, Legg. 799C; Every young man, not to say old man.
DIN. pa/ntes a)/nqrwpoi and forms 8 times: 1.3. 22. 66. 84. 88. 107. 3.19. 22.
LYCURG.27: pa/ntwn a)/r' a)nqrw/pwn e)/sesqe r(a|qumo/tatoi. 54: pa/ntwn a)/r' a)nqrw/pwn e)/sesqe a)gnwmone/statoi. 75: pa=sin a)nqrw/pois. 89: to\n ka/kiston pa/ntwn a)nqrw/pwn.
HYPER. 1.14 (= fr. 172): e)k panto\s tro/pou. 2.2: pa/ntas a)nqrw/pous. 5.1: e)pi\ pa/shs a)lhqei/as. fr. 70.2: pa/ntas . . . a)nqrw/pous.

DEM.2.12(see above). 3.7 (= 25.39. [26]DEM., 23.[43]DEM., 1): e)k panto\s tro/pou. 5.18 (= 18,61. 19,332. 21.173.
